PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate.
(c) control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest.
(d) increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDS Commercial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners request that the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health cause to cease immediately the broadcasting of any AIDS commercials which have as their premise that the use of condoms makes casual sexual activities acceptable particularly amongst young adolescents because of the detrimental effect which such campaigns have upon the morals of our society.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Immigrants : Discrimination
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth.-

That although Australia claims to have adopted a non-discriminatory policy in respect to immigrants, yet this policy discriminates against those who have been responsible for development of Australia, the Anglo-Keltic majority who compose 75% of the population now, by the deliberate selection of immigrants from areas from which Anglo-Keltic peoples are not likely to be obtained. At the same time although the Asian percentage of the population of Australia is 4.5% of the population yet Asian immigrants are represented by between 40% and 55.5% of the immigrant intake. Evidence is enclosed.
Continuation of this policy must eventually alter the ethnic composition of Australia and increase the possibility of racial strife as in Sri Lanka, Fiji and other well known areas of racial strife.

Your petitioners therefore request that immigrants be obtained from areas which will tend to maintain the ethnic structure of Australia as notified in National Agenda for a Multicultural Australia page 2.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Age Pension: Tax File Number
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows that the 1990-91 Budget of the Australian Government announced on 21st August 1990 will be detrimental to the health and well being of pensioners in that the proposal that the continued receipt of the aged pension is dependent on the production of a TAX FILE NUMBER is a harsh and unconscionable measure that will cause great hardship and distress.
Your petitioners request that the Senate will not support the proposal.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Constitution: External Affairs Provision
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows our concern regarding what we see as the misuse of the `External Affairs' provision in our Australian Constitution.

We protest concerning lack of publicity, public consultation and even Parliamentary debate before various United Nations Treaties, Covenants, Declarations and the like are signed by the Federal Government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that honourable members of the Senate request that proper publicity, public consultation and Parliamentary debate take place before any such United Nations Treaties are signed.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Constitution: Referendums
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows our concern regarding what we see as misuse of the referendum provision in our Australian constitution.

We protest that the Federal Government only allows its own referendum proposals to be put to the people. We believe in a true democracy an opposition party or any reasonably large group of electors should also be allowed to submit referendum questions whenever a Federal election or referendum is to be held.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Honourable members of the Senate do all in their power to establish this democratic principle.

PETITION.TITLE: Age Pension: Injustices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows our concern regrading what we see as age pension injustice.
We protest against the injustices hereafter mentioned:
- Compared with other OECD countries our pension system is the least generous.
- Public hospitals do not give pensioners the priority they deserve.
- The financial discrimination against married couples who on a per person basis are worse off than a single person.
- The virtually continuous changing of rules relating to a pensioners other income makes it extremely worrying and difficult to plan ahead.
- The refusal of taxation and pension income assesors to use `real' income for the interest only deposits and investments commonly used by pensioners.

- The outrageous case where investment capital gains accrued over many years are regarded as income occurring in ONE year for pension income assessment when surrendered or sold, this often resulting in a drastic cut or total loss of pension for one year.
Your petitioners therefore pray that honourable members of the Senate do all in their power to correct these injustices.

(a) notes the persistent and alarming systematic violation of human rights in the Province of Kosova, Yugoslavia, as reported by numerous recognised and highly respected human rights organisations such as Amnesty International, the United Nations International Federation of Human Rights and the Helsinki International Federation for Human Rights (Bratislava), such violation including the suspension of the Kosova Assembly and the indiscriminate killing and brutal treatment of peaceful Albanian demonstrators;

(f) calls for the immediate lifting of the state of emergency and of measures contrary to freedom of expression and assembly;
(g) calls in particular upon the Serbian authorities to:
(i) recognise and respect scrupulously the 1974 constitution, and

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notices of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This morning I was elected to chair the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. On behalf of that Committee and pursuant to standing order 78, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate notices of motion Nos 1 and 2 standing in Senator Colston's name for nine sitting days hence for the disallowance of (1) Wool Marketing Regulations (Amendment) as contained in Statutory Rules 1990, No. 203 and made under the Wool Marketing Act 1987; and (2) Control of Naval Waters Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1990, No. 206 and made under the Control of Naval Waters Act 1918. I seek leave to make a short statement on the concerns of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 October 1990 the then Chairman of the Committee, Senator Colston, reported to the Senate on the concerns of the Committee with this legislation, which in the first case related to the inappropriate power given to a statutory authority to demand certain information from any person and, in the second, related to a presumption of guilt upon the unreviewable opinion of a public official. I am pleased to report to the Senate that in both these cases the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has undertaken to amend the legislation to meet the concerns of the Committee. The Committee is grateful for this cooperation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the correspondence of the Committee on these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows-
24 August 1990
The Hon John Kerin MP
Minister for Primary Industries and Energy
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Wool Marketing Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1990 No.203, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 23 August 1990.

The Explanatory Statement states that new r.21 (2a) provides that the Australian Wool Corporation may ``seek from registered persons information (etc)'' (emphasis added). If such a provision was made in the Amendment then the Committee would have no objection to this reasonable requirement. The actual provision of the Amendment, however, is that ``the Corporation may make inquiries arising out of the information and may direct (to give information)'' (emphasis added). The Committee would be grateful for your advice as to whether the Amendment as drafted affects the intention of the instrument advised in the Explanatory Statement. As the instrument now stands this appears a wide provision, for which there is a penalty of $1,000, which applies to any person at all. It appears, for example, to permit the Corporation to require banks and other financial institutions to provide details of accounts. There do not appear to be any safeguards or restrictions on this power which as it stands could apply to personal information.

If it is the intention of the legislation, contrary to the advice in the Explanatory Statement, confer on to the Australian Wool Corporation the power to direct any person to provide information, then the Committee believes that the Regulations should be amended to provide clear and extensive safeguards.
Yours sincerely,
Mal Colston
Chairman
3 October 1990
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston
I refer to your letters of 24 August 1990 concerning the Wool Marketing Regulations (Amendment) and the Wool Marketing Act 1987.

In the Wool Marketing Regulations (Amendment) it was not intended that the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) be able to request information from other than registered persons. There are instances where documents may be provided by any one of a number of registered persons at a particular organisation. The intention of the subregulation is that the Corporation be able to seek further information by notice from any one of those registered persons, even though that registered person may not have provided the documents in the first place.
The regulations will be amended accordingly at the next available opportunity.

You also noted that the direction issued by me on 31 May 1990 under section 120 of the Wool Marketing Act did not include any system of numbering or citation as is preferred for every series of delegated legislation.

Directions issued under section 120 are not instruments in the nature of subordinate or delegated legislation which attract the obligations of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 or the Statutory Rules Publication Act 1903. They are administrative directions, to an agency for which I am responsible, on how that agency is to perform its functions.

However, I do agree that matters such as this which are of general public interest should be easily accessible to the public. To that end, and in accordance with the requirements of section 120, the direction has been published in the Gazette (on 13 June 1990) and tabled in Parliament (on 21 August 1990). In addition, the AWC will, in accordance with section 120(3)(b), publish particulars of the direction in its Annual Report for the relevant period.
I believe all of these requirements ensure that the direction is included in the public record in a systematic method.
Yours fraternally
John Kerin
10 September 1990
Senator the Hon Robert Ray
Minister for Defence
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Control of Naval Waters Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1990 No.206, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 23 August 1990.

The Committee noted that these Statutory Rules, among other things, methodically remove a number of strict liability offences from the principal Regulations, which were last amended in 1976. This is a helpful development which removes from those principal Regulations provisions which are not in accordance with contemporary standards of personal liberties.

The Committee also noted, however, that the Statutory Rules provide, in new r.5, that the Superintendent of Naval Waters may cause to be removed from those waters persons who ``have contravened these regulations''. Your advice would be appreciated as to whether this power is intended only to remove persons who have already been convicted of contravening the Regulations. If this is not so intended, then the Regulations should be amended to clarify the position. Until an offence has been proved by conviction in a court then there is no certainty that the Regulations have been offended. The superintendent is not the final judge of whether an offence has, or has not, occurred.

The Committee noted that the wording s.4 (k) of the parent Control of Naval Waters Act 1918, as amended by the Control of Naval Waters Amendment Act 1978, is in the same general terms as the present Statutory Rules. In this context the Committee points out that contemporary standards of personal liberties dictate that whether or not a person is guilty of an offence is determined only by a court of competent jurisdiction, not by an opinion formed by a public official.
Yours sincerely,
Mal Colston
Chairman
8 October 1990
The Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston

I refer to your letter of 10 September 1990 to Senator Ray that queried the intended scope of regulation 5 of the Control of Naval Waters Regulations (which was inserted by Statutory Rules 1990 No. 206).
I agree that it is the role of a court, rather than a public official, to determine whether a person is guilty of an offence and it was not intended to override this principle.

The aim was that regulation 5 should apply where persons are in apparent contravention of the provisions of the Regulations (which, for example, restrict entry into naval waters). You will appreciate that such a provision enabling prompt action is necessary for public safety and operational reasons, and is a matter that is separate and distinct from any question of criminal liability. Exercise of the power could not await prosecution and conviction of the person concerned.

However, I agree with your Committee's view that the provision should be clarified. Bearing in mind the purpose of the Regulations, I suggest a suitable approach would be an amendment of regulation 5 to ensure that the power of removal from naval waters or the foreshore of those waters is explicitly tied to situations where persons are in contravention of a notice under the Regulations. On this basis, a person would be apprised of the specific requirement and have the opportunity of compliance before the power of removal was exercised. This would not involve a judgement as to whether an offence has occurred. I would appreciate your Committee's views on this approach.
Yours sincerely
GORDON BILNEY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No 2) amends several Acts within the Industrial Relations portfolio and also makes an amendment to that part of the Defence Act 1903 which is administered by the Minister for Industrial Relations.
The proposed amendments are explained in detail in the explanatory memorandum and many are of a merely technical nature. I will confine my comments to a number of the more noteworthy amendments.
Amendments to the Defence Act 1903

The Bill amends the Defence Act to reduce from five years to one year the period during which a former member of the Defence Force is excluded from being a member of the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. The Bill also replaces the existing provision for a fixed term of appointment of five years for members with a provision which establishes that period as a maximum term. As a result, shorter periods of appointment will be possible in appropriate circumstances.
These amendments will extend the range of people who are eligible for appointment to ensure that a wider range of candidates with relevant skills and expertise are available to serve on the Tribunal.
Amendments of the Industrial Relations Act 1988
A number of amendments are proposed to be made to the Industrial Relations Act to improve its operation, particularly in the area of award observance.

Although most employers, especially those who are properly informed about their award obligations through membership of an effective employer association, observe awards, breaches are too common. In the past financial year, inspectors appointed under the Act detected over 20,000 breaches. About 17,500 of these were monetary breaches. Over four million dollars was recovered. Most breaches are voluntarily rectified, but regrettably, legal action is frequently required.
Amendments are being proposed which will assist in securing the observance of awards in the interests of employers, workers and the community generally.
This is to be achieved by:
* establishing means to supplement for short periods the number of inspectors who secure award observance;
* providing for action to be taken under the Act to bring about the observance of award provisions requiring the payment of superannuation contributions on behalf of employees;
* widening the range of persons who may bring proceedings relating to the non-observance of award obligations; and
* ensuring better employment records are kept.

Under the Act, inspectors have a primary role in securing the observance of awards made by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. At present, only persons employed or appointed under the Public Service Act 1922 may be inspectors. It is proposed to permit the appointment of other persons for a fixed term and with such of an inspector's powers as may be specified.

The amendment will permit short-term peak workloads to be met more satisfactorily. In addition, it will enable persons with specialised qualifications to be appointed for particular tasks, for example, where highly technical areas of work are involved. Those persons will, of course, be obliged to exercise their powers in good faith and with the same integrity as permanent inspectors under the Act.

An area of particular concern relates to the observance of awards which require the payment by employers of contributions to superannuation funds for the benefit of their employees. Since it was held by the High Court in 1986 that such provisions could be included in federal awards, there has been a spectacular increase in the extent to which workers enjoy such benefits. Indeed, it is estimated that over 50 per cent of workers have some form of superannuation cover and 80 per cent of workers covered by federal or State awards are in that position.

Occupational superannuation is a key element in the Government's retirement and incomes policy. Greater use of superannuation is being actively encouraged to achieve higher living standards for people who have retired. It is clear that the most important means for accelerating the spread of superannuation in recent years has been through awards.

All the available evidence including data collected by the Australian Bureau of Statistics suggests that a substantial minority of employers are not meeting their obligations in this area. In some cases, this may be a result of ignorance. The Government has developed, in consultation with the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions, a national strategy to deal with the problem, including educative and information components and appropriate award inspections.

In some cases, legal proceedings under the Act may be necessary. A difficulty has arisen, however, in relation to the enforcement of award provisions requiring the payment by an employer of an amount on behalf of employees to a superannuation fund.

Under the Act, where an award requires an employer to make a payment to an employee, the court may order the payment to be made. This does not, however, apply to a contribution required to be paid by an employer on behalf of an employee to a superannuation fund, rather than to the employee concerned. An amendment is proposed so that where such superannuation contributions have not been paid, payments may be ordered by the court to rectify the failure.
Provision is also to be made for the court to be able to order the payment of an amount equivalent to any return foregone as a result of the non-payment of the contributions.

In consultations over the Bill, the Confederation of Australian Industry has not agreed that a court should be able to order the payment of any amount in addition to unpaid superannuation contributions in a proceeding to rectify their non-payment.

The Government considers that it would be unfair to exclude the possibility of complete restitution. Indeed, the minority of employers who deliberately refuse to meet their obligations could merely be encouraged to avoid making contributions when they are due. It should also be noted that it will be for a court to decide what amounts should be paid where a failure to make the required payments has been established.
Another reform is proposed to the provisions of the Act under which penalties may be imposed for award breaches and under which employees may recover amounts due to them.

At present, because of the wording of the Act, an employee who is not a member of a federally registered union does not have access to the provisions of sections 178 and 179 which permit a court to order the payment of amounts due under an award. Yet in many ways the non-unionised work force is more vulnerable to award breaches. It is unacceptable for an employer to be able to evade proceedings under the Act which would compel compliance with award obligations simply because a worker does not belong to a union.

Accordingly, it is proposed to revise the wording of the relevant provisions to allow workers who do not belong to a union to use the more practical and convenient remedies under the Act to recover amounts owing to them under awards.

An important amendment proposed in the Bill will permit regulations to be made under the Industrial Relations Act requiring employers to keep time and wages records relating to employees. The regulations will also provide penalties for failing to keep such records.

There is currently no provision in the Act which requires an employer to have such records. At present, a minority of federal awards require time and wages records to be kept. The award clauses vary considerably in style and content and no standard prescription has been established. This leaves an inadequate situation which has caused difficulties in the identification and correction of award breaches. The Act permits proceedings to be brought within 6 years of the occurrence of a breach. The absence of proper records can cause substantial difficulties for both employers and employees in establishing the true position.

Provision will also be made to clarify the capacity of courts to award interest on amounts due under awards to employees which are recovered under the Act. At present, the availability and amount of interest depends on whether an action is brought in the Federal Court or a lower State or Territory court. A uniform rate of interest will apply to amounts for which judgment is entered but which have not been paid.

The Confederation of Australian Industry has also expressed concerns about interest being ordered to be paid in these matters. While the CAI accepts the clarification of powers of courts in this area, it does not support any extension of those powers. At present there is some doubt about the capacity of some courts to order interest on amounts due before judgment is entered for those amounts under section 178.

The same problems do not apply to proceedings under section 179 for amounts owing to employees. It would be anomalous for the availability of interest to depend merely on the nature of the proceedings even though exactly the same failure to pay can give rise to proceedings under sections 178 and 179 and, in either case, an order can be made for payment.
It should also be remembered that the awarding of interest on amounts owing before judgment is entered will be discretionary and that, in proceedings under the Act, costs are not normally available.
Amendments of the Industrial Relations
(Consequential Provisions) Act 1988

A new provision is proposed for inclusion in the Industrial Relations (Consequential Provisions) Act. It concerns the application of the Judges' Pensions Act 1968 to a Presidential Member of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. A Presidential Member has the status of a judge of the Federal Court of Australia and thereby comes within the Judges' Pensions Act unless, before appointment, that person was eligible for benefits under the Superannuation Act 1976. Such a person may, however, elect to forgo those benefits and to come within the operation of the Judges' Pensions Act instead.

No provision has been made, however, for such a Presidential Member's prior service as a Presidential Member of the former Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to be taken into account in determining whether such a person qualifies for a judicial pension under the Judges' Pensions Act. The proposed amendment so provides. The time in which such an election may be made is stipulated.

Provision is also made to prevent a person who has made such an election from continuing to have entitlements under the Superannuation Act as well as under the Judges' Pensions Act. The amendment does not affect other persons who have been or may be appointed as Presidential Members. Their right to make an election of this type, where necessary, is provided for under the Industrial Relations Act.
Amendments affecting Australian Federal
Police Staff

The Bill also contains amendments to the Industrial Relations Act 1988 and the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976, consequential on the commencement of certain provisions of the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Act (No 2) 1989. That Act created new employment arrangements for staff members of the AFP, bringing them into line with uniformed AFP members and replacing the previous Public Service Act arrangements.
These amendments are of a consequential nature to reflect the new staffing arrangements.
Amendment of the Remuneration and
Allowances Act 1990

Part 8 of the Bill removes A.C.T. Magistrates from the scope of the Remuneration and Allowances Act 1990. That Act currently sets salaries for A.C.T. Magistrates and provides that they be paid from the Consolidated Revenue Fund. The A.C.T. Administration will now be responsible for funding salaries of A.C.T. Magistrates and can refer the determination of their salaries direct to the Remuneration Tribunal.
Amendments to the States Grants
(Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave) Act 1949

The amendments to this Act are mainly of a drafting or machinery nature. The principal amendments will allow the Commonwealth to make certain advances to the States and to recover its administration costs in relation to the Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave Scheme. A preliminary estimate of the Commonwealth's administration costs is about $250,000 per annum. All States which are parties to the Scheme are able to recover their own administration costs and have agreed to the provision.
Consultation

The ACTU and the CAI have been consulted over the Bill, with detailed discussions over the award observance amendments proposed to the Industrial Relations Act taking place through the National Labour Consultative Council. Apart from the CAI's concerns which I have already mentioned, the proposed amendments are generally accepted.
Financial Impact Statement

The provisions of this Bill are not expected to have a significant financial impact on the Commonwealth. The amendment of the Remuneration and Allowances Act 1990 will allow formal transfer of responsibility for A.C.T. Magistrates salaries to the Territory. The amendment of the States Grants (Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave) Act 1949 will facilitate cost recovery by the Commonwealth.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration I table a report entitled Development of the Senior Executive Service. I also table the submissions and incorporated documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION REPORT ON DEVELOPMENT OF THE SENIOR EXECUTIVE SERVICE TABLING STATEMENT BY COMMITTEE CHAIR SENATOR JOHN COATES
The report I have just tabled represents the outcome of more than 12 months work by the Committee and is the result of one of the larger inquiries undertaken by the Committee in recent years.

The SES was established late in 1984 with specific objectives in view. It seemed desirable to evaluate the extent to which those objectives had been achieved after five years. The Committee was also aware that there have been large changes in departmental structures and senior staffing arrangements since 1984. The effect of these changes on the SES and its morale seemed worthy of review. In addition, there have been reports of significant disquiet in the United States at the effects of the 1978 Civil Service Reform Act in that country which is thought by some to have been a partial model for the Australian SES.

The Committee found that many of the specific objectives of the SES had not been fully met. In particular, this applied to measures concerned with career planning, staff mobility and personnel management in general. The Committee noted that creation of the SES was only one of many managerial changes in the public service during the 1980s. The effect of some of the other changes worked against many of the specific features originally proposed for the SES.

The main effect of the changes of the 1980s on senior public servants has been a substantial increase in the power of department secretaries over SES officers (5.7). There is considerable discussion in the report of the implications of that shift in power. The Committee concluded that some central restraints on the powers of department secretaries are justified by more than just the need to protect individual public servants. Although the arguments for increased autonomy of department secretaries have been advanced on efficiency grounds and based on an analogy with the private sector, the Committee was sceptical of many of the efficiency arguments and ruled out any simple analogy between private sector and public service management (5.34).

The inquiry came soon after a period of turmoil in the upper levels of the Australian Public Service. The Committee found that only about half the members of the SES as at January 1990 had been members when the Service was established five years earlier. Between 15 and 20 per cent of the foundation members of the SES were soon displaced from their positions and the majority of those officers subsequently accepted voluntary redundancy packages and left the Public Service.

Given the pace of change over the period, it is not surprising that the Committee heard claims of low morale in the senior public service. Morale is a notoriously difficult quality to measure and the Committee attempted no substantive assessment of the general level of morale in the SES. However, we did conclude that the retrenchment of senior staff should not continue at the pace of the past three years. There is no indication that the general standard of SES members is low. The evidence before the Committee was strongly the other way (5.36).
As to the third broad area of concern, the consensus of evidence before the Committee was that, while there may be a``quiet crisis'' in the US Civil Service, the situation is not so bad in Australia.

The report deals in some detail with the issues of mobility, tenure, selection, relationships between Canberra and regional offices, remuneration and training and development. Its review of these issues led the Committee to conclude that there is a need for better personnel management and policy development in the Australian Public Service. The Committee's conclusion in this regard reflects what is clearly an emerging consensus across the public service (10.23) and the Committee acknowledges recent official initiatives in this area.

The report contains 37 recommendations for improvement. The Committee believes that the improvements it seeks will require a modest increase in central leadership and coordination in the personnel field.

The Public Service Commission is the obvious location for such a function. Many of the Committee's recommendations would involve increased activity by the Commissioner and, to the extent that they would require increased resources, those resources should be provided to the Commissioner. The Committee stresses in the report that its conclusions on deficiencies in personnel management should not be taken to be criticism of the Public Service Commissioner. Given the devolutionary thrust of recent public service management changes, the limited resources available to the Commissioner and the pressure of events since his office was created, it would be most unfair to criticise the Commissioner or his staff for the deficiencies that the Committee has identified (10.29).

The detailed recommendations fall into three groups. One group of recommendations is designed to improve accountability for personnel management. The Committee believes that department secretaries should be held accountable for the way in which they manage the people in their organisations as they are for the public monies they expend. Accountability requires public disclosure of performance.

The Committee has recommended the collection and publication of basic statistical information on SES staff mobility trends, the comparative performance of department secretaries in retention of their senior staff, the extent of senior staff interchanges between public and private sectors, and the operation of the SES recruitment system. The Committee sees all this as basic accountability information, much of which would be useful for management purposes as well.

A second group of recommendations recognises the scope for common service provision in the personnel area. The Committee believes that some functions, such as training and recruitment, are suited to a degree of centralisation. This is desirable because of the economies available through specialisation but also and more importantly because individual agencies left to themselves may provide less effective services in this area than is in the interest of the service as a whole (10.34).

Among other things, the Committee recommends in this regard that the Public Service Commissioner experiment with executive search techniques and with the concept of team recruitment as well seeking to increase the opportunities for staff interchanges with state public services and access by SES staff to postgraduate study.

A third group of recommendations aims to encourage leadership and a degree of entrepreneurship in personnel policy development and implementation. The example provided by the Department of Finance in broader management reform is instructive. A similar approach will be necessary in the personnel field if the deficiencies in APS personnel management are to be confronted and corrected and the Committee believes that the Public Service Commissioner should fulfil this role.

The Committee's recommendations involve, for example, the Public Service Commissioner operating an SES temporary assignment pool, reviewing decisions by department secretaries to `spill' SES positions in their departments and nominating additional officers for consideration for particular vacancies when he considers that such action would advance the mobility objectives of the SES. The Committee also recommends that the Public Service Commissioner review and publicly report on such matters as the operation of the interchange and executive development schemes and performance based pay (if the last is introduced).

None of this requires the restoration of the former Public Service Board. Few of the Committee's recommendations involve increasing central controls or centralising responsibility for major personnel management functions. The abolition of the Board in 1987 represented a large step away from centralisation of control and of personnel management. Three years later, the Committee is recommending fine tuning of the new system, not a reversion to the old.

I should note in closing that the hearings on which this report was based were completed in the last Parliament and that Senators Alston, Calvert and Durack were able, with the agreement of their party, to continue as members of the Committee in this Parliament until the report was completed. This ensured a considerable degree of continuity of committee membership over the period of the inquiry and avoided the prospect of serious delay in completing the inquiry. I would like to thank the Senators I have already named as well as Senators Burns, Loosley and Walsh and former Senator Black for their efforts during the inquiry.

The Committee Secretary, Peter Hamburger, carried prime staff responsibility for the inquiry while Barbara Allan, Glenice Castles, Steve Curran, Carol Fagan, Michael Game and Krys Turnsek all assisted with aspects of the project. Di Morrison and Michelle Ricketts of the Senate Publications Unit undertook the large task of typesetting the report. On behalf of the Committee, I thank all these officers and also thank the officers of the Public Service Commission, the Department of Finance and other departments and public service agencies who provided written submissions, gave oral evidence at five days of hearings and subsequently responded promptly and graciously to numerous requests for information.

I believe that this report usefully documents the development and current state of an important component of the Australian Public Service. This inquiry has helped to confirm me in my opinion that the Australian people generally can be proud of their public service. To the extent that the Committee has proposed improvements, its recommendations should be read as seeking finetuning rather than wholesale change.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, on a Thursday to which the hours of meeting for a Thursday of Week 2 apply, the Senate meet from 10 a.m. to 6.30 p.m. and from 8 p.m. to 10.30 p.m.

This motion would have us meet from 8 p.m. to 10.30 p.m. on every second Thursday. Currently we get up at 6.30 p.m. It is introduced not so much to extend time for Government Business, but because of one of the problems that I have perceived in this chamber which has been the inhibition on the part of the Government to bring forward ministerial statements. Because of the sometimes almost undisciplined approach-and I do not criticise anyone for this-there is always a great reluctance on the part of Government, especially in the business committee of Cabinet, to give approval for ministerial statements, knowing that they may well run out and grossly inhibit the time that is normally given to legislation.

I have been looking for some time for a solution to this problem. I believe that if we inserted most ministerial statements in this chamber on a Thursday afternoon, we would have extra time to consider them. We could then have more statements, especially in areas such as foreign affairs, defence and the economy, than we have had in the past. I must say, I am sick of blocking Ministers from making statements on the basis that it will delay the legislative program too much.

This particular measure is one of those rare ones that, I think, one introduces to the procedures that has advantages for the Government, the Opposition, independent senators and others. The advantage to Government is that many Ministers like to put down a statement in this Parliament rather than by way of press release or some other method. The advantage to the Opposition is that it gets to debate the statements in this chamber. There is a cautionary note for all of us in this: if the Opposition and the rest of the senators decide they want to a five-hour debate on a ministerial statements, they will cut into their own time in terms of private business. It is one of those well-devised Mexican stand-offs in which we all benefit, but in which there is a little bit of punishment all round to make sure it is not done to excess.

I do not like extending sitting hours for honourable senators, but I point out that one of the reasons for the 6.30 p.m. finish was that we used to have a full day starting at 9.00 the next morning. That will be true of some honourable senators-hopefully not every Friday from now on-depending on which committee they are on.

I believe that this motion has much to commend it. There are no hidden agendas in it. I hope to see, especially at the start of the next parliamentary sittings in the autumn, more ministerial statements. They will not always come in on a Thursday because I cannot drive the House of Representatives agenda in that way, but certainly all the statements by Senate Ministers will be made on Thursday afternoons, and I will be encouraging my House of Representatives colleagues to replicate that. Obviously, if a very urgent statement comes in the House of Representatives we will not be restricted just to Thursday to discuss it. If it is urgent and important we will have to discuss it outside the Thursday time zone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the Government's indication that we might anticipate more ministerial statements. I have been critical of the fact that in the area in which I have responsibility-foreign affairs-in the years that Senator Evans has been Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade there has been only one ministerial statement in this place, and that was in relation to regional security. I think that is highly disappointing. It is very frustrating on important matters. I can remember he introduced what the Government certainly claimed to be an important new relationship with the Pacific, which, I think, it called constructive commitment, and a new relationship with south east Asia, which it called constructive engagement, through lectures to the press in Sydney. Matters of such moment should be put to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: While I still think there has been the capacity I do not totally accept that we have had to wait for this reform in the Senate for ministerial statements to be made. I want to put on the record not only what I have expressed in the past, that is disappointment at the lack of these statements, but also my pleasure if that is now going to be remedied so that Ministers can put down statements in this place on matters of major importance that can be properly debated where they should be debated.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Spindler:

That new regulation 129 contained in amending regulation 26, and new regulation 142B contained in amending regulation 28, of the Migration Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 237 and made under the Migration Act 1958, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express the Opposition's position in this debate and the reasoning that has guided our attitudes to these particular regulations which Senator Spindler is moving to disallow.

SPEECH.PARA: My first observation is critical of the Government. Its whole handling of the dispute between the pilots and the domestic airlines last year was atrocious. The Opposition had a great deal to say in the Parliament at the time about the bungling way in which the Government handled the matter, and the massive damage done to Australia's transport and tourism industries. I do not need to go over all the details of the criticism which the Government then deserved, and still now deserves.

My second observation is to note the bungling incompetence of this Government in its handling of immigration policy and legislation in the last 12 months. An enormous amount of confusion has been caused through poor drafting and administration of the regulations made under the new Immigration Act. It is little wonder that there have subsequently been so many extra changes to the regulations in recent months to try to correct errors that have emerged. The regulations we are debating today are part of a larger set of regulations which the Government needed to introduce to cover its errors and its mismanagement.

Thirdly, I deplore the secrecy with which the Government surrounded the making of these regulations, as the Government did not do anything to make known to the community that these particular regulations affecting foreign pilots had been made. They were approved on 11 July and gazetted on 12 July, but it was only after a number of weeks had passed that their existence became known. With a highly sensitive and controversial matter like this that is not good enough.

My fourth observation is to underline the Opposition's concern that the Government made these regulations in July with the deliberate intention of trying to chop off the legal challenge being mounted to its action in allowing the foreign pilots to enter Australia under previous regulations. The Opposition believes in the rule of law in this country, but clearly this Government only believes in it when it suits the Government.

The Australian Federation of Air Pilots was in the process of testing the Government's actions in the Federal Court and an injunction had been granted on 31 May by the court, because there was a question to be tried as to whether the Government had acted in accordance with the Immigration Act. Yet the Government was obviously fearful of the outcome and fearful that it risked being found out as having acted contrary to law. It has therefore by this deliberate executive action interfered with the normal course of consideration of the matter by the courts.

I have referred to these four direct criticisms of the Government. All these factors are of concern to the Senate and they reflect no credit at all on the Government. Those factors on their own, of course, are not enough to give grounds for disallowing the regulations. Rather, the Senate needs to consider as a practical matter what the actual effects would be of approving this disallowance motion and making its judgment on that basis. It has to be said that at the end of the whole process, whether handled by the Government in legitimate ways or by the steps that it has in fact taken, the Government is in a position one way or another to achieve its policy of approving these foreign pilots remaining in Australia, and this is the pivotal point to make about the pilots.

The pivotal point is this-and it is the foundation of the Opposition's position-that the Government does have the policy initiative and the legislative or regulatory means one way or another to eventually achieve its intention for the foreign pilots to enter and remain in Australia. Even if all the possible court actions were undertaken and the Government only then sought by legislation, even new legislation, to regularise the position of the foreign pilots, the Opposition would not resist such legislation. In short, disallowing these regulations today would not in the end alter the outcome. There is therefore no good purpose to be served in supporting the disallowance.

Disallowance would not affect any approvals already given under these regulations, and there is no dispute about that, even if indeed there had been any approvals already given under these regulations. I understand that since 12 July 1990 and up to noon on 10 October 1990 a total of 94 foreign pilots plus their dependants had lodged applications for a class 439 pilot extended eligibility temporary entry permit. A further five pilots were also expected to lodge applications. The Department has not yet processed any of these applications. As a result, none-not one of the pilots-has been granted a temporary entry permit. None of the pilots has therefore been eligible to apply for the class 811 pilot permanent entry permit.

In addition, on 28 September of this year, the Federal Court varied the then standing injunction on the entry of foreign pilots from overseas. This variation of the injunction has allowed two pilots who were processed for permanent entry at the beginning of 1990 to enter Australia. So disallowance makes no difference to the standing of any of these applications.

Further, all those pilots who have made application before the date of disallowance cannot be affected, at least in the traditional view of the law on this point, a view which I understand is held by the Government. I am aware that there is a contrary view also being argued about this, but I do not want to take the time of the Senate with a lengthy discourse on the interpretation of section 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act. Section 50 makes it clear that repeal-which by section 48(6) includes disallowance-of any regulation at all made under any Act shall not affect any right, obligation or liability acquired, accrued or incurred under any regulation so repealed. Any departure from what I call the traditional interpretation of that section-and it is the traditional interpretation which I have summarised and which I believe to be the view of the Government and it is the view also of the Opposition-would have very wide implications for all law, for all regulations, far beyond this particular case.

There are wide areas of immigration law where, with the changes that took effect last 19 December, applications previously made but not at that date processed are to receive consideration on the basis of the law as it has been to now interpreted. I would contend that to abandon the traditional view on this point-and of course it is not for us to abandon it, it is for a court to determine-would produce many outcomes that would be inequitable and undesirable.

I note also that these regulations are not retrospective, at least not in the narrow or strict sense of the word. That is, legally they are not retrospective. They simply are in effect from July and applications are made subsequent to their coming into force. Thus the new regulations may not technically prevent the seeking of judicial review of the use of the employer nomination scheme to sponsor the pilots, but they make it pointless to do so. In that wider sense they may be thought to have a retrospective effect on the consequences of past actions, but in the narrower sense they are not retrospective.

I understand that the Australian Federation of Air Pilots is currently seeking to mount some form of legal challenge to the new regulations. They are of course perfectly entitled to make those attempts in the courts and that can proceed if the Senate chooses not to disallow these regulations. In fact the courts, if the Federation's argument is accepted, are in a better position to give a remedy than is the Parliament. If disallowance were successful it would only open up a new course of action for the Federation, it would not reinstate the position to that which applied before the new regulations were agreed to. In summary, the Opposition does not believe that disallowing these regulations would have any practical effects in the long run, and therefore we do not support this disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to the speech by Senator Teague on behalf of the Opposition. It was a well-constructed, erudite examination of the question at hand. However, I consider that the latter observation that was made by Senator Teague needs to be analysed very briefly. What Senator Teague was saying was that the courts are in a better position than the Parliament to deal with the question which is of concern to the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, in that if this disallowance motion is carried-the new regulations concerning which the Federation has some legal action on foot-well then obviously that legal action would be useless.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that the purpose of the Federation in taking that legal action is for that very reason, to render the regulations void. They are either rendered void by that action before the court or they are rendered void by the disallowance by this chamber. I am carrying no can at all for the Federation. I believe the Federation, in its activities, went beyond the pale in the dispute, but that is not the issue here. As I see it, the issue here is whether the courts are to be regarded as the sole protector of the rights of individuals or whether the Senate, which has always been regarded as the protector of individual rights as well as, theoretically, of State rights, should be able to play its part and should exercise that function adequately.

I believe that we have a responsibility to scrutinise and to audit executive government decisions. What we have here is an executive government decision taken to undermine the rights of individuals when it was seen by the Executive Government that those individuals may have succeeded in the courts. To my way of thinking, as Senator Teague has said, that was not an appropriate action for the Federal Government to take and that is agreed by the Opposition.

I am prepared to support this disallowance motion and I hope that it will be carried because then the issue itself may come before the Parliament in the proper way by way of legislation if the Government so chooses. It will be then that the issues can be canvassed and a decision made at that time on the basis of the second reading speech of the Minister, the responses of the Opposition and of other senators, the Democrats and Independent senators, and indeed the ability of the House of Representatives to consider the issue in its proper form.

It is my view that that is the correct course to follow. I will not go into the merits or otherwise of the issue itself and whether or not there should be foreign pilots in this country at this time. That is not the issue at the present time. The issue is whether the Government acted correctly in bringing in new regulations when it could see that the previous regulations would not have held up before the court challenge. That is the issue. It is my view that, in considering that issue, we should support the motion that has been moved by Senator Spindler for the disallowance of these regulations.

After that has occurred, the Government may wish to bring legislation into the House of Representatives and into the Senate. It will then be available for members of both Houses of Parliament to give mature consideration to the issues surrounding the introduction of that legislation and vote accordingly. I am not prepared to forecast at this stage whether I would vote in favour of such legislation or not. What I am certainly prepared to do right here and now is to vote for the disallowance of the regulations because I do not think that the Government acted properly in bringing in the new regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding on behalf of the Government, let me say that although disagreeing with the first part of Senator Teague's speech, which of course was political and he has the right to make those comments, I commend him for the second part where I think he quite lucidly put out the situation at law in respect of the effect of what Senator Spindler is attempting to do this morning. The reality is that, no matter what we do this morning, the rights of those individuals that are sought to be affected by the move of the Democrats will not be affected. I believe Senator Teague put it quite well when he referred to section 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act. My advice also from the Attorney-General's Department confirms the point that was put quite forcibly by Senator Teague.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Harradine has said, we are not here to relive old wars, to canvass the rights and wrongs of the airline dispute. What we really have to tackle today is the precise issue that is raised by the move for disallowance, and that is the effect that that would have on the rights of the applicants and the rights of the individuals involved. This is a useless exercise. I do not know why Senator Spindler has fallen for it. I do not know why he is pursuing it because no matter what the rhetoric, no matter how much time we take this morning, the reality is that the rights conferred by such regulations will still accrue to those individuals involved. Without taking up the time of the Senate much longer, I repeat that this is a useless exercise, one born out of the politics of a year ago, one born out of an exercise which this country would do best to forget, and one I cannot understand the utility of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-When I first raised the issue and gave notice of this motion of disallowance, I stated quite clearly that I did not intend to canvass the merits or otherwise of the pilots strike but that we were dealing with the issue of separating the judicial system from executive government and from the legislative system. I believe that principle still stands. Senator Teague has paid lip service to that principle and I regret that the Opposition is not prepared to fulfil the words it is using by actions.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact remains that the Executive Government has intervened in a court case which, to put it bluntly, was going against the Government. The Australian Federation of Air Pilots (AFAP) had obtained an injunction on this basis:
Mr Justice Keely said the AFAP had a real case to answer.

In that situation the Government decided that it had better make sure that it could impose its will on individuals who challenged the legality of Government action. The Government proceeded to do so and now that the Opposition has decided to cave in on that principle, it will be able to continue to do so. Stripped of all the legalese, the arguments that Senator Teague has brought forward simply mean that the Opposition is prepared in practice to give the executive government that right. It seems to me that once again the Opposition has given up its responsibility as the Opposition in this House, the house of review. I thank Senator Harradine for his support and for the clear argument on the principles of this situation that he has enunciated.

Again, I suspect that when we look at the practical effects-and there are some because it is admitted, I believe, that those pilots who have not yet been granted permits to stay under the new regulations would still be affected by a disallowance-we see from the evidence on the table that several hundred pilots have not gone through that process. There would be some pilots who would have to go back to the Government's original legislative basis, which would ultimately be judged by the court, as indeed some of them still will on the basis of the case brought by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. To the extent that several hundred pilots would be taken out of the job market, it would appear to me that several hundred Australian pilots would be in a position to achieve jobs.

Here we have a Labor Government imposing its will to allow in a strike situation for the importation of scabs to break a strike. Once again I do not advert to the merits or demerits of the strike; I simply recite the facts. Also, we have a situation in which the Opposition, perhaps anticipating that at some time in the future it will be in government, wants to preserve unto itself a precedent which allows it to import scabs to break strikes. Whatever the Opposition's motivations, it seems to me that it is a sad day for the Senate when we have the two parties agreeing that it is satisfactory for the executive government to intervene in the judicial process and to take away the rights of individuals in that process.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Button:
That this Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Patterson had moved by way of amendment:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:
(a) calls on the Government to allow patients to ensure against the `gap' which is the difference between the scheduled medical fee and the Medicare benefit;

(b) condemns the Government for providing automatic CPI increases to maximum patient contribution which will remove the opportunity for public and parliamentary scrutiny and debate of these increases;
(c) calls on the Government to implement an education program on its minimum pricing policy and on the use of generic drugs;
(d) condemns the Government for abolishing Medicare cover for those medical expenses incurred by Australians while travelling overseas; and

(e) condemns the Government for its attempt to usurp free market forces by establishing the Pharmaceutical Restructuring Authority to make recommendations on applications for new pharmacies, and on the amalgamations and closure of other pharmacies''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated to the Senate yesterday, our principle concern about this unnecessary system of accreditation is the cost element and the absolute disregard that the proposed trojan horse will have for the rights of consumers. In other words, it is a measure driven by those who are much more concerned with the rights and entitlements of people working in the industry. It is disappointing in the extreme that the relevant Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, Mr Staples, has been so unforthcoming when various opportunities have been provided to him to explain the nature and extent of these proposals. One could say that his desire to expand his empire makes the Taj Mahal look like a backyard tent. It is quite clear that the Minister is proposing with these regulations to open up a new industry which will agonise, no doubt at great length, over what is meant by quality control and what ought to be regarded as quality standards.

SPEECH.PARA: I pointed out yesterday the hypocrisy of arguing on the one hand that there was great community support for an accreditation system and in the same breath urging the necessity for a strong community education component of the system to enable substantial community input to the accreditation process. It is quite clear that this is the product of vested interests who have very little regard for cost factors.

To call it an industry based voluntary accreditation system is pure casuistry because we know from reading the committee's report further that it has decided to recommend that a relationship be established between the proposed accreditation system and conditions for fee relief. It is perfectly clear that people will not get fee relief unless they comply with a set of open-ended requirements which can be amended endlessly under this carte blanche legislation that the Government has introduced. That is why we are very concerned to see strict limits placed on any guidelines that might be introduced and a requirement that the Minister adhere to those guidelines. Further referring to this biased committee report, it stressed that introduction of accreditation for centres should be seen as a forerunner to the introduction of accreditation across the range of children's services. Yet more empire building without any explanation or justification for such a need.

I think that the Minister owes the Australian public a much fuller and franker explanation than we have had to date. All that we have had is a secret analysis by a one-sided committee pushing its own agenda but a Minister utterly reluctant to come into the open and to explain the need for this ideological nonsense.

After talking about the need for a voluntary process and the effectiveness of accreditation in improving quality in the long term-this is probably the high-water mark of this ridiculous approach being adopted-the report goes on to say that these factors are best addressed by the industry itself with assessment by early childhood education professionals. They are the people who have a vested interest in this exercise. They are the ones who will push endlessly to jack up the standards to a point where anything other than community based, non-commercial, services will be unaffordable. I find that hypocritical in the extreme. It is yet another example of this elitist view that somehow child-care is too important to be left to parents.

We fundamentally disagree with that proposition. We think the whole system should be driven by the needs and concerns of parents. They are the ones who ought to monitor child-care centres. I have no doubt that every mother in the country is particularly concerned to know whether her children are being properly cared for in a child-care centre. It is absolute nonsense to suggest that the only ones who have expertise to make those judgments are early childhood education professionals.

If honourable senators read some of the literature, especially from the United States, they will find that it is almost impossible to demonstrate the different outcomes that derive from different levels of child-care treatment. I think that the onus is very much on those who argue the need for this whole range of quality control and quality improvement to demonstrate that somehow there will be any better result at the end of the day.

We know that the standard will vary from child-care centre to child-care centre, depending upon the attitude, the initiative and the commitment of those in charge. We simply cannot legislate for standard quality in that area any more than we can regulate student attitudes in class. It is a futile process but it is not just an ideological binge on the part of some when it will have very significant cost impacts. That is our primary concern about all this nonsense.

I therefore want to stress to the Senate that we entirely reject that report. We understand that the final report to the Minister (Mr Staples) will involve calls for child-care centres not only to comply with State licensing and regulation, which we do not have a problem with, or to comply with accounting and audit systems but also will establish a quality assurance committee within the centre, composed of parents, staff and other interested community members-a classic trade union approach and again, hypocritical, because this loaded industry committee had no representatives of parents in the first instance. This will simply be yet another way of adding to the career structures and the staffing arrangements which will add to the cost burden.

I do not know why effective staff developments, which are mentioned in the report, are not in place now. I would have thought that those matters could very easily be dealt with at State level. The report makes recommendations to document and implement a program of appropriate developmental activities across all age groups, to regularly hold staff meetings of which minutes are to be kept and made available for inspection, to adopt or develop an appropriate philosophy, to register with State quality assurance bodies and to implement the above points by 1 January 1992.

In other words, this is an absolute field day for all those in the industry who see this as the next gravy train. There is no concern at all for parents or the burden they will have to bear in increased costs. I could do little better than refer to the Sydney Morning Herald editorial of 10 October 1990 which stated:

. . . The Government must ensure that its historic decision to extend the availability of child-care is not undermined by those who consider private centres ideologically unsound, or who put the interests of child-care workers above the interests of parents.

This is a very serious issue. We do not for one moment want to see any reduction in standards but we believe that the proper and appropriate place for these standards to be monitored is in the home by those who have the greatest interest-not the 9 to 5 bureaucrats who stand to make money out of the system but those whose welfare is of paramount concern: the parents of the children.

That is why what Senator Walsh said to that Sydney meeting recently was such great commonsense. Senator Walsh even claimed that in Queensland-and probably in other States but to a lesser degree-the Department of Community Services and Health was deliberately locating children's services program centres close to commercial centres with the unstated intention of putting the commercial centres out of business. I do not discount that for one moment. The way in which that Department has tried to get control of the whole process by requiring income testing to be carried out by the Department of Social Security and having the payments made by another department is the high-water mark of unnecessary duplication from a department which for many years has opposed any extension of fee relief to the private sector.

I regard it as a very unhealthy involvement, apart from a flat contradiction of all the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) professes to be concerned about in the lead up to the special Premiers' Conference. The sooner that Department can be weaned off this unnecessary bureaucratic expansion the better. I do not think one can do much better than to refer to Peter Walsh's article of 4 September in the Australian Financial Review to demonstrate the length to which some people seem to be prepared to go to turn the debate on its head.

We remain firmly committed to parents having high quality child-care service. But we also think that their interests ought to be paramount and that cost factors ought to be very much at the top of the list rather than completely ignored, as they have been to date by the Minister and the loaded advisory committee that he established in secret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In replying to the second reading debate on the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, I thank those honourable senators who have contributed. I remind honourable senators that, in fact, there are three main parts to this Bill, which attempts to achieve several objectives. I am glad for the support, with modifications, that has been indicated from around the chamber in relation to at least the first two parts.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will be aware that it is the Government's intention that non-residents of Australia, whether they be Australian citizens residing abroad or long term visitors from overseas, should not have access to Medicare eligibility. The Government believes that only persons who actually legally reside in Australia should have Medicare entitlements. I believe that that policy would be well supported in the Australian community.

It is also the case that the Government has decided to discontinue the payment of Medicare benefits for medical treatment received overseas. This will, of course, require Australians travelling overseas to look to their insurance cover. But I believe that this amendment will also be generally understood in the community.

More importantly, as I say, it is certainly the intention of the Government-this is manifested in this Bill and, I believe, supported on all sides of the chamber-that only those legally resident in Australia should be entitled to share in the benefits of the Medicare scheme, which is supported by the taxpayers of Australia by way of a special levy and in other ways.

Secondly, the Bill gives effect to some of the structural reform being undertaken in relation to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in that the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority is to be established. This is one of the key elements to come out of the very long process of consultation and even confrontation between the Government and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia.

The restructuring of the retail pharmacy industry has been a painful process. I believe that the various measures which will be under the auspices of the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority to assist that process of reconstruction will ameliorate and alleviate some of the hardship which market forces alone would have wreaked on many pharmacies carrying on business in situations where there is a conglomeration of retail pharmacies in very close proximity to one another.

At the same time and at the other end of the extreme, the Authority will have a special duty to ensure that persons who live in isolated areas of Australia have reasonably ready access to a pharmacy. To that extent, special provision will be made to ensure that pharmacies are available to dispense pharmaceuticals in a way that makes them accessible to people in rural and provincial Australia. I believe that that is also very important. But there is no doubt that the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority is going to have a very key role to play. I believe that it is a very sensible arrangement and a very good result from the long period of consultation that took place.

As regards child-care, I think the Government has to take note of the underlying sentiment of some of the contributions that have been made today. I for one certainly believe that any system of child-care which has as its primary focus the enhancement of the opportunities for work of those who take care of the children in those centres is not properly focused. I believe that the Government is very conscious of the need to keep in mind always that the welfare of the children committed to the care of the various centres around Australia is the absolute primary responsibility of those involved in childcare, whether it be non-profit, commercial or however it is organised.

Many thousands of Australians are involved in the provision of child-care. The large majority of those would be extremely dedicated people who take a great deal of pleasure, quite apart from professional satisfaction, in standing in for parents in relation to the care of children during the course of the day because of the need for a parent to undertake employment or engage in other activities of a social or community kind. Enabling children to be placed in this sort of care allows the parent concerned to have freedom to engage in activities in the community which would otherwise be more difficult, if undertaken at all. If the child-care were not available, parents might feel that they would be trapped at home.

It is a salutary warning to give, but I do not believe that the Government's proposals are in any way motivated or designed to achieve a simple increase in the role of child-care supervisors. Rather, they are designed to ensure that the very proud record of this Government in the provision of child-care continues so that we have one of the very best integrated systems available in the world, going from non-profit community-based centres through to the more commercially-based sector of child-care.

As I understand it, the improved fee relief system in relation to non-profit child-care services now covered by the program came into being a couple of weeks ago on 1 October. This Bill extends the improved system to commercial, employer provided and other non-profit child-care centres not currently covered by the program. It is intended that these new arrangements will come into place on 1 January 1991. This will be of great help to the many thousands of families which currently use these centres. I believe that the fee relief will be well accepted and regarded by them.

In so far as the provision of certain criteria for the accreditation of these centres is concerned, I understand that this is not a duplication of State licensing regulations in relation to, for example, the space that is available per child or the ratio of workers to children. It is more to do with the quality of the care that is being provided and undertaking activities which will ensure that there is a stimulating, friendly and happy environment for the children committed to the care of these centres by the parents concerned.

Despite Senator Alston's misgivings and some cynicism, I would hope that the committees which will have a role in this regard will, indeed, listen very carefully to the parental input and will, quite rightly, regard the child-care centre as simply standing in the place of parents. I hope that they will give very full weight to the contribution of parents in that process and not be swamped by other contributors to that committee process who claim to have an expertise in the matter.

In this regard, I believe that the commonsense of parents ought to be given the fullest possible consideration and weight. I am sure that that would be the intention of those undertaking this accreditation process which is, as I say, concentrating on what happens to the children hour by hour and day by day. That is obviously an area in which parents, in association with the dedicated workers who are to be found in these various centres, have a primary expertise.
I thank the honourable senators who have contributed to the debate and commend the second reading of the Bill to the chamber.
