TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Acting Deputy President, I understand that both you and I were perhaps confused. I am not asking for a recommittal of the vote. The Australian Democrats now wish to inform me that they were voting against the amendment to the second reading, whereas I had understood that they were voting and nodding in favour of it and that is the way you properly called it, being under the same impression. For that reason I did not call for a division. Had the Democrats properly signalled their intention, the vote would have been in the negative and would have been recorded that way in a division. It is a matter of confusion. I do not think there is any point in trying to recommit the whole process.
—The nods were very clear. I also made it very clear in the summary that I gave, so the decision of the Senate stands.
—Yes. I just wanted to get that onto the record.

—by leave-It was our understanding in the Opposition as of last night, and I conveyed this to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), that because we were concerned that this matter would come to a vote last night we had, in fact, sought what the situation was with the Australian Democrats. We understood as of last night that they were supporting the amendment and that is why we undertook the procedure that we did. There was certainly no mechanism by the Opposition to have any skulduggery going on in the Senate today.
—by leave-I understood from Senator Coulter's speech yesterday that he was supporting the amendment, because he said that, and that was the basis on which we were operating.

—by leave-As Senator Coulter was not in the chamber, and he is the one who is advising on this matter, and as those of us who were in the chamber were not all of the one mind, as it were, I therefore thought that it was my obligation to vote as I felt. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on behalf of the Opposition on the First Home Owners Amendment Bill 1990 which puts into effect the Government's decision to abolish the first home owners scheme. The Bill also makes a number of minor amendments to the First Home Owners Act 1983 by removing provisions which have been duplicated in the Crimes Act 1914 and making it an offence to recklessly make a false or misleading statement when completing an application for the first home owners scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: It also establishes 30 June 1991 as the cut-off date by which applications for assistance under the first home owners scheme must be received by the Department of Community Services and Health. It also corrects drafting oversights affecting applications made since last December and corrects anomalies which occurred when references to migration law in the First Home Owners Act 1983 were amended by the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989.

Financially, savings from the abolition of the first home owners scheme, according to the Government's figures, will be $33.4m in 1990-91 and $61.8m in 1991-92. The Government announced its intention to abolish the first home owners scheme in the 1990-91 Budget with effect from 22 August 1990. However, all approved ongoing payments will continue to be met and persons who entered into a contract to purchase or build a home before 22 August 1990 will also be eligible for assistance provided they submit an application prior to 30 June 1991. The Government also proposes, in place of the first home owners scheme, to give additional funds to the States for home purchase assistance.

The coalition will not be opposing the Bill because essentially we believe that the principle behind the devolution of the first home owners scheme to the States is the correct procedure. However, we still have concerns about the way the Government has made the changes. The shadow Minister for housing-the honourable member for Forrest, Mr Prosser-is particularly concerned about the lack of detail which has been given accompanying the changes, in particular the reduction of funding that will result for housing. The Government has allocated only $14m to be distributed among the States this financial year and $30m next year. This compares with Commonwealth funding for the first home owners scheme of $119m in 1989-90 and $176m in 1988-89.

This paltry amount to be allocated to the scheme this financial year means that financial assistance to first home buyers has dropped by a massive 850 per cent. It also means that this money has been held in the Treasury and has not flowed on to first home buyers. Once again, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has shown his true mettle-not only record interest rates burdening home buyers but also pocketing money which rightly should have gone to first home buyers. I point out that if ever there was an example for the States of what this Federal Labor Government means by devolution of authority to the States, this is a classic example of the way it operates. It should be a warning to the States when they are negotiating a transfer of powers with this Government down the track at the Premiers Conference. I say to the States: count your change; make sure you have not been ripped off; make sure you are not being required to make a silk purse out of a sow's ear. Clearly, although the authority may go to the States, it does not look as if the money is travelling with it.

As I have said, the Opposition has no problem with the principle of devolving responsibility to the States because, given the varying price of houses and land in each State, it is appropriate that the scheme be administered in a manner which takes account of those differences. The States are best placed to do this. For example, the average price of an established home in Sydney is now $206,000; Melbourne, $127,000; Brisbane, $86,000; Adelaide, $89,000; Perth, $97,000; and Hobart, $78,000. There is also merit in the administrative savings that this would mean by transferring the responsibility to the States because the States already have their own housing assistance programs while the Commonwealth administered the first home owners scheme. This has doubled up on work, is inefficient and is certainly more expensive.

It is clearly inappropriate and inefficient to continue to have two levels of government administering the same type of home purchase assistance, but this still does not overcome the fact that the Government is not properly funding the States. In fact, the cutting of this funding goes back on one of the commitments of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Prime Minister gave his assurance that where functions for which the Commonwealth had responsibility were transferred back to the States, fair compensation would be given. I would hardly claim that dropping funding by 850 per cent was fair compensation. One wonders that the Government could claim that it is doing a fair job in this respect. The veterans in this country who are fearful at the moment of the handing over of the repatriation hospitals to the States should also take a close look at what is happening to the funding of the first home owners scheme. I believe that it will be a pretty similar operation. First the Government hands over the authority to the States and then it forgets to hand over the money with it.

In addition, the Government has not developed any formula for the allocation of funding between the States. The shadow Minister, in his speech in the other place, asked the Minister whether the funds will be allocated on a per capita basis proportionately according to house prices or whether they will just be split between the States and Territories eight ways. Until the States know what level of funding they are to receive it will be impossible for them to start developing a replacement strategy to assist first home owners. The Opposition criticises the Government for this inefficiency and lack of planning. It is a classic case of all gas and no lemonade: announce a policy and there it stops. This is what happened with the training levy and now it is going to happen with the first home owners scheme. Here we have a very good concept failing at the implementation stage.

The Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) said in his second reading speech that the Commonwealth will develop broad guidelines against which the States will develop more flexible deposit assistance. But these guidelines have not been forthcoming. The Opposition is concerned to see that when these guidelines are developed the Government will ensure that home deposit assistance, as administered by the States, remains targeted at low income first home buyers. I trust that this will be the case. The Minister also stated in his second reading speech that the new deposit assistance arrangements are envisaged to come into effect from 1 January 1991 provided agreements can be reached with State and Territory governments. I find it very odd that the appropriate guidelines were not negotiated before the Government's announcement of its decision. It would certainly have eliminated much of the uncertainty that is being experienced by the States and prospective home purchasers.

As the new arrangements are not expected to come into effect until 1 January next year-and that is if the Government and the States can reach agreement-and the old scheme was abolished as of 22 August this year, there is some time gap where no assistance is available at all. A funding vacuum exists where home buyers are completely locked out of home purchase assistance. The Opposition is concerned for those eligible first home buyers who would otherwise have been approved to receive assistance. Because of the time lag, this vacuum, there is nothing available to them. It is a problem that will be exacerbated if the State and Federal governments cannot reach agreement and the implementation drags on.

This flows on to the very important economical problem that this Government's high interest rate policy is having for families trying to make ends meet and to afford a home of their own. Home ownership has become a privilege. It is almost incomprehensible that that could have happened in our country. At one time owning a home was the great Australian dream and now it is only a dream.

I draw the attention of honourable senators to the increased costs for families trying to repay their mortgage. In December 1989, families were spending up to 36.4 per cent of their income just on repaying their mortgage. That meant that the average family was making mortgage repayments of over $1,000 a month, and those were families that had started out making repayments of $227 a month. The situation is even worse in Sydney. By June this year home owners there were paying 44.3 per cent of their income on their mortgage. That equates to almost $1,300 per month.

What has this Government done to our young people, our young families? For those who have managed to cope with the huge increases in interest rates, inevitably there have had to be dramatic changes in lifestyle. Families have been forced to make enormous sacrifices. In some cases, couples have put off having children because they simply cannot afford them. One salary is no longer enough. Mothers are fast becoming economic conscripts, many having to take up outside work and be forced to leave their children in day-care just to make ends meet. The percentage of women forced back into the work force has increased dramatically in recent years. Whilst I recognise that not all people are there because they need that income, a high proportion are. I draw your attention, Mr Acting Deputy President, to some of the figures. In 1983-84, 2.3 million women were in the work force. In the last financial year this had increased to 3.2 million. This represents an increase of over 34 per cent. As I say, financial necessity is not the sole reason for this increase. Women's emancipation obviously accounts for much, but not all.

It was interesting to read a study done by Helen Glazer of the Institute of Family Studies in 1988. She found that 56 per cent of women with babies under 18 months were back in the work force `because they needed the money'. Yet, we hear the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) attacking the Archbishop of Brisbane because he had the gall to criticise the Government's performance and the high interest rates on mortgages.

As the academic from Deakin University said on AM this morning, the Prime Minister is not too good at accepting negative feedback. I will tell the Prime Minister, I will tell the Government, in no uncertain terms, what any Australian who lives outside the Lodge or Kirribilli House really knows: high interest rates are hurting Australian families; they are seriously hurting Australian families. They are hurting them in the change of the lifestyle for those who wish to stay at home with their small children and have no choice but to go back into the paid work force. They are hurting the young couples who are putting off having children in order to be able to have a home. They are hurting those who, because they are on low salaries, can never aspire at all to getting a home. This is the Government that has reduced the funding to first home owners in such a dramatic measure.

Let me remind the Senate that at the moment the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, the National Australia Bank Ltd and the Commonwealth Bank are charging home owners 16 per cent for their mortgages and that the Westpac Banking Corporation is still charging 16 1/4 per cent. That is the reality, whether the Prime Minister likes it or not, and whether the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) suggests that it is all the banks' fault, it is a direct result of Government policy that we have high interest rates on mortgages in this country, and there is no getting away from that.

I draw the Senate's attention to the latest figures published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on the makeup of Australian families. Those figures show that 50 per cent of households, either through choice or of necessity, have two full-time breadwinners, and that the proportion of Australian two-income families with children is increasing at a fast rate, from 20 per cent in 1988 to 24 per cent currently. Furthermore, 27 per cent of childless couples have both partners working full time, and many of those couples are madly trying to get a deposit together in these difficult times.

The Deputy Director of the Australian Institute of Family Studies, Mr Peter McDonald, commented on the preference that mothers with young children have for part-time employment, but the evidence was that many families had to have both husband and wife with full-time jobs in order to meet their housing costs, particularly in Sydney, where the costs of a standard mortgage require two people to work full time in order to meet those costs.

The Government can rant and rave about banks until it is blue in the face; the fact remains that because of Government policy Australian families have had extreme difficulty in getting or maintaining homes or home loans. Families have been forced out of their homes and onto the streets because they have not been able to meet their mortgage commitments. Record numbers of people have been opting to stay in the private rental market. Constantly we hear welfare organisations saying that the number of people coming to them for help has increased dramatically and that the sort of people coming to them for help has changed dramatically.

No longer is it only low-income families or people who would have been deemed to be in low socio-economic groups; it is also people who would have been expected to survive a downturn in the economy. They too are coming for help because of the commitments that they have been caught up with in coping with the high cost of housing. Waiting lists for public housing have increased dramatically as more families find it difficult to cope in the private market. Public housing lists are currently at record levels. The Commonwealth Government simply has to act fast in giving the States both direction and funding.

In summary, the Opposition supports the Bill and the principle that it outlines, but we condemn the Government for its failure to put into place the necessary guidelines, the funding and the directions to have the policy function properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that the Australian Democrats, too, will not be opposing the First Home Owners Amendment Bill and also that I find myself in agreement with many of Senator Newman's remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) said in his second reading speech, the main purpose of this legislation is to preclude any further payment of assistance under the First Home Owners Act 1983 to applicants who contract to purchase or build, or commence construction of, a house after 21 August this year. The Bill also incorporates a number of minor amendments by establishing offences for misleading statements made in relation to an application under the first home owners scheme and for obtaining payment of assistance under the scheme by false means.

The Government argues that the decision to end the first home owners scheme was based in part on the fact that the scheme was no longer proving to be an effective way to assist low income earners who wanted to enter the housing market. That is true; but we need to look more closely to identify the reasons for it.

One of the reasons which most affect New South Wales is that there are massive discrepancies between the States in terms of housing costs. In view of this, I find it disturbing that the Government then goes on to suggest that the housing situation since the scheme was introduced in 1983 has actually improved because of its policies. This argument appears to be based on the Government's presumption that the alleged benefits arising out of a deregulated financial sector have allowed for an increase in the supply of housing finance, thus making it easier for people to borrow.

The question which we have to ask, though, is: At what cost do people in the community now have to borrow in order to buy a home, particularly in Sydney? The answer is quite simple: hundreds of thousands of Australians are currently experiencing considerable hardship because they have been unable to obtain adequate and affordable housing and housing finance. I am afraid that most of those people are in New South Wales.

Public housing waiting lists are longer than at any other time since 1983 and there are now more families in the suburbs of Australia's main cities who do not have enough money to spend on the necessities of life and who are actually spending less and less on the basic household items of food and clothing because the bulk of the family budget now has to go towards the cost of meeting mortgage repayments or rent.

We all know that it is now immensely difficult for people to become home owners because of the lethal combination, especially in Sydney, of high interest rates and high home prices, both of which are the result of the Government's policies.

Figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) now show that housing affordability has been dramatically eroded over the last few years. In fact, the ABS, through its housing affordability index, shows that housing in this country is now more expensive and more difficult to achieve than ever before. It is this trend of increasing pressure of housing costs on families in all kinds of situations that is of enormous concern to us. Of course, we accept that some of the causes for this situation are complex, but the pressures of high interest rates and of the Government's consistently reducing its own outlays of expenditure in housing over the years must surely be major factors.

Groups as diverse as the Housing Industry Association and the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) have expressed similar concerns about the Government's housing policies and about abolishing the first home owners scheme. ACOSS in particular has in recent years, in its pre-Budget submissions to the Government, devoted a great deal of attention to housing. It has consistently been at the forefront of community-based organisations warning the Government of how serious the crisis in housing has become for those families struggling to meet repayments or to put together a deposit, and probably while they are paying rent. High housing prices and high interest rates have eroded the home purchasing power of all Australians to such an extent that, as Senator Newman said, the great Australian dream is that-just a dream. Nearly one in four private tenants have incomes below the poverty line after paying their housing costs. Rents and mortgage repayments have pushed thousands of Australians into poverty.

Total Government funding for housing to the States in this year's Budget has again been reduced. Added to previous years, this year's allocation now means there has been an effective decrease in funds available for housing and for housing assistance since 1986-87 of more than 40 per cent. If one looks at the Budget's forward estimates, one sees that funds to be allocated under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement in the years 1993-94 will actually be held at the value of 1990-91 dollars for each of the next three years. The Government plans a decrease in real terms of more than 20 per cent over the next three years.

I find this an alarming situation. The most alarming feature of this Bill comes in the claim that, as a result of ending the first home owners scheme, the Government will redirect to the States and Territories the money saved so they can distribute the funds to assist low income earners in purchasing homes through schemes already administered by them. Some additional funds have been promised to the States for housing assistance but, as Senator Newman has told us, those amounts do not equal what would have been the case had the scheme continued.

The Government has committed itself to providing only $14m this year and $30m in 1991-92, equalling a cost saving for the Government of $33m this financial year and $62m for 1991-92. The Government is arguing that, although the scheme has been abolished, the funds that would have ordinarily been set aside for it will now be redirected back to the States and Territories for them to administer. Clearly, this is not the case. Terminating the first home owners scheme and then handing over less than half the money to the States does not represent fair compensation to the States.

Another interesting point in the Minister's second reading speech is the suggestion that the scheme must be abolished because it is no longer viable. Yes, as I said before, this is true; but why? As far as we can see, there are two basic reasons: firstly, the Government has consistently tightened the eligibility provisions of the scheme, making it extremely difficult to qualify for assistance; secondly, the Government has refused to index the income eligibility threshold since 1985.

Obviously, these two factors, as well as the rising cost of living, mean that the threshold is now at a totally unrealistic level. In fact, instead of indexing the scheme in order to keep it in line with inflation, in 1986 the Government actually reduced the value of the grant from $7,000 to $5,000. Since then, inflation and the cost of buying a home-particularly in Sydney-have increased massively while the size of the grant has stayed at $5,000.

As I said at the outset, the Democrats will not be opposing this Bill, but, as Senator Lees will say in a moment, we do have a number of concerns surrounding the Government's apparent lack of commitment to the housing sector, and this legislation obviously typifies that abrogation of responsibility. We trust this type of policy decision is not an indicator to further cut-backs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: -As my colleague Senator Bourne has already indicated, the Australian Democrats will not be opposing this legislation, which abolishes the first home owners scheme. As Senator Bourne has pointed out, our main concern about this legislation relates to the lack of commitment on the part of the Government to direct the net savings from its decision to terminate the first home owners scheme towards other forms of housing assistance. The Government says the savings from its decision-and I will simply run through them before I state where we believe they should go-will be as follows: $33.4m this financial year; $61.8m in 1991-92; and $81.5m in 1992-93. That is a total of $176.7m over the next three years.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that the Government has allocated $14m this year and $30m next year towards the additional deposit assistance under a scheme to be administered by the States. As Senator Newman and Senator Bourne have already pointed out, we have no details as to how exactly this is, indeed, to be administered. That still leaves significant funds saved from the abolition of the first home owners scheme which are not being committed to housing. In effect, the Government has cut its overall housing support in the Budget and, with its usual rather misleading rhetoric and bluster, is trying to disguise the fact that a very sizeable cut has occurred. The Australian Democrats believe the decision to abolish the first home owners scheme and the failure to maintain real levels of funding to its housing responsibilities reflect the Government's paucity of ideas when it comes to tackling the housing crisis in Australia. It is now making its impact felt beyond the low income earning area and is increasingly starting to bite into so-called middle income Australia.

I am not greatly concerned at the death of the first home owners scheme, as it was becoming increasingly obvious that the scheme itself was not within the reach of many low income families. In fact, the scheme was underspent this financial year by $26.5m and I think it is fair to say that in many ways the scheme had already outlived its usefulness. What is so disappointing about the decision that the Government has made is that the Government has chosen not to capitalise on these so-called savings, or additional money, generated from the abolition of the scheme and turn its mind to more creative funding options to provide secure low cost housing for Australians.

It is also disappointing to see the increasing willingness of the Commonwealth to look at devolving its respon- sibilities in a very half-hearted manner to the States. I do not want to labour this point, as it has already been quite well covered, but it is often of concern that the Government appears eager to practise a policy of devolution to the States in several key areas without ensuring that commensurate funds are available, and without proper consideration of the effects on the community of this devolution.

The Australian federal system provides excellent opportunities for the financing of innovative housing programs, and it is high time the Government directed funds towards exploring some of these alternatives. Certainly, we welcome the establishment of the national housing strategy, headed by Dr Meredith Edwards-although I would make the point that this is something that community groups have been pressing for for quite a long time. However, the Democrats do not believe that the Government needs to wait for the reports of the strategy in order to direct funds towards innovative housing options. Many of these options have been around for quite some time-many years. They are popular in other countries and, with many Australian families now being squeezed out of the housing market, they deserve closer examination here.

The Australian Democrats believe we urgently need to take a new look at the way people, particularly those on low incomes, are housed. We need new ways of, firstly, reducing the overall cost of housing; secondly, cushioning the impact of rising house prices; thirdly, making better use of our existing housing stocks; and, fourthly, developing new forms of tenure. It is this last option that I particularly want to look at now.

In some ways, the existence of the first home owners scheme reflected our obsession with owning our own homes; it was also a by-product of a housing system which remains largely locked into one form of tenure-home ownership. It is not the case any more that this form of tenure is attainable by the vast majority of Australians. Indeed, it may not even be the preferred option of many Australians who would be content with security of tenure at an affordable price. Home ownership continues to be supported by policies favourable towards it at the expense of other options. The favouring of this form of tenure above all others means we are limiting or denying access to affordable and secure housing for a significant and growing proportion of Australians.

One alternative form of tenure that I personally have seen working well in my home State of South Australia is cooperative housing. Cooperatives have been with us for many years but they have, unfortunately, generally been seen as fringe alternatives to home ownership. I believe this is not because cooperatives as a form of tenure are inadequate or have less to offer; rather, it comes, we believe, from a lack of commitment at Federal and State levels to fund and promote cooperative home ownership as an attractive and viable alternative. I am not saying this sort of scheme would suit everybody. What I am saying is that a continued failure to fund these sorts of programs as demanded is denying many Australians the opportunity to access secure and affordable housing.

While cooperatives may not be in vogue in Australia, in many European countries close to half the housing stock is held in cooperative tenure of varying sorts covering the range between public housing and home ownership. South Australia's housing Minister, Mr Mayes, recently returned from a trip to the Netherlands during which he observed that 45 per cent of all housing in the Netherlands was held in cooperative forms of tenure, largely funded by private banks. As in other European countries, cooperative tenure is not seen in the Netherlands as just the province of those on low incomes; rather, it is seen as a way of improving and extending housing options for the community as a whole.

It is fair to say that the Commonwealth has encouraged some minor experimentation through local government and through the community housing program under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, but this level of commitment remains paltry in the overall scheme of things. For example, a total of only 367 dwelling units were approved under this program in 1988-89.

Perhaps the best developed model in Australia is that of the common entity rental cooperatives (CERCs) in Victoria. A CERC is essentially a small tenant-run version of public housing involving several households. Properties are owned by the cooperative and cannot be sold. Initial capital is provided by the Government and the remaining funds, usually some 20 per cent, are borrowed privately. A guarantee against default is provided by the State. Although this program is at present restricted to low income tenants who provide no equity, it would be possible to extend the scheme along European lines to cater for tenants who are able to contribute equity. I believe it was one of the shortfalls of the first home owners scheme that it was not available for cooperative ventures.

Cooperative housing and shared-equity housing are two alternative forms of tenure that could quite feasibly attract significant private sector support, and ultimately prove to be a method offering secure housing to more Australians. However, a move away from the preferential treatment we presently give to home ownership as our dominant form of tenure requires some leadership from the Government. It is a great disappointment that the Government has not chosen to exercise a bit of leadership by seizing upon the opportunity provided by savings made from the termination of this first home owners scheme to redirect funds towards other forms of tenure.

At the very least, the Government should have ensured that the savings were not lost to the housing sector in toto. This sector is feeling the pinch of the Government's economic policies and, as we all know, housing is being driven further and further out of the reach of ordinary Australians. To abolish a scheme which, despite its many shortcomings, at least improved the housing opportunities of some Australians and further compound the damage by failing to direct the resulting savings to the Commonwealth's housing responsibilities, is yet a further indication of how out of touch the Government is with the savage effects its economic policies are having on middle and low income earners in this country.

This is the Government's response to that growing group of desperate people who cannot afford to buy or even rent housing. Here I want to look at another sector that could have been significantly assisted through these savings, had the Government chosen to do so. I would like to quote now from a series of reports looking at homelessness and looking at those who are living on the streets in Australia. I begin with the Burdekin report of the National Inquiry into Homeless Children. Yes, I acknowledge that the Government has responded to this report, but as yet we have seen no significant changes and no significant results from that response. The report states:
Crisis refuges do not offer stable, secure and adequate housing for young people, or the other support services which young people need to move towards either family reconciliation or independence.

Public housing authorities do not offer significant affordable and adequate housing for young people who simply need accommodation. Private sector accommodation is inaccessible for many because of their low income, legal barriers and discrimination.
Finally, it states:
It is clear that tens of thousands of Australia's children are being denied their basic right to special protection; adequate housing; protection from neglect, abuse and exploitation . . .

I move on to another report, prepared in South Australia by Suzi Quixley for the South Australian Youth Housing Network called Whose Children?, which particularly looks at the problems associated with under 16 year-olds who are homeless. I quote from this report:

Preparing to write this report was like listening to a broken record! Time and time again, both respondents to the survey and the literature stated the urgent need for long term, stable, secure accommodation for under 16 year olds.

I move to another area, and that is accommodation for people with disabilities. There is a recent Senate report, the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs which I am sure the Minister has plenty of copies of. But the problems that were found through that inquiry are highlighted in another report on Homeless People with Severe Mental Disorders in Inner Melbourne. Here it highlights the difficulties, not because there are increasing numbers of people with mental disorders, but because the available housing stock is decreasing. I quote from two tables. The first relates to rooming house numbers in St. Kilda. In 1963 there were some 605 independent rooming houses and by 1987 that number had dropped to only 117. If we look at the second table, boarding houses and apartment houses and this again is in inner Melbourne we see that in 1960, there were some 34,000 beds available for these people. By 1980, the number had dropped to less than half, down to 15,881. This is another example of the areas in which the Government could have taken some serious interest and allocated the funds that have been made available through the savings in the first home owners scheme.

With an estimated 1.5 million Australians living in housing related poverty, this is not a response that can be excused or justified or obscured by the window dressing of the National Housing Strategy. It is simply a sleight of hand trick which cuts the Commonwealth's housing budget at a time when it should be recognising its responsibilities in this area and moving towards extending the housing options available to those people in this country who are desperately in need of them.

The Government likes to remind us ad nauseam of our need to stop seeing ourselves as the lucky country, and instead to become the clever country. I, for one, am constantly amazed by the Government's inability or unwillingness to match its rhetoric and take up opportunities which would actually make progress towards that mythical goal of the clever country. It seems to me that here was one such opportunity to improve and extend our range of housing options and provide at least the basis of ongoing Commonwealth responsibility for innovative housing alternatives. Instead the Government has, once again, failed to put its money where its mouth is and middle and low income Australian families, the homeless and people with disabilities will once again bear the brunt of a Government decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on the First Home Owners Amendment Bill 1990. I think that in particular Senator Lees is to be commended-along with Senator Bourne and Senator Newman-for her contributions in which she placed emphasis on the need for Australians to have access to affordable and accessible housing, rather than with having an obsession with the absolute need to have home ownership in the name of one person or as joint holders of the title, which is the common practice in most households in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought that many of the points that Senator Lees made about cooperative housing, as a different way in which housing stock can be held by persons in the community, were very fascinating and very interesting. I would hope that in the strategy review being undertaken at the behest of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe), which is looking at Australians access to affordable and accessible housing, that that particular form of ownership, which has great currency in certain European countries, is one of those forms which is considered. I hope that whatever assistance can be given by governments is made available.

We are not only talking about home ownership, although primarily that is the focus of this particular scheme, but we are really broadly looking at the question of affordable housing-that is shelter for Australians. Of course, when one thinks of that, one also thinks of the rental market, which is an increasingly important focus of the attention of both the Federal and State governments. Indeed, in the guidelines for the mortgage and rent assistance program-which I am quite willing to table and which are being made available by the Minister in regard to the reallocation of funds which can come about through the abolition of the first home owners scheme at the Federal level-there is a lot of attention paid not only to deposit assistance and mortgage relief to help those who are experiencing difficulty in securing their accommodation by way of those traditional methods of acquiring home ownership, but also there is quite major provision in relation to assistance for rental payments.

For example, there can be assistance provided through the scheme in regard to the payment of rental bonds; removal expenses and utility deposits; payment of rental arrears; flat rate payments or payments to reduce rent payments to a specified proportion of gross income for those persons experiencing short term financial difficulties; and payments to community organisations and local Governments to enable them to purchase, upgrade, lease or otherwise acquire dwellings for rental to low income persons requiring short term rental accommodation. This is a matter which I know Senator Lees is particularly concerned about. A very good illustration in relation to the availability of that sort of accommodation is the St. Kilda area.

I know from my own experience in Hobart around the university in old Sandy Bay that when I was a student, there was plenty of accommodation around those areas but as the trendy little boutiques have moved up from the main street into the side streets and taken over a lot of those dwellings for fashionable retailing outlets, so much of that accommodation is no longer available. Payments to community organisations can also be made, as to local governments, for the provision of housing information and referral services to renters. I believe we will see there that what the Government has in mind is that not only deposit assistance and mortgage relief but also assistance to renters should be a real focus because there are so many different housing needs being experienced by Australians, either by necessity or, of course, in certain situations by choice.

It is not always traditional home ownership which is the focus, as Senator Lees quite rightly pointed out. Nevertheless, it is because the Government's first home owners scheme achieved many of its objectives that it is now thought appropriate that the Federal Government retire from that particular field. The Senate will recall that when the scheme was first introduced on 1 October 1983 there was a need to assist moderate to low income people into home ownership, to stimulate construction of new dwellings and to create new jobs. We were in a situation where that was a target. Of course, the stimulation of the housing construction sector is always a way in which that sort of economic activity in creating new jobs and providing new dwellings can be accomplished. At that time, the Senate will recall, housing activity was at a 20-year low. Only 105,000 dwellings were commenced in 1982-83. Since its inception, the first home owners scheme has helped 360,000 households into home ownership at a cost of around $1.53 billion to other Australians contributing their taxes to that particular program. I do not think any of them would begrudge that expenditure on behalf of those 360,000 Australian households who have benefited from it.

Having achieved many of its objectives, the thought is, and the Government policy embodied in this Bill provides, that the various target groups and the various objectives be approached not through two levels of government, as is the case at the moment, but by allowing the administration of the schemes to be streamlined and the funds provided to the States to enable them to assist Australians into affordable housing. That is being achieved as part of the social justice strategy of the Government. I believe that affordable and appropriate housing will be made available through the proper placing of responsibility for these programs in the State administrations rather than through this scheme administered by the Federal Government. I thank those senators who have contributed to the debate and I commend the second reading to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate, you said you were willing to table the document. Are you in fact tabling the document?

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I table a letter from the Federal Minister to his colleagues in the various States. Attached to that letter will be found program guidelines for the mortgage and rent assistance program under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STEVEDORING INDUSTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990STEVEDORING INDUSTRY LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 October, on motion by Senator McMullan, on behalf of Senator Cook:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the Minister who is in charge of these Bills is not in the chamber.
—That is an accurate observation.
—I wonder whether we should not draw the attention of the Acting Deputy President to the state of this chamber so he can get here.
—The Minister will not come in. There is a roster of duty Ministers and Senator McMullan will be taking the place of Senator Collins until lunch time.

—I am happy for Senator McMullan to come in at the appropriate time, but it seems to me that if we have a Minister introducing a Bill which is supposed to be a major plank of the Government's micro-economic reform, he should be here.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating cognately the Stevedoring Industry Levy Amendment Bill 1990 and the Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. The purpose of this legislation is to facilitate the collection of employer contributions to the new retirement and redundancy scheme. What this will do is collect around $150m from the industry, which in turn will collect it from the users, who in turn will collect it from the people of Australia. The Government will match that figure which it will then collect directly from the taxpayer. A total of $300m is to be put into a fund simply to pay out those people on the waterfront who are redundant.

The reason for the fund build-up, the expenditure of which is to be authorised by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA), is to pay out 3,000 employees on the waterfront who are 55 years of age or over and for 1,000 younger people to be recruited. As part of the package, enterprise agreements are supposed to be introduced to the industry, that is, the pooling arrangement is to be replaced with enterprise employment. The question I ask is: Is it really going to happen?

I noted with interest an answer to a Dorothy Dix question on Monday when the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) came in here full of excitement, like a bullfrog in spring, and said he was pleased to announce that the agreement had been reached between National Terminals (Australia) Ltd and the relevant unions for an enterprise agreement. As one industry person said to me, `He had to say that so he would not have to resign, as promised earlier in the year'. It is interesting to note just what the Minister said in answer to that question. I will quote in part what he said:
. . . I was also in the happy position to announce that agreement had been reached between National Terminals and the waterfront unions on enterprise agreements . . .

There are only minor drafting alterations to be made to the agreement and the sending of the agreement to the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority for its assessment is now imminent. All major issues have been agreed and only minor drafting changes now need to be made.

I would like to direct a series of questions to the Minister about his happy announcement that this agreement has been entered into. I would like to see him answer these questions, either in response to the second reading speech debate or during the committee stage. I ask: Have the agreements been endorsed by the employees of National Terminals? Have they even seen the agreement? Have they been signed by the relevant unions and the company? When they are submitted for approval of WIRA, will the Authority adopt the same approach to the assessment of work practices as it did in the case of grain manning, that is, are operational requirements to be the criterion? Do the indicated productivity increases, performance improvements and costs savings warrant the expenditure of taxpayers' money on special redundancy payments?

It is apparent that an enterprise agreement means very different things to different people. It should not, for instance, mean a single union monopoly with identical agreements. It should not mean a closed shop. If that is what eventuates-and it has all the earmarks of happening, I might say-$300m will have been wasted and the Minister will have failed in his micro-economic reform claims.

We are an island continent. We are a long way from overseas markets compared with many of our competitors. We have an acute and entrenched current account deficit running at the rate of some $20 billion a year. Hence, with our debt increasing at that rate, our gross debt is now in excess of $150 billion. Our primary industries, and in particular wheat and wool, are facing an appalling crisis. The aim of this Minister and of this Government must be not just to have a token improvement in productivity but to have the most cost efficient ports in the world. We should aim to be the best, not just to have some token increase.

The Minister claimed in his answer that there would be productivity increases of 30 per cent in the port of Melbourne and 60 per cent in the port of Sydney as a result of this particular agreement. I want to ask the Minister how real that productivity improvement is. How much of it is reflected in the capital injection made by National Terminals to lift its game-I do not object to that; I agree with it entirely because it always has to be a part and parcel of the operation. What is the real labour productivity increase, if any?

The Senate may remember that one of the great claims made at the time of the in principle agreement was that productivity-and labour productivity was referred to specifically-would increase by something in the order of 25 per cent. I might say that that still does not lift us into being among the world's best but it is an increase and it is a move in the right direction to which no-one would object.
In the understatement of the year, the Minister stated, in his second reading speech to the Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill:
Australia has been poorly served by its waterfront industry, with major costs for the rest of the economy.
Of course, as I mentioned earlier, the Australian waterfront is the achilles heel of this country and any costs which are unwarranted flow on to the whole economy. The Minister continued:
This Key point in the export trading chain has been characterised by gross inefficiencies and high costs due to any absence of competition and competitiveness.

This is a big step forward for the Government as it does at long last recognise that there is a problem. The Government has valiantly defended the actions of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia on every past occasion in this place. I frankly have lost count of the number of times that we in the Opposition have raised this as a very serious issue.

What the Minister should also have said, if he had the intestinal fortitude to do so, is that with the waterfront being the soft spot for Australia's exports and imports the country has been held to ransom by a handful of militants who, because of self-interest, very effectively sabotaged Australian industry by guerilla tactics-not just on a yearly basis but monthly and daily.

How serious is the Government about micro-economic reform on the waterfront? Is it handing out $300m directly and indirectly in taxpayers' money to a bunch of mates who have over a long time, because of the monopoly of power held by a few people renowned for featherbedding, been paid for work not done? They were also renowned, as everyone knows-this is nothing new-for phoney strikes on safety issues and strikes in opposition to another government's domestic policies.

Those of us who receive the monthly reports from the Australian Chamber of Shipping cannot help but notice that month in, month out there is always a dispute at one of the major ports in respect of such matters as the domestic policies of South Africa. Late last year there was a series of them in respect of Fiji. I do not know when the militant trade union movement decided that it was going to be responsible for the foreign affairs of this country but that is the way it is acting at the expense of every Australian citizen. Every time this action is taken, serious damage is done to our exporters, particularly our manufacturers who are struggling already with incredibly high interest rates and an exchange rate which most people agree is overvalued.

The Minister referred on Monday to the enterprise agreement. I want to ask him a number of questions to which he must respond in the wind-up debate if he is to give credibility to both micro-economic reform and the use of a substantial amount of taxpayers money genuinely to reform the waterfront. We do not want a veneer. I would hope that all of us in this place are here for a purpose and that is to improve the lot of this country and every Australian. We want to be assured that at the end of the day there will be genuine improvements, not just marginal improvements.

I would also ask to what extent the rorts have been removed from this agreement. In my own report entitled Rorts in the Ports in May 1989 I highlighted quite a number. I am one of a long line of people who have been hammering home to this Government that if we are in some way to get Australia right, we have to do something about the incredibly appalling situation in our ports.

I want the Minister to come clean and advise whether these restrictive work practices are or have been totally eliminated in the enterprise agreement or whether they are still there. Does he have a copy of it? Not only I but, I am sure everyone in this country would appreciate just seeing what is in it.

I will give a few examples of very serious restrictive work practices which I believe have not been eliminated because of the demands by the Waterside Workers Federation not to give them up. These practices, which have come in over many, many years, are the result of the waterside workers being able to hold stevedores, shipping companies and users to ransom. In other words, if they did not pay up there would be incredible delays. I can go on and on. But let me give a few examples; and I would like some answers.

The famous two-up two-down arrangement is the requirement for cranes to have two drivers. One drives up in the crane and the other stands on the wharf and does nothing. Has anything been done about this precious little arrangement which over a year can amount to in excess of 480 shifts being allocated to down drivers in a single port? This, in fact, was the figure for 1988-89 for the Port of Brisbane, which is nowhere near the size of the ports of Sydney and Melbourne.

The next one is stop-work meetings. These, as everyone knows, are held at a time in which productive work should be being carried out. If we have genuine enterprise agreements, are stop-work meetings to be restricted to the enterprise involved or will it be the old story of applying them to the whole port? My understanding is that the Waterside Workers Federation has refused to give up this little rort.

What about the amenities men? This is one of the classic featherbedding cases on the wharf and there are many. The sole role of the amenities men is to tidy up amenities rooms after breaks and safeguard waterfront workers' personal belongings. They do not trust one another. The amenities men have no real cleaning jobs to do as the job in most cases is carried out by port authorities. It is also well known that the cost of using cleaning contractors is one third of the cost of using Waterside Workers Federation labour. In reality, the amenities jobs are given to those in the Waterside Workers Federation ranks who I understand have some sort of skill or disability problem.

What about all the allowances: travelling allowances, site allowances, telephone allowances, laundry allowances, dirt allowances, rain allowances, cold allowances and so on? I do not know the answer to those latter questions. The Minister should tell us, however, whether any of those have been eliminated in these so-called enterprise agreements. All of us-not just members of this chamber but the Australian people-need to know what we are getting for paying out $300m to reform the waterfront.

Another rort is first-aid men. In the ports that I looked at over the years I found that a fully qualified waterside worker was employed in each stevedoring gang to man the first-aid station. I understand that the union demands that this person be retained. In 1988 alone it was calculated, again in the Port of Brisbane, that these first-aid men cost $1.5m and in the process tied up 17 qualified waterside workers who could have been doing other jobs.

Critical to any genuine enterprise agreement is the recruitment process. If we are genuinely moving to enterprise agreements, the enterprise must be able to choose its own employees on merit without interference. Again, my understanding is that the Waterside Workers Federation continues to insist that the union must have a say in recruitment, promotion and demotion of all employees within the enterprise. I also understand that the union demands that it will determine who will make up the supplementary work force. For those in the Senate who are not aware what that is, it is the supplementary labour force when additional labour is required at peak periods in ports. The union is demanding who should make up that supplementary work force.

These questions go to the core of enterprise agreements. We either have them or we do not. If the position is as I understand it and as outlined, the enterprise agreements will be nothing more than a disgraceful sham to the cost of every Australian.

Another critical area is that of maintenance. When announcing the reform process, the Minister quite clearly stated that the parties had to agree to arrangements to enable the effective contracting out of maintenance work where it is more efficient than in-house facilities. This was quite clearly stated by the then Minister, Mr Willis-it is very sensible stuff.

What that means-and there can be no quibbling about that statement-is that where it is more cost effective to do so, outside contractors will be brought in to maintain the equipment; in many cases, equipment that they themselves built or supplied. I understand that the union will not agree to that prerequisite which has been laid down and which is part of the plan for waterfront reform.

I again wish to refer to the Port of Brisbane which, as I said earlier, is an indicative port; it is not one of the two major ports in Australia. Conditions that apply there almost certainly apply in every other major port in Australia because the WWF always make sure that the same conditions apply right around the country. In 1988, all maintenance work on Brisbane wharves, such as repairs to common ordinary fork lifts used throughout Australia, cranes and refrigeration equipment-there is nothing terribly unusual about it-had to be done by WWF members. At that time, those tradesmen were among the most highly paid employees in Australia on the wharves, earning around $80,000 a year. That is in 1988, so one could presume that the figure is higher today.

At that time, I was advised that outside contractors would cut maintenance costs by more than 75 per cent. That is real micro-economic reform. We must be looking at cutting costs so that we can be more productive. It is not a matter of being conscious of the fact that tradesmen, who probably should not be there in the first place, will lose jobs. No one likes anyone losing jobs. But, we must recognise the fact that we are part of the world scene. Unless we are cost competitive, there is no hope for this country correcting its balance of payments deficit.

If the issue of contracting out is not included in enterprise agreements, clearly this Government and the unions-it is a tripartite agreement-are not honouring the in-principle agreement of 12 months ago. I understood that one of the points that had to be taken on board by WIRA when it handed out the money was that all the issues in the in-principle agreement were to be adhered to.

These are very serious issues and I believe that they must be addressed and responded to by the Minister. After all, it was he who came in here the other day and basically said, `We've done it. We've got a real enterprise agreement.' I want to know what is in that and what is not in it. Otherwise, the public who are paying the $300m to buy out work practices can quite legitimately claim to have been conned by this Minister and, yet again, by this Labor Government.

Notwithstanding the costs on the waterfront, by far the major concern of our overseas customers is lack of reliability. We have very regrettably an appalling reputation overseas for lack of reliability. I do not know one exporter who is obliged to use our ports who has not had to run the gauntlet of claims of lack of reliability when dealing with overseas buyers. There is no doubt whatsoever that this factor alone has cost this country billions of dollars in lost export income.

Before I came into this place, year in year out I would try to persuade overseas buyers and potential buyers that our industrial relations were improving. I might as well have been whistling up a wind. I might say that this caused me substantial embarrassment because I knew I was apologising for my fellow Australians who were wrecking our export industries.

The problem with lack of reliability is that to buyers it equates to a lack of trust. Everyone knows that one of the most devastating and destabilising remarks that could be made of another person is that he or she is unreliable. I think every individual is aware of that. When it is applied to a country it brings great shame on that country and the individuals whose sole aim is to promote it and promote the export of our goods and services.

To a buyer, reliability means that goods will be supplied to the buyer at the time specified and required by the buyer. It is a matter of honouring one's commitments. It is, in fact, a matter of honour between two people from different countries. Regrettably, I have seen no indication that this critical factor is even recognised by the Waterside Workers Federation.

Even though we have serious reservations about the claimed beneficial effects of the expenditure of $300m in buying off the Waterside Workers Federation-and I will frankly be surprised if the Waterside Workers Federation does not end up playing the Minister and the Government off a break-we will not be opposing the legislation because it is, I believe, a move in the right direction. It is only a minor move but at least it is a move. We will be keeping our eye on this to ensure that the Government's claims, the Government's promises, in micro-economic reform are fulfilled. As I indicated, I have serious reservations about it.
Having said that, we will not be opposing the legislation. I foreshadow that during the committee stage of the Stevedoring Industry Levy Amendment Bill we will be moving an amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share Senator Parer's concern that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, is not in the chamber while the Stevedoring Industry Legislation Amendment Bill and the Stevedoring Industry Levy Amendment Bill are being debated. I wonder whether he is counting the days on his calendar to the time limit concerning his very public undertaking to resign if waterfront reform was not implemented within a certain time. I guess that he is a little anxious at the moment as the days tick by.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Parer has said, the Liberal and National parties do not oppose this legislation because we believe that some reform, minuscule though it is, is better than no reform at all. We believe that the reform proposed for the stevedoring industry should have been greater, but it is not with this legislation. We are supporting it because even little reform is better than none at all. We wish to place a timetable upon the Government to ensure that the reform proposed takes place within a finite time, and Senator Parer has mentioned that amendments will be moved at a later stage.

One of the issues of reform which needs very careful consideration by the Government, and the Minister in particular, relates to reform in regional ports right around Australia. These are places where trade and business is not sufficient to have waterside workers working full time on stevedoring labour. The Inter-State Commission Report on Waterfront Investigation, volume 1 at page 147, acknowledged this, stating:

The existing cross-subsidisation of stevedoring labour in smaller ports should be terminated. The Waterside Workers Federation should enter into in-principle agreement for withdrawal of its coverage in ports where integrated workforces are established. Port authorities should consider the establishment of integrated workforces and initiate discussions with all interested parties but they should not inhibit stevedoring companies from operating under the new enterprise employment arrangements. In ports where it is considered more efficient to operate labour pools the pools should operate on a fully commercial basis; that is, they should be separate enterprises.
The then Minister for Transport and Communications, the honourable member for Gellibrand, Mr Willis, told the House of Representatives on 1 June 1989:

The gross inefficiencies which have been allowed to develop in these industries have restricted our economic growth, reduced our living standards and impaired our capacity to develop our export markets. In part our balance of payments difficulties are directly attributable to the acute inefficiencies in these key industries in the export chain.

Later in the same speech the Minister said that the Government believed that a satisfactory agreement would need to include firm commitments from industry parties on a number of matters, one of which was the following:

The parties will need to commit themselves to the introduction of measures to improve the small and intermediate ports, through revised employment arrangements, including enterprise employment, commercial port labour pools and the use of port authority labour.
Later the Minister said:
The Government endorses the broad thrust of the ISC's recommendations in relation to port authorities.

The Cairns Port Authority has proposed an integrated port work force which is described as being employment by a port authority of port and stevedoring labour interchangeably, so that if workers cannot be employed full time on stevedoring duties they can be interchanged and used for other matters. This goes against what the Waterside Workers Federation (WWF) usually requires and is quite insistent about.

As I understand the situation in the Cairns port, in the past there have been some 23 Waterside Workers Federation employees working only part time stevedoring ships, as the ship traffic into the Cairns port is not continuous. There have been 23 people there to do it. In addition to this, the Cairns Port Authority also employees a work force of about 40 people in general multi-skilled work, mainly doing maintenance and repairs around the port and otherwise being gainfully employed on a full time basis.

I understand further that the port authority in Cairns believes that it needs an integrated port work force which would include five or six of the current Waterside Workers Federation workers. The Cairns Port Authority, I understand, thinks that only five or six are needed to do the work that 23 are now being paid to do. When these five or six workers were not loading and unloading cargo, they would be incorporated in the multi-skilled maintenance work force operated by the Authority in the Cairns waterfront area.

I understand that the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority has reached an agreement with the Waterside Workers Federation which provides that 13 of those 23 WWF members currently working at the Cairns port would be retired out of the industry on very generous redundancy packages which are being offered all around. The talks to date have suggested that 13 should be retired. That would leave 10 WWF workers remaining at the port. I understand that this 10 that it is proposed be left cannot be legitimately and gainfully employed and that only a maximum of six can be properly, gainfully and economically employed at the Cairns port.

I understand that the issue is so important to Cairns businesses and manufacturers and people who use the Cairns port-so important to the overall viability of the Cairns port and business generally in the Cairns area-that the Cairns Chamber of Commerce has arranged alternative employment for those four or five Waterside Workers Federation members who cannot be gainfully employed at the port but who have not been one of the 13 to get the generous redundancy packages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I took my place in the Senate in May one of the first requests I received for help was from a small South Australian health fund. That fund, and I might add others which have followed asking for similar help, have continued to call and visit my office regularly. The simple fact is that these funds are in trouble. They are being forced out of business. They are in trouble despite providing an excellent care and contribution package. They are in trouble despite being viable. They are in trouble despite being expertly run with administration costs being kept to a minimum.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, these small health funds find themselves with problems through no fault of their own. They are in trouble simply because of government policy. My colleagues in the other States tell me that they too receive regular calls and visits from small health funds. These people are begging for help, begging for some respite from the ill-considered government policy known as reinsurance. Of course, I realise that this complex and damaging policy is at present the subject of an inquiry by the Senate Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance.

As a senator for South Australia, I wish to put on record as a matter of public interest the damage reinsurance is doing to the small health funds in my State. In general, health funds, big and small, are experiencing difficulties in South Australia, as they are around Australia, but in the past year membership losses and health funds deficits have been far greater in South Australia than in many other States. Health fund contributions last month again rose significantly in South Australia. Accordingly, membership will again drop just as significantly.

Management of one health fund has estimated that less than 42 per cent of South Australians will have private health insurance by the end of 1990. In these difficult economic times young families and young people leaving school are increasingly finding that ever-escalating and expensive contributions to the big funds are simply impossible to maintain. So yet again the pressure on the public health system grows.

In this situation one would have thought it logical for any government to attempt to keep as many people as possible with private health cover. But, no, that is not the approach of the Government. The Government with its reinsurance policy is crippling the small funds, which had no need to increase their contribution schedule at the rate or to the level of my State's major fund, Mutual Community Ltd.

Reinsurance really comes into the stranger than fiction category, or maybe it would be in the Monty Python category if it were not so painful. In South Australia it is certainly causing some great pain. Mutual Community, our major private health fund, has a membership of more elderly and chronically ill people than other funds in the State. The Government's reinsurance principle argues that, because this is so, Mutual Community must bear higher costs per member than other funds- which, I might add, is still a matter of considerable debate. Accordingly, the other funds, the smaller funds, the ones which have worked hard to keep their administration costs and contribution charges down, are made to pass on a percentage of their funds to Mutual Community. It is like asking the corner shop to prop up Coles Myer Ltd. It is about the same sort of principle.

The members of the small funds, which have lower contribution charges, are being forced by this policy to subsidise the members of the biggest fund, which already charges its members more. The Government calls that fair; others would call it simply ridiculous. Why on earth should the funds whose members happen not to be so chronically ill or the funds with older members which still manage to remain more viable be expected to prop up the big fund with the older population on its books? Economic writer in the Adelaide Advertiser, Malcolm Newell, put the crazy situation into the Yes, Minister category with a description that I would like to quote to the House. He said:
Of course, if viable funds keep forking out members' money to shore up non-viable funds, the non-viable funds will become viable in the short term-only as long as the viable funds are still viable.
When, eventually, the viable funds become non-viable because they have been propping up the non-viable funds, that are now (temporarily) viable, the temporarily viable funds become non-viable too.
So in time, all the funds fall into a black financial hole.

No-one can deny that there are definitely shades of Sir Humphrey in that quote. Worse, it is happening in most States in Australia. One representation made to me-in fact, the first representation of many made to me about the reinsurance policy-came from the South Australian Police Health Fund, which is forced by this policy to deliver almost half a million dollars each year to Mutual Community. That fund has some 4,000 members-not a large number of members-but it is a requirement under the regulations of the South Australian police force that a member of that force shall be a member of the South Australian Police Health Fund. One cannot be a police officer in the State unless one is a contributor to that health fund. So police officers are in a no win position. Mutual Community has some 30 times that number of subscribers or members.

Where is the fairness? The South Australian Police Health Fund is clearly a very small fund. Established in 1935, it has always had a reputation for excellent service, low contribution costs and high management standards which means it spends just 6 per cent of its income on administration. Despite this display of good management and service, it is now, as one would describe it, being bled dry by a policy which says it must support the big fund in town. Its contributions are being forced up sharply by the pressure of the reinsurance proposal and demands. Its funds are being rapidly eroded and it announced in June that its future viability now was, in fact, in serious jeopardy.

In total, South Australia's small funds have been forced to subsidise Mutual Community to the tune of more than $5m in the past year. Last year, the then Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, asserted that funds such as Mutual Community would be able to reduce their contribution rates with the subsidies the smaller funds had to hand over under the reinsurance proposal. That is simply wrong. The opposite has happened. Mutual Community's rates have continued to rise and more and more people have dropped out of health insurance. The vicious circle has meant subsidies from the small funds to Mutual Community have also had to rise.

The debacle of Medicare continues unabated, and we continue to put bandaid on top of bandaid. Instead of damaging and knocking out of the market the small funds which have been so successful, would it not have been fairer to keep out of the issue and ensure they provided an efficient service to their contributors and their members as being the qualifying factor? Would it not have been fairer to leave it to the big funds-in South Australia's case Mutual Community-to tailor their charges and benefits to suit their contributor's needs? Other areas of insurance do that; why not this one?

What is so different about health insurance that it needs draconian government measures like reinsurance to prop up certain elements of it? If the small health funds are forced out of the market by reinsurance, we will most likely create monopolies in private health care in each State-a situation which could see charges rise until only the very wealthy can afford health insurance. That is a totally undesirable objective, goal or result from a policy that we now have in place.

In South Australia I have watched with dismay the struggle of the small health funds to stay in business. As I said earlier, I know that this is being repeated in other States throughout Australia. I hope that wisdom wins the day before it is too late, before we squeeze out of existence small health funds providing an invaluable service to their contributors and their members. I repeat that if people want a job in the South Australian police force they have no alternative but to be members of the police fund, because under the regulations they cannot be employed as police officers unless they are. What we are doing with the reinsurance is putting the viability of that fund in serious jeopardy.

Before it is too late, I trust and hope that the Government will review the proposals. I trust and hope that the Select Committee which is currently reviewing this matter will provide, in its report to this Parliament in due course, some light at the end of the tunnel for small health funds throughout Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address a few remarks on philately. Mr Deputy President, you might well ask whether philately is a matter of public interest. I can assure you and honourable senators that in fact it is. No less a newspaper than the Adelaide Advertiser was able to point out on 21 September that, in fact, stamp collectors have saved Australia Post from massive losses at least three times over recent years. Philatelic services, or stamp collecting, have generated revenue of $40m each year over the past few years and involve about one million Australians. So philately is of some considerable public interest. The Adelaide Advertiser noted that there were 60,000 South Australians on Australia Post's South Australian mailing list.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject of philately was sufficiently important to instigate a review of the administration of philatelic services by Australia Post by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, and the report of the Committee was presented in the other place in August.

The Committee found that the contribution of philatelists to the total profit of Australia Post is about 20 per cent. But in absolute terms the philatelic profits have fallen by about 50 per cent in recent years. That is probably why this matter was the subject of the Committee report. In part of the report the Committee postulated that the decline was the outcome of stagnant revenue sales and increasing costs and then set about addressing those matters.

There was an audit review of Australia Post which encouraged Australia Post to adopt a more professional and businesslike approach to the production, marketing and sale of philatelic products. The Committee endorsed that course. I do not endorse that course and I certainly know of a number of philatelists who share my views.
