That particular course, of adopting a more professional and businesslike approach and talking about marketing, implies that stamp collectors are a market waiting for the stuff to be foisted upon them.

It is because of this stuff-I cannot find any other term to describe it properly-this marketing strategy, that collectors are leaving the hobby. The Chairman of the Committee recognised that when he suggested that people might have been giving up stamp collecting in the belief that Australia Post had too many stamp issues each year. That is probably correct but more important is the marketing attitude.

I have brought into the chamber some examples of the sorts of things which are presented to collectors as a marketing technique. Multi-coloured brochures are presented. They can be found on the counter at Australia Post and they come through the mail with standing orders to stamp collectors. There are such things as Christmas gift ideas for all the family. We are presented with images of nature with pretty pictures, semi-postcard sorts of things, and books, booklets and diaries and deluxe executive book collections-the list goes on.

I suggest that that matter is not much different from the unsolicited marketing matter found in the letterboxes of all Australians who have them which accumulates and is generally known as `guff stuff', unsolicited mail. Some of this stuff can be accumulated. It can be purchased and put on the bookshelf, but that is not really collecting and it is certainly not what philatelists are interested in. It is certainly not what will save Australia Post from continued declining philatelic interest and therefore sales to those sorts of areas.

I do not want to take up too much of the Senate's time on this matter, but I do think it is important to consider, as this has been the subject of a report elsewhere, what philatelists are interested in and what might be done to reduce this decline in interest and perhaps bring about a return to the days when $40m and more might be contributed to Australia Post's revenues.

I think we should recognise that philatelists are in fact interested in things such as postmarks-the real ones, not the special commemorative ones-postal markings, markings on envelopes such as `Return to sender' or the redirections that we sometimes see on our electoral mail: the sorts of things which occur in the process of normal postal services, things which have not been commercialised.

All one has to do to find proof of such an assertion is look at the specialist journals and the auctioneers' catalogues when this sort of material is being sold. Some of this material sells for thousands of dollars. In fact, quite often this matter is sold overseas and forms a considerable part of our invisible exports. This sort of material is the subject of philatelic journals.

I have also brought with me the Courier, which is published by the Tasmanian Philatelic Society. Just from looking at the table of contents without reading the thing, one can get an indication of the sort of material which is collectable and the sort of material which is of particular interest to this hobby. It may sound a little esoteric in this place, but I will just read part of the table of contents. What is being considered in this journal-and it is a fine journal and well recognised as such throughout Australia-is The Crotty Closure Puzzle, Manuscript Cancellations on Tasmanian Pictorials, Surveys of Tasmanian Manuscript Cancellations, Amendments to the List of Tasmanian Commonwealth Postmark Rarities, and so on. To some people it may seem esoteric and fairly irrelevant, but to the specialist philatelist it is not: it is fascinating, interesting and not possible to commercialise, not possible to market in the modern whiz-bang marketing sense.

I suggest that perhaps one of the best things that Australia Post could do to encourage the growth of this sort of interest and, therefore, the growth of normal mail processing sorts of items, would be to stop trying to take advantage of collectors by marketing unwanted guff. Perhaps the best Australia Post could do for philatelists would be simply to provide the vehicle for postal activities. The normal postal activities will provide the rarities and varieties which philatelists would be interested in and they can then, through the passage of time, collect them and specialise in them. But to be able to do that, those very people would then have to take part in the collection of the complete set of normal postal items. The extra revenue comes to Australia Post from making larger sales of this normal product to philatelists.

Nobody really, in that sort of area, wants to collect the extraneous guff. I would suggest that to have a marketing expert try to find ways to foist more of it on to new collectors and incidental collectors is entirely the wrong attitude to have and entirely the wrong direction to take. I would hope that Australia Post will be very careful about how it interprets recommendation 4.25 of this report. I hope that it realises that a marketing expert is perhaps not the person who might know the most about what philatelists could be interested in. I would refer such a person, in fact, to the sorts of journals I have quoted and hope that they may be interpreted.
I have spent some time in expressing concerns which I know reflect the concerns of other philatelists and I hope that they are taken note of by Australia Post.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put on record some recollections of three meetings I have attended very recently. The first of these was the fifth global meeting of World Women Parliamentarians for Peace which was held in Harare late in September, attended by about 45 women from 25 different countries. This three-day meeting was extremely successful. Much of this success was due to the very courteous hospitality that was shown to us by the Zimbabwe Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I am now the immediate past President of this organisation and have been succeeded by Edna Madzongwe of the Zimbabwe Parliament. The temptation to go into detail about that meeting is strong but I am resisting it on this occasion. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the declaration of that particular conference and an appendix to the declaration on HIV infection.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
WORLD WOMEN PARLIAMENTARIANS FOR PEACE DECLARATION OF THE FIFTH GLOBAL CONFERENCE HARARE, SEPTEMBER 24-26, 1990

We World Women Parliamentarians for Peace, attending the Fifth Global Conference in Harare, representing parties from across the political spectrum, still consider the nuclear arms race the greatest continuing threat to humanity. We welcome the end of the cold war and the development towards democracy in Eastern Europe, Latin America and Africa. We note with satisfaction that disarmament-agreed and unilateral-is proceeding.
Nuclear Arms Race

Only 3% of all Nuclear Weapons build-up has been destroyed, Naval nuclear weapons have not even been the subject for negotiations. Ships in the Persian Gulf armed with nuclear weapons are an added threat. Nuclear arsenals are an ever present danger to humankind. We call upon all governments to denounce the use of nuclear weapons and work jointly and individually towards their complete elimination. We affirm our determination as Women Parliamentarians to use our resources to work for disarmament, development and international peace and security. We demand the immediate cessation of all nuclear tests and call upon all Governments to actively work for a Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. The production of more weapons, both nuclear and conventional, consumes economic and human resources which should be used for peaceful development.
Biotechnology

The rapid development in the field of biotechnology creates many positive opportunities, but, at the same time, gives rise to a number of new problems such as the military application of biotechnology.
WWPP will work so that that knowledge in the biotechnology field, is applied in such a way that it promotes peace and equality and counteracts war and poverty.
Environment
Environmental problems create conflicts and kill as effectively as weapons. Therefore the struggle for peace and against environmental pollution has the same goal-survival of humankind.

Huge resources will have to be channelled to research and development of environmentally sound technologies in the l990's in order to eliminate major threats to the survival of humankind posed by unchecked environmental degradation.

In 1992 a U.N. Conference on Environment and Development will be held in Brazil. We demand that the U.N. undertake a major study into the conversion of military production to environmentally sound technologies, and to present a plan of action for its implementation. All delegations to the Brazilian Conference must consist of as many women as men.
Disarmament

Disarmament, development and environmental protection, should be achieved together. We urge the Soviet Union and the United States as a matter or urgency to sign a treaty to substantially reduce their strategic nuclear arsenals. We oppose any attempt to remodernize or to substitute nuclear weapons that have been banned. As a first step towards naval nuclear disarmament we urge all nuclear weapon powers to destroy their tactical nuclear naval weapons.

We call for substantial reductions of conventional weapons in all regions of the world; for abandonment of offensive strategies; for non military solutions of conflicts and for a new concept based on interdependence and common security.

We denounce the use of chemical weapons and urgently demand the speedy conclusion of a Universal Treaty on banning and completely eliminating all chemical weapons, without endangering other countries.

We stress that peace will not be achieved without taking into account the aspirations and concerns of all nations and all people. All nations should therefore participate actively and extensively so that negotiations, which affect us all, do not become the exclusive domain of the superpowers.

We welcome the fact that the United Nations, supported by vigorous and broad-based popular movements and non-governmental organisations, is growing more effective in conciliating between disputing members. The United Nations and the Secretary General must continue to play a leading role in promoting peace.
Children and War

We are Women Parliamentarians, but we share with all women the concern about the future of our children. We consider it an absolute right for all children of the world to breathe clean air, drink clean water and have clean and healthy food. We believe, therefore, that the united voices of women from all parts of society are needed to attain real peace, disarmament and the survival of future generations.
As Women Parliamentarians we are committed to resolving conflict, wherever it may occur, without violence. We are concerned about the abuse and exploitation of children in war.
As women we demand an end to the practice of using and recruiting children as soldiers.
We welcome UN's Convention on the Rights of the Child and urge all governments to ratify the Convention.
THE GULF CRISIS
We categorically denounce the invasion and occupation of Kuwait by Iraq, and condemn this violation of the principles of self determination, international security and human rights.
We fully support the adoption by the U.N. Security Council of resolutions and recognise the fragility of international security.
We urge Iraq to immediately withdraw from Kuwait.

We note the joint statement of the United States and the Soviet Union of September 9, 1990, as a positive step towards the resolution of the Gulf Crisis. We urge the leaders of the two nations to ensure that the situation will not escalate into a conflict of even wider proportions, further threatening international peace and security.
We emphasise that no solution can be reached by military means, as we all know that violence breeds violence. A political resolution can, and must be reached by strict adherence to the U.N. Charter.
We deplore the callous use of foreign nationals as hostages and demand their unconditional release, and the restoration of the human rights of displaced women, men and children.
SOUTHERN AFRICA

We Women Parliamentarians for Peace are concerned about the continuing destabilisation of the Front Line States, (Angola, Namibia, Swaziland, Zambia, Mozambique, LeSotho and Zimbabwe) by the minority racist regime in South Africa which has cost these states loss of lives, untold human suffering and enormous losses in their economies and social structures.
We note with deep concern the covert sponsoring of the violence in South Africa which is erroneously referred to as Black on Black violence.
1. We as women call for the intensification of sanctions against South Africa.
2. We call for the immediate dismantling of the vicious apartheid system.

3. We expose President de Klerk's hypocrisy in handling the obstacles hindering the peaceful negotiations towards peace in Southern Africa. This is borne out by the increase in the South African military budget for the years 1990-1991.

We call upon all the Parliaments, especially women parliamentarians of the World to exert pressure, and through their Governments to mobilise support for the International Community, the World Council of Churches, the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, the International Parliamentary Union, Amnesty International, and the United Nations to take positive action against this repressive regime.

We note with anguish the plight of women and children in many parts of our globe, and we call upon all governments, United Nations, and other non-governmental organisations to give priority to the needs of those who suffer most from war and economic deprivation.
VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN AND
CHILDREN
WWPP will work for a situation where violence in all its forms against children is brought to public notice and legal protection is strengthened.
CONCLUSION
We as women, demand the full participation of women in all decision making on peace, disarmament and development, not only as a matter of equality, but also as a matter of substance.

We demand that women must be present at every negotiating table and any conference where issues of life and death are discussed. We refuse to share the responsibility of destroying this planet, but we believe that we can and must play a decisive role in saving it.
We call on all Women Parliamentarians of the World to intensify their efforts to preserve our planet for present and future generations.
H.I.V. INFECTION
(Appendix to WWPP Declaration)
WWPP recognises that HIV (Human Immuno Deficiency Virus) infection is pandemic with above 70% of cases leading to AIDS (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) within 8 years and then to certain death.

In developed countries HIV is a disease primarily affecting homosexuals and bi-sexual men and intravenous drug users. Women and their children are increasingly at risk. The potential for prevention and treatment can, depending on resources and the will of governments be realised by targeting specific at risk groups. In developing countries however, HIV is a disease of families and communities, and in some African nations, of their country.

While firm statistical data is not readily available we note recent estimates reported in the Lancet that as many as 70% of the Ugandan population may be HIV+; and a WHO estimate that 25% of adults in urban areas in East and Central African countries are HIV+. According to a news report WHO estimates that 10 million children will have been infected by the end of the century, with one third of all known AIDS cases to date having occurred in children under 5 years old. Most such children are African.

Infants born to a HIV+ mother may succumb to an AIDS related pneumonia within days of birth. They may live to 3 or 4 years old. Women may be infected by blood transfusion at delivery and pass the virus to their babe through breast milk.
HIV/AIDS has devastating consequences for developing countries, debilitating and killing millions of men, women and children. There is no vaccine and no-cure. Prevention is therefore critical.

WWPP supports the efforts of the WHO. We identify HIV/AIDS as a consequence of underdevelopment and assert that whole country prevention can only be achieved by an urgent redirection of resources from military budgets within and outside these countries into prevention programs. These programs would focus on the reduction of sexual transmission through
- the training of specific AIDS prevention health workers,
- the distribution of free condoms,
- education programs in schools and workplaces, etc,
- improvement of antenatal care,
- provision of sterile medical equipment,
- safe blood transfusion systems.

WWPP also notes the potential for transmission of HIV/AIDS through tourism. WWPP members are urged to alert their governments to not only inform travellers of the risks of unprotected sex, but also to educate such travellers as to their responsibility not to exploit women, men and children for sex in underdeveloped countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second of the meetings that I attended was a conference in Canada of Commonwealth Ministers for Womens' Affairs. This is the third of such meetings, the first having been held in 1985 and the second in 1987. At that conference I was deputising for the Australian Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women (Mrs Fatin), as I had done for the relevant Minister on the two previous occasions. I found this a very satisfying experience. The Canadian Government clearly concentrated a considerable amount of effort, resources and time on organising this conference. As a result, 47 Commonwealth countries were represented at this meeting. The calibre of the debate over the three days is clearly reflected in the official communique which will be a public document once it is transmitted to the Australian Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The theme of the conference was economic equity and women. Other agenda items were population issues, structural adjustment, women and the environment and, for the third time, having been on the agenda for each of the two previous meetings, domestic violence. The quality of the debate was very high. Although half the delegations were lead by men, invariably the male Minister would defer to his women experts on his delegation whenever he felt that his own knowledge was insufficient to meet the requirements of the occasion.

I emphasise, Mr Acting Deputy President, that between 1985 and 1990 the consciousness, the sensitivity and the determination of Commonwealth governments to come to grips with the issues of women and inequality have greatly been expanded. The Canadian Government is to be congratulated for its role in ensuring the success of this conference and the Commonwealth countries which brought their delegations and which were well briefed should also be congratulated.
The Commonwealth Secretariat provided excellent papers for the meeting, and I would like to offer to make available to anybody who is interested the background papers that were provided for us.

I also recently led a delegation to the Union of Socialist Soviet Republics when six Australian women parliamentarians who attended a 10-day series of meetings at the invitation of the Soviet Women's Committee. Reports have already been given by the three other senators who were on the delegation. I will try not to repeat matters upon which they have already very competently commented.

There were a great number of meetings, inspections and visits. We worked hard; we worked constructively; and I was very proud of the delegation. We all took our own experiences, philosophies, convictions and backgrounds with us. But for the whole of the 10 days and during the whole range of experiences that were new to many of us, the conduct of the exercise reflected nothing but credit on the Australian women and certainly a great deal of credit on the Soviet women who had organised this event for us.

In the very short time that is available to me, I would particularly like to comment on four of these meetings. One was with a member of parliament and human rights activist by the name of Valery Borschov. Recently elected, Mr Borschov has been very closely involved with the development of the Helsinki charter on human rights. He also has the distinction of being requested to present himself to a psychiatric institution for examination after he resigned his membership of the Communist Party in 1970. He declined the invitation and apparently nothing very evil befell him as a result. He is now a member of the Soviet Presidium. He described what he called an interesting and a dramatic time in Soviet history, including his membership of the Moscow Helsinki group on human rights since 1975 and having worked with Andrei Sakharov. He is also on a committee which has defended the rights of believers.

He told us that he believed there were still about 120 people in the Soviet Union held as political prisoners. In response to direct questioning he said that he believed that they had had been given a fair trial. When, after an hour's conversation-and a very, interesting one-we broached the questions of racial intolerance, he gave us his opinion that this was mostly as a result of a very poor economic situation, and that the tensions were temporary ones and not directed to any particular group.

When asked about equal rights for women, which are guaranteed by a constitution in the USSR, he acknowledged that practically all of the burden of everyday life is on the shoulders of women, regardless of the constitutional, legislative and labour provisions that exist to lighten that burden. When asked what his message would be to Australians about human rights in the USSR he said, `Tell them we are working on it', that he was optimistic; that it was hard to learn democracy; that there would still be a lot of headaches, but that he believed the position in relation to human rights had greatly improved.

The second meeting I wish to refer to was with three members of the Presidium in the Kremlin. Once again it was a very interesting experience. One of these was a man of Korean extract who led the discussion. Of the two women, one described herself as a `Party boss' within the CPSU. The other, newly elected, was previously the medical director of an obstetric and gynaecological hospital in Riga. She told us that she had been preselected and elected ahead of a very large field of men and women. Our discussion with those people ranged mostly over questions of the health of women and general community issues relating to women but also relating to the environment. I feel quite sure that Senator Vallentine has covered that last issue very well.

We pressed the point about the availability of contraception within the USSR, because we had discovered by then that the easy availability of abortion seemed to have lead to a state of affairs where there had been very little emphasis on the availability and quality of contraception. It seemed to us that repeated abortions were probably very bad in a health sense for the women involved. We were told that the average number of abortions that women are having during their reproductive lives would be from eight to 10. This also seemed to be a great waste of resources and something that we felt could be dealt with very easily simply by making contraceptives available to men and women.

Apparently the quality of condoms in the USSR is very poor, the pill is not widely used nor advocated, and vasectomy is practically unknown. When we mentioned the advantages to the gentleman with whom we were speaking of vasectomy he seemed quite shocked. He told us that people in the USSR are conservative generally and men particularly so. We heard about new pension laws, new payments for families with children, and other income supporting measures. This man particularly seemed very keen to get off the question of contraception, but we took it up later, as I will tell the Senate in a few minutes, in another context.

On that day we also met with the Women's Political Club, which has recently been set up in Moscow and is chaired by Tatiana Ivanovic, who describes herself as a politologist. She is, I think, the equivalent of somebody like political analyst and historian Dr Marian Sawer in Australia. We heard from these women, again, what we had been hearing in the 10 days that we had been in the USSR-that although previously women had been guaranteed a quota of seats in all governments, since there had been free elections women were not being elected in significant numbers; they were not being supported by women; they simply did not have a basis in the community such as we in Western nations have had to establish in our communities.

They are taking action to overcome this: to develop non-governmental women's organisations, to make better use of the women who are organised into trade unions, but also to start analysing ways in which conditions for women, in the USSR can be eased. There is no doubt about the fact that currently Soviet women are greatly under stress as a result of running households, of maintaining jobs and of having considerable difficulty in keeping their cupboards stocked.

This does not mean that Soviet families are starving. It is not understood, I think, in the West that Soviet children receive a hot breakfast and a hot meal at lunchtime each day; that the majority of workers receive a meal at work; that much of their shopping is actually done through the enterprise. In fact, the enterprise on the whole provides an enormous range of supportive systems designed to make life a little easier.

My last visit that day was to see he editor of a wonderful women's magazine established in 1914 by Ilyanova Lenin, Lenin's oldest sister. It is the largest women's magazine in the USSR, with 24 million subscriptions and a readership of 100 million. It receives 150,000 letters a year and each of these is replied to. Its editor is Zoya Krylova, who is also a member of parliament and who is waging what may be a very effective campaign on the very issues that were of concern to us- the representation of women, developing women's political acumen and representation, and the issue of contraception and women's health and the standard of health services for women generally.

The suggestion that one of our group made that Mr Yeltsin might be persuaded to have a vasectomy as a part of an educational campaign was one that appealed mightily to her. I do not know whether she will follow it through or not but I can see the story making headlines in a future issue of the USSR magazine Women at Work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity afforded by this public interest debate to draw to the attention of the Senate what I consider to be a serious problem confronting people who wish to pursue appeals through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT).

SPEECH.PARA: In 1988 I was asked by a constituent to assist him in pursuing a compensation claim through the AAT. When looking at the length of time for which it had dragged on, the delays that had occurred due to the file being misplaced, certain injustices and a reversal of Comcare's previous position, and on checking on what costs would be involved to my constituent, it appeared that he had a legitimate claim for appeal and so I agreed to act as his representative.

At this time, when my office telephoned the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in Hobart and queried what costs would be involved to my constituent, we were advised that there would be no costs apart from those personally incurred by the applicant-for example, the cost of the doctor's report or the solicitors-and this was confirmed to the defendant on two other separate occasions.

Because of the complex nature of the claim and the financial situation of my constituent, being an invalid pensioner, the above information was a major consideration in pursuing this matter and I have his full authority to raise this matter in the Senate. The determination which was forwarded by my constituent advising that the claim was rejected and that he had a right of appeal to the AAT made no mention of costs other than those of a personal nature as explained previously. I quote from the determination:
You will be liable to pay your legal costs, if any, if you ask for a review and the AAT's decision is not in your favour. If you succeed, costs or part costs may be payable.

As I have stated, this information is quoted in both the determination and on the document headed `Notice of Rights and Obligations-Commonwealth Employees Compensation Form' which was forward to my constituent. In addition, my constituent personally telephoned the Tribunal to ascertain for himself the information on the question of costs, as he was most concerned about this aspect of the appeal. He was given the same response as my office-that no costs would be incurred, only his personal costs for doctors and other ancillary costs.

This verbal assurance was given and taken in good faith and therefore the issue of costs was not raised in the usual preliminary conference calls as it was not considered, therefore, to be a problem. The preliminary conference duly took place.

In July of this year a letter was sent by my constituent seeking written confirmation of the previously given verbal assurances relating to costs, because it was not going to be a simple resolution for the Tribunal. It was obviously going to take some time given the nature of the response in bringing legal representation from the mainland and medical people having to travel many hundreds of miles to give evidence.

No response was forthcoming from the AAT on this matter, and it was not until my office contacted the AAT to see why the letter had not been responded to that the advice was received to the effect that costs would in fact be awarded against the applicant by the AAT. I mention that I took this precaution because I was aware of the situation in previous actions and that there was the possibility of costs. So it was necessary to get an absolute clarification.

Because of the fact that it was a compensation case, the awarding of costs-and my constituent is a invalid pensioner as a result of the damage and the injury-is naturally contained in the Compensation (Australian Government Employees) Act 1971. It appears that no cross-reference is made between this Act and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act. I believe that, to prevent a recurrence, and because of the high risk of my constituent being permanently deprived of the small amount of savings that he had, he just said it was not worth the risk, given the strength of the representation that Comcare was going to provide in bringing high level people in to fight this case from near and far-in other words he was perhaps being victimised because of his financial difficulty at the time and the tremendous resources that the Commonwealth was going to throw at him.

I believe that as a minimum, to prevent a recurrence of such a situation, a reference should be made in the AAT Act or in the correspondence that it has with regard to this matter. I am also dismayed that, despite a verbal assurance in the correspondence that it would be answered, to date no written reply has even been received by my constituent. I think that is in poor taste and shows a lack of courtesy and consideration, especially considering the special nature of my constituent's indisposition.

I find it most disturbing that in all the dealings with the AAT it took so long before my constituent was fully informed of exactly what the financial implications of pursuing his appeal would be and the tremendous inconvenience that was caused to him. I do not complain about the time that my office took in handling this matter, but I think the whole thing was quite disappointing.

In another case I was approached by a person seeking to lodge an AAT appeal in relation to the higher education contribution reimbursement of fees. Again, it was disturbing to find that in all the information that was sent to this person-by another department this time, the Department of Employment, Education and Training in Canberra-no mention was made of the $300-odd fee which would be incurred should such a person decide to appeal. In this case, had the person not approached my office, that person would have appealed only to find a $300 fee payable, which would perhaps have been higher than the amount involved in the appeal.

These are but two instances that cause one to begin to wonder just how many other people have found themselves in such circumstances. I therefore urge the Government to take immediate steps to ensure that, when information is given out by either departments or statutory bodies, particularly in relation to AAT appeals, full and detailed information is provided to the people concerned. I believe that it is only fair and just that before a person proceeds with an appeal he or she is made fully aware of the implications of his or her actions.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Customs Service v. Midford Paramount Pty Ltd

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I rise to speak on today, the matter of public interest, is one I have mentioned before. My concerns remain the same but some of the information I have is new. It concerns a case I have mentioned before, namely, the Australian Customs Service v. Midford Paramount Pty Ltd and others. I mentioned this before and I am mentioning it now because I am concerned about two aspects of the case. The first is that the Director of Public Prosecutions made a decision to finally lay a prosecution in this matter after relying on information and evidence provided to the Prosecutor by the Department of Industry, Tech- nology and Commerce, namely, by Dr Fitzpatrick from the Light Industry Division. Not only was the provision of that information subsequently found by the magistrate who heard the case to be unreliable but also the witness was totally discredited and there was an air of cover-up permeating the whole Department.

SPEECH.PARA: The case basically is this. At the end of 1987 Customs thought that there was a case to investigate regarding the import- ation of shirts from Malaysia by a Wollongong based firm, Midford Paramount Pty Ltd, in that it had a quota under which it had been operating and had sold its business but was still sourcing its imports from Malaysia. The case was based upon the premise that there were conditions attached to the quota which in fact meant that the importer had to be actually owning and manufacturing the shirts in Malaysia in order to attract the concessional duty arrangement.

As events subsequently turned out, that was absolutely erroneous. In fact, the source and the authority for the quota it had was an agreement reached between the Australian Government and the Malaysian Government in 1977. That agreement effectively gave an advantage to Association of South East Asian Nation (ASEAN) countries. The requirement was that the manufactured product be sourced from in this case Malaysia-Malaysia being an ASEAN country.

Had the existence of that agreement been made known to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP), at the time of the laying of the information, the case would simply not have proceeded because Midford did not breach the conditions that were attached to its quota. But it was the evidence given by Dr Fitzpatrick and the wording of the statement, which he gave evidence that he himself had drafted, that in fact led the DPP to believe that the conditions were that one had to own and manufacture in the country of source. Indeed, at page 7 of Dr Fitzpatrick's statement, which he swore, he said that if any part of this statement was untrue to his knowledge he may be liable for punishment. He said:
It is DITAC's invariable practice to advise the Australian Customs Service to withdraw quota once it has been advised of circumstances which altered an importers eligibility for quota.

Upon cross-examination, Dr Fitzpatrick admitted that in fact there was no such precedent. There had been no such example of DITAC finding that a breach had occurred, advising Customs and Customs withdrawing the quota. What had happened previously was that some people who had a quota of this type had voluntarily returned it; handed it in, requiring no verification at all from DITAC. Indeed, in cross-examination Dr Fitzpatrick agreed that the second and third sentence in this statement which I have just quoted from were careless at very best and that the evidence that he had given was therefore not good evidence, but the DPP relied on much of that evidence.
As one Miss Hannam, who is a senior legal officer of the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, says in her statement dated 6 October 1989:

During the ensuing months, until April 1988 I met with representatives of Customs, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and other officers of the DPP to discuss the evidence available for possible criminal offences committed by the defendants and others. I examined a large number of documents in this regard.

Dr Fitzpatrick would have had access to Cabinet documents which would have evidenced the agreement of 1977 and, indeed, which were subsequently subpoenaed by the defendants and, over the objections of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the magistrate did say that the documents proving the existence of the agreement were to be circulated to the counsel concerned. It was following that that the case was withdrawn by the DPP.

Dr Fitzpatrick would have had the power to go back to that source document. The truth of the matter is that he did not bother. He simply said there was an anomalies register; that this quota had come from that anomalies register and then the subsequent variation of that in 1982. But he did not go back to the document which, indeed, sourced the authenticity of the quota. He did not do any of the research himself. He relied on information given to him by others, but in Estimates A last Friday he admitted to me that he did not ask people to search all the files. So, at very best, the evidence that was given was careless.

The second point that is equally of concern relates to the behaviour of Customs and, in particular, the behaviour of one Mr Robinson and one Mr O'Shannassy who were operating and reporting to one Mr Strang who heads up the investigative division in New South Wales. Mr Robinson and Mr O'Shannassy were two Customs officers who went to Malaysia in September 1988, after the information had been laid, to get evidence in pursuit of their case. They obtained documents from Midford and various agents and companies associated with it. They obtained some of that evidence on 15 September 1988. In evidence and in her statement Miss Hannam says that indeed the two officers left Malaysia on 15 September 1988. No doubt she was of that view because she was told by Customs.

However, I have three affidavits that I want to table that have been sworn by one U. Mat; by another gentleman, Ong Kok Cheng; and by Keith Neon Woo who, together, have sworn affidavits that, first of all, those officers were still in Malaysia on 16 September 1988, which is the day on which the Malaysian court granted orders preventing those officers from obtaining any documents concerning Midford Paramount Pty Ltd. Nonetheless, those officers were spirited out, and I say it wisely because there is no evidence on the passports of the officers concerned of how they left Malaysia-into Singapore and they left, according to Customs and the evidence given by Mr Kelly last Friday, before the order was made and that was the reason the order could not be served. On the other hand, the evidence of the gentlemen I have just mentioned is that those officers were still in Malaysia on the 16th and, indeed, attempting to get further documentary evidence. I read from the evidence of one of those affidavits:
In the course of the search, the Chinese officer-
who was accompanying the two Australian officers-
enquired whether my wife . . .-
this is sworn by Mr U. Mat-

had applied to emigrate to Australia. When I answered in the affirmative, he informed me that it would be in our interest to extend our co-operation to them if she was to secure what she had applied for, since his companions other than the 4th respondents were Australian Government officers.
There was another statement, sworn by Ong Kok Cheng, in which it was said:

They asked me whether Shirley Sin Lee Kian could be persuaded to `cooperate' and work with them by which I understood to give evidence against Midford Paramount. They told me that Shirley Sin Lee Kian had applied and was keen to get a permanent residence status in Australia and it could be arranged for her if she would work for them.

There are similar examples of what I can only describe as coercion that was used to gain control of these documents. Mr Kelly said very positively and very affirmatively in his evidence to Estimates Committee A last Friday that, indeed, these documents had been handed over voluntarily. On that basis, when they came back to Australia, despite the fact that the Malaysian Government had an order asking for the return of those documents, the Customs officer and Mr Strang in particular told the officers that they were going to remain here in Australia and that the documents would be kept.

This subsequently has caused a great deal of concern between the Australian and the Malaysian governments. The Malaysian Government wished to start extradition proceedings against Mr Robinson and Mr O'Shannassy. However, Mr Kelly, in his evidence last Friday, said that he was not aware of the details surrounding the nature of these activities. This is despite the fact that I have subsequently found out that Mr Kelly went himself to Malaysia to try to hose down the whole episode and to try to deal with the question of extradition.

It is a sad and sorry case and it is not isolated. The Law Council of Australia, in a submission it made this year to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, said that there is a lack of accountability in the Customs Service. It said:

This lack of accountability is also reflected in the cavalier approach adopted by investigations officers when conducting their enquiries. The `Elliott Ness' style of raid is still prevalent and there are numerous examples of investigation officers acting in a threatening manner towards importers and their staff. Issues of serious concern include the reliance upon defective Notices to Produce Documents and Warrants by Customs officers who demand immediate access to all documents and records in particular premises and then threaten repercussions if asked to relinquish . . .
The Council gave an excellent example where it said:

On another recent occasion an investigation officer visited a prominent and respected importer of electronic equipment and under false pretences proceeded to interview junior staff members claiming that he was carrying out a survey for Customs. He then explained that it would be necessary to take certain files and records of the importer's with him for further perusal and that the importer had no legal rights to object or retain possession of the documents.

I raise this matter because the Minister concerned has shown a cavalier disrespect and disregard for this matter. He said that he first became aware of it only when he read an article by Bruce Jones in the Sun-Herald published on 7 October 1990. Two very senior officers who report to him have shown themselves to be less than satisfactory and yet the Minister will not take responsibility in this issue. I seek leave to table the affidavits of Keith Chong Neon Woo, of U. Mat and of Ong Kok Cheng.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted for the tabling of the three affidavits?
—Not until I have seen them, no.
—Leave is not granted for the moment but honourable senators can view the affidavits and the question can be put at the end of your speech.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I have raised this matter because I think it is one of grave seriousness. It has brought about bad relations between Malaysia and Australia. On one particular report I heard, it was even raised by the Malaysian Prime Minister with our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the last Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. It is a serious matter and it is simply not good enough for the Minister who is responsible to show a cavalier attitude and try to laugh it off as being a matter of no consequence. It is a matter of very serious consequence. I still ask that the documents be tabled.
—Is leave granted for the tabling of the three affidavits?
—Not yet, no. I am happy to look at them and indicate later.
—Leave is not granted at this time.
—I think my time has expired, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I ask that it be dealt with nonetheless.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in terms of a matter of public interest. I want to put some facts on the table with regard to the current situation in the wool industry. In doing so, I wish I could be making this speech to the Senate in much more satisfactory circumstances. But I also have to say that the recent drop in the dollar is most welcome in terms of the position of not only the wool industry but, of course, all our exporters and a number of our other industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I start talking about the wool industry, I would like to comment briefly on the dollar and interest rates. It has concerned me in this Senate over the last week that claims have been made here that the drop in interest rates that we have seen over the last three or four months has not had any effect on the dollar. I suggest to the people who have made those claims that, if they had addressed them to a reasonable, rational economist, they would have had to come to the conclusion that, had those interest rate drops not occurred, with the events that occurred in Iraq and the oil crisis, our dollar would not have hovered around the 82c, 83c and 84c mark for a time, but in fact would have gone much higher, probably in excess of 90c, and the unemployment figures that we have seen in recent times would have been much worse.

Nonetheless, the recent drop in interest rates certainly is welcome and I believe that it points in the direction that is required in this country to get some of our exporters, some of our businesses and industry in general, back on track.

I want now to lay a few facts on the table about the wool industry. I have before me a table which shows the export figures for the wool industry as follows: In 1979-80, $1.287 billion; in 1980-81, $1.463 billion; in 1981-82, $1.47 billion; in 1982-83, $1.469 billion; in 1983-84, $1.573; in 1984-85, $1.957 billion; in 1985-86, $2.285 billion; in 1986-87, $2.838 billion; in 1987-88, $4.274 billion; and in 1988-89, $4.604 billion. In bringing those figures to the attention of the Senate my objective is to emphasis the importance of the wool industry to the Australian economy. Not only has it been our greatest export earner since Federation but also it has been in the top three export earners in the last 10 years, in most of those years our top export earner.

I shall now read some figures in terms of the current position that we face in terms of the wool industry. The wool stockpile is close to four million bales and is expected to be over five million at the end of the 1990-91 wool selling season in June next year. The stockpile is expected to remain at that level or more in 1991-92 and 1992-93. The Australian Wool Corporation has never sold more than five million bales in a year, and in the 1980s average annual sales were between 3.7 and four million. Production for 1990-91 is estimated at close to six million bales. The trade is expected to buy about four million bales, leaving the Corporation to buy up to two million. The cost to the Corporation of buying these two million bales is estimated at $1.6 billion. Storage and handling will be an additional cost. The current Wool Corporation debt is $2 billion and is expected to peak at more than $2.5 billion this season.

The wool tax or levy to support this type of buying would have to be well above the current 25 per cent level to maintain a reasonable grower equity in the stockpile next year, and even higher in subsequent years. However, this does not address the continuing oversupply situation and exacerbates the already critical viability problems of growers and the Wool Corporation. Even the most optimistic demand projections for next year do not begin to bring supply and demand into balance. As every one per cent of the wool tax yields $40m, the recently announced increase from 18 to 25 per cent will not be adequate to maintain grower equity unless the wool stockpile is stabilised. The proposed legislation of a 30 per cent ceiling plus a possible 20 per cent surcharge could be necessary, but it would be self-defeating as growers are bankrupted by the dramatically reduced net returns for the wool for several years.

In addition to the already announced low value slaughter scheme to humanely slaughter old sheep at an estimated cost of up to $2 a head, a commercial scheme to slaughter the younger sheep must be considered. I would just like to say that unfortunately, in my view, the industry has no choice but to put in place a commercial slaughter scheme. In other words, I am saying that in terms of the situation now with the oversupply of wool the industry is at D-day and it is absolutely essential that the numbers be got down to around 130 million so that we have some chance of equating production with demand.

Unfortunately, and as unpalatable and difficult as it is, I cannot see any other way. If this action is not taken the stockpile will become an albatross around the neck of the industry and more and more producers will be bankrupted as the tax goes up. This is not a debate about the floor price or the Corporation's existence or non-existence. Regardless of the floor price or the role of the Corporation, supply has to be reduced to demand.

Since 1974, as I have already stated, sales have ranged between 3.4 and 4.5 million bales with an average of just under four million bales. This means that the Corporation will have to buy close to two million bales this year if the market does not improve. Figures prepared by the Farm Consultancy Group in Western Australia show that between now and November 1991, if the trade buys 4 million bales and the Corporation two million bales the tax to service this will be in the order of 38 per cent. If the trade buys three million bales and the Corporation three million, the tax will be in the order of 45 per cent. If the trade buys two million bales and the Corporation four million, the tax will have to be in excess of 50 per cent-if the Corporation is to maintain an equity of 50 per cent in the stockpile.

This situation cannot continue because all that will be left of the wool industry is a huge stockpile and almost every grower in Australia will be bankrupt. To summarise what I am saying, the wool industry has reached D-day. The industry has no choice but to put in place a commercial scheme to reduce flock numbers by 50 million, to around 130 million. To do otherwise would be to condemn most woolgrowers to bankruptcy. Unfortunately, this is the most cost effective short term method of getting production back in line with demand.

For the Wool Corporation to purchase an additional two million bales over the next 12 to 18 months would cost not less than $1.6 billion plus interest, handling and holding costs. This is on top of the Wool Corporation's debt of $2 billion. The costs of further purchases for the stockpile and maintaining it will mean growers will face a tax of between 35 and 45 per cent at the end of this financial year.

A commercial slaughter scheme would cost in the order of $400m and would in fact save growers an enormous amount of money. As unpalatable as it is and as much as I hate the prospect, the industry has no option. Primary Industries Minister John Kerin and his advisers should immediately communicate with all growers as they did in May of this year. I am astonished at how incorrect the information that was given then was. Those who are responsible should be made accountable.

The day has come when the Minister's office, the Wool Corporation and the Wool Council must spell out precisely the state of the industry. In February we heard the tax had to be 15 per cent, then it jumped a couple of months later to 25 per cent then a little bit later the Minister made a decision to set it at 20 per cent. Now we have prospective legislation before us for a tax of 50 per cent. That is a totally unsatisfactory and untenable position for any industry to be in. They must get on with the job, no matter how unpalatable and undesirable it might be, of putting Australia's wool industry back on an even keel. Not to do this will be to tax producers out of existence.

This is not an issue about party politics or about political point scoring; it is too serious for that. It is about putting what has been Australia's most important export industry since Federation back on its feet, and getting it back to being an international trading force. The medicine is not nice; it is downright untenable and extremely difficult to administer. I remind the Senate that we are talking about people in terms of the wool industry; rural people and the people in the support industries who live in the cities. Some vote Labor, some Liberal, some National, some Democrat, some independent and some informal. The political point scoring that has gone on this week when debating the rural crisis has amazed me.

To give an example of how serious the situation is for some people, I want to refer to the local cafe in a little place on the south coast of Western Australia called Hopetoun. Hopetoun is a town of some 300 people, mainly pensioners, and it relies very much on the holiday period. That cafe, in the first week of the holidays, took a total of an additional $50 across the counter. The chap who owns the place and runs it is John Crocker, and he had people coming in there who actually asked him for three half-pieces of fish and a dollar's worth of chips to feed their family. So I must point out that the situation is serious.

We must also recognise causes of the problems and the things that we can do. There is little point in talking about or blaming what is occurring overseas. We all know the problems with the American farm support and the European farm support, and we know the efforts that the Cairns Group is making. But there are some things that can be done in terms of the Australian situation. There must be further examination of the part that monetary policy has played in this country in terms of putting the wool industry and other businesses where they are today. There must be more cognisance taken of the effect that even the still relatively high interest rates have on us when compared with our competitors, and we must look very carefully at fiscal responsibility.

I particularly want to deal in the time that I have here with the position in the States. I think the States have to take an enormous amount of the blame for some of the problems that we have in industry today. If I just run quickly through the tax increases in the 1990-91 year, we find these figures: New South Wales 10 per cent; Victoria 16.3 per cent; Queensland 7.5 per cent; Western Australia 8.1 per cent; South Australia a massive 18.2 per cent; and Tasmania 12.6 per cent. I do not consider that fiscal policy management to be responsible. I find it very irresponsible, and a great contributor to one of our main problems-that is, inflation.

We must ask ourselves these questions in terms of the economic management of this country: why has New Zealand an inflation rate of 5 per cent, compared with Australia's which is much higher; why has transport reform not been moved on quicker; why has waterfront reform not been moved on quicker and more effectively; and why there has not been effective labour market reform?

I have endeavoured to outline in the time that I have had the situation which exists currently in the wool industry. I have identified a number of key areas which will help alleviate the problems that exist there. But it is not only about the wool industry, it is about all our exporters, the coal industry and others, and it is about small business. As I said earlier, the wool industry itself has to make a very hard decision, and this is an industry that I have been involved in all my life. I do not believe it has any choice in terms of our current situation but to get supply and demand under control and I can see no way to do that effectively other than by putting a commercial slaughter program in place and getting our numbers back to the 130 million that I talked about.

In addition to that I have mentioned fiscal management, and I believe it is necessary in terms of our current situation for particularly the States and also the Commonwealth to look very closely at the expenditure patterns and, in fact, put in place mini-Budgets which will allow them to lower the heavy tax regimes that they have placed on the Australian community this year. It is essential that these types of actions be taken because we need to restore confidence to business, we need to restore our international competitiveness across all industries, we need to get our inflation down, and hold down our current account. Otherwise, I fear for all our exporters, not just the wool industry, and I also fear for our unemployment figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator MacDonald, is leave granted for Senator Bishop to table the documents that she referred to?

—In the 35 seconds I have left in this debate I just want briefly to congratulate Senator Button on raising the profile again of the space base which is planned to launch satellites from a base in Cape York in north Queensland. The proposal that has been put around and put to government is a very good one. It will be of major benefit to the Cairns area and it is a project that I hope goes ahead at the very earliest opportunity. I congratulate Senator Button for raising the matter again and bringing the publicity to it in trying to encourage it to get going at the earliest possible time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Who made the decision that Navy personnel, at least in Sydney, should not wear their uniforms in public? Is the Minister aware of the widespread community concern which has already occurred as a result of this order? Was the decision based on information which had suggested that naval personnel may have been harassed in public? How long will the order be expected to apply?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —These matters were set in train some weeks ago based on classified material. The first steps were taken on 1 and 2 October, when a suggestion was made to Navy personnel in Sydney that it was discretionary whether they wore their uniforms to work, and also that they should vary their daily routine. This situation has been reviewed from week to week and a decision was made to direct Navy personnel in the Sydney area not to wear uniforms to work.

ANSWER.PARA: It is essential that at this stage I reject those accusations that have been made in Sydney, not the least by the senior Sydney politician, that this is in any way due to questions of harassment or otherwise. This has had a very wide currency on various talkback radio programs this morning. It is typical of their standard of journalism that it has been given such a run. It has also been kicked along by Mr Greiner, at least in his first interview, although I notice that in his second interview, having spoken to me, he qualified some of the statements he had been making.

This is not a decision that relates to domestic politics or residents in Australia, but to other information that I and the Navy have available that would be of concern. I am aware, in answer to the second part of Senator Durack's question, that there is widespread community concern. Again I stress that that is based on the erroneous publicity that emanated from a newspaper this morning and certain talkback radio programs.

On the question of harassment, some naval personnel have been harassed in Sydney; that comes with the territory. I think that it is despicable that they have been harassed, but they are readily identifiable and any clown who wants to abuse them in the street knows that they will not respond. The people who have been involved in harassing have my utmost contempt, but it would certainly not be justification for telling people not to wear their uniform.

On the fourth part of the question put to me by Senator Durack, the matter is being reviewed weekly and will continue to be reviewed weekly. On that basis I will leave it there. But let me put one other thing to rest. There has been an accusation from the Premier of New South Wales that this is a slur on the Muslim community in Australia. I am standing here to say that it is not; it is nothing to do with the Muslim community in Australia. I point out to the Senate that I am one of the few politicians who have gone on public record in the past few weeks defending the Muslim community in this country. The fact is that members of that community have been vilified by the yellow press of Sydney sending some snot-nosed reporter down to stick microphones under their noses asking them the most ridiculous and provocative questions known.

The only other question that has been raised on this matter, and it has been raised a few times, is `Where is the leadership of the Australian Muslim community? Why don't they speak out on the matter?'. I would like to say that most of them would love to, but most of them cannot do so. Most of them have hundreds of relatives in very vulnerable positions around the rest of the Middle East.

If they were to adopt a high public profile on that, they would pay a massive price for speaking out. I do not expect them to do so. No-one in this chamber should. In summary, these decisions were made on the most valid of security grounds. I assure Senator Durack of that. I would be pleased to have him personally briefed on the matter. I am sure that, as a former Attorney-General, he is aware that I cannot publicly release those reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of recent claims that the United States facility at Johnston Atoll may not be needed for the destruction of chemical weapons? Did the Minister discuss this matter in his recent talks with Secretaries Baker and Cheney in Washington? Can the Minister inform the Senate how such developments fit in with Australia's policies on chemical weapons and disarmament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the suggestion made by Professor Neil Foster of the University of New South Wales that an alternative method of destruction of chemical weapons is being developed, namely, the direct application of super critical water technology, as it is called, to chemical weapons stocks. I am also aware of the comments made by Professor Foster that there is a common belief in the US Army Research Office that the high temperature incineration unit on Johnston Atoll will never be fired up.

ANSWER.PARA: I can only say in this respect that the only currently operating technology for destruction of chemical weapons is high temperature incineration and the only facility currently available to destroy stocks of the US nerve agents is on Johnston Atoll. With my colleague Senator Robert Ray I had a very thorough discussion on chemical weapons issues with Secretaries Baker and Cheney last week in Washington, in which there was no suggestion at all in any of their comments that the Johnston Atoll facility operation would not go ahead as planned.

Both Australia and the United States are deeply committed to the destruction and total eradication of chemical weapons. We are agreed that the sooner the process of destruction of existing stockpiles is started, and the sooner their total destruction can be completed in the context of the comprehensive international convention now in the final stages of negotiation, the better off the world will be.

At last week's AUSMIN talks in Washington, Senator Robert Ray and I made clear the basis for Australia's support of the Johnston Atoll facility, which is, in short, that it not be used except for the destruction of stocks already there and those being brought there from Germany and perhaps elsewhere in the Pacific, that it be closed down after those operations are finished, and that its operations be conducted in an environmentally sound way. The final communique from that meeting explicitly stated:

The United States reiterated its intention to operate the facility in an environmentally safe manner, and reaffirmed its intention to destroy on the island only those chemical weapons already stored there, the US CW stocks being shipped from the Federal Republic of Germany, and obsolete World War II munitions which may be found in the Pacific area.

I should just finally, however, make clear for the record that if new, more efficient technologies became available and were safe, we would be glad to see them used. Our objective remains the early destruction of chemical weapons in an environmentally sound manner. We have no commitment to any particular technology. I make clear, however, that the Australian Government's own scientific advisers considered alternative forms of destruction before concluding, and reporting to us, that high temperature incineration was the best method currently available.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. I welcome the fact that the Minister shares the concern of the Opposition at the harassment of naval personnel and their families by some members of the community, which has led to the official direction that naval personnel not wear uniform in public. Does the Minister acknowledge that all Defence personnel are required to carry out the policy of the government of the day and that similar harassment of servicemen and their families in the Vietnam conflict led to long term psychological problems and bitterness? Does the Minister agree that Australians expect their servicemen to be free to wear their uniforms with pride on our streets and that the protests against our personnel are cruelly misguided?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we look at military tradition and pride, I cannot point to a country with greater military pride and tradition than Great Britain. Senator Newman would know that it is now a standing order in most areas of Great Britain for personnel not to wear uniform to and from work. That is not a condemnation of their military. It is a condemnation of certain aspects of society today. It is a great pity.

ANSWER.PARA: I would agree that all those servicemen that serve Australia do so with pride and take a great pride in their uniform. On the other hand, I have a responsibility to protect their personal safety. I would not do anything, no matter what the gutter press in Sydney says, to abrogate that responsibility.

On the question of the situation 20 to 25 years ago, I always detect two very distinct categorisations of those that opposed the war. In some cases, people did take out their feelings on people in uniform. I assure Senator Newman that I was not one of them, although I opposed the Vietnam war. A lot of us could make the distinction between the political decision involved and the military participation. Some could not. Some lacked that sophistication. That was a pity. I hope, as does Senator Newman, I think, that the cleansing operation that went on a year or two ago in the form of a welcome home parade made some people rest more easily in those circumstances than they previously did.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Has the Minister considered representations about the possible adverse effect on the viability and standing of the Australian Furniture Research and Development Institute based in Tasmania of the proposed action of the Scientific Services Laboratories in the Department of Administrative Services to also enter into the furniture testing and evaluation field? What action does the Minister propose to take in this matter, given its importance not only to Tasmania but also to the successful establishment of a national body capable of providing a reliable high quality service to the Australian furniture production industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Devereux does raise a matter which has been brought to my attention by a number of senators on both sides of parliament-not only by Senator Devereux but also by Senator Tate and, in the House of Representatives, Mr Duncan Kerr. I have to acknowledge those representations and, as a consequence of those strident representations from, in particular, Mr Kerr and Senator Tate, I have had a close look at this particular issue.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be acknowledged that the Australian Furniture Research and Development Institute was established in 1989 to undertake research, consulting and testing programs for furniture products. The Government's ceding money has, in fact, provided for the Institute to get off the ground. Last year, the Tasmanian Labor Government provided $30,000, followed by another $513,575 from the Commonwealth Government. This was the first allocation of Commonwealth funds under the Helsham agreement. I also understand that the second allocation of $536,400 under the agreement was provided on 12 October, last week.

I must also say, in this context, that it is not intended that the Institute be totally reliant on government funding. For its long term future, it recognises, I believe, that it must rely on industry support. I understand that in that context the Australian Manufacturing Council believes that the Institute is, in fact, a role model for that support. However, because of that ceding money from State and Federal governments, the Institute is able to provide a wide range of technical services to the national furniture and timber manufacturing industry.

Senator Devereux raises the question of the Scientific Services Laboratories in the Department of Administrative Services. Last year those laboratories decided to enter into furniture testing and evaluation. In response, as I said earlier, I have received quite a number of representations, the basic thrust of those representations being that this initiative would adversely affect the Institute's becoming a viable ongoing concern. I met with representatives of the Institute yesterday, having pursued the issue, and decided that, when my Department does receive requests from Commonwealth departments and agencies for furniture testing or evaluation, this activity will be referred to the Institute.

I have reached this decision for three particular reasons. I think there is compelling evidence of the need for a single national body to research, test and appraise furniture products to national and also international standards. Secondly, I believe that there is a need for the Commonwealth to demonstrate support for this combined government-industry initiative to establish what will be and is, in fact, a centre of excellence in furniture technology. Thirdly, there is a strong relationship between testing furniture products and establishing a system of accreditation as well as developing industry standards, and the Institute is best suited to cover those three strains.

To enhance the primary role of the Institute as the national centre for furniture research and the setting of industry standards, the Institute has offered a seat on its board to a representative from my Department and I have accepted this particular offer. The arrangement that I have outlined will operate for the next three years, at which time it will be reviewed. Until then, as I said, all requests for furniture testing through the Department of Administrative Services will go to the Institute and the Scientific Services Laboratories will not duplicate the activities of the Institute.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is dir- ected to the Minister for Social Security and concerns responsibility for the projected funding of welfare rights centres across Australia. My question is in two parts: firstly, in view of the fact that the Minister invited the welfare rights centres earlier this year to put a submission for funding to his Department and, following the Budget announcement, promised that although they had missed out this year they would be included in the next Budget, can the Minister confirm that it is indeed his Department and not some other department that will make this allocation available? Secondly, is the Minister aware that complex changes in the social security budget this year have resulted in greatly increased numbers approaching the welfare rights centres for assistance, which proves that such centres are useful and necessary to the community? In view of this, would the Minister be prepared to bring forward his promised funding to help these centres which, because of lack of funding, are in danger of closing down long before the next Budget session?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did suggest to the welfare rights centres that they should produce a submission for funding. I told them that in the climate of this year's Budget with projections for substantial cuts to government spending I did not think Cabinet would agree that they would be able to receive funding. I did tell them that I would attempt to get them some funding next year, and I repeat that assurance-I shall.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as complex changes increasing the numbers of people using welfare rights centres is concerned, while I do not have any concrete evidence that that is true, I would imagine that it is so. It is not hard to believe that there were some substantial changes introduced during the Budget and, naturally enough, that will lead to an increase in the number of people using welfare rights centres.

It should be noted, of course, that not everybody goes to a welfare rights centre because of Commonwealth problems. Many people going to welfare rights centres have State issues in mind, be it housing or a whole range of issues that they want to take up with them. I think the main complaint of welfare rights centres, at least as it was put to me, was that some States, in particular New South Wales, have been withdrawing from their funding and they wanted the Commonwealth to take up the place that had previously been occupied by the States. I think there is some merit in their case. Obviously in the course of the next Budget deliberations we will have to determine just where that merit comes in our priorities list. I, for one, will be a voice raised hoping that we can get some extra funds to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Can the Minister just confirm that it is his Department that they should be dealing with?

—Any proposal to get them extra funds can come through Senator Tate's Department because some legal centres receive funding through his Department. It could come through Mr Howe's Department. With the obvious housing and aged care aspects of the Department of Community Services and Health, one would imagine it could come through there, or it could come through my Department. I will be putting up a submission to Cabinet. Pride of authorship in that submission would not mean that I would insist on administering the funds; that would be a matter for Cabinet and my colleagues to determine in consultation with me. I am a reason- able vehicle for it to go through, but if the welfare rights centres wish to see Senator Tate, they are more than welcome to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. I ask the Minister: Has he seen in Hansard interjections made by Senator O'Chee and Senator Short during my speech last Thursday on Government rural policy? Were the two senators correct in claiming that a conservative coalition had introduced the first Commonwealth soil conservation program in Australia, or does it appear that conservative senators do not have a mon-opoly of knowledge on rural matters as they claim? What has been the policy record of this Government on this most important rural and conservation matter?

—Mr President, on a point of order: Senator Maguire referred to conservative senators. If honourable senators are referred to in this place, do the Standing Orders not require that they be referred to as Labor senators, Australian Democrat senators, Liberal senators or National Party senators? It is well-known that there are more conservative senators in the Australian Labor Party than anywhere else. To avoid the confusion, ought Senator Maguire not be required to disclose the party that the senators are members of?
—There is no point of order.
—Mr President--
—Senator Alston, are you speaking to the point of order?

—Yes, to another point of order. The second part of the question invited the Minister to indicate what the Government's policy was. Mr President, I direct your attention to standing order 73 which specifically precludes Ministers from answering questions relating to government policy.
—I thought the second part of the question was in reference to the Government's record. If that is correct, Senator Cook is able to answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I did notice that in Hansard the other day some conservative senators were claiming bragging rights for the Fraser Government on its alleged, by them, record on soil conservation. One of the things that I am particularly proud of in my period in the resources portfolio in the last Hawke Government is that we did forge a bipartisan arrangement with the Opposition on soil conservation. We did so because we believed it was important that parliament signal to land-holders that the most serious environmental issue in Australia was that of land degradation. There was a bipartisan political will to try to provide a platform to encourage them to address the issue as well.

ANSWER.PARA: I commend Bruce Lloyd for joining us on that and indeed, in essence, endorsing the statement made by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, last year-the first ever national environment statement made by a Prime Minister-in which he committed this Government and future governments to a decade-long program of soil conservation. So it is against that background that I am somewhat reluctant to descend to the level of trying to turn a major issue such as this back into a political football. On that basis I will, in a restrained way, simply correct the record and not enter into the spirit of being invited to undermine confidence of land-holders that there is indeed some political argument about the importance of the issue.
