The facts of the matter are that the single most significant event carried out in the last decade or more on soil conservation was carried out by Mr Kerin in 1983. When we came to power in 1983, Mr Kerin moved immediately to repeal legislation that was on the books from the Fraser Government that there be a subsidy for the clearing of land. One of the problems for soil conservation has been that land degradation is generated by overcutting and overclearing. There was a subsidy to encourage that by the former Government. Mr Kerin remedied that immediately and legislatively.

In the period of the Whitlam Government, Moss Cass, then a Labor Minister, commenced an inquiry into land degradation. The inquiry proceeded and reported in the period of the Fraser Government. The then Minister responsible, Kevin Newman, is to be commended for promoting the findings of that inquiry and proposing measures on soil conservation. Unfortunately for him, his proposals were slashed by the razor gang in the dying period of the Fraser Government which said that the responsibility was not a national one but a State one.

In August 1983, Mr Kerin introduced a Bill to form a national soil conservation council. That Bill was supported, of course, by the Government and I believe by the Australian Democrats. It was voted against by the Opposition, obviously in a demonstration of its commitment to the issue. In the first year of funding for the national soil conservation program, the Government allocated $5m. In the last two years-1989-90 and 1990-91-our funding base has been $49m, and we have committed $260m to soil conservation programs over the decade from 1990 to the year 2000.

I repeat, Mr President, that when we came to power there was no Federal government involvement in soil conservation and no Federal government funding. One of the things that this Government has been able to do is extract a commitment-if there is ever a future coalition government-that it will change that and will help fund a national soil conservation program along the lines that have been bipartisanly agreed to address this urgent national environmental issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the recent statement by the Minister reported in the Sydney Morning Herald that `there is not one other way now that I can shave money off the social security budget'. Does this mean that he therefore has no problems with the fact that during 1989-90 the Department of Social Security spent $7.8m on Commonwealth car hire-an average of almost $160,000 per Senior Executive Service member and more than 10 times the amount spent on cab charges-almost $1m for each issue of a quarterly self- congratulatory Government propaganda broad sheet, known as Age Pension News; $11.5m on promotional projects and activities, with more than--
—Pensioners in the Territory like getting it.
—Order!

—I am sure they do; they think it comes from your office, I suppose-$11.5m on promotional activities worth more than $2.4m not having been subject to a tender process, and almost $7m on the Department's forms unit which was apparently not capable of drafting a simple letter which the Department recently contracted out to the private sector. Is the Minister therefore seriously telling the people of Australia that he has given up the ghost in trying to reduce the Department's administration budget, which is currently running at almost $700m a year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I like to keep learning, Mr President; it is important in this job.
—It is a steep learning curve.

—I wish you would embark on one, Senator Hill; it would do you a lot of good. In attempting to keep up with this learning I have had the opportunity to observe Senator Alston over time and I know what he is. Yesterday for the first time I found out something he was not. I discovered that in spite of the importance of social security this shadow Minister is not even a member of the shadow cabinet. That is an extraordinary omission, but not so extraordinary now that we find that members of the Opposition want to sell it off; they also want to sell him off with it.

ANSWER.PARA: I think that once again this question shows the fundamental hopeless misunderstanding of social security, this unbelievable ignorance of what social security is supposed to be about. Here we are spending $23 billion and I get asked: Should you spend money on Age Pension News? I am told it is some propaganda vehicle for the Government. The sad thing for Opposition senators to understand is that it is a very, very important method of communicating with the aged in Australia. In fact there probably is not a single more important method that we have. To even think of abolishing it would be just plain stupid. So, if the honourable senator is asking me whether we will we stop it, the answer is no.

We are told that we hire too many cars; that we even promote. We have the hide over here to spend money explaining the 300 changes we have made since 1986, and Senator Alston thinks we should do none of it. Really, Mr President, this is just plain hopeless. Senator Alston will have to do an awful lot better than that. If he wants to make the shadow Cabinet he will have to do very much better. Mind you, I do not understand that either. Given the lack of talent over there I thought anybody could make the shadow Cabinet.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to the transport of chemical weapons from Germany destined for Johnston Atoll in the Pacific which are en route in the Indian Ocean at the moment. Has the Australian Government been notified by the appropriate United States of America Government department regarding the route, and does it, at any point, fall within Australia's 200-mile exclusive economic zone? If so, what safety precautions have been put in place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the vessels carrying the chemical weapons stocks from Germany to Johnston Atoll have already left Germany. Before their departure the United States authorities indicated that they had been considering several possible alternative routes for the transportation of chemical weapons stocks previously on German territory to Johnston Atoll, but no announcement has been made of the route eventually chosen. Obviously, there are issues of security involved in any public disclosure of that route. It is most likely that the route chosen will maximise transit in international waters. I have no reason whatever to believe that the vessels will pass through Australian territorial waters. While there is no obligation on the United States to consult with Australia on the route, we have been given to understand that there is no expectation that the ships will pass close to Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: On the environmental questions involved in relation to this transport, our embassy in Washington has obtained the United States Army's environmental impact statement concerning the possible routes for the movement of these stocks. That statement evaluates the environmental impact of the various alternative routes. In the impact statement the US has described the measures it is taking to ensure that this transfer takes place safely and that the risks of any environmental danger arising from the transport are minimised. Finally, at an earlier point Australian experts were fully briefed by United States officials about the measures being implemented to ensure that no leakage or other environmentally damaging impacts took place during the shipment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to yet another leaked document entitled `Purchase Australian' Commonwealth Sector Campaign-Extension to State, Territory and Local Governments, which was supposed to be considered at the coming special Premiers Conference. I ask the Minister: Is he really serious about pursuing the loony Carmichael plan to centralise purchasing for all levels of government in Canberra in the Purchase Australia office-the sort of ideological claptrap, I might say, that contributed to the collapse of communism in the USSR and Eastern Europe? Is not this proposal diametrically opposed to the Government's financial management improvement program, which is aimed at giving more autonomy and responsibility to individual departments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you have got to feel sorry for the Opposition. I do not know what Dr Hewson is going to do, looking at the quality of the questions coming from the other side of the House. I must admit that, I do feel sorry for Senator Parer because, sitting where he is sitting, he has got to come up with something. Last time it took him 125 days. He can feel the hot breath of Senator Bishop down his neck, about to take his position, and he has got to come up with something this time.

ANSWER.PARA: What has he come up with? Another alleged leaked document. It may be a leaked document-Senator Parer might have got it out of some rubbish bin in the gutter somewhere, it might have been delivered to him by friends in the Government, or whatever-but let me say one thing about government purchasing. Senator Parer is talking about a great Soviet plot to take over the whole purchasing of government, State and Federal. There is no need for glasnost in this Government; we are approaching government purchasing in a way that Senator Parer would never understand. He never understood it with the Purchase Australia campaign, and he would not understand it now.

Senator Parer refers to the item being on the agenda for the special Premiers Conference. He may know that-fair enough, he might have grabbed it out of his leaked document-but let me ask him to note that on the whole question of government purchasing, the whole impetus being given to coordinating administrative services Ministers has not only been from the Federal level. We have also had support and encouragement from Mr Webster, the Minister in New South Wales, and, next Friday in Perth, there will be a meeting of State and Federal administrative services Ministers where the question of government purchasing is, I believe, to be on the agenda.

That is not put there by us solely; it is put there by consultation with State governments. There is a recognition by State governments and the Federal Government that a degree of assistance, cooperation and maybe coordination could be quite effective. It could be quite effective when one looks at the desirable outcomes. Senator Parer should talk to the Australian technology industry, for instance, in terms of what it would like to see from government purchasing. He should talk to small businesses and see what they would like to see. All those concerns and interests are at the forefront for this Government. We are not going to be deviated by Senator Parer coming in here, alleging he has a leaked document claiming a socialist plot. He can do better than that-and, unless he does, Senator Bishop will be sitting right where he is, on his lap.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of the latest industrial disputes statistics? If so, can he inform the Senate whether there is statistical evidence that the Government's industrial relations policies have contributed to a significant reduction in the level of industrial disputes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should preface my answer to this question by saying that the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) statistical series, `Time lost through industrial disputation' is not the most important measure of lost productivity to industry. The most important measures are, of course, the levels of time lost through accidents and industrial disease, and time lost through what I call the silent strike; that is, absenteeism from work and high labour turnover. Both those measures are running at about 10 times the amount of time lost to industry than through disputes.

ANSWER.PARA: But there is a fascination in the media, and an absolute obsession in the Opposition, about industrial disputes and they do focus on this quite closely. The latest figures were released by the Bureau on 2= October for June 1990, and for the year ended June 1990-that is, for the month and for the year. The figures released by the Bureau show that in June 1990 there were 21,400 working days lost in 86 separate disputes. This is the lowest June working day lost figure since the ABS commenced its monthly series in 1967. In the 12 months to June 1990, there were 1,173,100 working days lost, which is 9 per cent lower than the working day lost record for the year ended June 1989, and 31 per cent lower than for the year ended 30 June 1988. The lowest financial year working day lost figure was recorded last year since the financial year 1967-68.

The working days lost per 1,000 employees figure of 184, which is another measure, for the year to June 1990, is the lowest financial year figure since this measure was introduced on a monthly basis; that is since the Bureau commenced to record statistics on that measure. At the end of June 1990, the Hawke Government had been in office for 91 months compared to the Fraser Government being in office for 88 months. So, one can make some rough comparisons between the record of the two Governments based on that monthly duration of office. The monthly average number of working days lost since March 1983 is now 113,500, a 54 per cent improvement over the average recorded under the Fraser Government. When one uses the working days lost measure per 1,000 employees, the improvement is even more marked. The annualised average number of working days lost per 1,000 employees since March 1983 is now 228, which is a 61 per cent lower figure than the average of 591 recorded during the period 1976 to 1982.

Of the major disputes that occurred in the period that the Bureau reported, two of the three major disputes were reported within the Australian Capital Territory which for a small population is a record. One of the disputes was about the administration of the Australian Capital Territory Government and the other about teachers. It is interesting to note that that is a Liberal Administration with a very high level of industrial disputation compared to the rest of the country. On the other hand, Western Australia, a Labor Administration, had record total gross figures; the lowest number of working days lost since the ABS commenced collection. It also had the lowest number of working days lost as a percentage of 1,000 employees.

They are heartening figures. They are consistent with our performance in Government. It is fair to say that in the current period there have been more industrial disputes attending the Australian Council of Trade Unions in-the-field national wage case campaign, and I expect the figures in the next quarter to show an increase in industrial disputation because of that campaign. However, it is interesting to note that the Opposition spokesman for industrial relations, Mr Howard, has told employers that they should continue with that campaign and continue in direct negotiations, bypassing the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. A feature of direct negotiations is a high level of industrial disputes, so when the figures for this next quarter come out reporting the level of industrial activity due to the in-the-field campaign, I do not expect Mr Howard to criticise them, its being a model similar to the one that he is advocating for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. What assurances can be given that the agreement signed by State and Commonwealth Ministers for World Heritage listing of Shark Bay will not involve duplication of approval for pastoral, mining, fishing and commercial activity and the use of a Commonwealth veto over such activity? Can the Minister inform the Senate of what effect the agreement will have on current property rights within the area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Mrs Kelly has reached agreement with Mr Pearce, the Western Australian Minister. I understand that the basis for that agreement is the adoption of the Shark Bay regional plan as a basis for ongoing management of the area. Furthermore, I understand that a final agreement was reached on boundaries at some stage in the last two weeks. I am not exactly certain what those boundaries are, but I shall inquire of the Minister and bring that before the honourable senator.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe at the heart of the agreement was the capacity of both the Commonwealth and the State to accept that management plan as the basis for future management of the area and to ensure that in its management we can take into account the views of local people. It has never been the case that all of the pastoral properties around the Shark Bay area were to be included in a final boundary, even though pastoralists seem to form the heart of the opposition. I believe the view that not all those pastoral properties were to be included has in fact happened now that we actually have an agreed boundary. I will make further inquiries of the Minister and try to produce that agreement in the Senate in two weeks time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and express some surprise that my comrades on the right have not seen fit to ask this question. Is the Minister aware that the Salvation Army and the Smith Family report an increase of approximately 50 per cent in their emergency relief claims during this financial year? Is the Minister aware that unemployment has risen by 25 per cent between September 1989 and September 1990, and that the Prime Minister has often stated that unemployment is the major cause of poverty? Does the Minister agree that this outcome is the result of the economic slowdown engineered by the Government's high interest policy on the basis of the Government's own explanation of that policy? Finally, does the Minister agree that the concern about the worsening of child poverty expressed by Archbishop Hollingworth, as a result of the Government's high interest policy, was both justified and constructive and should not be dismissed lightly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the particular report from the Salvation Army which was the premise of Senator Spindler's question but in relation to the question of unemployment, I am able to say that the Government's track record on employment growth has been very well proven indeed. Employment growth has been almost five times the average annual rate recorded during the previous Government's term. We have generated over 1.6 million jobs since we took office, of which over 90 per cent were in the private sector.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the case that more recently, of course, the labour market has been subdued, with employment falling in August and September, but there has been no major shake-out. The success of the accord in preventing a wages blow-out has helped prevent a collapse in employment in that respect. The accord has, of course, achieved unprecedented real wage moderation in the face of a booming economy. The rise in the unemployment rate since late 1989 was almost entirely due, as Senator Spindler should be aware, to the significant rise in labour force participation.

That participation rate is showing its normal cyclical response and in the face of the slower labour market it is starting to decline. That is one of the key factors, of course, in the present unemployment figures that we are now seeing. The slowdown in demand growth which is a product, among other things, of deliberately high interest rates has been the centrepiece of government policy along with fiscal policy for some time now. That slowdown is necessary to produce the reduced current account deficit. It cannot be achieved without affecting both output and the labour market. The Budget forecasts an increase in unemployment this year, as Senator Spindler would be aware, although it should start to decline next year.

The Government's position on the particular question of child poverty-and there is no disagreement between the Prime Minister and Archbishop Hollingworth in this respect-is that child poverty continues to be a matter of concern for us. We have made very significant commitments over the past three years in this respect with funding of the order of $3 billion being devoted to increasing payments to families and children most in need, payments that simply would not have been made if this Government and Ministers like Mr Keating, Senator Richardson and Mr Howe had not been in Cabinet to advance and pursue them with all the vigour that is appropriate to this very difficult subject area.

The Prime Minister wants to make very clear-and no doubt he has had the opportunity to say so himself today-that he will continue to work with Peter Hollingworth to address the needs of Australia's children. It is a matter that we are very conscious of. It is affected, clearly, by the unemployment situation, which was mentioned in the first part of the question. We know that, but our whole economic strategy is designed to redress that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister did not really advert to my question relating to the Prime Minister's attack on the Archbishop. Can we expect a personal attack from the Prime Minister every time a community leader expresses disagreement and concern about the effects of government policy?

—The Prime Minister is a model of restraint and decorum. On all occasions, as we are all aware, when he is criticised in a way that he regards as fundamentally unfair he will, of course, from time to time demonstrate just a little smidgin of irritation. That is a perfectly understandable human response. The point is, as I have indicated, there is no difference of approach on the basic gut policy issues involved here. The Government is proud of its record on child poverty and will continue to pursue policies that are designed to reduce that terrible blight on our society.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In light of the apparent assurances given to the Green independent, Dr Bob Brown, by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, for an end to the woodchip industry, can the Minister please advise whether the Federal Government is to intervene in the Tasmanian Labor Government's plans to raise the woodchip quota above the present 2.889 million tonne level? To allay concerns, can the Minister give an unequivocal assurance that the Federal Government will not use either the Export Control Act or its corporation powers to destroy the plan for the future management of Tasmania's forests, which has emerged as a result of detailed considerations by the community groups, industry and politicians of all persuasions? Finally, is Minister Kelly's wish to end the woodchip industry destined to become government policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I will not embarrass you by seeking your guidance as to whether I should answer questions on government policy. I will pretend that none of us heard Senator Alston's silly point of order earlier and I will answer Senator Calvert's question.

ANSWER.PARA: I can recall seeing-I think in one of yesterday's newspapers-a comment from Minister Kelly that she did not believe she would be able to take up all that was on Bob Brown's agenda. I have not seen any indication from Minister Kelly or the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, or the Minister for Resources, Mr Griffiths, that the Commonwealth is to intervene on the setting of the woodchip quota in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook couldn't give us the assurance last week.
—I am not sure what Senator Watson is saying, so I will ignore him. I am not aware of any intention of Mrs Kelly to intervene. I shall confirm that with her.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to Mrs Kelly's wish, as I think Senator Calvert said, to end the woodchip industry, I think that the Government has been concerned for some time about this matter. I have heard Senator Cook say in this place on many occasions that we would be delighted to see more secondary processing of our raw materials, certainly more than just chipping wood. That would certainly be an aim of the Government. We have not so far as I am aware, however, said that that means the end of woodchipping now, but I would hope that in the course of the next decade or two we will direct our energies to making sure that there is secondary processing. I do not believe that any Australian would be advantaged so long as all we do with our timber is chip it.

However, I shall not give categorical guarantees and assurances on the things the honourable senator has raised without checking them first with the Minister. All I can say is that I have heard nothing from the Minister to suggest that Commonwealth powers will be used in the way that Senator Calvert thinks they might have been.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: COLLECTION OF INFORMATION

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has recently referred to the Department of Social Security as a clearing house for matching data between departments. Exactly what information will go through the clearing house and what departments are involved? What information will the Department of Social Security be collecting from the Australian Taxation Office, and will the Department of Social Security be issuing tax file numbers as part of that proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley should be aware that a number of honourable senators have expressed interest in this matter, as has the Privacy Foundation and a whole host of community organisations. There are a number of government agencies which would be involved in the current plan that was announced in the Budget. They include the Department of Veterans' Affairs, which pays pensions; the Department of Employment, Education and Training, which pays Austudy; and the Department of Community Services and Health, which is responsible for the first home owners scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: The purpose of the data matching proposals is to pick up two problems. The first is the detection of duplicate payments, and we would do that by matching information from the other departments. We shall also attempt to secure some knowledge on those who are seeking to frustrate government income tests in particular.

The way in which the system would work is that the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Community Services and Health will give family identity data, the current recipients of their payments and, where applicable, that of their partner or parents to my Department at regular intervals as is necessary to achieve that stated Government aim.

Tax file number details will be supplied to my Department as part of that family identity data. They will be given to it by these other income support agencies. The Department of Social Security will at the same time match that family identity data supplied by other income support agencies with the family identity data of its own clients. This will detect, we trust, all incorrect duplicate payments.

The income test provisions are being strengthened through the comparison of income disclosed to the income support agencies with that disclosed to the Australian Taxation Office. That will be achieved by my Department seeking taxable income and dependent spouse rebate data for the income support clients whose records are included in the computer matching process.

In nominating the cases to the Australian Taxation Office for which the Department is seeking taxable income details for comparison purposes, the Department of Social Security will indicate to the Taxation Office the tax file number of the cases concerned and a minimum amount of confirmatory information so that the Taxation Office can be satisfied about the accuracy of the data it is giving back to the Department of Social Security.

However, as honourable senators probably know, my Department has an arrangement with the Australian Taxation Office whereby social security clients who do not already have a tax file number can apply for one through a Department of Social Security regional office. It is notified to the client by the Australian Taxation Office and at the same time the Taxation Office also notifies my Department. The Australian Taxation Office has sole responsibility for the issue of tax file numbers and the computer matching arrangements will not change that.

The Government believes that the connection of those taxation and income support payment systems in the way in which I have just described will detect a considerable number of incorrect payments which previously could not have been detected. All of that will be done under the monitoring and the very watchful eye of the Privacy Commissioner. Furthermore, even if the system were to break down during operation, instead of technicians being able to get into the system to make sure that information is further protected-as is now the case- we will ensure that no entry into the system can be undertaken without a representative of the Privacy Commissioner being present and unlocking the system. I do not believe that we can put in place any more safeguards in the use of tax file numbers than we have now announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy: What information can he provide in respect of the numbers of Indonesian fishermen detained at Willie Creek throughout the year? Can he give an undertaking that the conditions they are detained under comply with Australia's human rights obligations? Will he give an indication of the conditions of detention? Further, given that the fishermen are allowed to walk freely in and out of the quarantine area and mix with tourists, why do we bother to bash a post in the sand and mark it as a quarantine area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure that, speaking from the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio, I am able to answer a question relating to an international covenant that has been referred to in this question. But let me do the best I can.

ANSWER.PARA: My understanding is that the well-being, health and safety of Indonesian fishermen conducting illegal activities in the Australian fishing zone are checked, firstly, when Navy patrol boat crews board their vessels at sea and, secondly, by the Australian Fisheries Service officer when the boat is brought into harbour. In terms of quarantine function, the crew are checked by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service officers for communicable quarantine diseases and checks are made for any diseases in animals.

There have been cases of boats being found beached on islands in the Bonaparte Gulf area in which chickens or whatever have been carried from Indonesia for meat or eggs at sea and those chickens have got loose. We have been concerned from a quarantine angle about the possibility of Newcastle disease. On the one occasion that I am aware of that occurring, the quarantine officer killed all the chickens and made sure that there was no possibility of a communicable, quarantinable disease being brought into Australia.

Any problems from a health point of view that have been identified were referred to the Broome Regional Hospital for treatment, as have any dental problems. The caretaker at the area in which these people are held has the obligation to supply food and water. I understand that it is an obligation that he discharges quite well. The Broome Regional Hospital has advised that in recent times four Indonesians have been treated for tuberculosis, about 15 people have been treated for cuts, abrasions and urinary tract infections, one person has been treated for an injury received when using a fishing line and one case of hepatitis B has been treated.

If people are able to walk in and out of the station-I do not know whether that is true; I cannot verify the assertion in Senator Vanstone's question-it must only be applicable on the basis that there is no risk of disease and that their human rights are not inhibited, given that they were illegally in an Australian fishing zone in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to address himself to the detail of the question. He was not simply asked whether these people were given food and water by the caretaker; he was asked whether he can give an undertaking, given that the Department on whose behalf he is responding has primary responsibility for this area, that the conditions under which the Indonesian fishermen are held comply with Australian human rights obligations, which are not limited simply to providing food and water. Secondly, the Minister was asked why, if the fishermen are allowed to walk freely in and out, we bother to mark the area as a quarantine area. Surely we do not bother to do that unless there is a problem. If there is a problem, why are those people allowed to walk freely in and out of the area? I ask the Minister to address himself to those two aspects of the question and, for that matter, the first one: what information can he give us with respect to the numbers of fishermen who are held at Willie Creek? Does he know anything of any substance about this?

—I assure the Senate that fishermen detained by the Navy for illegally fishing in the Australian Fishing Zone are held in humane circumstances. I imagine that they absolutely comply with our international obligations, but I am not in a position to answer from the primary industries portfolio what is an obligation of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I will obtain some advice for Senator Vanstone if she just contains herself and I will answer that part of the question. As far as the other parts of her supplementary question are concerned, I stand by the answer that I have given. If there is anything that I care to add to it, I will examine her question and add to my answer later.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 September 1990 Senator Reid asked Senator Button a question for which I now have an answer, and I seek leave to incorporate the text in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The rebate to which the honourable senator referred is the pensioner rebate and has been available to pensioners since 1982-83. The rebate ensures that persons wholly or mainly dependent on Australian social security or repatriation pensions do not have to pay tax on those pensions.

As the honourable senator indicated, a pensioner receiving the single-rate of age pension was able to receive up to $8,262 in 1989-90 and not pay tax. The amount of $8,262 represents the pension of $6,962 for the year plus $1,300 of non-pension income. The rebate shades out at 12.5 cents in the dollar for each dollar of taxable income in excess of $8,262; ie it is fully extinguished at an income of $13,574.
For 1990-91, the level of the pensioner rebate will be raised so that a pensioner receiving the single-rate of age pension can earn an additional $40 per week of non-pension income and not pay tax.

Persons in receipt of a low level of Commonwealth superannuation pension who satisfy the income and assets tests and the residency requirements will be eligible for a full or part age or service pension and hence for the pensioner tax rebate.

For example, provided a person satisfied the residency and assets test requirements, an aged person receiving $8,000 of superannuation in 1989-90 would have been eligible for a pension of some $3,980. On the total taxable income of $11,980, the person would have received a rebate of tax of $199.25.
Those in receipt of a Commonwealth superannuation pension who are not eligible for a part age or service pension pay income tax on the same basis as other individuals.

In the 1989-90 Budget, the Treasurer and the Minister for Social Security announced a comprehensive and far-reaching retirement income policy. This policy recognises the need to balance the requirements of providing adequate income support to those whose need is greatest whilst encouraging greater self-provision in retirement through superannuation.

The Government is introducing a better integrated system of social security and tax administration for retirees. A three-stage reform process will be implemented, culminating in 1995 in the complete removal of all age and service pensioners-both full rate and part rate-from the taxation system and making part rate pensioners subject only to the withdrawal rate of their pension entitlement. This means that from 1995, no age or service pensioner will pay tax.

In addition, the pensioner rebate will be withdrawn beyond the pension shade-out range. This means that a superannuant of age-pension age would be eligible for the pensioner tax rebate and pay tax at the applicable marginal rate plus the rebate shade-out rate on income above the pension shade-out point.

In this way all retired persons at the same income level will be treated equally and there will be continuity of treatment between those receiving an age or service pension and those whose non-pension income places them beyond the pension cut-out point.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Campbell asked me a question about the Australian company number (ACN) on all company documents. I have a further answer to supplement the answer which I gave yesterday. The Australian company number will help us move towards the uniform registration system of companies by giving a unique number to every company. It is a fact that the Corporations Act 1989 includes the requirement for all companies to display their Australian company number on all business documents.

ANSWER.PARA: In September 1990, the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) released an information sheet which described the purpose and use of the ACNs in detail. The ASC is advising companies of their ACNs as annual return forms are distributed. The ASC anticipates that by the end of next week about 90 per cent of companies will have been notified in this way. Other companies will be advised separately by mid-November, except where the ASC is unable to reach them because they are inactive or defunct.

While the introduction of the ACN may result in some incidental cost to Australian business, the national system of corporate regulation facilitated in part by the use of ACNs is expected to result, overall, in a considerable cost saving to business. I note that in today's press the Australian Business Council is reported as saying that the implementation of the scheme would not impose heavy cost burdens.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked a question by Senator Boswell on the sale and lease back of a boiler and the sale of a veneer mill and some questions as to how that fitted or did not fit into the agreement that the Government had with the mill in Ravenshoe. I have this answer for him.

ANSWER.PARA: The financial advisers of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Price Waterhouse, Canberra, visited the APS Ravenshoe mill on 31 May 1990 in the course of the review of the assistance provided to the mill, which was initiated by the Department on 30 March 1990 as part of the ongoing evaluation of the structural adjustment package.

Price Waterhouse was advised on the day of its visit by the manager of the mill that he, the manager, had just been informed by the head office that the head office had sold to AGC Finance Co. and leased back a wood waste fire boiler which had been purchased by Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd with Commonwealth assistance. The cost of the boiler was approximately $412,000. The sale of the boiler to AGC was prior to the appointment of the receiver and managers.

A veneer hardwood timber plant was sold for approximately $425,000 prior to the appointment of the receiver and managers in April 1990. This plant was no longer required because the APS mill was being restructured from a hardwood operation to processing plantation timbers. The sale of this equipment was only advised to the Department in the receiver's and manager's letter of 19 September 1990.

On 16 October 1990 the Minister referred to the Commonwealth Attorney-General the two reports received from the receivers and managers of Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd concerning the company's use of Commonwealth loan and subsidy payments. This was in accordance with the Government's decision of 25 September 1990 that, if satisfactory clarification of expenditure of Commonwealth funds provided under the assistance agreement were not received, the matter would be referred to the Attorney-General to investigate what legal action should be taken with regard to any moneys not accounted for. As will be apparent from the above answer, the Government did not know of these sales beforehand and, accordingly, I did not give my permission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

—I table the document.
—I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the order of the Senate of 28 September 1988, I ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) who represents the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) why answers have not been given to my questions No. 141 and 142 asked over 56 days ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Macdonald, a couple of days ago in this chamber I tabled a very long answer which I thought covered all of the questions asked on the Ravenshoe Mill including those from Senator Macdonald, Senator O'Chee and Senator Boswell. I will go back and check whether anything was missed. It is a very long document and I thought it had covered all that Senator Macdonald had asked. If it has not, I will try to find out.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on my feet, in respect of the answer I tabled, the paragraph on the second page of the document which referred to the ownership structure of several companies as a complex corporate structure-this is a point that I think Senator O'Chee made in an adjournment contribution recently; I am not sure whether it was last night or the night before-was typed in error. The paragraph should have read: The Associated Plywood Sales Pty Ltd (APS) sawmill operates as a division of Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, which was part of the Scotwood Street Ltd group of companies. National Associated Plywood Pty Ltd and the APS Sawmill at Ravenshoe use the business name Timbertech.
I will go back and check and if I have missed anything, I will certainly answer on the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you wish to speak to it?

—Yes, I do, just briefly. I point out to Senator Richardson that parts 7, 8 and 9 of question No. 141 have not been answered. They relate to whether the Government does accept that extended credit was given by business people in Ravenshoe to this mill because the creditors believed the company was being supported by the Government. Paragraph 9 asks:

SPEECH.PARA: Does the Government accept that it has a moral if not legal obligation to reimburse creditors who extended credit on the understanding of the Government's intention?

In relation to question No. 142, paragraph 4 asks whether or not the Government would be prepared to make long term low interest loans or grants available to the people in the Ravenshoe area wishing to set up tourist industries and tourist businesses in that area. Paragraph 5 asks for specific information on what steps have been taken by the Government in accordance with its promises to commence reafforestation projects; what areas of land have been acquired; how many people have been employed and how long that will continue.

I want to make Senator Richardson aware of this matter in view of the comments he made in tabling the lengthy answer to which he referred. He suggested that I and my colleagues Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee have politicised this matter in the way we have gone about it. I assure Senator Richardson that at all times I have been involved and interested in this matter only in an attempt to do something for the people of Ravenshoe who have lost so much.

I say to Senator Richardson: in the spirit of not making it political, on 18 July this year I wrote to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, in what I thought was a very moderate letter, which gave credit where credit was due. I will quote one paragraph from that letter, which states:

Because of your Government's generous and widely publicised offers of assistance grants to the mill for retooling, the business people of Ravenshoe had no hesitation in extending credit to the company. They did this in the knowledge that your Government was funding the project and would obviously be monitoring the grant monies to ensure that the grant monies were spent for the stated purpose of your government's grants, that is to ensure that the mill remained viable and that consequently the town of Ravenshoe continued to exist.

In that letter I suggested that Mrs Kelly and the Government might make a one-off, ex gratia payment to cover the debts that these small businessmen had incurred in giving credit to the milling company and also to streamline contractors. I did not make that letter public. I did not issue any press releases in relation to that for many weeks, in the hope that I might get an answer from Mrs Kelly. I also said in my letter that I understood Mrs Kelly was sympathetic to the plight of these people and that she was going to look at it.

I might say-and I find it disgusting from a Minister-that that letter of 18= July 1990 has not yet received so much as a formal acknowledgment, let alone a letter giving the answers to my questions. I raised this matter in Estimates committees with Senator Richardson and, I think, Dr Turner. Dr Turner was horrified to hear that and promised he would get me a response to the letter. The Estimates committees were almost a month ago and I still have not got an answer.

This is a very serious matter to the people of Ravenshoe. The amounts of money involved-that is, the amounts that have been lost-are minute, minuscule, compared with the money that had been put aside for compensation at Ravenshoe, and that money has not yet been spent. I think there was about $75m allocated or said to be for use over a period of years for that compensation. Nowhere near that amount has yet been used. I ask the Government, on behalf of these people, to spend just a couple of hundred thousand dollars-a very small amount to the Government in terms of the Budget allocation, but a very large amount to the people involved.

There are small businessmen there who have lost something like $50,000 or $60,000. A business that has a usual profit of about $20,000 simply cannot afford a long term permanent loss of something like $50,000 or $60,000. The end result will be that the small businessman who has put his whole life's effort and work into his business will go bankrupt. He will lose his house and his car; his children will lose the pleasures that they had in that little town; and he will become yet another person on the dole queue. All this will happen simply because those people, in all good faith, extended credit to the company because they believed the Government was looking after it. I again plead with Senator Richardson to speak with Mrs Kelly to see whether something can be done.

I know that this should never be done as a precedent. I know that the Government is concerned and says, `If we do this here, when do we stop?', but I suggest that this is a particular one-off situation. It is a situation which would never have arisen if these people had not believed that the Government was propping up the mill. I keep saying that, but that is why they did it. I accept that the Government does not pay debts that are not payable because a company such as Associated Plywood Sales Pty Ltd goes into receivership. As a lawyer, I accept and understand that but, in this instance, one might say they were duped into giving credit because they thought the Government was there.

I ask Senator Richardson to plead with Mrs Kelly again that these moneys be given back as a one-off, ex gratia payment so that a number of small businessmen do not have to join dole queues simply because they did what they did in the expectation that they were doing the right thing. I would appreciate it if Senator Richardson could refer these questions to Mrs Kelly and ask for an answer. I ask her to deal with the matter very sympathetically.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my voice to Senator Macdonald's in a plea to have compensation paid to these subcontractors and contractors, to people who have sold timber off their properties and to the timber workers themselves. I can recall, and I think Senator Richardson will be able to recall too, the day that we both flew to Cairns and-I think it was at the Pacific Hotel in the conference room-Senator Richardson, in front of a press conference, said that $75m compensation would be paid for World Heritage listing. We were going to see plantations springing up and we were going to see all sorts of magnificent tourism ventures coming forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Now, two years down the track, the whole thing is in a mess, and I think Senator Richardson would agree with that. I am not blaming the Government in particular; well, I am blaming it because it has not monitored the money that it gave to the timber mill. As I said last night, Senator Richardson made a commitment on behalf of his Government, and he is a very senior Minister in that Government, that no person would be disadvantaged; no person would be worse off. We have now come to the conclusion that a great many people are now worse off. Millions of dollars have now gone from where they were supposed to go in Ravenshoe to re-equip and build a mill in Kyogle. They are very serious charges, and today Senator Richardson responded to a question that I asked yesterday saying that yes, the boiler and the veneer mill were sold and he did not give his permission.

Senator Richardson has assured the Senate that while he was Minister as far as he could ascertain everything was done in accordance with the agreement set down between his Government and the mill. Today he makes an admission that an agreement was not stuck to. I do not want to draw any conclusions, but I do want to say, `Senator Richardson, you have a very serious obligation. In fact, your whole credibility is on the line'. It is no good abusing Senators O'Chee, Macdonald and myself for doing our duty. That is what we are elected to do, to come down here and point out inadequacies and things that are going wrong with Australia.

There is a lot wrong with Ravenshoe. The Minister's credibility is on the line; his Government took 2,500 jobs out, destroyed an industry that was worth $33m and made the promise of compensation. That compensation has not been delivered. The Government may have done everything that it thought possible to deliver it, but the compensation has not been delivered, the town now is in crisis and the mill never had a chance to exist because bits and pieces and money were being siphoned off that mill and sent down to rebuild, re-equip or establish another mill. While this was happening the Minister had his hand on the tiller and he let it happen.

As I said before, these are very serious charges. I hope the Minister will take back to Cabinet the request from this Senate that it honour its obligation and provide jobs, a future and security to those people in Ravenshoe now, and that he gets through Cabinet the continued operation of that mill to provide jobs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The questions that have been raised by Senator Macdonald and are unanswered by Senator Richardson go right to the heart of what is wrong with Ravenshoe, because, as a result of the actions of this Government, the people of Ravenshoe have been left in the lurch. The questions that Senator Macdonald raised concerned money owed to innocent, unsuspecting, unsecured creditors who blindly put their faith in Senator Richardson's assurance that nobody in Ravenshoe would be disadvantaged as a result of World Heritage listing. They believed, based on Senator Richardson's assurances, that the Government would back that mill all the way. They probably even took note of his press release in 1987-I believe it was-when he said, `We will spend $75m, or whatever it takes, to ensure that nobody suffers in Ravenshoe.' Unfortunately, the Government has not spent the money that it will take to ensure that nobody suffers in Ravenshoe, because $600,000 is owed to unsecured creditors who put their faith in the mill, who put their faith in the Government and who have been let down.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson has had ample time to answer the questions that Senator Macdonald has put to him. Senator Macdonald put those questions to Senator Richardson on 22 August, and since then 56 days have elapsed. Senator Richardson said just this afternoon that he was of the belief that the statement he tabled in Parliament on Tuesday answered Senator Macdonald's questions. Quite clearly it did not, because it did not make mention of the plight of the unsecured creditors. It did not pay any heed to Senator Macdonald's questions. Senator Richardson, if he had paid any attention to the answer he was tabling in Parliament, would have known that, but he obviously did not pay any attention to the answer he tabled in Parliament. We find an answer that, supposedly, was prepared with departmental assistance and has embarrassing typographical errors that alter the essence of the answer relating to the group of companies in question.

Of course, we now have to start wondering when Senator Richardson became aware of the reference of this matter by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy). In the statement that Senator Richardson made today he said that the report of the receivers and managers was contained in a letter of 19 September 1990. He went on to say that on 16 October 1990 the matter was referred to the Attorney-General's Department. That date, 16 October 1990, was Monday.

TALK.START.PARA: —The day we asked the questions.

—It is the day Senator Boswell asked a question of the Minister and the day I asked a question of the Minister. In fact, in answer to the questions that I asked and Senator Boswell asked, Senator Richardson did not even mention the Attorney-General's Department. It was only after I had to table a series of embarrassing documents, and give a long dissertation on where the money went, that Senator Richardson could tell us that the matter had been referred to the Attorney-General's Department.

SPEECH.PARA: I have the sneaking suspicion that this matter was referred to the Attorney-General's Department with the speed of a telephone call that may have been made from the lobby outside this chamber. If Senator Richardson knew, before I spoke, that the matter had been referred to the Attorney-General's Department, he would have told us; but he did not. I suspect the matter was not referred at all or, if the matter was referred to the Attorney-General's Department some time between 19 September 1990 and 16 October 1990, it is very clear that Mrs Richardson-Mrs Kelly-did not bother to tell Senator Richardson.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mrs Richardson tells me things all the time.

—I am glad that somebody tells the Minister what is going on because Mrs Kelly does not seem to be telling him what is going on. We are talking about a period of time from 19= September to 16 October. The other revealing thing about the answer that Senator Richardson has just tabled in Parliament today is this: He says that the reference of the matter to the Attorney-General's Department was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in accordance with the Government's decision of 25 September 1990 that, if satisfactory clarification of expenditure of Commonwealth funds provided under the assistance agreement were not received, the matter would be referred to the Attorney-General to investigate . . .

Assuming the decision was made to take some action on this on 25 September, we still have this disturbing period of time between 25 September until sometime after three o'clock on 16 October when Senator Richardson saw fit to advise this Senate, to advise the Parliament of Australia, that the matter had been referred to the Attorney-General's Department.

There are only three conclusions that can be drawn and I will not say which one I believe is correct but I will lay them on the table. One is that Senator Richardson either knew about the reference to the Attorney-General's Department and did not tell Parliament, or he did not know about the reference to the Attorney-General's Department because Mrs Kelly did not see fit to tell him, or maybe she did not trust him. The third possible inference is that absolutely nothing was done between the time of receipt of this report and the time when these documents were tabled in the Senate on Monday afternoon. Then, it was as a result of a hasty telephone call from maybe outside in the lobby here, or maybe from Mrs Kelly's office where she was watching it on television, or maybe from one of the Minister's staff who was watching in alarm in the ministerial suite. But one of those three things happened, and whichever one it was, it raises very serious allegations about the conduct of this Minister, about the conduct of this Government, about and the way it accounts to the people of Australia through this Parliament.

We find that Senator Richardson says that he was not aware until the receivers' report of 19 September that $837,000 of plant and equipment was sold from out of that mill. He tells us that he was not aware of its happening, notwithstanding the fact that it occurred before the appointment of the receivers when he was the responsible Minister. He told this Parliament on 16 October that he was satisfied that all the conditions of the assistance agreement had been met. They included the conditions contained in clause 3 of the charge agreement that the assets of the company would not be disposed of without the approval of the Government.

Well, if Senator Richardson knew on 19 September when the letter was received that those assets had been disposed of, then when he said on 16 October that all of the conditions relating to the assistance agreement had been met, he must have been incorrect. I will just give him the benefit of the doubt and assume that that incorrect answer arose as a result of a good natured error. But other people would draw other inferences and they are right perhaps to do so. I will not do that but other people could.

The answers are quite clearly inconsistent, and we still have to ask, `How did $837,000 of plant and equipment get sold from that mill, get disposed of by that company when Senator Richardson as the responsible Minister and his Department were supposed to be overseeing the operations of the company?'. He said in his answer on Tuesday that his officers periodically telephoned the company to find out how the installation of the equipment required for retooling was going, and that statement that was also tabled on Tuesday said that periodical inspections were made.

Quite clearly, that was not sufficient. Quite clearly, the monitoring process put in place by the Minister and his Department failed to notice that $837,000 of plant and equipment had been sold by the mill. Even assuming that it would be reasonable to overlook the fact that the boiler had been sold and leased back and was therefore still on the premises, there is still the question of the $425,000 for the veneer mill which was sold and, I presume, left the premises. We are yet to find out, but I only assume that it left the premises.

We have to ask how the Minister's departmental officers, if those officers visited the place on a regular basis or even on an occasional basis, could have failed to notice that a veneer mill worth $425,000 was there on their last visit and when those officers visited again it was not there. It only took up half the factory. I suppose it is an oversight we could all make, is it not? I suppose when the officers visit the mill, they will not even bother to do a stocktake.

TALK.START.PARA: —It did not take up half the factory; don't be silly.
—It did, it took up one side of the factory.

—It took up one side of the factory, as Senator Boswell says, but the Minister's departmental officers did not notice. The Minister's departmental officers did not notice because I suspect those officers were not fair dinkum, and neither was the Minister, about the monitoring of the operations of this company.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us recap on all of the things we have just discovered this afternoon. We have discovered, first and foremost, that Senator Richardson does not seem to be able to read a statement prepared, I assume, by Mrs Kelly and does not seem to be able to understand that in that statement there is no response to a question which was outstanding for in excess of 50 days in relation to innocent people, good people, in Ravenshoe and north Queensland who have lost together over $600,000 as a result of this Government's incompetence. We have seen Senator Richardson admit that the Government received a report on 19 September yet did not do anything about it until 16 October, when I raised the issue in Parliament and tabled the necessary documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald raised it on 11 October.

—Senator Macdonald asked questions about it on 11 October and the Minister did not know about it then. We reach the conclusion that one of three things happened: either Senator Richardson knew about the report and did not tell Parliament; Senator Richardson did not know about the report because Mrs Kelly had not bothered to tell him; or the matter had not been referred to the Attorney-General's Department and was referred to that Department only as a result of the matters that I raised in Parliament. We have seen that Senator Richardson and his Department were wholly incapable of keeping track of where $830,000 worth of assets, including a veneer mill half the size of the building, disappeared. Senator Richardson does not seem to have been able to keep track of that. The Minister has this disturbing inconsistency in his answers that a report was received on 19 September. That is when the Minister became aware of the report, on 19 September. The Minister said on 16 October that he believed all of the terms and conditions of the assistance agreement must have been met, yet it is very clear that Senator Richardson must have had knowledge of the fact that the terms and conditions of the assistance agreement were not met because the result of a Government decision on 25 September 1990 was that if sufficient clarification were not received, the matter would be referred to the AttorneyGeneral's Department.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen the extraordinary financial incompetence of this Government in allowing $5.7m, perhaps, of money to leave Ravenshoe to flow directly or indirectly to Kyogle where a new mill was built, while the mill at Ravenshoe was still not properly retooled. We have seen, as a result of this Government's financial negligence, the people of Ravenshoe lose the money out of that town that was rightfully theirs by the labour and the credit they supplied to the mill, in good faith that this Government was going to support the mill all the way. We have seen the dreams of innocent, hardworking Queenslanders shattered by that Government and its negligence in dealing with the matter.

When I was up in Ravenshoe last a man came to me. He is owed $60,000 by the mill; he pays $1,000 a month for his business overdraft because he remains unpaid; and he faces losing his home, his business and everything he has worked for. What really gets him and me is that if he loses his business he will not be able to fulfil his dream to apprentice his son into his business. That will shatter his and his son's dreams. Senator Richardson and the Government do not seem overly perturbed because they are hiding behind a wholly inadequate assistance agreement and saying that the agreement is not between the Government and the people, but between the Government and the mill.
We have already seen, as Senator Macdonald has said, that there is a very strong moral obligation on this Government to make good the money that the people of Ravenshoe have lost.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a moral duty on you to shut up for a few weeks.
—Order!

—But more than that, this extraordinary tale of ministerial, departmental and governmental incompetence goes to the point where, as a result of the Government's negligence, it almost has a legal obligation to make good that money. I think Senator Richardson has a lot of explaining to do. If, when Senator Richardson gets up in a few minutes, he tries to blame me, Senator Boswell, Senator Macdonald or anybody else on this side who is genuinely interested in the people of Ravenshoe and in the future of their town, for the closure of the mill or for any failure in the commercial viability of that mill, he will be wholly wrong. The continued existence of that mill is dependent upon the Government's meeting its obligations, obligations made by Senator Richardson when he was sprouting on about $75m or `whatever it takes', when he was sprouting on about how nobody would suffer.

SPEECH.PARA: One of Senator Richardson's promises was that 12,000 hectares of pine plantation would be put in over a six-year period. Three years down the track we have not seen one of those trees planted, let alone 12,000 hectares. These are the things that are getting people on this side of the chamber and in Ravenshoe annoyed. The Minister should not try to blame us for any failure of the Government, the Department or himself to monitor the operations. He should not try to blame us for the mill's closing down, because we are not to blame. We did not make the decisions; the Government made them. Certainly Senator Richardson cannot blame us if the Government chooses to withdraw its commitment to support the mill and its offer of a grant. We cannot be blamed; it will be as a result of a decision of Mrs Kelly and the Cabinet. That is the truth; they are the facts; that is why people everywhere are getting annoyed at what has happened.

We have seen a damning list of facts which I think Senator Richardson has, to date, been wholly inadequate in answering. I believe he has an obligation to explain right now when he became aware of the reference to that matter, when it occurred, which of the three possible explanations that I have outlined is correct. Senator Richardson's performance during this whole shameful affair has been inadequate and his performance in answering the questions put to him by the people and the Parliament of Australia have also been wholly inadequate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is said that the three iron rules of politics are: never explain, never apologise and never resign. I certainly will not seek to break the third rule today, but I might seek at least to bend the first and break the second. In respect of the apology, as I think I said, the statement which I tabled yesterday-in answer, I thought, to all of the questions which had been asked on the matter of the Associated Plywood Sales Pty Ltd mill at Ravenshoe-was prepared on the basis of departmental advice and had some rhetoric added to it in the office of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly. I seek to withdraw none of the rhetoric that applies to Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee and will, in fact, add to it in a moment or two.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as Senator Macdonald is concerned, I will concede that there is no evidence that he has acted irresponsibly on this matter. I regret that his name was included in the last paragraph in that reference and I apologise to him for it. However, in so far as his colleagues in the coalition are concerned, Senators Boswell and O'Chee, I make no such apology and seek to add something. As Senator O'Chee, unction oozing from every pore, seeks on behalf of the Queensland National Party to lecture this Government on competence, we can all begin to laugh, and laugh heartily.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stick to the subject.
—Don't worry, I am going to, but every bit of rhetoric Senator O'Chee uses he will get back in this place. That is something you will learn, boyo.
—You have been giving it all the time and you can't take it.
—Just look at Senator Boswell. Here we have Senator Alston, who did not make the shadow cabinet, but Senator Boswell could not make the shadow ministry.

SPEECH.PARA: I have in front of me the answer that I have just read out to Senators O'Chee and Boswell and to the Senate at large. In reading that I pointed out that the first time that Price Waterhouse became aware of any of the problems to which Senator Boswell had referred yesterday was when they visited the mill on 31 May 1990 in the course of the review of the assistance provided to the mill, which the Department had initiated on 30 March and which was before the receiver-managers had even gone in. So before they had gone in the Department, as a normal part of the process of monitoring assistance given under that structural package, had asked Price Waterhouse to go in and have a further look.

When Price Waterhouse representatives went into the mill on the day of their visit they were advised by the manager that he had just been informed by his head office of the sale and lease back of the boiler. So far as the veneer timber plant was concerned, it was sold prior to the appointment of the receivers and managers in April-I am not sure at what date. I was not made aware of what was in the receiver-manager's report which Mrs Kelly got on 19 September on that day. It was the subject of a report to the Cabinet on 25 September. I was not made aware of it then either, because that was the day that I left for overseas and I was not at the Cabinet. Had I been at the Cabinet, I would have been in a position to have been made aware of the contents. But when I am out of the country it is a bit hard to be in two places at once, and I was not there. I do not apologise for not being there. It is just a fact that I was not. One wonders how I am supposed to know what happened at a Cabinet meeting that occurred when I was out of the country. So I did not know.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all Kelly's fault.

—No, it is definitely not Mrs Kelly's fault; I am not saying it was. The questions that I was getting were: when did I became aware? I am saying that Mrs Kelly became aware of the first report received on the nineteenth. As I am told, a second report arrived-in fact while the Cabinet meeting was taking place-on the twenty-fifth. I was not made aware at the time of the contents of either.

SPEECH.PARA: I have in the last week or however many days it is-I cannot put an exact moment on it-been made aware, and have come to the Senate and made the Senate aware of all I have been told about that report. So I have no apology to make to anyone. I certainly did not seek to hide any information from a report that I had never received and never read. To suggest that I had is nonsense.

So far as this Government being so terrified of Senator O'Chee that we have to race to the lobby to make this hasty telephone call; really, Senator O'Chee will have to do an awful lot better than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he's done pretty well.

—Oh, I will get to what he is doing in a moment. I said that I would. There is no problem with getting there. Just be patient, we will be there. When it comes to the question of some hasty call in the lobby to get the matter referred to the Attorney-General's Department, that is just nonsense. What has happened, as I understand it, is that since those reports have been received on whatever it was, the nineteenth and the twenty-fifth, if they are the right days, the Minister, Mrs Kelly, and her office and Department have been preparing advice for the Attorney-General's Department-he knew that it was coming over those couple of weeks-and it came on Monday. It would have got there whether we had been asked one question or no questions from people here, because those reports raise very serious matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I would dearly love to have the opportunity to respond to some of the things that Senators O'Chee and Boswell have said about what is supposed to have gone on at that mill, and where the Commonwealth's money went. But I cannot, and I will not, for obvious reasons. We have already said that legal action may be taken as a result of what is in those two reports. That is why they have been referred to the Attorney-General. It would be irresponsible indeed of me, or Mrs Kelly, to respond directly to those allegations, so we have not. But I long for the day, frankly, Senator O'Chee, when I can.

The point that I made to Senators O'Chee and Boswell and I seek to repeat is that at the time when we are negotiating with the receiver-manager about keeping this mill as an ongoing concern, negotiating with the receiver-manager about the further offer of government assistance to keep it in business, the raising of these matters does no one any good and can only harm the process. I accept that as a matter of course in this business one has to cop flak. I do not mind how long and how hard those opposite go at me, but I do mind when it will interfere with the process of delivering to the people of Ravenshoe all that we promised. That is what the Opposition is doing now.

Once those negotiations with the receiver-manager have been completed-and I hope that they can be successful; I am not conducting them but I sincerely hope they will be-and the Commonwealth's further assistance is accepted and the mill continues as a going concern, then Senator O'Chee or Senator Boswell can hack at me all they like. But any punt for a political scalp that they will never get is hardly worthwhile at a time when the people at Ravenshoe are looking to see whether the mill can be kept open.

We are negotiating this very day to try to make sure that that can happen. I do not want to do or say anything in this chamber that would put that process in jeopardy, and so I will not do so. I give up appealing to the National Party in Queensland to do anything that is sensible. Its record suggests that that is just not possible. But I appeal to all honourable senators to remember that it is not possible for Government Ministers to respond to matters which may be the subject of the Commonwealth taking legal action. It prejudices the rights not only of the Commonwealth but, more importantly-and I still believe in these rights passionately-the rights of those we may be taking action against. Therefore, I will not respond to any of those allegations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ministers can answer for their responsibilities, though.

—Well, I think that I have done that; I do not see that there is anything more that I can say. I am merely commenting on those aspects of what has been said that refer to what may or may not have happened at the mill itself. I am just unable to respond to them, but I long for the day. The Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) will, I am sure, be taking prompt action on this. Given that we received a first report on the nineteenth, a second report on the twenty-fifth and had that report, together with the thoughts of officers of the Department of the Attorney-General, on the sixteenth does not suggest tardiness. It suggests that we have been moving fairly quickly. I would hope that all honourable senators understand that fact.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that in the answer I tabled the other day the thrust of Senator Mac- donald's questions on the creditors in Ravenshoe are answered. There are several paragraphs that refer to those matters. However, I will check the wording of the original questions and if the statements are unsatisfactory, I will look into it. It is apparent that at least parts of the second question are not answered. I accept that from what was read out and I will get those answers for the honourable senator tomorrow. I will take to Mrs Kelly the concerns that he has put forward about the people in Ravenshoe because I share those concerns. I am just not certain that it will be possible to address them. The main point made in the answer is that what has happened with those creditors is not as a result of World Heritage listing, but of what has occurred at the mill since. There is a big difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is convoluted logic.

—There is nothing convoluted about it and no-one would ever attempt to put logic to Senator Boswell; that is simply not on. It is a serious matter, and I will take it up with the Minister and provide a further answer.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Michael Baume proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The bleak job prospects facing thousands of Australian school leavers completing their secondary education this week resulting from the Hawke/Keating government's failed policy of reliance on excessively high interest rates which have had a disastrous impact on youth unemployment, pushing it up since February by more than one-third so that one in every five workers under 20 years old is now out of a job-the worst September figure for three years.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-
