TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In accordance with agreement reached between the Whips of the respective parties, the time allocated for each speaker on the matter of public importance will be as follows: Senator Michael Baume, 15 minutes; Senator Bolkus, 10 minutes; Senator Spindler, 8 minutes; Senator Walters, 10 minutes; Senator Sherry, 10 minutes and Senator Bell, 7 minutes. I ask that the clock be set accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no more grievous measure of a government's incompetence than the failure of that government to provide an environment in which young people can get jobs. This matter of public importance is:

SPEECH.PARA: The bleak job prospects facing thousands of Australian school leavers completing their secondary education this week resulting from the Hawke/Keating government's failed policy of reliance on excessively high interest rates which have had a disastrous impact on youth unemployment, pushing it up since February by more than one-third so that one in every five workers under 20 years old is now out of a job-the worst September figure for three years.
Let us look at the statistics. I know that is not something the Government would be terribly attracted to, but let us look at the facts behind this matter of public importance.

The raw figures-the original series, not mucked around with for seasonal adjustment or anything else-show that, instead of the usual fall in youth unemployment from the beginning of the year, this year there has been an increase. Every year there is a fall in youth unemployment, but not this year. This year it has gone up from January's 18.5 per cent to September's 19.7 per cent. Compare that with the youth unemployment figures of the alleged disaster years of the Fraser Government, particularly 1982, which we keep hearing about from those on the Government side. In the last year of the Fraser Government-this Government keeps referring to that period as a disaster-in exactly the same period, unemployment fell from 21.3 per cent in January to 18.7 per cent in September.

Let me stress that, on the raw figures, this September has a worse youth unemployment rate than the worst ever year under the Fraser Government. This is absolutely appalling. This trend clearly is under way before we see the worst impacts of this Government's disastrous high interest rate policies-according at least to the Budget. It has forecast for the current financial year a 32 per cent increase in unemployment benefits.

Let us look at the seasonally adjusted figures. These are the ones which statisticians would say are the fairer to look at. They show that so far this year-let us just take the figures from February; January and February have the same seasonally adjustment figures, so it is immaterial-there has been a one-third increase in the unemployment rate in Australia. That is a far faster rise than took place in any comparable period under the Fraser Government.

The figures, seasonally adjusted, for the same period in 1982 show there was about a 13 per cent increase in youth unemployment. The Australian Labor Party went off its face about that. Why are we not hearing the heroes of the Labor Party, who protested so violently at a 13 per cent increase in unemployment in the same period of 1982, complaining about this one-third increase in youth unemployment from 15.4 per cent in February to 20.8 per cent in September? Why do we not hear those cries of protest?

The fact is now that the rate of youth unemployment is three times the rate of adult unemployment. Youth are in the firing line of this Government's economic policies. They are being bowled over in terms of jobs at an appalling rate. The young people who are in their final year at school, year 12, now preparing for their final examinations, have a bleak outlook under this Government. It is appalling that we have had so little comment from the Government. On the contrary, we have had some misleading information from the Government on this matter. Even if we look at the trend figures, we see a huge one-third rise. The trend figures-that is, the statistical trend figures put out by the Australian Statistician-generally tend to diminish the size of swings in official statistics; but not in this case. The trend to disaster is so large that there has now been an increase in unemployment for people aged 15 years to 19 years looking for full time work from 15.2 per cent to 20.4 per cent-in other words, a one-third increase.

By the way, that nine-month rise this year is equal to the total rise in the trend figures for the whole of 1982, which, according to the Government, was a Fraser disaster year. If we are now doing worse than Fraser's disaster, what will the Government do about it? That is a real question. The Government does not apparently know about it; or, at least, it will not admit that it knows about it. It was only a few weeks ago that I asked Senator Richardson this question:

What level of youth unemployment-that is, among those between 15 and 19 years old-is incorporated in the Government's Budget forecast for unemployment benefit payments this financial year? What percentage of the 32 per cent budgeted rise in unemployment benefits is forecast to go to unemployed youth?
Naturally, the answer from Senator Richardson, as the responsible Minister-the Minister for Social Security-was:
. . . I do not know but I will find out.
When he found out, his answer was that he did not know. He said:
. . . that Budget estimates of unemployment and the number of unemployment beneficiaries are prepared by the Treasury, which does not give a breakdown by age group.

This Government apparently has no idea whatsoever of what youth employment will be this year. It is incredible. These are the worst possible figures we have seen for the rise in youth unemployment. Maybe I should not say that, as we will probably see worse figures in coming months. Yet, the Government does not know and apparently has no idea what is likely to happen to youth unemployment under its disastrous policies.

I say that the Government does not know what is happening because Senator Richardson, in response to my question about this growth in youth unemployment, which I raised on 11 September, replied-and I hope that it was an innocent misleading of the Parliament; no doubt it was, because I do not think Government senators do know:
This growth is easing at present and is consistent with Budget estimates.
Is that not extraordinary? He went on to say that, for example, between 3 August and 7 September the number of JSA-that is, job search allowance recipients-declined a little. He went on:

The increase in the number of people on unemployment benefit, including JSA, has been trending down over the last month. The increase in the last week ending 7 September was 1,200 compared with an average increase in the last month of 1,800 per week.

Trending down! There must have been a disaster in the last few weeks of September that the Government had no knowledge of because for the full month of September there was, in fact, an increase in both the seasonally adjusted and the raw figures. So it was trending down in the beginning of September. What happened at the end of September? Without any doubt at all, it does seem that this Government simply does not know what is happening with regard to youth unemployment.

Senator Richardson's response to me-it was a prepared response, delivered not at Question Time but a couple of days later-indicates quite clearly a monumental level of incompetence which, in effect, is a heartless refusal to recognise one of the great disasters that this Government has brought to the young people of Australia.

However, there is no doubt that the Government has been able to generate those magic words `a consensus' in this area. There is a consensus that the Government has made a mess of it. The captains of industry, people such as Sir Arvi Parbo and Nobby Clark, and bodies such as the Confederation of Australian Industry clearly believe that the Government's economic policies have failed. In the left wing Senator Bruce Childs, Frank Walker and Peter Duncan have publicly stated that the Government, or certainly Mr Keating, has made a mess of it. The more moderate Labor leaders, such as Bob Carr in New South Wales and Rosemary Follett in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), believe that the Government has made a mess of it.

Archbishop Hollingworth clearly believes that Mr Hawke has made a mess of it, so much so that Mr Hawke has once again gone off his face and insulted the Archbishop, simply because the Archbishop had the hide to say that it was clear that child poverty was getting worse. In fact, he said that child poverty was probably now marginally worse because of the continued pressure on families of high mortgage rates and high rents. Of course, that was enough to enrage the Prime Minister because it struck home. Journalists as far apart in ideology as Ken Davidson and Terry McCrann are saying that the Government is totally wrong.

Back in the 1950s and 1960s, we were able to resolve youth unemployment. It was not the serious matter that it is now. So there must be a response. There must be a way of resolving the problem. When we look at what is happening, we see that the simple way of resolving it is clear cut, apart from, of course, ending this Government's absurd reliance on high interest rates. Only a couple of months ago, we had Rosemary Follett, the Labor Leader in the ACT, saying:
Youth unemployment in the ACT is a `disgrace' . . . More than 25 per cent of the territory's young people were without a job . . .
Only last month an article in the West Australian read:
Embattled employers are sacking young workers when they turn 18 as the economic recession bites in WA.
The WA Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Confederation of WA Industry say young, inexperienced workers are the biggest victims of the recession.
A spokesman of the Commonwealth Employment Service said:
Unskilled school leavers would find it tough . . .
Perhaps we could associate that-although the Labor Party might not like this-with the fact that just a month before there was a press release revealing the following:
Hundreds of teenage workers in fast-food outlets have been granted pay rises of up to 62 per cent after a landmark decision in Western Australia's Industrial Relations Commission.
The union describes the increases as the biggest in the hospitality industry in Western Australia and possibly in the whole country.

The Government cannot pretend that there is no link between increasing wages, relative to other employees, for youth and the massively increasing level of youth unemployment. Of course, that was brought out in 1983 in the Bureau of Labour Market Research report, Youth Wages, Employment and the Workforce. It found out-this must have been embarrassing for the Government; it did nothing with the report and abandoned the body-the following:
. . . virtually all studies confirm that increases in youth wages relative to those of other groups decrease employment of youth.
As my former colleague John Hyde so rightly said:
This conspiracy against the young is, arguably, the strongest single indictment of the way we run Australia.

What is the Government doing about it? It has had a failed community employment program, a disastrous Priority One program, and an Australian traineeship scheme which was supposed to have 75,000 people coming into it this year but the intake is expected to be 16,000. There has been non-stop failure. The Government and its Ministers must indicate that they have concern, have a plan of action and know what on earth is going on. Will the figures get worse? If the Government does not believe that they are going to get worse, can it explain why not? If they do get worse, what is the Government going to do about it? Until the school leavers of Australia have some coherent response to that, they have every reason to be terrified by this Government's policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a sad contribution to the debate. This afternoon we are talking about a problem that is of concern to the Government. It is sad because of the hypocrisy that has flowed from the Opposition in raising this issue in the way that it has been raised and with the contribution that we have just heard. It is raised at this moment because, in essence, all the Opposition seeks to do is cover up the grand exposure yesterday of the inadequacy of the Opposition in the area of social issues. It has been exposed as being totally inept in this area, as not applying itself and as not caring, but its spokesman comes in here today with a set of figures and a purely political argument, something that the people out there, especially those concerned, really do not want to hear. They do not want to know about petty politics in the Senate, and that is what they have got this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition comes in here pretending to care, to be concerned and to have a prescription for the future when it knows that it is totally inept and that the policies it puts forward will be even more damaging to the people it pretends to care about. Dr Hewson has been exposed as wanting to do away with not only the Department of Social Security but also the department of education-the two departments that most affect the people that we are talking about this afternoon and that most impact on youth. What sort of policy is that?

What we have at the moment and what we have seen this afternoon is nothing more than policy prescriptions emanating from economic bovver boys who are finding their way through political puberty. They are doing it very slowly. The economic theory is easy, but it should be put in a social context. If it is not in the economic model, it just does not rate with the Opposition at all. With this new Opposition policy direction, as Opposition members achieve political puberty, we are seeing the economics of rejecting people to a prejudicial scrap heap.

That is the sort of policy that the Australian people have to keep in mind when they listen to contributions such as the one we just heard. It is a policy of dismembering social infrastructure, reducing the sorts of kids that we are talking about to the scrap heap and to reliance on bush biscuits and Vegemite from the local sisters of charity. When one tosses in those sorts of policies with the Opposition's oft stated policy of deregulating the labour market for youth, what has one got? One might as well put the kids up the chimneys in the homes in Bellevue Hill. What does an overlay of the Opposition's general economic direction and an economic policy without a wages policy-we all know that it has no wages policy-lead to? It leads to a greater reliance on the policy of high unemployment.

Those opposite should not come in here without a social policy, without an unemployment policy and without an economic policy and preach that they are concerned about children. We have seen what has happened in the past and we can see that the prescription for the future is not all that much different. We even see it exposed in the motion brought on for debate this afternoon.

Let us look at the numbers. The motion refers to one in every five workers looking for a job-a cynical extraction from a pile of documents and a pile of figures. Full-time unemployment as a proportion of the teenage population has dropped from 12.4 per cent in April 1983 down to 7.5 per cent now. It is almost a 50 per cent reduction. That is an important figure which those on the other side choose to ignore. If they want to make a comparison with 1983, they should look at the real statistics and look at the context of what we are talking about.

Let us look further at the motion. It refers to the thousands of Australian school leavers completing their secondary education this week. I will be kind to Senator Michael Baume. I think what he means to say is that they might have finished classes this week. He is talking about year 12 students. They have not finished their exams and there is no way in the world they have finished their schooling this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it didn't say that; it said education.

—One does not finish one's education and then have examination. Maybe Senator Michael Baume did and that is why the contribution that we got earlier on is the same as we are getting now. We are talking about what prescription this Government got for the people involved. This Government has been enormously successful--
—What about--

—It is a pity that these policies did not apply in Senator Walters's time. This Government has been enormously successful at raising the level of participation of young people in education, especially in the later years of school education and tertiary education. We have almost doubled the number of people who stay at school until the school leaving age from a 36 per cent base in 1983 to over 60 per cent now, and it is still growing. There is nothing more important for a kid's future than to be able to get as much education as possible. The way in which these people develop their lives will be an enormous contribution to the social environment. Members of the Opposition should not come in here and say that this Government has no concern and has done nothing for them.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another major comparison. I know I have only a few minutes left. Whereas in 1983 these kids were put on the scrap heap with no recognition of their problems and no support, this Government has a number of programs in place to change that. With Austudy the Labor Government has made sure that people in low income families are not forced to leave school for economic reasons. For the people who left school early in order to get a job, our emphasis on training ensures that they have a decent career path, that they are not left with dead end jobs. For those who have become unemployed, we have introduced Jobstart. Rather than have them simply passively living on social security, active training measures ensure that these people are not trapped into a cycle of poverty as they were in the late 1970s and the early 1980s.

We on this side of the House understand the effect of unemployment on young people. We understand the lifestyle and culture that they fall into, and we are concerned and have put heaps of money into programs to ensure that these kids get mentally, if not physically, active. We have the social structure and we have applied ourselves to ensure that the forums, services and structures of government respond to the need and anticipate the need. We have integrated and developed the programs in various departments-the Department of Social Security, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in particular. These are the departments that those hypocrites on the other side, who come in here with crocodile tears, want to destroy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The Minister has just described us on this side as hypocrites. I do not believe it advances either his case, the dignity of the House, or his own standing in this place. I ask him to withdraw it.
—I withdraw.
—The Minister has withdrawn.

—They are the very departments that these political, economic bovver boys, led by Dr Hewson, want to knock off altogether. What sort of caring is that? What sort of social structure do they give kids? As I said before, when they toss that in with their economic policies without a wages policy they will find, as we found in 1982 and 1983, in the last 12 months when the coalition was government that the parents of 500,000 kids were without jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite found then that there was no social infrastructure. That will not happen under this Government. Those opposite represent the policies of the last century. Senator Michael Baume's contribution today is a very sad one; it is a parasitical one. It bleeds and sucks off the problems out in the community. He does not come in here with a policy prescription; he comes in here puffing his chest up, wanting to score political points. That is not the sort of tactic that wins friends and votes in the community. For those opposite it has lost them friends and votes out there four times in a row. What they have to do, what their leader has to do, and what those intellectual midgets on that side of the House have to do, is respond to the problems of the 1980s and the 1990s into the next century.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at the polls.

—We looked at the polls 12 months before the last election and we saw the result thereafter. Next time round those opposite will get a greater drubbing than they got last time, and a bigger one in Tasmania, because the electorate will wake up to them. We will give those opposite enough time to get back home so that the electorate will get to know them for a start.

SPEECH.PARA: The policies those opposite represent are the policies of the last century. The sorts of institutions and structures they want to destroy are important for the continuation of the real fabric of our society. So what do they do? Through their social policy, their economic policy, and their employment policy, they would reduce these kids basically to living off the scrap heap. Brian Howe gave them some great advice yesterday: Forget the prejudices; forget the easy way out; do some hard work on social policy. Those opposite should try to bring it into their mental framework and should try to adapt their economic policy to the needs of this nation. They come in here preaching deregulation and bring on motions such as this-a total inconsistency. They leave the field open for the knee-jerk policies of prejudice. They are the New Right merchants of work for the dole. They have shown time and time again that they do not care, they cannot respond and they cannot see into the future.

What really disgusts me about this afternoon is the parasitical nature of this sort of cynical exercise. Members of the Opposition were exposed in the House of Representatives yesterday as being inadequate and uncaring. All this matter of public importance does today is confirm and entrench in the minds of those listening the inadequacy of the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. Before I call Senator Spindler, I remind the Minister and, indeed, all honourable senators that Standing Orders require senators to address the Chair and not to address individual senators or even to address the other side of the House. I call Senator Spindler.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: — In the short time available to me, I intend to address particularly the Government's economic policies. My colleague Senator Robert Bell will then address the effects of that policy on our young people in greater detail. I will lead off by quoting from a document:

SPEECH.PARA: At this point in Australia's history there is an overwhelming need for realistic and practical policies which are grounded on an understanding of our circumstances.
It is not a time for empty rhetoric or glib wonderful world solutions.

Honourable senators have guessed it-the author is Mr Paul Keating. The quote is from his economic statement of February 1990. I should have paraphrased it and used the singular `a wonderful world solution' because, in effect, we have been confronted with a single monetary policy-high interest rates. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has so often reminded us, the objective is to get the overseas debt down. To do this we must lessen imports and increase exports and the only way to go is to have high interest rates. The people trying to buy homes and the people trying to run a small business had to pay for the Government's single policy to have high interest rates as the one blunt instrument in trying to get the debt down. To do that it felt that it had to throttle the whole economy. Now that the genie is well and truly out of the bottle and we are harvesting the effects of that policy with a deepening recession, the Government is desperately trying to get that genie back into the bottle. Unfortunately, it might have some problems. The community as a whole, particularly young people, are bearing the burden.

Let me compare our interest rates for the last two or three years, which were hovering around an effective 20 per cent in most areas, to the interest rates that were obtaining in other countries. In the United States interest rates were 9 per cent; Switzerland, 6 per cent; Japan, 7 per cent; and Belgium, Canada, Denmark and France, 10 per cent. Approximately half of the interest rates that we had to contend with in Australia were all in the interests of the single item policy-to get the foreign debt down.

The results of that policy are now becoming apparent. Bankruptcies have risen by 12 per cent in the current year. Emergency relief applications have risen by 50 per cent, and unemployment has risen from 500,000 in September 1989 to 627,000 in September 1990. The unemployment level for those under 20 years is now at 20 per cent. As I said, my colleague Senator Robert Bell will deal with that in greater detail.

The Treasurer has often stated that the Government is not pursuing a scorched earth monetary policy. If that is not a scorched earth policy, I wonder what is. The bad news is obviously only just beginning and it will continue to get worse. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has often stated that unemployment is the major cause of poverty. We are now seeing that trend harvesting greater poverty among children and the community as a whole.

We saw how the Prime Minister reacted yesterday when a respected community leader, Archbishop Hollingworth, drew his attention to the ill effects of the high interest rate policy. He reacted by making a personal attack. I believe that that sort of reaction from the Prime Minister is not worthy of his stature and it is certainly not worthy of the problems facing our community which we must address.

I would like to turn to the alternatives that the Government had available had it not subscribed so solidly to the deregulation policy, which is a policy shared by the Opposition parties. It is all very well for the Opposition to say that we should not have high interest rates, but it has not offered an alternative. In fact, it supported the Government in the early stages of that policy-until now when it becomes apparent that it is mistaken and that the community is paying for it.

But there was no suggestion, for instance, that we should slow down tariff reductions to protect our producers and employment in Australia and discourage imports by that measure. There was no suggestion, certainly by the Liberal Party, that we should review our anti-dumping provisions. Senator Boswell is obviously having a hard struggle in convincing his coalition partners that we need an inquiry into anti-dumping procedures. I wish him well. If he does not succeed, the Australian Democrats will pick up the cudgels and take some initiatives in that area.

There has been no suggestion that we should discourage overseas loans by Australian companies-that we should perhaps put a halt to borrowing large amounts for paper shuffling, unproductive take- overs. There has been no suggestion-and I am still waiting for an answer to my question several days ago to the Minister representing the Treasurer, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button)-that we should increase the withholding tax on interest paid to overseas lenders. This is an easy method which does not affect Australian borrowers and Australian companies: it affects foreign lenders.

The withholding tax, which is now at 10 per cent-that is laughable-could easily be increased to 15 per cent, which is the rate normally set by reciprocal trade and financial agreements. But there are countries which have no such agreement with Australia and the withholding tax could easily be raised to a higher point. As a first step, I have suggested to the Government that it might like to remove the exemptions from the withholding tax which currently apply to debentures which are raised overseas. But there has been no response. The Government is not prepared-and, I regret to say, the Opposition is not prepared-to look at alternatives.

Another major area to look at is fiscal policy and raising tax revenue. The only fiscal policy trend that both the Government and the Opposition can look at is cutting community services in needy areas. They are not prepared to look at raising additional revenue. One could see that by the hubbub I caused yesterday when I suggested that it would be useful social policy to raise the tax rate for incomes above $100,000 to 60 per cent. That was an impossibility in their minds, yet that measure would have raised $600m. A wealth tax at one per cent on assets above $1m would raise $500m. But I know that would just about cause a revolution on the Opposition benches. What about an increased tax on tobacco, alcohol or woodchips?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: -It was only this morning that once again we were told that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Government were out of touch with what is happening on the ground among the poor in our community. That was stated by Bruce MacKenzie, Senior Lecturer on Social Science at Deakin University. Again, we had the spectacle of the Prime Minister attacking the Most Rev. Peter Hollingworth, accusing him of economic ignorance because he dared to tell the truth regarding that section of the community that is rightly the responsibility of the church. If Archbishop Hollingworth has not the right to speak out about the increasing poverty of children in Australia, and his view that this is being escalated by the high interest rate policy of the Government, who on earth has? I quote from the Australian newspaper:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke ridiculed the Archbishop, saying he undoubtedly understood the Holy Trinity, but knew nothing of the `unholy trinity': wages, fiscal and monetary policy.
This outburst was the result of the Archbishop's statement that he stood by his comments that child poverty was getting worse. I would now like to quote from the Sydney Morning Herald:

The archbishop said that, since his celebrated clash with Mr Hawke in June, child poverty was probably now marginally worse because of the continued pressure on families from high mortgage rates and high rents.
This attack on Archbishop Hollingworth follows the Prime Minister's earlier abuse on him last June when Mr Hawke said of Archbishop Hollingworth's comments:
. . . it's just an unchristian bloody statement . . . it's a grossly irresponsible bloody statement.
He told Archbishop Hollingworth:
You ought to be ashamed of yourself.

Mr Hawke's fury and indiscretions, to put it politely, are a result of his promise at the previous election that no child would be living in poverty by 1990. Of course he knows that not only has he not succeeded but also that Archbishop Hollingworth was right; child poverty is increasing because of the Prime Minister's deliberate policies.

Let us look at what is happening with youth unemployment. I have before me a report on teenagers in the labour market by Russell Ross. It is an analysis of the Australian Bureau of Statistics' data for the period between 1983 and 1988. The Government has been in power for the whole of that period. The report states:

The evidence is that, despite the general improvement in the labour market, teenagers have fared very badly over the last five years . . . . The relative position of teenagers, i.e. those persons 15-19 years old, has deteriorated over this period.
The report goes on to explain that between 1983 and 1988 the employment level of teenagers has gone down by 1.4 per cent. The report states:
Full-time employment among teenagers actually fell in absolute terms due to a decline in female employment . . .

Teenage female employment went down by 3.9 per cent. Female full time employment rose steadily until 1986 and then subsequently collapsed with the loss of 25,000 full time jobs in the final 24 months leading up to March 1988. There was a net loss of full time employment among teenage women over that period.

The report goes on to state further figures, which are really quite disastrous. But as the report says, this is only the tip of the iceberg, because any teenager who is employed for just a few hours a week is regarded as being employed. This of course creates the hidden unemployment of all those seeking a full time job. The hiding of those figures is just staggering.

That 1988 report is now several years old. We are all aware of what has happened in the interval-things have got much worse. Unemployment generally has increased, but teenage unemployment-that is, people aged between 15 and 19-is now a disaster. Teenage unemployment increased from 15.5 per cent in August 1988 to 16.5 per cent in August 1990. I have the latest figures-the September figures-before me, and they are even worse. One in every five 15- to 19-year-old is out of a job.

Yesterday we saw an attack on Dr Hewson by Mr Keating. Mr Keating said that, because Dr Hewson wanted to save the costs of duplication incurred by the Federal departments so that more money could be spent on those in the social welfare area, he did not have a morsel of compassion. Yet the poverty-the Very Reverend Archbishop Hollingworth talks about it in the report I have just quoted from-plus the worsening figures I have quoted, are a direct result of the policies of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister

There is no use the Government trying to duck for cover on this issue; the direct blame is entirely at its feet. We have headlines saying, `Hawke Era Worst since World War I'. The Treasurer should read the Burdekin report entitled Our Homeless Children: Report of the National Inquiry into Homeless Children. The Burdekin report told us that youth unemployment is the single most frequent factor associated with homelessness. The report gives the case of a homeless youth, James, a 19-year-old. James was presented to the inquiry on 2 September. The report states:

He was not streetwise and needed a bed until he could find a job and get a place to live. He was exceptionally motivated and made every attempt to find work . . . However, we could not find accommodation for James outside Kings Cross because generally refuges do not accept people over the age of 18. As disillusionment with his failure to get work grew, James became more acquainted with the Cross, more acquainted with the street life and he began using drugs . . . On the 26th of the ninth, that is three and a half weeks after arriving on our doorstep, James left us to go to a squat. In three and a half weeks that highly motivated person was on the street using drugs . . .

That is the net result of this Government's economic policies. If Mr Keating were to get out to look at those areas-go to the Cross and look at the places that the Burdekin inquiry members looked at; look at the places that members of my Committee looked at when reporting on homeless youth-he would understand the final result of his harsh policies. It is no use his saying that it is not the fault of government, as Senator Bolkus said today; Mr Keating has to get down to the street level and visit the areas to find out just what is happening.

Mr Bruce MacKenzie is quite right-the Government is out of touch with what is happening on the ground. All those welfare organisations that tell us that more and more people are coming to them seeking their help are also saying this to the Government, but it is not listening. It is the Treasurer and the Prime Minister who do not have a morsel of compassion for the unemployed youth. This is what this debate is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I commence, I will respond to that last comment by Senator Walters. This Government does have great compassion; it does care. It is unfortunately a side product of a capitalist economic system in which we live, and in which I accept we live, that, to some degree or other, there is always a level of unemployment. It has not mattered who has been in government in any Western democratic nation, over the last 100 years there have been varying degrees of unemployment, whether it has been a labour, liberal or conservative government in power. Whilst I certainly do not like unemployment-I have a vehement hatred of the consequences of that unemployment-it does not mean that this Government does not care and that it does not have a program to combat the evils of the effect of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation as outlined by previous speakers on the other side is not as grim as they would have us believe. Teenage unemployment has always been at a higher level than that of the rest of the labour market. There are good reasons for that. There is a far higher job mobility amongst younger persons; it is 24.5 per cent. That of adults is 19.1 per cent. In our society, there is also a tendency, in any economic recession or depression, for the principle of last on, first off to apply. This inevitably means that young persons are more adversely affected. Having said that, we do not excuse what is happening in our economic system. The important thing is to have the policies to respond to those particular problems. This Government has those policies. It has made the very best attempt it can to address the emerging problems.

I would like to draw the Senate's attention to a number of policies that the Hawke Labor Government has initiated in its 10 years. It is not a matter of simple, empty rhetoric, or of crying tears; it is a matter of doing what is needed to try to minimise the effects of unemployment, particularly youth unemployment.

I draw the attention of the Senate to a wide range of programs to assist people to obtain skills and employment. In recent years, many separate support arrangements have been consolidated into an integrated program, which recognises the different circumstances and needs of Australian job seekers and provides local labour markets. These programs include Jobstart. The Jobstart program helps disadvantaged job seekers to find work by providing wage subsidies to private sector workers. Despite strong employment growth since 1983, some groups in the labour market continue to find it difficult to gain and keep a job. Jobstart assists these disadvantaged people by providing subsidised work experience for up to 20 weeks. The 20-week subsidy rates depend on the job seeker's age and type of disadvantage.

Needy and disadvantaged groups on the labour market include the long term unemployed, disabled people, overseas born job seekers who have English language difficulties or who experience cultural barriers in getting a job, Aborigines, Torres Strait Islanders and sole parents. Since 1983 this Government, with Jobstart and other wage subsidy programs, has helped 434,000 people obtain jobs. In 1990-91, $72m has been allocated to Jobstart for an estimated 44,000 new places.

Jobtrain is another Federal Labor Government training initiative. It provides long term unemployed and disadvantaged job seekers with short term vocational training, closely linked to the needs of both the individual and the local job market. In 1991, funds for job training will be increased to $120.9m.

Newstart is a major initiative to help retain and re-employ people who are out of work for more than 12 months. The Government has allocated $85m for the next financial year to assist 43,999 persons under the Newstart program. All people aged 21 to 54 who have been unemployed for 12 months or more are eligible for Newstart.

Each year 40,000 intensive interviews are jointly carried out by the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security. About 190,000 specialist information packages have been provided over 12 months for people in the target group. The guidelines have been relaxed to allow certain short courses to be undertaken while unemployed people remain on unemployment benefits. There are active job placement and community awareness strategies.

Under the jobs, education and training scheme-commonly known as JET-the Labor Government has a proud record of achievement in assisting sole parents. The JET scheme is one of the flagships of this strategy. It was established in 1989 to help sole parent pensioners obtain a job. Sole parents who want to take part in JET receive assistance including assessment of job barriers and prospects; referral to jobs; placement in training and education programs run by the Department of Employment, Education and Training; and child-care. A recent review of JET demonstrated a high level of appreciation for the program among sole parents. In 1990-91 12,000 people a year will be assisted by the program at an estimated cost of $19m.

Concerning our active employment strategy, in February 1990 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced the next logical step in completing the move towards an integrated active system to abolish the unemployment benefit and replace it with a payment system which more clearly projects the Government's labour market objectives both in name and in terms of structured links to labour market assistance, opportunity and client obligation. It is proposed to replace the unemployment benefit with a new active income support structure comprising two separate payments: a job search allowance for eligible unemployed people aged 18 years and over for up to 12 months; and a Newstart allowance for those aged 18 and over who are unemployed for 12 months or more.

All of the above initiatives which represent an integrated employment, education and training strategy will be under threat if the Federal portfolios of Social Security and Employment, Education and Training are abolished, as is advocated by those opposite. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) demonstrates a staggering level of stupidity in suggesting that these programs, to name a few, could be devolved to voluntary agencies, the States or Territories or, more likely, abolished.

Perhaps our biggest achievement has been to obtain a greater employer commitment to training workers with a training guarantee. The training guarantee legislation which came into effect on 1 July requires employers, both private and public, with an annual payroll in excess of $200,000 to spend at least the equivalent of one per cent of payroll on structured training every year from 1 July 1990.

This Government does have a clear direction in terms of targeting need and assistance to unemployed persons. It is simply not good enough to give persons who are unemployed money; they have to be given assistance and direction in obtaining job skills to secure jobs.

Contrast this with the policies of the Opposition. The Liberal-National Party response, as projected by the Leader of the Opposition, is to blame the bureaucracy for swallowing up money which should be going to the genuinely needy. His suggestion is that we devolve all this to the States. There seems to be a basic contradiction: we will end up having more State bureaucrats doing what one bureaucracy does at the present time. He does not explain where all the money is going to be found to employ the bureaucrats, but he probably does not have to because the reality is that the Opposition will not continue to fund the sorts of initiatives that this Government has commenced for unemployed persons. The Opposition's basic philosophy is: scrap all this sort of assistance.

The Leader of the Opposition recently reaffirmed this in radio and television interviews. He said on the ABC PM radio program, `Do we really need Federal departments of social security, health and education?' I would say very strongly that we do need departments such as those departments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be so selective.

—We do need departments such as them. If we do not have departments performing the tasks that these departments carry out, where are the unemployed to receive assistance? To simply suggest, as Dr Hewson does, that the voluntary agencies can take care of it, and that it can be palmed off to the States and Territories with the resulting lack of coordination and, probably-almost certainly-a lack of funding in those areas, is simply not good enough. The reality is that those opposite have no solutions to the problems; it is empty rhetoric.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I came down here to listen to this debate thinking we were discussing a matter of public importance, and that I would hear contributions from either side-from the old parties-which might shed new light on this problem which, Senator Sherry has assured us, has been with us for some time; but I return to the first impression I had when reading the letter presenting the matter of public importance. My first question was: Is the Opposition really interested in youth unemployment or is it, as is transparently obvious here today, only a vehicle for the Opposition to tackle the Government's monetary policies? What we have seen and heard this afternoon has confirmed my first impression.

SPEECH.PARA: I was hoping, as perhaps Senator Sherry was too, to hear some alternatives from the Opposition. If it was genuinely interested, and genuinely thought that this would be a matter of public importance, I think we would have been given some alternatives. Senator Spindler, in his contribution, was stopped mid-stream by lack of time when he was wheeling out dozens of opportunities to act on this and achieve something useful.

The letter contains the accusation that the anxiety which the Opposition feels for Australian school leavers about their employment prospects is a result of the Hawke-Keating Government's failed policy of reliance on high interest rates. Yes, youth unemployment is a real problem and is a tragic waste of our young potential. Any figures-no matter where they come from-highlight the appalling number of young people who are without conventional work.

The contributions so far have described the problem and argued about statistics. This letter has attributed the problem to interest rates, and we have not heard anything else. The arguments that we have heard about statistics were comparing statistics and figures from Senator Michael Baume earlier-seasonally adjusted participation rates. We even had an argument about whether school finishes this week or on Christmas Day or something. I do not think that is the matter that should be discussed; it has nothing to do with it. In fact, there is a lot more to it than statistics. Rather than describe the problem-which is what the Opposition did-in an endless morass of statistics, I hoped that we could have had some strategy and alternative solutions; but we did not.

I suggest that interest rates are not the sole cause of youth unemployment. They are certainly influential. For example, they have an immediate impact on the building industry, which does take in a considerable amount of unskilled or semi-skilled labour. It is where young people are able to make a start in employment in many cases. But interest rates are not the start and end of it. The Government's so-called youth strategy is, in fact, a dismal failure. Part of that failure is that although we have a policy to increase school retention rates-and that has worked in a way, in that it has kept people at school-it should be recognised straight away that that, in fact, delays the time when unemployment might be reached. As has been recognised, in fact, it creates hidden unemployment. Because young people are still at school, they are not on the unemployment list, and that provides an addition to the unemployment rate eventually, unless training and work programs are also in place.

The Government claims to have-I have lost track of the last lot-the RED scheme, the CYSS scheme, the EPUY scheme, the CEP scheme, the Priority One scheme, the Jobstart scheme, the JET scheme, and the last thing we got was integrated active unemployment income support-I forget. It is ridiculous, and I think people who are involved in this area cannot fathom it either. Rather than come up with a lot of mumbo jumbo about titles, schemes and things, what this Government should be doing is providing a tangible, real alternative to the present muck-up.

Senator Spindler launched off into a group of policies which could lead to an improvement in our employment situation. I would hope that this Government, rather than be tangled up in debating the issue of the statistics and where they came from and which season they were adjusted to, would give some credence to what Senator Spindler offered. Perhaps we could then have a debate on the usefulness or otherwise of some of the suggestions the Democrats have been making for years. I would hope that these would not be buried in statistics and the argument about whether the statistics are accurate or not, but rather about whether the programs, whether the initiatives, might achieve the goals that should be shared by all Australians. It is frustrating to be a member of our Australian community and to see so much of what we could achieve tangled up in schemes and statistics which categorise people as being either employed or unemployed.

I would like to challenge the definition of employed or unemployed. It is like suggesting that some people are worthy of support and other people need to be cut off, disregarded and thrown on the rubbish heap. To do that is to ignore the potential productivity that this country has. To do that is most unwise and we cannot continue to do it any longer. I would hope to see us follow some reforms such as slowing down the rate of our tariff reductions, reviewing our anti-dumping provisions, discouraging overseas loans for paper shuffling ventures, and subsequent repayments to overseas countries for totally unproductive ventures. I would like to see an increase in withholding tax on the payments made to overseas lenders. We could see some fiscal policy alternatives, especially raising revenue instead of just shuffling paper.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, are you sure that an hour has expired? This is a matter about which I have had a considerable amount to say over a period of time and I have a considerable interest in it. As I understood it, when I saw Senator Michael Baume on his feet it was five minutes to four.
