DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON TENURE OF APPOINTEES TO COMMONWEALTH TRIBUNALS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Tenure of Appointees to Commonwealth Tribunals and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address some remarks to the motion moved by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook. The response by the Government is to a report of the Joint Select Committee on Tenure of Appointees to Commonwealth Tribunals. That was a committee set up early last year and which reported to this Parliament at the end of November last year. I was a member of that Committee and I propose to make some comments largely in that capacity, rather than on behalf of the Opposition which of course has not had an opportunity of studying the response.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the response is an important and a valuable one, because it does indicate a very wide measure of agreement between the Government and the recommendations of the Committee. The Committee had been asked in its terms of reference to determine principles which would govern the tenure of office that covers the wide area of appointment, conditions, term and length of appointments, salaries, and removal of appointees. So the principles would cover all those matters which were addressed by the Committee.

The pleasing thing about the response is that the Government has agreed, in most cases, with the recommendations of the Committee as to what the principles should be. The Committee did not propose any major statutory changes to existing Acts, although it suggested that consideration should be given to embodying the principles it laid down in an Act of Parliament. The Government does not agree with that but if agreement can be reached, which looks very likely as a result of the response of the Government, then perhaps resolutions could be agreed to in both Houses of Parliament about these principles, which I think would be sufficient. It would not be necessary to actually have an Act of Parliament which, of course, Parliament could itself amend at any later date. For that reason, as the Government points out, it is probably not a satisfactory way of handling the matter.

The genesis of the establishment of this Joint Select Committee was the Government's decision not to reappoint the former Mr Justice Staples to the newly established Australian Industrial Relations Commission when it was re-established by legislation early last year. That Industrial Relations Commission was replacing the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of which Mr Justice Staples had been a member. His term had not expired at the time that the Commission was abolished. All the other deputy presidents of that former tribunal were reappointed to the new Industrial Relations Tribunal, except Mr Justice Staples.

It was that decision by the Government, and the controversy that was associated with it, which led both Houses of Parliament to set up this Committee. Its purpose was not to investigate the circumstances regarding the non-reappointment of Mr Staples but to lay down principles which should govern this situation. One of the principles that the Committee did indicate should be adopted was that where a tribunal is abolished and then restructured, all existing members of the tribunal should be reappointed to the replacing tribunal.

Therefore, the Committee did not support-in principle at all events-the fact that Mr Justice Staples was not reappointed. However, the Committee also went on to provide that where a tribunal is abolished and not replaced compensation should be paid to members of the tribunal who have lost their positions and for whom no alternative position is found. In giving effect to that, in regard to the situation of former Mr Justice Staples, the Committee recommended that the Government should establish an inquiry to determine the issue of compensation for former Justice Staples in view of his non-reappointment to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

The Government has more or less agreed to the principles laid down, that where a tribunal is abolished and a person is not reappointed to it or where a tribunal is not replaced, the question of compensation could be considered, although it said that this:
should be decided in the circumstances of the particular case and having regard to such matters as-
- whether or not the office was remunerated-
of course, in this case Mr Justice Staples clearly was-
- the period of any unexpired term-
Mr Justice Staples had an unexpired term-
-other benefits and opportunities available to the individual.
The Government's response says:
It would not be appropriate to provide for an automatic right to compensation.

It was with those matters in mind that the Committee recommended that there should be an inquiry to determine the issue of compensation. In other words, it may well have been that Mr Justice Staples had other means or other compensation available to him. The Committee was certainly not prepared to make a firm recommendation that it should pay compensation to him, only that it should establish an inquiry to do so. The Government has rejected that and has done so on the basis that there is provision in the new Industrial Relations (Consequential Provisions) Act which entitles former Justice Staples to a judicial pension. There is a specific provision to cover not his situation by name but the situation which had arisen in his case.

It is clear that former Justice Staples does receive a pension. However, that does not mean that he has not suffered financial loss because he would have had further years in his office if it had not been abolished. A pension, of course, is not as high as his salary and other conditions that he would have enjoyed had he continued. A question also arises as to whether he has opportunities for mitigating that loss by going back to practice and so forth. Those are all matters that would have to be considered. The Government has decided that it does not propose to give any further consideration to that matter or have any inquiry about it. That is really the only issue of any great significance with which the Government disagrees with the recommendations of the Committee.

I believe that is an unfortunate decision on the part of the Government and that the Government ought to give some consideration to that matter. In view of the fact that it has agreed that the question of compensation does arise and should be decided in the circumstances of every particular case, it seems extraordinary that the Government has decided that there should be no such consideration given to the situation of former Justice Staples.

However, apart from that difference in all important respects the Government has agreed with the principles laid down by the Committee. I believe that, in view of the very great importance-indeed, the growing importance in recent years-of quasi-judicial tribunals, these principles are laid down in respect of such tribunals only, not all Commonwealth tribunals. It is only those tribunals that are equated in their importance and status to the judicial system. They are known as quasi-judicial for that reason. There are a number of these tribunals, the most important being the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. There are a number of other such bodies, and no doubt Parliament will be creating other tribunals in the future.

It is important that there should be wide agreement within the Parliament and between the political parties about the status and the principles which should govern the status, terms of office, removal, et cetera, of the members of such tribunals. It is most important because of the need to attract people of the highest calibre to these tribunals. That is possible only if these people believe that they have protection from political interference and that they are looked at by the Parliament, though they are not judges, as performing work which is analogous to that of the judiciary.

We have not suggested that those people should be put on all fours with the judiciary. The Committee did not recommend that they should be given, in all cases, the same protection as judges have from removal because circumstances change from tribunal to tribunal and between different classes of members of such tribunals. It is not a simple matter to lay down detailed rules, but principles are important. The important thing about this response is that there is clearly wide agreement within the Parliament and between the Government and the Parliament on such an important matter as this. Apart from the qualification I have made in the case of former Justice Staples, the Opposition-and on a personal level, I-clearly welcome this response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — This is an important issue. All of what Senator Durack said is very pertinent and, in my view, correct. Senator Durack was the one who, in effect, chaired the Select Committee on Tenure of Appointees to Commonwealth Tribunals. The way he chaired that Committee deserves the highest praise. I think the effect of that has been brought out in the response that the Government has given to the various matters raised by the Committee. Indeed, the only matter that the Government has not accepted is that there ought to be compensation for former Justice Staples.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Durack said, that was directed not so much at whether or not Mr Justice Staples himself was a person who had been badly treated or otherwise, but rather at the principle that there ought to be on important tribunals a security of tenure so that the people who occupy those tribunals can do so without fear or favour and can proceed to their decision making untrammelled by any thought that they can be removed or that their tenure can be cut short.

It is important that that independence be assured. It was in that context that it was put that fair compensation ought be made as a means of ensuring that people's occupation of a tribunal could not be terminated lightly and that at least some cost-I think it is not a sufficient cost, of course; nevertheless it is some cost -could be imposed upon those who have the ability to appoint people to tribunals and on those who have the ability to set up tribunals and to abolish them. I think that was a part of ensuring some sort of sanction to see that that was properly done.

The other issue I want to speak about is this: Members of tribunals and decision-making bodies must remember that it is essential that they function according to the standards appropriate to the high offices they occupy. I think, as Senator Durack said, there is some concern that in this case a person was shut out of the work which he had been appointed to undertake without a reason ever being given for his being so shut out. When the appearance, at least, of capriciousness in the appointment to work is present, I think it is a matter of great concern.

The Government, quite rightly, said that there was not much it could do about it. I think that is absolutely correct, but I think the matter should not be set aside in Parliament and that Parliament ought to indicate that it hopes that the members and head of any tribunal should so conduct themselves that they act appropriately and are able to give to the community the service that the tribunal was set up to give and that the head of that tribunal was appointed to deliver.

I am not in this instance pointing to any tribunal; I am simply talking about the general principle. As a matter of general principle, any tribunal and any head of a tribunal should always keep in mind the high task which they were appointed to perform. Although in this particular instance, as the Government says, there is nothing it could do about the situation, I think it is appropriate that those matters be pointed out.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901 I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 8 of 1990-91-Department of Social Security-payment of pensions overseas.

INTERJECT.PARA: I also present the Auditor-General's annual report of the Australian National Audit Office for 1989-90.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.

These two reports from the Auditor-General from the Australian National Audit Office are both important. I hope that the Senate and the wider community will give them the consideration they deserve. I wish to restrict my remarks today to the annual report of the Australian National Audit Office. Other honourable senators may wish to speak on the other report which is also, as I have said, an important report.

Whilst, of course, we have not had access to this report for sufficient time to become familiar with its details, it would appear from my initial report that the Audit Office and the Auditor-General are to be congratulated on their performance last year, particularly in view of the uncertainty and the difficulties created for the office by the Government's inaction in a variety of important areas. I particularly welcome the added number of performance indicators which are available in this year's report.

The number of significant recommendations, particularly as they flowed through to acceptance by the auditee, are impressive. I especially welcome the $49m of estimated savings identified by efficiency audits. Within that $49m I draw particular attention to the potential savings of $40m identified by the Auditor-General in the area of administration of the Austudy program by the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET). That is a very significant saving indeed in administrative costs. It is an example, I believe, of the very considerable scope that there still remains within the area of government expenditure across all departments for a significant pruning of costs to induce a greater efficiency within government administration. The example of $40m in relation to DEET is a very noteworthy example.

The Department of Defence is also shown as having potential savings of $4.5m as a result of the audit of the Squirrel training helicopter, utilisation and maintenance. A $3m potential saving is identified in the area of the Department of Transport and Communications in respect of the administration of national broadcasting transmitting facilities. So they are some of the efficiency audit results that are recorded in this year's annual report and they bear, as I say, careful scrutiny.

It is clear from the Auditor-General's foreword to his annual report this year that there are continuing tensions between the Audit Office and the Government over the appropriate role of the Auditor-General and the Audit Office. It is an indictment of the Government that the issues that I will mention today are substantially the same as those that were raised by my colleague Senator Michael Baume last year when discussing the Auditor-General's 1989 annual report. The Government has been dilatory and managerially incompetent in refusing to act more quickly on these important issues.

Foremost among the Auditor-General's concerns is his view that the Australian National Audit Office should be established as a statutory authority. This matter has been raised many times in the past. It has been the subject of detailed consideration and reporting by the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts. It has been the subject of questioning by many senators, including myself, at Estimates committee hearings. I raised the matter again only last month to try to find out exactly when the Government might be making up its mind on this issue. I was told by Senator McMullan who was handling the Estimates committee hearings for the Government at that stage that reports and recommendations about this matter were with the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I understand that they had been there for some time and he could not give me a date on which we could see a decision coming out of the Treasurer's office. I think that is unfortunate. I welcome the fact that a decision is pending, but it is very important, as Senator Watson and I said in debate in the Senate yesterday, that the Treasurer make that decision quickly and that the decision is one in favour of the establishment of the Audit Office as a statutory body.

The Deputy Auditor-General, Mr Jacobs, made it clear at the recent Estimates hearings that he saw the issue of becoming a statutory authority as very important indeed in terms of attracting and keeping good staff. That point is reiterated in the Auditor-General's foreword to the 1990 annual report.

In this report the Auditor-General actually reiterates a statement he made in a report signed over a year ago that the Audit Office should be established as a statutory authority. We strongly agree with that. He also said that the Auditor-General should have improved ability over staff terms and conditions and over hiring and firing, while maintaining consistency with the Government's policies of public sector restraint. He went on to say:
Without this support, the ability of the Auditor-General to achieve efficiencies in the operation of the ANAO, while maintaining high professional auditing standards, would be substantially reduced.

Apart from the question of the ability to attract staff by offering private sector competitive terms and conditions of employment, the status of the Audit Office is also very important from the perspective of the independence of the Auditor-General. This issue needs to be given high priority given the importance of a strong and effective Audit Office in an effective democracy.

The Auditor-General in his foreword to this annual report has also raised the erosion of the mandate of the AuditorGeneral. He suggests that it should be confirmed as covering the audit of Commonwealth undertakings of whatever legal form. I believe that is a very important recommendation and I know that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has reported upon it and has strongly endorsed that view. The whole question of public sector audit should be wide ranging and any restrictions on the Auditor-General's mandate in that sense is very unfortunate. There are now constraints on the Audit Office conducting efficiency audits on government business enterprises. That is yet another issue which the Government still has, I understand, under review.

I also note that the Auditor-General supports the possible establishment of an audit committee of the Parliament. That, too, was another recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its report No. 296. That is a matter for the Parliament to decide, on which I hope we as a Parliament can express our views and take decisions.

The other point I wish to mention in passing, as we dealt with the matter in debate here yesterday and my friend and colleague Senator Watson may wish to mention it again today, is the extraordinary situation whereby one of the two reviews of the Audit Office that have been undertaken in the past 12 months, namely the review by the Auditor-General of South Australia, Mr Tom Sheridan, has not been released by the Government. The report of the second review of the Audit Office undertaken in the past 12 months-namely, the report tabled yesterday of an efficiency audit of the Audit Office by the independent auditor, Mr Michael Sharpe-listed at least some of the recommendations of the Sheridan report and expressed support for them.

The Auditor-General in his report today again lists some of the recommendations and comments upon them in terms of his support or otherwise. It seems extraordinary that the Parliament is being fed bits and pieces of the report into the Audit Office by Mr Sheridan without the Government seeing fit, for whatever reason, to release that report. I think that it is about time the Government came clean on this. Certainly it should release the Sheridan report, but at the very least it should, as a matter of immediacy, say why the delay has occurred.

Those matters are important to the Parliament. The Audit Office is a very important institution. I take this opportunity to congratulate Mr John Taylor on his work as Auditor-General over the past two or three years. I think that he has made a very notable contribution to that position. He has followed the line of some illustrious predecessors and certainly loses nothing in comparison with them.

The coalition is a very strong supporter of the role of the Audit Office. We shall continue to be so and we will use this Parliament, wherever possible, to reinforce that and to expose any problems caused for the Office by the actions-or in this case at the moment the inactions-of the Government. I commend the report to all honourable senators and I hope that it receives wide attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity on the occasion of the tabling of the 1989-90 annual report of the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) to comment briefly on some significant matters affecting the office of the Auditor-General.

SPEECH.PARA: A feature of the report is the very large number of references to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, of which I am Deputy Chairman, and in particular to the findings of that Committee's report No. 296 Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament, which was tabled in April 1989. I would also like to refer to the close association that the Auditor-General has with committees of the Parliament, and especially the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. He is an attender at all public hearings and makes a valuable contribution when required.

A major feature of the Auditor-General's report and concern is the question of mandate-the scope of the responsibilities in relation to the Auditor-General. The question of mandate is also referred to in the annual report in these words:
The mandate of the Auditor-General for Australia should be confirmed as covering the audit of Commonwealth undertakings of whatever legal form.

I remind the Senate that this view is consistent with the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on government companies and their reporting requirements, which was tabled in 1989, and also of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

We should also note that the New South Wales Public Accounts Committee makes similar recommendations in its 1990 report on the New South Wales Auditor-General's Office. I find it rather disturbing that as recently as last week, when we were debating the corporatisation of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL), I sought but was unable to obtain an assurance from the Government that the Auditor-General would be the auditor of this new corporation covering the CSL. This is somewhat disturbing. It is also disturbing that the Government has taken so long to respond to the Sheridan report-a report by the former Auditor-General of South Australia. My colleague Senator Short has drawn attention to this matter today.

I referred to this matter previously on the tabling of the report of the independent auditor. I think it is quite atrocious that the Government has not only withheld this report for so long but has now allowed two significant reports to be tabled before this Parliament without the Cabinet releasing this report and further, without the Cabinet coming down with its recommendations on this report. That is quite atrocious and indicates some disrespect that this Government has for the office of Auditor-General and for the Parliament.

It is also quite atrocious that the Auditor-General has had to labour for years with insufficient funding from this Government. This raises the whole question of the independence of the Auditor-General and the need for him to have a very close association with the Parliament. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts recommended a committee of the Parliament to act as the liaison between the Parliament and the Auditor-General. We must separate the Auditor-General's office, in terms of funding and accountability, from the Executive. He is responsible to the Parliament, as report No. 296 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled Auditor-General: Ally of the people and the Parliament recommended. This must be preserved at all times.

I am therefore concerned about this question of independence. The Auditor-General is also concerned. In fact, the Auditor-General responded to our report No. 296 on 7 September 1989, in a document entitled `Auditor-General: Accountability, Independence and Objectivity'. He said:

. . . that the ANAO should be established as a statutory authority and that like Canada, the United Kingdom and New Zealand, the Auditor-General should have improved ability over staff terms and conditions, over the hiring and firing while maintaining consistency with the Government's policy of public sector restraint.

Another aspect of the inadequate funding is that the Auditor-General had to ration resources to the very important audit function of performance auditing. The Auditor-General mentions that a positive result of the efficiency audits he carried out during the year was the identification of a potential saving of $49m. Had the Australian AuditorGeneral been able to devote the same sorts of resources as the Canadian Auditor-General devotes to efficiency auditing, that potential saving in Australia would have run into hundreds of millions of dollars. It is a criticism of the Government and its short-sightedness that in the withholding of funds, which has prevented a more adequate efficiency audit coverage, the ANAO has been denied the opportunity of saving government money at such a critical time.

Recently I had the opportunity of delivering to the Institute of Internal Auditors a paper on `Risk management within the public sector'. I would like to put on the public record that I congratulate that institute on lifting its professionalism. The Institute now provides a national education program, based on the international standards of the common body of knowledge, of uniform quality across Australia. In recent years the Auditor-General has been a frequent critic of the level of internal auditing within the public sector.

Several years ago the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was so concerned about the lack of recognition of internal audit in the public sector that it produced a special report. I am pleased, therefore, that the Institute of Internal Auditors has got together in a very meaningful way and is conducting national seminars and emphasising its professional responsibilities. In fact, there is now an Australian accreditation award based on an education program and an international accreditation which is similarly based. The aim is to improve professionalism within government internal auditors. Therefore, it is necessary to have some formal recognition of the Institute's education and accreditation program. An increase in professionalism and status of internal auditors should lead to increased productivity from auditors and ultimately from their clients, overall improvements in the public service, a decrease in adverse comment from the Australian National Audit Office and the maintenance of high levels of accountability. I take this opportunity to congratulate the Institute on its increased professionalism, on its awareness of the problems of the past and on its determination to rise above that criticism and to present its members as a highly professional group within the Australian public sector. I commend the Institute and its executive.

I cannot let this opportunity pass without acknowledging the tremendous strains under which the staff of the Australian Audit Office have had to labour in recent years. During the current year there have been two significant reports: the report of the independent auditor on the Australian Audit Office, which I referred to a few days ago; the second was the report of Mr Tom Sheridan. It was suggested by Mr Sheridan that the Australian Audit Office should now be given the opportunity of settling down and getting on with many of the reforms that it is currently undertaking. Mr Michael Sharpe, the Independent Auditor on the other hand, differed slightly in that he suggested that there should be a further independent evaluation of the information technology that has required such a high investment of funds with the ANAO.

I congratulate the staff on the way in which they have adapted to change, have adapted to their new responsibilities and have accepted so graciously the recommendations of committees of Parliament. I believe this close association between the Auditor-General and the Parliament must be for the good of the Parliament and the people. Therefore, I would like to join with my colleague Senator Short in paying special tribute not only to the staff of the Audit Office but also to Mr John Taylor, its head, in charting a very positive course through what have been some very turbulent times for the AuditorGeneral of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with section 121 (3) of the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959, I present the annual reports and financial statements of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia and the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia, together with the Auditor-General's report thereon, for the year ended 30 June 1990.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Commonwealth Bank is probably the jewel in the crown of public business enterprise in Australia. It has a distinguished history as both a commercial bank and, prior to creation of the Reserve Bank of Australia, a central bank. For the financial year ended 30 June 1990 the bank group produced an operating profit after tax of $494m and the total assets of the group grew by over 10 per cent to more than $67 billion. The group has provided for a dividend of $160m. That is a direct injection into the Budget which can be spent on community services. It is well and truly a public utility owned by the people of Australia.

The return on average equity was 13.21 per cent for the year and its value is at least $4 billion and possibly a lot higher. It is against this background that we must look at the Government's attempt to privatise this public utility which, as I said, is owned by the people of Australia. The acquisition of the State Bank of Victoria is tied to the proposed initiative to strengthen the national public financial sector.

Yet only a couple of days ago we had a report from the University of Melbourne, by Professor Davis, who has established and documented in a report supplied to the Victorian Government that the sale of the State Bank of Victoria is not necessary. His report has been queried by Treasury. However, I believe that it needs careful consideration. The whole debacle of trying to sell a public enterprise at national level because a public enterprise at State level has failed or is in danger of failing may turn out to be a furphy-a furphy that was grabbed very quickly by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to justify the satisfying of his ideological bent to privatise, that is, to sell at bottom bargain prices any public utilities that he can lay his hands on.

I set aside for the Government's consideration the issue of whether it is, in fact, necessary to acquire the State Bank of Victoria. I hope that the Victorian Government and Premier Joan Kirner will reconsider their position after careful study of that report from the University of Melbourne.

But there are a number of other issues that we should address in the context of the Government's attempt to privatise the bank. On 13 September, I had occasion to ask the Minister representing the Treasurer in the Senate, Senator Button, what the Government would do about the community service obligations of the Commonwealth Bank, which are now being fulfilled, if the Government, in fact, privatised the bank to 30 per cent as proposed. The obligations include exemptions from fees for accounts operated by pensioners, other long term beneficiaries and people under 18. They include special banking packages for charities, free bank statements in braille for visually impaired customers, subsidised electronic banking for disabled customers and a social as well as commercial emphasis on lending decisions made by the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia. An extremely important aspect of this discussion is that it is now not fashionable to provide venture capital for our industry and for initiatives in the small business sector that could add to Australia's export income.

The Minister representing the Treasurer wiped this issue simply by saying that these community service obligations were being provided as a matter of commercial necessity rather than according to the principle of community service obligation. In other words, he was saying that they were only being offered to attract customers. I believe that he is downgrading the policy of the Commonwealth Bank, which is to serve the people of Australia first and foremost, in accordance with its charter. I believe that the Government should reconsider because, if it is really true that this is the principle that the Government intends to implement once the bank has been partially privatised, we are losing a very important aspect of the Commonwealth Bank as it is currently operating.

The other major aspect of the bank, which is the property of the people of Australia, currently in place is that it enables the community to exercise some check on the private banking sector. Unless we have that comparison and unless we have that window on the private sector to set standards and to assess the operations of the private banking sector, we will be even further removed. If the Government intends to regulate the financial sector, to tighten up the regulations governing the banking sector and, as we would propose, to extend those regulations to the non-banking sector as well, there might be some purpose in the policy of the Government. At the moment, unfortunately, we seem to be bent on a course of action which sells off to the private sector anything that is of value and leaves in the public sector anything that is losing money.

I have one final point. I refer to a letter written by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to Mr Kevin Scott, Federal Secretary of the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association, on 21 February 1990-that is, before the polling day of the last Federal election. I quote from the letter:

. . . I want to emphasise that my Government is not contemplating the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. We oppose not only the proposal put forward by the Opposition to sell the Bank but also question the economic and financial rationale on which they base their short-sighted propositions.

That was said by the Prime Minister on 21 February 1990. Is it not surprising how quickly circumstances can change? This letter was written before the election. How much is an election promise worth? I can only say that I can sympathise with Mr John Scott, a Federal Labor member of parliament from South Australia, who was reported on 30 August, 1990 as saying that, as a result of the whole issue of the promise broken by the Prime Minister and the intent of the Government to sell off public utilities which are the property of the people as a whole, he is considering quitting the Australian Labor Party (ALP). I believe that that is a consideration that not only Mr Scott but also many other members of parliament on the ALP side should consider because very clearly that Party is no longer the Party of the people. It is no longer the Party that once had a light on the hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to make a few comments about the annual report of the Commonwealth Bank group. The Commonwealth Bank annual report makes very interesting reading, coming, as it does, on the heels of the speech of the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia to the Australian Institute of Bankers just a couple of days ago and also coming, of course, just a few weeks after the release of the Reserve Bank's annual report, which, as the Senate may recall, was-when one appropriately read between the lines as is normally required with the annual reports of the Reserve Bank-a damningly critical commentary on the economic performance of the Federal Government. The failure of the Government's economic policies expressed in Mr Bernie Fraser's speech to the Institute of Bankers two nights ago is echoed in the opening section of the report of the Commonwealth Bank group under the heading `Economic Environment'. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the current account deficit for 1989-90 remained at an unsustainable level, equal to around 5.6 per cent of gross domestic product. The inflation rate also remained unacceptably high, with the consumer price index rising by 7.7 per cent over the year to June quarter 1990.

It is impossible, particularly for a public, government-owned institution, to give a greater condemnation of the Government's economic mismanagement than this. The Commonwealth Bank is stating boldly that on the two items at the top of the Government's economic agenda- namely, inflation and debt-the Government has failed and has failed disastrously. The statement I have just quoted could not have been more unequivocal in its criticism of the Government.

The section of the report concerning the performance of the bank is also very carefully worded-I believe it bears further study than I have been able to give it in the brief amount of time that we have had access to the report-and who can blame the bank for that, given the recent spate of bank bashing by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I note that the bank states:
The effect of high interest rates has intensified competition for both deposits and good quality lending opportunities, and this has kept pressure on interest margins.

That would seem to indicate-indeed it says so-that there has been pressure on interest margins. The return on all the performance measurement ratios-that is, the return on average equity, capital employed and average assets-is down in 1990 compared with the previous year. I hope that the Treasurer and the parliamentary inquiry dealing with bank margins, when it gets under way, will take all the information in this Commonwealth Banking Corporation report into account in their deliberations.

The Opposition has said from the day that the parliamentary inquiry into bank margins was announced that the inquiry will be nothing other than a farce. If the Government were really serious about looking at the issues contained in the terms of reference to the parliamentary committee inquiring into the banks it would have had a much wider ranging inquiry and would have made it an independent inquiry along the lines, perhaps, of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System or the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System of the late 1970s and early 1980s, which led to the deregulation of the financial markets in Australia.

The coalition has said that it would welcome such a review. We think that it would not be inappropriate to do that as we are now getting down the track towards a decade after the opening up of the financial markets in this country. Many other nations reviewed their financial system at about that time after deregulation and we would be happy to do that and would be happy to see that done. We do not agree at all that the inquiry announced by the Government will in any way meet the needs in that respect.

As I said, quite frankly this inquiry is a farce. It is a diversionary tactic to try to divert attention away from the Government's chronic mishandling of the economy, the chronic problems facing the economy and to try to put the pressure elsewhere as the Treasurer and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) do time and time again. When they get into trouble they say, `Gee, it is not our fault, it is someone else's fault; we will blame someone else'. That is exactly what they have been doing with their spate of bank bashing in recent times. If they were really serious about this being other than a bank bashing exercise, they would have instituted a meaningful inquiry.

One other issue that I would like to focus on briefly today is the sale of the State Bank of Victoria to the Commonwealth Bank. This matter was the subject of Senator Spindler's remarks. I am sure it will come as no surprise to Senator Spindler that my comments will be diametrically opposed to the views that he put.

Unfortunately for the Parliament the annual report devotes very little space to the details of the sale. I think that is unfortunate. It is particularly disappointing after the Department of the Treasury was so obstructionist in answering questions that I put to that Department on this issue in the recent Senate Estimates hearings. Unfortunately, too, the report says nothing about the progress or outcome of the due diligence review, which is currently being undertaken by the Commonwealth Bank officials who are looking into the books and behind the books of the State Bank. I understand the results of the review are supposed to be available by now. The fact that the merger is also said to depend, in the bank's terms, on `certain other conditions' is worrying. I will come back to that in a moment.

In relation to the due diligence exercise being conducted, there are obviously some doubts in the financial community about whether the value of the State Bank will be anything like the $1.6 billion that was announced so triumphantly by the Treasurer and the Premier of Victoria, Joan Kirner, just a month or so ago when they saw this as the way to bail out Victoria which had been bankrupted by the policies of the Cain and Kirner governments.

In today's press, in the Australian, there is a report saying that Premier Kirner is confident on the sale of the State Bank of Victoria. The Victorian Opposition called on the State Government to make a full disclosure of any new developments concerning the proposed sale of the State Bank to the Commonwealth Bank. That call by my colleagues in the Victorian Opposition, particularly the Leader, Alan Brown, follows rumours that the Commonwealth Bank is attempting to renegotiate the terms of the sale. All that Mrs Kirner could say yesterday in the Parliament in Victoria was that she was confident that the original agreement would proceed as expected. That is obviously less than full certainty that the sale, firstly, will go through and, secondly, will go through at the price of $1.6 billion that was the subject of the press release and announcements by the Federal and State governments jointly just a few weeks ago.

It should not come as any surprise that there are concerns about the true value of the State Bank. As long ago as 17 September in a very important article in the Melbourne Herald by Terry McCrann-I have seen no refutation by anyone of what Mr McCrann was saying-he said:
Stand by for another State Bank disaster-the Commonwealth Bank wanting to cut its purchase price substantially. Perhaps by $500 million, perhaps even more.

He went on to elaborate on the reasons why he had that view. It was a view that was based, importantly, on rumours running around the financial markets at the time. There has been no rebuttal of those rumours since then; indeed, my colleague in another place Mr Warwick Smith said publicly last week that he, too, has heard of fresh rumours in recent days along the lines of the McCrann statements of a month ago.

I think it is very important indeed that the due diligence procedure be completed, that the public be told as soon as possible of the outcome of that review and that firm decisions be taken because many things are at stake, including the viability of the Commonwealth Bank; its position in the marketplace in Australia; the future of the State Bank of Victoria, of course; and, within that, the future for all Victorians who are now labouring under a public debt of no less than $33 billion-a figure that is almost unbelievable, but true. It is a debt that amounts to more than $7,500 thousand for every man, woman and child in Victoria. It is a debt that has accumulated almost entirely during the pathetic regime in terms of economic management-the disastrous regime-of the Cain Government now taken over, of course, by the Kirner Government. Let no-one think that that is a new broom sweeping clean because Joan Kirner was a senior member of the Cain Government for most of its period in office and, indeed, was the Deputy Premier in the year or so before she became the Premier.

The other matter I want to come back to is the fact that the Commonwealth Bank reports says that the merger-for want of a better word-is to depend on certain other conditions. I assume that the conditions it is referring to are those that were determined by Caucus on 28 August when it passed a resolution approving a merger of the Commonwealth Bank and the State Bank of Victoria to be funded `by an injection of non-government equity'. There are some extraordinarily tight conditions imposed by the Caucus on this action and indeed any suggestion that this is a privatisation exercise is refuted immediately one reads the Caucus resolution.

It is nonsense, in any event, to say that an injection of 30 per cent of private sector equity into a publicly owned institution constitutes privatisation. It quite blatantly does not. That is not what privatisation is about. Privatisation essentially is about putting the control and management of an institution in the hands of the private sector. This 30 per cent privatisation does not do that. It is merely a fundraising exercise that has been concocted to enable the Commonwealth to help bail out a bankrupt Labor State of Victoria.

It was done, very interestingly, not long before the Australian Labor Party (ALP) Special Conference that was to look at, and did look at, the sale of Australian Airlines Ltd and the sale of 49 per cent equity in Qantas Airways Ltd. Quite obviously, Treasurer Keating wanted to get Premier Kirner's vote in support of those proposals at the ALP Special Conference, and indeed he succeeded. Premier Kirner did vote with the Government at that time and broke ranks with her own socialist left faction. It was a very important thing for both Mr Keating and Mrs Kirner.

If we look at some of the conditions we see very clearly that this is not a privatisation exercise, nor is it regarded by the Labor Party as a privatisation exercise. Let me quote a few things from the resolution of the Federal Parliamentary Caucus of the Australian Labor Party of 28 August 1990:
The Caucus unequivocally rejects proposals to remove Government control of the CBA and to privatise the Commonwealth Bank . . .
In other words, the Caucus said specifically-`unequivocally', to use its own words-that it was rejecting any notion that this was a privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. It went on to say:
Further, the Caucus endorses the imposition of the following conditions on the introduction of non-government equity:
And there are no fewer than 17 conditions imposed. I will not go through the whole 17, but let me quote just some of them briefly. The first condition reads:
That the Government introduce to the Parliament legislation requiring majority government ownership and control of the Commonwealth Bank in perpetuity.
The second condition says, among other things:
That the issue of non-government equity in the combined CBA-SBV entity be restricted to . . . 30 per cent of the issued capital . . .
The fourth condition says:
That other banks, including foreign banks, not be permitted to acquire shares in the Commonwealth Bank of Australia.
The fifth condition reads:
Foreign portfolio interests be prevented from subscribing to shares.
In other words, no foreign investment at all-not in one single share of the Commonwealth Bank; and other banks will not be permitted to acquire shares at all. Condition No. 10 states:
In framing the terms of this equity issue, special attention be given to ensure the subscription of superannuation funds, including those funds of trade union members and small investors.

It is London to a brick that there will be great pressure put on the bank by trade union superannuation funds to inject equity. The long term implications of that in terms of influence by the trade union movement into the operations of the bank should not be overlooked in any way. It is a very important condition. So also is condition No. 13:
Non-government equity will not be introduced to the subsidiaries of the bank . . .
In other words, there will be not one cent of private capital permitted in any of the subsidiaries of the Commonwealth Bank. Condition No. 14 says:
The Caucus recognises that the arrangements for this introduction of outside equity-
that is, the 30 per cent for the bank as a whole-
will be made by the Commonwealth Bank Board on the approval of the Treasurer.

In other words, again it is the Government which will be determining and calling all the shots in relation to this funding proposal. That is all it is. It is a funding proposal designed to try to bail out the Government of Victoria. I seek leave to table the Caucus resolution. I did seek approval from the Minister responsible.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was his answer?
—He said yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Those conditions are very strenuous and what better demonstration is needed of why such assets should not be owned by government. The sale of the State Bank of Victoria raises a whole host of questions. Many of those remain largely unanswered, despite the Opposition's attempts to get answers in all possible forums. Why was the Commonwealth Bank the successful bidder when it did not put in the highest bid for the bank? The Westpac Banking Corporation had a higher bid for the State Bank of Victoria than the Commonwealth Bank did. Is it true, as has been reported and as Senator Spindler pointed out, that there are reports that the Commonwealth Bank could have purchased the State Bank without any injection of private equity? Were there moves to hide the true financial position of the State Bank from potential bidders to ensure the political deal with the Commonwealth could go ahead? Again, there are no specific answers to that question. These and many other questions are on the public record. They have been asked before many times and still we do not have any answers.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say to the Government that the coalition will be monitoring very carefully the situation surrounding further developments on the sale of the State Bank of Victoria and indeed the specific proposals that the Government will bring to this Parliament in relation to the sale of the 30 per cent equity in the Commonwealth Bank. If those conditions that are in the Caucus resolution are included in the legislation, as Caucus has in fact demanded, I can foreshadow a very interesting debate in this place.

I think we will hear much more of the Commonwealth Bank in the period ahead. If the 30 per cent sale of equity does go ahead, the annual report that is before us today will be the last of its kind in the sense of the bank being 100 per cent government owned. But, as I have said, it is not a privatisation proposal that is under way. It is really a mickey mouse funding proposal to bail out the bankrupt government of the State in which I reside.

As a Victorian, I know full well the burdens under which we, in Victoria, are labouring as a result of the Cain Government and the Kirner Government, overlaid of course by the overriding economic mismanagement that all Australians have encountered over the last 7 1/2 years under this Hawke Federal Labor Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE SEVENTY-FIFTH ANNIVERSARY COMMEMORATION OF THE LANDINGS AT GALLIPOLI, APRIL 1990

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the seventy-fifth Anniversary Commemoration of the Landings at Gallipoli, April 1990. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

At the outset, I express my appreciation for the support of the deputy leader of the delegation, former Senator David Hamer, DSC, a distinguished ex-serviceman and a great servant of this chamber. The delegation was strengthened also by the involvement of my colleague from Queensland, Senator Bryant Burns, the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the House of Representatives, Mr Tim Fischer, MP, Mr David Connolly, MP, and a further Queensland colleague, Mr Les Scott, MP. The delegation was assisted in an exemplary way by its Secretary, Mr Peter Gibson, MC.

I also pay tribute to the printing section of the Department of the House of Representatives for printing the text and to the Senate printing section for its work in printing the cover and completing the binding of this report. It was an outstanding cooperative effort.

Anzac Day 1990 on the Gallipoli peninsula was indeed a unique national event. As the report makes clear, it is difficult to imagine a similar circumstance in which four generations of Australians would gather with some of the original participants to commemorate the activities 75 years earlier of one of those generations, activities which altered the course of national events and so profoundly shaped a nation's perceptions of itself.

The delegation was to have been an official parliamentary delegation to Turkey, coinciding with the seventy-fifth anniversary commemoration of the landings at Gallipoli. Certain difficulties arose with the invitation, but these need not be canvassed in the Senate at this time. It transpired, with the active support of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Presiding Officers, that the delegation's main focus in Turkey was on the events on the Gallipoli peninsula on 25 April.

As the report indicates, to have been present as 47 original Anzacs returned to Gallipoli and to their varied memories was both a singular honour and an experience of quite extraordinary dimensions. The Anzac tradition has spoken now for four generations of Australians of all cultural, religious, racial, socio-economic and political backgrounds. It epitomises what it means to be `Australian'.

The delegation's participation in the commemoration activities began at about 5 p.m. on 24 April 1990 when the delegation boarded the motor vessel Samsun for the journey overnight down the Dardanelle from Istanbul to the Gallipoli peninsula. As guests of the Turkish Government, the delegation joined the Prime Minister's party, the New Zealand Governor-General's party and smaller groups from Canada, France and Germany. The Samsun left Istanbul just before dusk on 24 April 1990.

At this time 75 years ago, men of the 3rd Australian Infantry Brigade, the covering force to land at dawn the following day, were also at sea, having sailed eastward from Lemnos Island earlier in the afternoon. As night fell, the thoughts of all on board travelled back to that time. What thoughts must have occupied the minds of those original Anzacs? Were they, in Binyon's words, going `with songs to the battle'? Were they, as John Masefield wrote the following year `those marvellous young men . . . the flower of this world's manhood', to die `as they had lived, owning no master on this earth'?

Was there truly Masefield's `gladness of exultation that their young courage was to be used, [as] they went like kings in a pageant to the imminent death'? Or were the original Anzacs, rather, nervously apprehensive at what was before them; individually uncertain about what the dawn would bring to each of them and how they would respond; and totally unaware of the significance of their imminent actions in shaping a young nation's perception of itself?
One of those Anzacs wrote to his wife and young daughter at this time 75 years ago as follows:

We are on the eve of the landing on the peninsular . . . if I fall tomorrow morning, well, I will be one of the many brave fellows who have died trying to do their duty for God and country . . . if I had not come I would not be worthy of my name . . . I wonder what it will be like.
The author was Major J. W. Hamilton of the 6th Battalion, Second Australian Infantry Brigade. He was killed in action on the afternoon of that first Anzac Day near Lone Pine.

Anzac Day at Gallipoli in 1990 allowed this nation to pay tribute to what these men did and to what the men and women supporting them accomplished. The very geography of the peninsular and its fierce and forbidding countenance, particularly in the area of the Anzac landings, reinforced the perception of enormous difficulty. This was apparent to members of the delegation as dawn broke following the dawn service.

The perception was further reinforced when the delegation joined thousands of other Australians at the Lone Pine Memorial for the late morning commemorative service. It was an occasion of profound significance to share this time with, and to wonder at, the memories that must have flooded the minds of the 47 original Anzacs present. The report, in discussing Lone Pine, notes the following:

Here, at 5.30pm on 6 August 1915 began some of the bloodiest and most concentrated fighting faced by the Australian Imperial Force during World War I. Here, in an area of less than two hectares, where Australia now paused to remember and reflect, more than 2,200 Australians died in four days. Seven Victoria Crosses were awarded at Lone Pine. It is understating the circumstances, but members of the Delegation shared with so many of their fellow Australians, here gathered, a sense of meaning of the inscription by Monash on the Shrine of Remembrance in Melbourne:

LET ALL MEN KNOW THAT THIS IS HOLY GROUND. THIS SHRINE ESTABLISHED IN THE HEARTS OF MEN AS ON THE SOLID EARTH COMMEMORATES A PEOPLE'S FORTITUDE AND SACRIFICE. YE THEREFORE THAT COME AFTER GIVE REMEMBRANCE.

Members of the delegation, on Anzac Day and subsequently, had the opportunity to traverse the battlefields of Anzac in some detail. Time precludes a detailed description, but I would like to highlight for the Senate some snapshots. These were glimpses of the enormity of the sacrifice made by this nation and New Zealand as well as Turkey, Britain and France. At Anzac Cove is the epitaph to the Anzacs written by Kemal Mustapha Ataturk, the commander confronting the Anzacs on the landing who subsequently became the first president and revered founder of modern Turkey. In an inscription which symbolises some of the unique feeling that surmounted the bloodiness and bitterness of the fighting in 1915, and since, he wrote the following:

You, the mothers, who sent their sons from far away countries, wipe away your tears. Your sons are now lying in our bosom and are in peace. After having lost their lives on this land they have become our sons as well.
Members of the delegation noted on a headstone at Lone Pine the following:
805 Private G.R. Yuill, 7th Battalion, Australian Infantry, 25 April 1915, age 19. Dear is the spot to me where my beloved son rests. My Anzac hero. Mother.
Other sentiments were observed as follows:
To die for his country was so dear, but his young life was dearer.
Died the way he wished, to die for his country.
His last words `Goodbye Cobber God bless you'.
Who dies if England lives.

The report makes quite clear the delegation's enormous gratitude to all those involved in the success of the pilgrimage to Gallipoli in 1990. They are: The Australian Government for its active support and for its allocation of the necessary resources to effect such a complicated and difficult task; the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, his Department and its Gallipoli 1990 task force for their outstanding management in developing the plan to fruition and executing it flawlessly; the Turkish Government which could not have done more, in Ankara before and on the Gallipoli peninsula on Anzac day itself, to ensure that all aspects of the various commemorations were covered; the Returned Services League of Australia for its pivotal role in coordinating the arrangements for the dawn service and the Lone Pine service; the Australian Defence Force for its spectacular contribution to the administrative and logistics arrangements, and for its participation which ensured the ceremonial success and the deep symbolism of the occasion; and, most importantly, the World War I Veterans' Association which, through its patron Mr Bill Hall, was instrumental in conceiving the return pilgrimage and in convincing the then defence Minister of the need for active government support and involvement.

The report stands alone as a small tribute to the men and women of an earlier Australia who together forged, through the mystique of Gallipoli, an ethos for this young country. This serves us as well today as it did in the blood, the dread, the privation, the horror, the misery, the squalor and the filth of war 75 years ago.

To those surviving Anzacs and other veterans who made the pilgrimage, the nation has attempted to express its appreciation. For those who did not return from Gallipoli the report closes with the best possible tribute to the Anzacs of 75 years ago when it states:
THEY GAVE THEIR SHINING YOUTH, AND RAISED THEREBY VALOUR'S OWN MONUMENT WHICH SHALL NOT DIE.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to endorse the remarks made by Senator Colston in relation to the report on the visit of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the seventy-fifth commemoration of the landings at Gallipoli.

SPEECH.PARA: As a member of the Australian-Turkey parliamentary group, for some time I have had an interest in our relationship with that country. At group meetings with the Turkish ambassador, Ergun Pelit, who plays a very constructive role in developing understanding and friendship between our countries, I have been given an opportunity to have some knowledge of Turkey and its people which engendered in me a keen desire to visit that country and experience first-hand contact with the Turkish people.

Given the opportunity to visit as part of a parliamentary delegation to attend the seventy-fifth commemoration of Gallipoli was doubling impacting on me. Much has been said of the battles that raged, of the sacrifice, bravery and valour shown by both sides of the conflict. Prime Minister Hawke enunciated very ably and with feeling the views of most Australians reflecting their pride in the Australians who fought at Gallipoli, and their continued remembrance of their sacrifice. He expressed sadness and regret at the loss of lives on both sides and impressed on those present the need to learn lessons from those experiences and to ensure that it never happens again.

It has been observed by many that the conflict was probably the last occasion on which chivalry was one of the standards of behaviour on both sides. The years which followed the end of the conflict could have been marred by bitterness and hatred-particularly by those who had been invaded-but this is not the case. The Turkish national leader, Ataturk, personified the Turkish people's attitude in his 1934 epitaph for the Anzacs. This quote has already been recorded by Senator Colston who preceded me in reporting the visit of this delegation.

Turkey is a fascinating country to which more Australians should travel. Istanbul is the most interesting city to which I have travelled and its people are friendly and helpful, with a degree of honesty which I have not experienced in other places. It should be noted that Turkey's role in the current Gulf crisis is to deny the use of oil pipeline facilities normally used by Iraq. This action is in conformity with United Nations decisions and at great cost to the Turkish economy and living standards. I commend them for it. I commit myself to continuing to build on our current friendship and cooperation in the future for our mutual benefit-a future based, amongst other things, on the mutual respect which was established during that conflict 75 years ago.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING TRIBUNAL: TV VIOLENCE IN AUSTRALIA

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 October, on motion by Senator Bjelke-Petersen:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to begin my response to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal report on Television Violence in Australia by commending the Tribunal on the quality of the reports it has issued over the past 14 years or so. This is particularly noteworthy in view of the lack of funding provided to the Tribunal by this Government. Once again, the Tribunal has produced a well-researched document which presents some sound recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: Importantly, in the formulation of this report, the Tribunal was able to take submissions from over 1,000 individuals. The Australian Democrats believe that this type of public input is essential to ensure that the agenda does not become hijacked by those with vested interests. The large number of submissions is a clear indication of the level of concern there is in the community over televised violence.

The Australian Democrats welcome the recommendations of this report but have several reservations which I would like to elaborate on in the short time available to me this evening. The report on page 15 recommends the implementation of a uniform industry code on television violence. It requests the Minister to draw up such a code to be subject to the approval of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I endorse the suitability of this process. The implementation of the code is then to be reviewed in the normal licence renewal processes at which stage, if the licensee's performance is lacking, enforcement can then be incorporated as a condition of the licence.

As the report points out, this code will represent a formalisation and, hopefully, a strengthening of the procedures already in existence in the industry. One of the great benefits of a formalised code would be that it would clearly establish the guidelines industry should employ when dealing with the violent content of programs. Of particular concern to the Australian Democrats, and indeed of many who made submissions to the inquiry, is the handling of televised violence during periods in which children may be watching.

It is now a sad fact of life that children spend more time watching television than they do at any other waking activity, including going to school or other activities with family and friends. Around 99 per cent of Australian houses have a television set and by the age of 18, the average child has watched around 20,000 hours of television, seen 18,000 murders and viewed 640,000 commercials. Children obviously have to be resilient little creatures to resist this and I think that we have an obligation to help them resist the sort of desensitisation that must accompany such exposure.

With the deregulation of advertising standards we saw that the amount of advertising during children's programs was significantly increased. If we are to consider a type of industry self-regulation with respect to televised violence, we must ensure that a similar occurrence not be allowed. Some of the programs currently being shown in children's viewing hours contain a worrying level of violence, and already children are turning up to pre-school with toys and weapons from their favourite television programs. If this situation is not closely monitored I believe it will lead to children continuing to accept violence as a normal part of life and, indeed, as an acceptable means to achieving ends and solving problems when we all know the importance of other forms of conflict resolution. Recommendation 13 of the report suggests that the report be forwarded to the Australian Education Council for it to consider ways of introducing a television studies program into our primary and secondary schools. I know that such a program already exists in Queensland.

I can only hope that the Government takes this suggestion on board and allocates the necessary funding for this project. This is particularly important in view of the cutbacks in children's programming being forced on Australian Broadcasting Corporation television by the starving of funds it is subjected to. In conclusion, I agree we all have a responsibility in relation to the broadcasting of violent content on Australian television. This report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is a useful tool providing guidance to us all in accepting and acting on this responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —It causes me a great deal of concern that we are still producing masses of reports on what is happening in research areas of Australia. The effort that is going to be necessary for Australia over the next decade is particularly important. Many of the traditional sources of Australia's income, particularly our export income, are now in peril as a result of various movements, various complaints and various international situations. So, it is all the more important that we develop new strengths. This is going to happen by better science and better research.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government after seven years has achieved so little and has demonstrated in this area how well the old divide and conquer theory really can work. To further that, I can say that there are now nine departments that have research components. These are: Department of Administrative Services; Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories; Department of Community Services and Health; Department of Defence; Department of Employment, Education and Training; Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce; Department of Primary Industries and Energy; Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet; and Department of Transport and Communications.

Since the Government has been in power it has also put around it six major advisory bodies and produced 22 reports for the Parliament on various aspects of scientific research. What has happened? Where are the results of all this? We have had so much information and so little to show for it. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the list of those bodies and the reports. TALK.START.PARA: —Funding over the last few years is now proportionately lower than it used to be. There has been no improvement in the relationship between the academic organisations, the research bodies and industry. We have fewer scientists and engineers now proportionately than we have ever had, and it is getting worse. There is no bridge between innovative development and funding. We must produce schemes that are going to work. Various schemes have been tried and some of them are nominally available, except that they are not producing the results that Australia must have to survive.

SPEECH.PARA: Concerning report No. 22, Government Funding of Academic and Related Research in Australia, I find it particularly interesting to note that the main findings, in an abbreviated form, are as follows:
Australian government funding of academic and related research was low . . . in comparison with leading European nations and the US in 1987 . . .
There was a marked difference in the structure of research support between Australia and overseas countries in 1984-1987 . . .

Considerable divergence existed in the funding priorities for different fields between Australia and the other countries. In the period under study, the levels of Australian investment in engineering and physical sciences in particular appeared to be very low in international terms.

What I want to know is: Who is that any news to? After 22 reports, I would have thought that we could have had something more productive than that as the main findings of a body such as the Australian Science and Technology Council. There are excellent people on that organisation. Those people should be providing much stronger advice than that. We know that what we have is not working, we know that it is going to take quite a change to make scientific research do something for Australia in the next decade or two. I would ask that, instead of following up a couple of recommendations as to which way should be followed, we should ask that body to go back and come out with strong, positive moves as to how we are going to get things moving.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL WELFARE LEGISLATION (PHARMACEUTICAL BENEFITS) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Welfare Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1990 gives effect to some of the changes in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) that were announced in the Budget. In the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 we debated some other pharmacy related changes which were also announced in the Budget. Before turning my attention to the major provisions of this Bill, it is important to highlight the Government's thoroughly unprofessional approach to the implementation of its pharmaceutical related Budget proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: Within days of the Budget it was glaringly obvious that the $2.50 charge was going to cause financial hardship in particular for those pensioners who were very ill. Firstly, we had Cabinet Ministers arguing about whether this unintended financial hardship should be alleviated. Then the Government had the lack of commonsense to divide the changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme between two separate Bills as well as announce that further changes would be included in a third Bill. Now, as we will find out as the debate goes on, it has promised an amendment in the Committee hearing. I want to put on the record that this Bill was late coming to the House of Representatives and it was late coming to the Senate. Because of the haste surrounding this Bill, the amendment will appear in yet another Bill.

To me, it is plain stupidity to have one Bill setting up the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority while another gives effect to a Government-Guild agreement upon which the agenda of the Authority will be based. Why introduce a new minimum pricing policy in one Bill and new patient contribution and safety net provisions in another Bill? Members and senators are naturally finding it quite difficult in discussing these Bills informally to identify the Bill being referred to. Senator Crowley expressed her concern last night regarding this very point when she was speaking on the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill and said that it was causing confusion in discussing it with clerks and with other members and senators.

That is not the only reason for it. There is also confusion in the community. Pharmaceutical groups have made submissions to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs that do not refer to the Bill in question. Who is to blame for this confusion? It is the Government. Rather than owning up and not getting its legislation in order, it resorts to baseless media propaganda, claiming the Opposition is thwarting the Budget proposals by delaying this Bill beyond its start-up date. I want to put on record that I found it quite inappropriate to read in the Age that this side of the chamber was going to be using the committee stage to delay the Bill. We have never had any intention of doing that. We have all the will in the world to make those committees work.

This disjointed approach to implementing the pharmaceutical changes which were announced in the Budget typifies the Government's ad hoc way of finding solutions to the increasing costs of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The two most important changes that will be brought about if this Bill is passed in the Senate will be the introduction of a $2.50 prescription charge for pensioners and the taking of pharmacy remuneration out of the hands of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal.

The Government's Budget decision to charge sickness beneficiaries and holders of the pensioner health benefit cards $2.50 per prescription is a complete turnaround from what it said before the election. I draw to the attention of honourable senators the July issue of the Age Pension News. Only today, Senator Richardson, in an answer at Question Time, talked about the value of this publication and said how wonderful it was for pensioners. It was wonderful for pensioners in July. The headline in the July 1989 edition was, `Government Guarantee: No Charges for Pensioners'. What did it say under the headline?

The Federal Government has given an unconditional guarantee to age pensioners with pensioner health benefit cards that they will not be charged for medication they receive under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
Further on this wonderful Age Pension News says:
Payment arrangements for pensioners using the PBS will not be changing and the Government has no plans to charge pensioners with a PHB card for drugs subsidised under the scheme.

That is what pensioners were told in July. Time rolled on and in the December 1989 issue of Age Pension News, a smaller issue, pensioners were told, `Free medication to continue'. Honourable senators on the other side are hanging their heads in shame. This is what pensioners were told in December 1989: `Free medication to continue'. The article said:

Pensioners can rest assured that they will continue to get their medications free under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Since 1950, pensioners have received essential medication free under the scheme and this will continue.
These comments were not just confined to the Government's supposedly reassuring media propaganda campaign. It was the `Minister for pharmaceutical somersaults', who himself claimed last August:
But the sorts of things that have been put forward to offset the rising costs of the PBS, such as altering safety net provisions and making pensioners pay . . . I do not think solve the basic issues.
The same Minister must break out in a hot sweat, or at least embarrassment, every time he recalls the comment that he made. He said:

It concerns me that there are a lot of people who are currently being over concerned and frightened by what some pharmacists are saying. I think that is a concern because there are many people who are old and frail and who depend upon their pharmaceuticals for their health care and they are unnecessarily concerned. The reality is that many pharmacists have had posters in their windows that say `pensioners to pay-the Government's next step'.
