The Minister was condemning the pharmacists for scaring the pensioners. Well the pharmacists were right. The pharmacists' crystal balls were much more accurate than the Minister's crystal ball. So here we have pensioners being told in two issues of Age Pension News, those of July and December, that they are not going to pay for their medication and then in the Budget, less than a year later, that they will be paying for their medication. The hypocrisy of this Government has to be seen to be believed.

The Labor Party betrayed a group in our society which is quite understandably the least capable of coping with changes-on again, off again changes. No wonder pensioners are confused and feeling frightened. Before the election the Government repeatedly told them that it would not charge them for prescriptions and then it did exactly the opposite. To have Senator Cook sit there yesterday and say that the Government was going to stand by its election promises made me roar with laughter and must have made every pensioner in this country laugh. In the light of this complete turnaround I reckon we would have to go a long way to find any pensioners who still believe what this Government tells them.

Traits such as integrity and honesty are something that are very important to the elderly, but sadly these words have been deleted from the vocabulary and behaviour of the Government's dealings with its senior citizens. When people retire they are looking for some stability. What do they get from this Government? They do not get stability. They are looking for guarantees at last, not promises that are broken at the drop of a hat.

Since the announcement of the $2.50 pensioner charge in the Budget it has become very obvious that the Government gave no prior thought to how this initiative would be implemented. Almost daily we hear of the Government's latest cut and paste attempt to minimise the hardship caused by the implementation of this proposal. First we had Senator Richardson admitting that the social security phones were running hot about the imposition of this charge and something had to be done to compensate financially the chronically ill. Then we had Ministers Howe and Staples as well as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) telling Senator Richardson to forget his compensation proposal. Lo and behold, Labor's number-crunching right wing power broker won the battle and a joint press statement was issued announcing a $50 lump sum payment at the beginning of November.

Then Minister Howe was reportedly trying to convince the States not to apply the subsumed payment to people in State subsidised housing, even though the Government had not thought about how it was going to control nursing homes and had not thought through what sorts of amendments would be made to stop the nursing homes taking 87.5 per cent of the $2.50. That had not even crossed its mind. So at the same time as all this was going on, Minister Staples was claiming that he would ensure that nursing homes did not take 87.5 per cent of the $2.50 increase when it was subsumed in the pension in March 1991.

Then last night in the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs committee stage of this Bill, Minister Richardson told us that the $2.50 will not be subsumed in the pension but will remain an additional payment that will be quarantined from the pension. I also know that it will not be able to be quarantined for people in special accommodation housing and other facilities in the States that are not Commonwealth funded. The Commonwealth's never ending toing-and-froing in regard to this matter has left pensioners not knowing whether they are Arthur or Martha and the Government's teething problems are not over with even now. As I mentioned, how will the Government ensure that the $2.50 pension supplement is not incorporated into the fixed percentage fees charged by non-government subsidised housing? The fact is, as I mentioned before, it cannot.

Another question that should be asked here is why the Government has restricted the $50 lump sum payment to full-rate pensioners. Part-rate pensioners who are eligible for the pension health benefit card are just as likely to be chronically ill, but hardly any more able to cope with this costing position in the short term. Why is the same $50 lump sum payment being paid to single pensioners and pensioner couples? Surely married couples are twice as likely to be financially burdened by having to pay for multiple prescriptions within a short period. We keep getting the safety net argument from Senator Richardson, but it is irrelevant because this problem relates to the speed in which single and married pensioners will use the 52 pensions for which they are being compensated and not the level at which the safety net takes effect.

What will happen to the sick pensioner who has not got the money to pay for a prescription, but who fronts up at a pharmacy urgently requiring treatment? I suppose he might as well wait for the money because he is going to be waiting a long time while the pharmacist rings a doctor to get a substitute drug, especially if the pharmacist cannot find the doctor. I suppose the pensioner will be able to sit there and wait until the doctor gets the substitution and his next $2.50 turns up. I guess he will have to wait about as long for both. Will the pensioner, upon realising that it is going to take some time to get the substitute or that he has not got the money for his or her prescription just not bother to obtain treatment?

The President of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners claims that increasing morbidity and mortality in the elderly will ensue from this $2.50 charge. This claim should not be rejected as being totally alarmist. There will be some older pensioners who, in fact, go without their medication because of the confusion, because of the fact that this has not been thought through. It is a valid argument that this $2.50 charge financially rewards pensioners who do not get scripts filled and fails to provide emergency relief for those who want and need a drug but simply cannot afford it.

There has also been little consideration of how the Government's new minimum pricing policy will affect pensioners. As I said last night, the elderly are the biggest users of pharmaceuticals and they will be most affected by the decision to make the consumer pay the difference between the cheapest alternative and the drug prescribed. It will place an extra financial burden on pensioners especially as the extra amount paid for the more expensive drug will not count towards the safety net. I think many of them will opt for the more expensive drug, and may go without other things because they are familiar with that drug and also because they maybe too sick to stand and wait while the pharmacist gets the change. I am not sure that in six weeks we are going to be able to educate doctors to change their prescribing habits.

My concerns are not restricted just to the repercussions of this decision. There is growing evidence to suggest that this charge will not necessarily help stop the blow-out in the pharmaceutical budget. Given that I am of the opinion that these measures will not ensure that the cost of the PBS will not continue to grow, what else should be done? A paper prepared by the Australian Institute of Health, which is government-funded, found no evidence of hoarding and wasting of drugs by pensioners and that they might be more careful than other groups in the use of them. If this is correct, the $2.50 charge on pensioners appears to be addressing the wrong target. The Government seems to have refused to address overprescribing.

One might ask why there is a problem of over prescribing in the community. The significant factor would be community attitudes to drug taking. If people go to the doctor there is an expectation that they will leave the surgery with a script, and if that does not happen it is felt that the doctors have not been doing their job. I believe that we need to change this attitude in the community. We need to change it by educating doctors, and I shall be interested to see whether the new vocational registration program has any effect; I do not believe it will.

We need to change practices in medical schools so that doctors address preventive measures and look at other ways of treating patients than necessarily prescribing pharmaceuticals. Doctors should feel that it is okay to see patients and send them away without a prescription. The community should be educated to the view that in many cases this is the right thing to do.

Doctors also rely heavily on information regarding new drugs and therapies from the pharmaceutical manufacturers. We all know the great effort that goes into that-in fact, $200m a year is put into this effort by the pharmaceutical companies in providing this information. I believe that many doctors rely too heavily on this information, but a number of doctors have told me that the Government does not ensure that doctors have as much objective information about the available drugs as is possible and about their relative costs that are brought to their attention. This is another area where the medical community should be much more aware of their social responsibility, and of the fact that they are dealing with taxpayers' money when they write prescriptions.

Health promotion programs should also be directed to the area of prescription drugs so that the community is more aware of the dangers of drug interaction. We know-and there is evidence to suggest-that large numbers of admissions of older people to hospitals are as a result of drug interaction, which is based on over-prescribing by doctors. We were talking earlier about pensioners being frugal and looking after the way they deal with drugs, but many have been over- prescribed.

Let me give an example involving a friend of mine's mother who was admitted in a state of dementia to a public hospital in Victoria. Her doctor was bulk-billing and was visiting the woman every week. She thought that it was wonderful to see him every week, but he would also visit a number of pensioners and prescribe drugs. After the woman was detoxified in the hospital, she went from being demented back to her normal state. Now, six years later, with a new doctor and better control of her drugs, at the age of 87 she is still living at home. But at the age of 81 she looked to me as though she was heading for a nursing home and a dementia unit. That was the result of drug interaction.

There is another matter that interests me in this regard. There is more information on drug packaging to people who give their dogs worm tablets than there is on packages containing drugs to be given to humans. An owner who obtains a treatment for a tiny dog will see on the packet that so many tablets should be prescribed for a dog of that size. If the dog is an Alsatian, the owner will know the amount of drugs to be given for that size of dog. But for a thin, small woman as against a large woman-I would not use any examples here, Madam Acting Deputy President, for the purposes of comparison-or a large man, no comparative dosage would be offered on the packaging. Therefore, there are problems in that regard. Diseases or disorders arise out of the drugs that are being taken, and then a further increase in the drug bill arises from having to deal with drug-induced illness.

We should also be making the community aware of the fact that the other problem of the overuse of drugs is antibiotic resistance. It seems to me that people in the community feel that if they have a cough or a cold they have to go and get antibiotics. The other day I was with a student who was on work experience and got a sore throat. She went to see one of my colleagues here in this House and he told her, `You don't need antibiotics. You need some aspirin-and make sure you have some early nights and stay in a constant temperature'. That was the sort of treatment we had when we were younger. People actually did some home nursing. The student was quite astonished. She said to me, `I think that I need antibiotics'. I said, `Have you been spitting anything green or coloured?'. She said that she had not and I said that the doctor was probably correct in assuming that she did not need antibiotics. But that is what members of the community are demanding of the medical profession, and that is something we must change.

We should also consider how changes in lifestyle may reduce reliance on drugs. I was speaking only today to a pharmacist in my State who gave me an example involving a lady in his rural community. The lady in question was grossly overweight and was being prescribed six types of tablets a day. A new doctor, who took great interest in community medicine and preventative medicine, took her over as a patient and put her on a weight loss program which was very successful. That lady is down to one tablet a day. The doctor told me that he could relate story after story, and he is a doctor who takes an interest in his patients. Some of these patients are now reducing their medication. That is what this community needs. It needs an effective health education program aimed at doctors, medical students, allied health professionals and the community. In the long run that will be the answer to reducing the acceleration of PBS costs which are within our control.

The $2.50 is another example of the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) opening his mouth first and then being made aware of the adverse repercussions later. It is another example of this Minister-and we have seen this in nursing home legislation that he has put through-pulling a quick-fix solution out of the bag without really knowing whether his solution will have the effect that he desires.

The other major change that will be brought about by this Bill is that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal will be required to give effect to agreements between the Government and any organisation that represents a majority of approved pharmacists. I would be interested if the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasury (Senator McMullan) would say how often that could change if a group presents itself and has sufficient evidence that it represents a majority of pharmacists. I could see chaos occurring.

Clause 9 also stipulates that the Tribunal must cease any current inquiries in relation to areas which are covered by an agreement and cannot hold any further inquiries in relation to such areas. This clause renders the Tribunal redundant as an independent pharmacy remuneration decision-maker. Some of the Tribunal's recent decisions have not been well received by either the Government or the pharmacy profession, and I think most of us here in this chamber would agree. But it is a knee-jerk reaction by the Government to effectively do away with the Tribunal, as this Bill will do. When there is so much flak flying around about the Government's excessive intrusion into pharmacy, then it is surely far more sensible to maintain this independent body. Rather than making the Tribunal a mere rubber stamp the Government should direct its efforts towards improving the Tribunal's expertise and ensuring its impartiality.

The Government and the Pharmacy Guild have come to an agreement about remuneration and restructuring which the Government is desperate to implement as soon as possible-hence the speed at which this Bill has been put through this House. There is not inconsiderate disquiet in pharmacy ranks about the contents of the agreement and the effects of the changes announced in the Budget. Those of us interested in this subject know that there is not inconsiderable disquiet, and evidence could be forthcoming.

Evidence could be forthcoming, but to date I have not been given evidence which would unequivocally demonstrate that the agreement does not have the tacit support of the majority of the pharmacists. However, the need to implement one agreement does not warrant the destruction of the whole mechanism by which remuneration is decided. This is especially the case when the new mechanism leaves itself open to greater cries of government interference than before.

We have seen what has happened to education. Only yesterday, we had universities close down. One thing that has happened in education, which I argued about in this place when the legislation was going through, is that when there is no independent body between a Minister and an industry, whatever that might be-whether it be higher education or pharmacy-there is great concern. When I was speaking on the education legislation I referred to a speech by Mr Barry Jones, the then Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, when he was talking about the textile, clothing and manufacturing industry and how it was to have an independent body. In fact, I quoted from his speech. That Minister was aware of the need to have an independent body. But here we have Minister Staples making impotent the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal.

In the long term these changes subject the pharmacy profession to the whim of government as never before. It also increases the likelihood that informed and impartial decision making will be constricted by conflict between the Government and pharmacists. As well-we have seen it happening now-there will be internal squabbling within peak pharmacy organisations. Both the Government and pharmacists will soon learn that sacking the umpire because they do not agree with his decision can mean that they have to start playing the game according to the rules of the jungle.

The demolition of the Tribunal, like the imposition of the $2.50 charge, is a bandaid which the Government hopes will provide a quick fix to the most immediately pressing pharmaceutical problems. As I said before, the Government has failed to properly think through the short and long term ramifications of either of these changes. Most importantly, there is no evidence to suggest that either of these changes will result in any significant improvement in either the cost or effectiveness of our pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats consider the Social Welfare Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1990 to be particularly significant and one which will have a great and detrimental impact upon many Australians. As such, I welcome the opportunity to comment on the Bill and to foreshadow the actions of the Australian Democrats as this legislation is put to the vote.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators are aware, this legislation amends a number of Acts and has a number of implications. I shall be dealing with those parts of the legislation which give effect to the Government's announcement in the Budget of changes in the level of patient contribution under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS), particularly the decision to start charging pensioners and beneficiaries $2.50 per prescription from 1 November. My colleague Senator Coulter will deal with those parts of the legislation that cover the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal.

Honourable senators are already aware of the contents of this legislation, and I trust that they are also aware of the great concern being expressed throughout the community at the prospect of the introduction of a $2.50 prescription charge, particularly for pensioners. Indeed, since this move was signalled by the Government in the Budget the Australian Democrats have received numerous letters and telephone calls from invalid and age pensioners as well as community groups and welfare organisations, all expressing their concern about this ill-considered proposal.

Just how ill-considered the measure is can be clearly judged by the fact that it had to be significantly altered following its introduction to the House of Representatives when the Government realised that, contrary to its claims, the original proposal would adversely affect significant numbers of pensioners, particularly those suffering from chronic illnesses.

The bright sparks that thought up this proposal then had to do a quick back flip, with the result that we now have a provision for the payment of advance pharmaceutical supplements. This is certainly a welcome recognition by the Government that it had not properly considered the effects of this Bill in the first place. But it still fails to address the serious concerns which the Democrats and many welfare and pensioner organisations have about the Bill. We believe the imposition of a $2.50 charge on pensioners for pharmaceutical benefits is poorly considered and ill-founded.

The Government has been arguing for some time that there is some sort of massive blow-out in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme which justifies higher consumer contribution. This is yet another example of the Government's using colourful rhetoric in its desire to obscure the facts. Yes, the PBS expenditure is escalated, and yes, it must of course be of concern to any government.

But there are a number of important points worth making. First, the claim of a blow-out needs to be critically examined. The Government likes to bandy around the figure of about $1.2 billion per year in PBS expenditure. On paper and in the mouths of Government Ministers and spokespersons this figure looks and sounds alarming. Add to it the claims of the Department of Community Services and Health that PBS expenditure will double by 1992 and we have a startling picture of uncontrolled, rapidly escalating costs. Is this the real picture?

Many very well-informed people who operate in the real world beyond this Government's limited horizons say that this is not the real picture and that the Government is basing its policies on the reform of the PBS on misinformation and totally inadequate data. For example, the pharmacy consultancy firm of Feros, Riley and Associates, which appeared before the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs when it examined the Bill, has monitored PBS expenditure for the past two years. It believes the actual expenditure over the next few years will be well below the projections of the Department of Community Services and Health. I think we also have to bring some critical factors to bear when looking at PBS expenditure. The term `blow-out' is vastly misleading. It implies a sudden, dramatic escalation in costs, whereas what has occurred is a significant but gradual increase over many years, an increase that can be quite adequately explained by inflation, the increasing size of our population and, most importantly, the increasing aged population.

Secondly, a number of factors may be contributing to unnecessary expenditure beyond the role of consumers. Critical factors include: the role of doctors in dispensing drugs to pensioners; the role of promotional advertising relating to cost effective prescribing by doctors; the number and age range of pharmaceuticals available within the PBS; the role of pharmacists in dispensing drugs to pensioners and the lack of consumer awareness about pharmaceuticals in general, as Senator Patterson has already outlined.

I do not believe that the Government knows the true impact of these different factors on the PBS expenditure, and until it does, it has absolutely no justification for forcing pensioners and other consumers to bear the brunt of the Government's desire to reduce the cost of the PBS system. The Government's simplistic method of reducing the consumption of pharmaceuticals by raising consumer contributions is not supported by the available evidence. I can understand that it is tempting for the Government to take the view that drugs are subsidised, that there is some evidence of over-consumption, that there must be some sort of casual link between the two, and that, therefore, if it charges consumers more, the rate of consumption will fall. It all sounds very simple. But quite simply, it is not true. If this reasoning was correct, we would surely expect price rises to result in decreasing drug use. Clearly, that has not occurred, and the growth in drug use has continued steadily, despite a series of moves by various governments to increase consumer contributions.

Similarly, the demand for drugs does not fall with increasing prices. People do not suddenly start wanting prescriptions just because they are cheap. Price is quite simply not a decisive factor in the supply and consumption of pharmaceuticals. As Mr Ian McAuley, in his economic analysis of the PBS prepared for the Consumers' Health Forum, noted:

In summary, demand for drugs is largely outside the control of consumers or the control of the market price mechanisms. It has more to do with the prescribing practices of medical practitioners and with consumers' faith in drug based remedies more than with prices.
Similarly, the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia in its submission to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs stated:

Provider incentives have been generally reported to be more effective in altering health goods and service usage patterns than consumer copayments. Provider incentives are conspicuously absent from the PBS.

The Government's move to introduce new patient contributions is not based on fact. It is merely part of the current fashion of seeing market-oriented solutions as the be all and end all, regardless of whether or not they do, in reality, provide a solution and with scant regard for the facts fitting their theories. The Royal Australian College of Practitioners expressed it in these terms:

The aim of Government to cut down the pharmaceutical cost to the community for drugs needed by pensioners may be theoretically laudable: the effect on the elderly, however, may well be medically disastrous.

I think that is precisely the point. The Government does not know what the effects of this legislation will be on pensioners. It is gambling with the health and the lives of elderly, sick and disabled Australians. Further, even if PBS expenditure is $2 billion per year, this amounts to an expenditure of only $2 per Australian per week on pharmaceuticals-a lot less, I might add, than the country spends on cigarettes or alcohol every week.

What we do not know when the Department and the Government toss these figures around is how much in other health costs this expenditure may be actually saving; in other words, the Government has no idea at all of the cost effectiveness of this expenditure. Is it, in fact, keeping elderly persons and invalid pensioners out of hospital? Again, these facts are missing. Is it assisting them to continue their lives in their own homes rather than have them move into government subsidised hostels or nursing homes? Is it enabling them to contribute more productively to the community, such as through voluntary work, helping their families with child-care responsibilities, et cetera?

The Government simply does not know the answers to all these-and many more-questions about the cost-effectiveness of the PBS. It cannot tell us because it does not have the data, it does not have the information and it has not undertaken any analysis. It is precisely because of this lack of information that the Australian Democrats have repeatedly called for a full-scale inquiry into the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and we continue to argue that such a review is long overdue and highly desirable.

It is grossly irresponsible of the Government and the Opposition, if they support this Bill, to proceed with a set of measures when they have absolutely no reliable data on which to base them and a great deal of extremely disturbing evidence about the possible consequences for a large proportion of our community.

Aside from the fact that this Bill has sprung from an information vacuum, there are a number of other problems in the legislation. Some of these problems arise from a mistaken assumption that pensioners are all going to be in a position to actively protect their own interests and ensure they are not financially or medically disadvantaged. We believe it is pretty obvious that this will not be the case.

Clearly, any change in the rules of play affecting the elderly and the ill is likely to cause confusion. But it is not good enough to use this difficulty as an excuse and simply to shrug one's shoulders and say, `Oh well, any changes affecting elderly people will cause them confusion; it really can't be helped'. I think we have an obligation to minimise the potential trouble and confusion caused to older persons and we should, in fact, take even greater care when we introduce measures that affect these groups. Community and professional groups have expressed their views that confusion will indeed reign supreme as a result of this legislation and that many aged and invalid pensioners will be disadvantaged as a result.

As well as having sat through the Minister's evidence to the Committee, I have to say that I am far from satisfied with the Government's proposals for an education program in relation to these changes. I think that only $3m a year will be spent. I do not believe that with that small amount of money this confusion will be greatly reduced at all, especially amongst the old, frail and isolated pensioners.

With this Bill, we are in danger of introducing a two-tier pension system-a higher rate of pension for those who are fit and well and a lower rate for those who are ill and infirm. This point was made to the Committee by the Pharmaceutical Society of Australia. It stated:

The Pharmaceutical Society is concerned that this measure significantly reduces the equitableness of the PBS. Under this proposal, pensioners who are ill will be financially disadvantaged compared to pensioners who enjoy good health. Access to PBS drugs by those who need them most will be reduced. This seems to strike hard at the heart of the Scheme's oft stated social objective of access to subsidised pharmaceuticals according to need.

Other than these very fundamental problems, various other difficulties arise throughout this Bill and the Australian Democrats sought in the Committee to move some amendments that would at least reduce the impact of the legislation. I want to go through these in some detail because I think they demonstrate that the Government really does not understand how this Bill will impact upon pensioners.

Firstly, pensioners-especially those with a chronic condition-are likely to experience a reduction in their income due to the increased costs of medicines. It needs to be very clearly understood by this chamber that the additional $2.50 provided for does not allow for the increased costs a pensioner may have to pay if he is not prescribed the cheapest drug by his medical practitioner. Again, Senator Patterson went through this is some detail. The increased amount does not count towards the safety net. The safety net means that the pensioner will have to carry his card with him at all times when he wants medication. He will have to make sure that it is filled out properly, that he does not lose it or, indeed, that it is not stolen.

Secondly, the advance payment arrangements also raise their own problems. In reality, they will offer only limited protection to a small proportion of the pensioner population. The Government tells us that it introduced these moves to protect the chronically ill pensioners but, of course, it is simply not possible for the Government accurately to target such pensioners under its proposal and it has opted instead to target the poorest pensioners by restricting advances beyond the first payment to those pensioners who have liquid assets of less than only $1,000 and who earn less than $10 a week in non-pension income.

This move does assist in some way. But we believe that it is a paltry amount and in committee sought to have these amounts raised. It relies on pensioners themselves recognising that they are eligible for the additional advances and going through the process of making arrangements to secure such advances. This will be difficult, if not impossible, for those pensioners who are confused, frail, isolated in their own home or simply not in receipt of good, if any, advice.

It relies upon pensioners comprehending the nature of the advances and being able to exercise a choice about setting money aside for potential medical needs. As a number of groups have pointed out, many pensioners may forget what the extra amount was for and spend it on other items or may simply have other more pressing items on which they spend their $2.50.
The legislation still fails to address the problem of multiple scripts being required at any one time. The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners pointed out to the Committee:

. . . pensioners will have great difficulty in paying $10.00 in one hit for 4 drugs (repeat prescriptions); the choice of either postponing, buying the necessary drugs or not buying them at all will undoubtedly occur. As a result, increasing morbidity and mortality in the elderly will ensue.

The fact that the pharmaceutical supplement was not to continue beyond March 1991 was of major concern to the Democrats. It became evident as the Committee hearings went on that in some cases a percentage of the $2.50 was already being taken in some private rental markets despite the fact that this measure does not even come in until 1 November. Therefore, one of the amendments that we moved sought to redress this to some extent and, in particular, hopefully quarantine the amount from the hands of State governments so that the full $2.50 will flow on to pensioners.

I am very pleased to say that, though this move was defeated in the Committee by a combined vote of the Liberal and Labor senators, the Government has now taken this on board and will be moving an amendment later on in this session to another Bill to bring this into effect.

It has often been said during public discussion about these measures that they will reduce hoarding of pharmaceuticals by pensioners. Once again, I simply ask the Government: Where is the evidence? A 1986 survey by the Australian Institute of Health concludes:
No evidence of hoarding was found for either pensioners or any other group. If hoarding was significant then it seems that it should have appeared in 600 pensioner households.

The report actually goes on to say that pensioners waste fewer drugs than other drug users. But the most interesting conclusion the Australian Institute of Health reached in its survey of some 1,800 households was this:

If it is correct that persons with access to free drugs do not waste drugs-or if they do, at a rate no worse than people who pay for their drugs-then the imposition of user charges is unlikely to solve this `problem'. User charges would address the wrong target . . . if pensioners consume too many drugs then this is a problem of correcting prescribing practices.

I am very pleased to note that today I received-I stress that it is only three examples-the first examples that the Minister has provided of any overprescribing, where people received drugs in excess of their requirements. There has been no formal study that has proved that there is any large-scale overprescribing. I quote from one letter:
My aunt is not to blame.
She was 91 years of age. To continue:
She is too old to be aware of the significance of getting prescriptions dispensed unnecessarily. She merely accepts the prescription from her doctor and takes it to the chemist for dispensing.

With the Australian Institute of Health, we have an expert professional body saying that charging pensioners is not going to achieve the Government's aims. In fact, this Bill may actually promote hoarding as there is likely to be a tendency for pensioners to stockpile medicines once they reach the ceiling, the safety net. Pensioners have also indicated to me that hoarding will be encouraged as pensioners will be even more uncertain about future budgetary changes and may be more likely to stockpile their existing medications. As we heard before the Committee, there is government induced preprescribing going on now with a very large increase in the amount pensioners have obtained just in the last two months.

Another difficulty that has been the subject of much correspondence from pensioners is the fact that the supplement will be $2.50 for singles but only $1.25 per head for married couples. I must say that the continuing inequity between single and married pensioners is of particular concern to the Australian Democrats. I do not believe that in these times, when we give at least lip service to notions of equality, we can continue to see married couples as some sort of indivisible unit. Many pensioners have written to me pointing this out and arguing most convincingly that they will be individually, and as a couple, out of pocket because they both suffer from chronic illnesses with ongoing medication needs. If the Government is correct-if we do give it the benefit of the doubt just for a moment-and those pensioners who are well are going to be better off, those married pensioners are going to be only half as well off. Therefore, we say again that this is discrimination.

I also want to make a particular point about psychiatric patients. This group has been largely ignored in media and public discussion on these changes. These people were mentioned in several submissions before the Committee as being at particular risk because they may simply choose not to take medication if they are asked to pay for their prescriptions. Once again, we are talking about a group of pensioners who may lack the capacity to exercise judgment about these matters, and it is quite clear that these consumers are the ones most at risk under the new moves.

In this context, a number of groups representing people with disabilities have also expressed their concern on behalf of people with intellectual disabilities who will experience similar problems under the proposed arrangements. As well, we have heard from voluntary organisations operating nursing homes and hostels which are worried about incompetent older and disabled people who will not be able to keep track of their affairs sufficiently to be able to apply for the advances or to keep a full tally of all the prescriptions they have to the point that they reach their free limit.

There is much more that I could say about this legislation. I doubt that any proposal put forward by this Government since it came to power has attracted so much criticism and concern from the community. I can only say again that it is highly irresponsible that this Government can proceed with a move that is based on conjecture, misinformation and a total lack of knowledge about the likely effects of its proposals on the health of pensioners. What the Government and probably the Opposition are doing is quite blatantly experimenting with the health, and possibly even the lives, of a number of Australians.

I would like to put on the record the Democrat's amendments that we moved unsuccessfully in the Committee. There were a total of 14 either direct amendments or requests. The amendments covered five areas. I have already mentioned the one on quarantining. Secondly, we tried to have raised the eligibility criteria for advance payments from $1,000 to $2,000 and earnings from $10 a week to $30 a week. We still consider these to be very low amounts, but at least it represented some improvement.

We also attempted to increase the married rate of supplement to $2.50 per person. Earlier I detailed why we did this. We attempted to extend the payment of supplements to all concessional beneficiaries under the new definitions. This would have extended the supplements to recipients of unemployment benefit. We believe that the Government is creating a third or fourth class of beneficiary by continuing to hit unemployment beneficiaries extremely hard and to now imply, through this legislation, that they still do not need any assistance when other pensioners will be getting assistance for medication. That is unacceptable to the Democrats. Another amendment-and Senator Coulter will speak on this-was to remove clause 9. I note, unfortunately, that none of the amendments was supported by the Liberal or Labor parties.

I believe that the main concern of this chamber must be the effect this legislation will have on the mental and physical health of aged and invalid pensioners. It is clear that, despite the safeguards the Government finally acknowledged were necessary, this proposal introduces an incentive for forgoing medication. This would be the case with any group in the population, but it is particularly so for aged and disabled persons who are frail, confused, non-ambulant or isolated. The Australian Democrats cannot and will not support such ill-founded legislation. I can only hope that the Opposition will agree that there is no evidence to support the need for this legislation and that, even if some money was going to be saved, it is far too high a price to pay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Social Welfare (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1990 is a unique one. It is the first time, under the new Senate standing committee system, that the Selection of Bills Committee, with the support of the Senate, has recommended that a Bill be sent to the appropriate Senate standing committee before the second reading debate. The result of the actual inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, I believe, is very positive. I say `actual inquiry' because it is separate from the conduct of the Committee and is a totally different matter. I will speak on that later. First of all, I will deal with the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill introduces for the first time payments by pensioners for those drugs on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS). This is despite the promises that Senator Patterson referred to-promises made by the Government prior to the last election that no additional costs would be imposed for pharmaceutical benefits. The Government has said that this is purely and simply a cost cutting exercise. It claims that if pensioners are forced to pay $2.50 per prescription this will reduce the number of prescriptions that pensioners obtain and, therefore, will cut the cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme for the Government. We will have to wait and see whether this occurs. We will have to see whether the Government is right and whether pensioners will not take their prescriptions to pharmacists to be filled. We will have to wait and see what does happen as a result of this legislation.

To save pensioners being disadvantaged, the Government tells us that it intends to increase the pension by $2.50 a week, which it hopes will cover the cost of the average pension. The concern is that pensioners may decide not to present their prescriptions that are vital for their health because they either run out of money or have other priorities as to how they spend that $2.50.

To assist pensioners who require a number of drugs in the first few months, the Government has decided to give pensioners entitled to full pension a one-off lump sum of $50 and two other small lump sums at later dates. There will be a safety net so that once a pensioner uses the full entitlement in one year-that is, $130-all further PBS drugs will be free.

We have been told that the pharmacists will keep a record of the number and type of drugs the pensioner has bought so that when the pensioner reaches that safety net level, he or she will be able to apply for free drugs. The Government has decided to further save money by allowing only generic drugs to be prescribed for eligibility to that $2.50 benefit. Pensioners will have to change their usual brand of drugs for generic ones.

Mostly, there is very little difference between the chemical makeup of the generic drugs and non-generic drugs, but packaging, size and colour are vastly different. For an aged pensioner taking several drugs a day it can be very confusing. For instance, pensioners are used to taking the large blue one after breakfast, the small yellow one and the bigger green one with lunch and perhaps the small white one with tea. That is how it is described by the doctor; that is how it is described by the pharmacist. But now, if they are using the generic drugs, all the tablets will be white and all the same size. If they insist on using their usual brand, then they will have to pay the $2.50 plus the additional cost of that particular drug.

Evidence was given to the Committee regarding the need for quarantining. Evidence was given to us that if the amount of $2.50 for the total pension was not quarantined, then State governments, nursing homes, et cetera, could use that $2.50 as a percentage of their usual accommodation costs to pensioners. The concern was that after 1 February 1990, when the $2.50 became part of the increase in pension, the purpose of the amount would soon be forgotten.

Tonight the Australian Democrats have shown their concern by putting forward an amendment in an attempt to rectify this. But we were told by the Government that this was not necessary. In our last meeting on Wednesday night we were told that the Government has decided to bring in amendments to a subsequent Bill to quarantine this amount. This we applaud. This is why I earlier said that the actual inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs has been very positive. The evidence was given in front of the bureaucrats. The bureaucrats and the Minister heard the situation from the people who came and gave evidence along this line. They were able to get their views across very clearly. So the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) was able to change the legislation to have this $2.50 quarantined.

A list of people will be eligible under the scheme. I quote that list because most people think it applies only to aged pensioners. It applies to aged pensioners, invalid pensioners, people receiving a wife's pension, a carer's pension, a sole parent's pension, a widowed person's allowance, a sheltered employment allowance, a rehabilitation allowance, or a class B widow's pension. The rate of those pensions or allowances referred to in that list is not reduced on the basis of a person's income maintenance, income or property. An additional category to that list is people aged 60 and over who have been receiving unemployment benefits for at least six months. We all know the problems of those over 60 in being able to get a subsequent job.

The Bill also increases the maximum contribution by the general public from $11 to $15, again with a safety net, so that once a person has paid out $300 in any one year, all following prescriptive drugs will be free of charge.

This brings me to a major concern-the agreement between the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the Government. To permit the Government to lower the remuneration to pharmacists and save itself money, the Government has given the pharmacists permission to overcharge a general client by up to $2. Should a drug cost $13-we had evidence before our Committee that the average drug costs roughly between $12 and $13-then the pharmacist will be permitted to charge an additional $2, making a total of $15. That, after all the abuse heaped on the head of the profession just over 12 months ago!

We all remember those headlines in the papers-`Government may be forced to legislate to stop drug rip-offs' and `Federal Government is looking at ways of changing legislation for the pharmaceutical benefits scheme to prevent pharmacists overcharging for prescription drugs'. We then had the next one-`How chemists rip you off on prescriptions'.

In August last year the Federal Department of Community Services and Health launched an investigation into what is believed to be millions of dollars worth of overcharging by pharmacists. We now have the situation sanctioned by the Government. The Government is saying to the pharmacists, `You have a right to rip off the general public as far as the prescriptions are concerned. You can overcharge to the tune of $2 because, if you get that money in, we can pay you less as regards your prescription rate'. I have never quite believed that such hypocrisy by any Government could exist, but I guess this Government's hypocrisy is unlimited.

Last night on another piece of legislation I spoke at length about the closing down and amalgamation provisions of the Guild's agreement with the Government. Under this agreement, if a pharmacist has owned a pharmacy for, say, 16 years-and it does go up and down-then the Government, to encourage closures, will buy the pharmacist out. The Government would agree to pay the pharmacist $80,000-that is, if he or she owned it for 16 years. The Government, or rather the taxpayer, would pay half of that; the other half would go as a debt to the remaining pharmacists. The total buy outs could result in many millions of dollars. As I say, the taxpayer pays half and the remaining pharmacists pay the other half.

The method used to force the remaining pharmacists to pay that debt is 1c on every pharmaceutical benefits prescription written in the first year, 2c in the second year, 3c in the third year, 4c in the fourth year, et cetera, until the debt is paid.
At a meeting of the New South Wales branch of the Pharmacy Guild on 16 October, just a few days ago, a motion was passed by about 90 votes to 10. I quote that motion:

The Annual General Meeting directs the State Branch President of the NSW Branch of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia to advise the National President and ALL National Councillors that any Amalgamation / Closure package which is to be substantially FUNDED BY EVERY APPROVED PHARMACIST be removed from the current or any subsequent agreement between the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and any other party.

Ninety people at the annual general meeting of the New South Wales branch of the Guild voted against that amalgamation-closure. That is only New South Wales, and I do not know how the other States view that, but I do know that by a very large majority the New South Wales branch opposes that part of the agreement. It was not just that motion; there were many motions. Another states:
This meeting rejects the statement from the H.I.C. that ALL Pharmacies from 1st February, 1991 will be required to submit NHS and Repat payments by way of C.T.S.
There was also motion G, and this, perhaps, is the most telling of all because it states:

We, members of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, N.S.W. Branch, present at the A.G.M., demand the resignation of the National Councillors who were in office at the time the original ``Heads of Agreement'' was prepared and presented publicly on 22nd July 1990, because this National Council herein referred to has failed to further and protect the interests of its members by presenting with the Commonwealth, a parallel submission to the P.B.R.T. for ratification. By so doing this same National Council has disadvantaged its members both financially and professionally. Consequently, the Members of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia present at the A.G.M. direct the Branch President, to institute this action within 5 days.

I wish I had time to read the other motions because it would be very clear to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is at the table, that there is great dissension between the members of the Guild. I believe the Guild has already been presented with more than enough signatures to hold a referendum. I do not believe the Government should go ahead with the agreement between the Guild and the Government until that referendum has taken place.

I now come to clause 9 because that is the crux of the whole situation. Clause 9 requires the Pharmaceutical Benefits Tribunal to rubber-stamp any agreement between the Government and any organisation which represents the majority of approved pharmacists. At the moment, that is the Guild. What will happen after the referendum? Will it still be the Guild or will the Guild members-or hierarchy-be forced to go to another election?

We have been told there is to be a meeting tomorrow-and I would like to ask the Minister if he would verify that- between the Tribunal, the Guild and the Government, or between the Government and the Guild, for ratification. There are so many sections of that agreement which the New South Wales Branch, at least-as I say, I do not know how the other States fare-is totally opposed to, that I believe it would be wrong in the extreme if the Government went ahead with it under the present situation. As I say, the Guild has its problems. It has received more than enough signatures for that referendum. It should be held as quickly as possible, and the Government should insist upon knowing who it should be talking to-just which members of the Guild have the numbers. I believe it would be totally immoral of the Government, knowing the present situation within the Pharmacy Guild, to go ahead with this legislation, not knowing for sure that the majority of the membership backs it.

The agreement between the Guild and the Government covers many issues. One section of that agreement the pharmacists really believed was binding was that part in which the Government promised not to introduce any further cost disadvantages for pharmacists without full consultation. Of course, we now know that that promise also was broken-not only the promise to the pensioners that their costs would not be increased, but also the promise to the Guild that any further costs would have full consultation before implementation. Of course, we know that the budgetary decisions now place tremendous cost disadvantage on the pharmacists. This is in the way of computers, black boxes, et cetera. Many Guild members believe that, because this promise was broken, the whole of the agreement should be scrapped.

It is no use the Government saying it was a Budget decision, and that it cannot consult over Budget decisions. It need not have been a Budget decision; it could have been a decision made by the Government after the Budget-after full consultation-if it wished to keep its side of the agreement. But no, the Government decided that it would not stick to its agreement and that it would force through these Bills which are presently before us for no other reason than that it knows that the Opposition will not oppose a Budget Bill.

My remaining concern is the fact that a file is kept on every pensioner. We asked many questions about this in the Committee. We know that a pensioner's name and number and the drug that is being used are kept in the file and will be passed on to the Government. We are told that all the privacy in the world will be maintained, but this is of remaining concern to the Opposition and we will be maintaining a close watch on the situation. I asked if the general public's prescribing would also be kept and passed on to the Government. I was told no, that while the pharmacists may collect the names of members of the general public and the drugs used, they would not be passing on that information to the Government.

As I said, I believe the actual inquiry undertaken by the Senate Standing Committee resulted in a sensible change being made by the Government, that of quarantining the $2.50. I only hope the Government will not rush through the signing of that agreement between the Guild and itself, which, I believe, it intends to do tomorrow. If it does, and the referendum results in the majority of pharmacists being opposed to that agreement, the Government will only be brewing trouble for itself. I urge the Minister to take note of my concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Welfare Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill 1990 is ill-conceived and unfair, and I believe it will not work. To the extent that it does work as the Government hopes it will, I believe it will cause more harm and trouble for the people on the receiving end of this legislation and, indeed, the Government itself. The Australian Democrats certainly will be voting against this legislation at the end of this second reading debate. I invite members of the Opposition, in view of the way in which they have adduced all the very good arguments as to why this legislation should not pass, to join with us in voting against this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: If members of the Opposition are minded to vote for the legislation on the grounds that this is a money Bill or a Budget Bill, I reflect back to them their own arguments that the costs which are intended to be saved by this legislation will be spent elsewhere in the Government's Budget, that the Government will neither gain nor lose money and that, therefore, to vote against this legislation will not make one jot of difference to the budgetary outcome.

In view of the observation that we have several journalists in the press gallery and no doubt many others outside looking at television screens, I ask them to observe-given the arguments raised by the Opposition-the way in which the Opposition votes at the end of this second reading stage.

The explanatory memorandum which the Government has provided says that the Bill seeks to reallocate-I emphasise `reallocate'-Commonwealth subsidies through the introduction of a charge of $2.50 for those pensioners who currently receive prescriptions for free under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) with a protective safety net and a corresponding increase in pension payments of $2.50 for single pensioners and $1.25 for married pensioners.

I ask the Senate to observe the word `reallocate', because it is our contention that, except for the pitfalls in the legislation-I will mention those later on-which may indeed cause the overall cost to the Government to increase rather than decrease, even if this legislation works as intended it may well be that all that will happen will be a redistribution or a reallocation, to use the Government's word, from that money which appears in the PBS pile to the money which flows to pensioners through this alternative means of an addition to pension payments of $2.50 per week.

The cost is further picked up, as several honourable senators have mentioned, through the initiation of a safety net of $130 a year, which corresponds to the $2.50 per week or one prescription per week. We believe that, as my colleague Senator Lees has stated and, indeed, as several members of the Opposition have already stated, this legislation is ill-conceived because it aims its cost impediment at the wrong people.

It is doctors who write prescriptions and pharmacists who dispense them. This would intrude into the system by placing an extra cost impediment on the recipient of the final drugs. It is very difficult to conceive precisely how that cost impediment will feed back to the doctor when he writes the prescription and whether it will cause him to write less prescriptions. When the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) came before the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, in a hearing which I was able to attend briefly, he said that the estimates of savings were quite rubbery and that there was no clear indication that the Government would save any particular and precise amount.

There was an expectation, based, evidently, on unexplained foreign experience, that when a charge was put in the way of pensioners the number of prescriptions would fall. Quite clearly, it would depend upon the pensioner saying to the doctor, `What are you prescribing for me? Do you really need to prescribe that because I don't want to pay any more than I absolutely have to', and the pensioner, who has to pay the extra $2.50, prevailing on the doctor to prescribe fewer drugs. Presumably, the scheme will work to the extent that the pensioner is successful.

There was no really good evidence provided that doctors are overprescribing and that pensioners are receiving large numbers of drugs which are not absolutely essential for them. So it seems to the Democrats that the Bill is basically ill-conceived. It aims its impediment to cost increases at the wrong people. The impediment really needs to be aimed at doctors, if there is overprescribing.

In the hearing to which I referred to a moment ago and which I attended, the Minister pointed out that the Government was going to spend an extra $3m in an advertising campaign aimed at doctors. But when I asked the Minister whether he had any estimate of the amount being spent by pharmaceutical companies which, from my own personal experience, I know regularly visit doctors-they put a foot in the door and give doctors all sorts of lovely goodies and a great deal of very glossy literature, which perhaps does not influence older doctors so much who are more worldly wise in these matters but which certainly influences the prescribing habits of young doctors-he said that he believed that some $130m was spent by pharmaceutical companies to persuade doctors to prescribe the drugs of the company's choice.

It is easy to make the comparison between $3m and $130m and to suggest that the Government's amount is paltry-it is about 2 per cent of the amount being spent by drug companies. Again, certainly in my mind, it is doubtful that the little bit that is being done by this Government-which is aimed in the right direction-will be particularly effective.

We are also concerned, as I think Senator Walters has pointed out, that there are a number of pensioners who are on non-generic drugs and that the safety net does nothing to pick up the difference between those non-generic drugs which may be more expensive and the generic drugs.

We are left with a situation in which if a doctor insisted, for very good reasons, on a non-generic drug being prescribed, an individual application would need to be made for special dispensation so that pensioner could get that particular drug for a reason that was laid out for him. Of course, that is a very expensive, time consuming process and it is doubtful whether it would apply to very many pensioners.

Senator Walters has also pointed out the difficulties that may well arise when pensioners who are old and frail and are becoming somewhat mentally confused are changed from a non-generic drug to a generic drug. This can happen if, in some instances, the generic drug is different in shape or colour. Examples were given to the Committee of pensioners who had not taken a drug. In one instance it was thought that two tablets were identical and in other instances doses had been doubled up because the tablets appeared to be different.

One does not need to have very many instances of that sort, with the consequence of a patient spending time in hospital, for there to be a very considerable blow-out in the overall cost to government of the treatment of pensioners. Of course, the costs are not going to show up in the PBS. The PBS costs may indeed go down. But they will certainly show up somewhere else in the Government's costs for hospitalisation.

While on that subject I, and I think several other honourable senators, raised with the Minister the problem of psychiatric patients, specifically those patients who were suffering from schizophrenia. In my recent experience I know of two patients who went off medication and attempted suicide. It is well-known by anybody who has had anything to do with patients like this that these patients very often are extremely difficult to keep on medication. When they are well they feel they do not need it; when they are deluded they are not sufficiently psychiatrically able to judge that they do need their medication. To place a further impediment of $2.50 in the way of the continued medication of these patients may well lead to numbers of them finishing up in hospital.

I simply point out again that the costs to the Government may well not appear in the PBS account but they will certainly appear elsewhere as a cost either to the Government or to the community somewhere. That is something which I believe the Government has not given sufficient consideration to. The charge for PBS prescriptions to pharmacists will also place a further considerable burden on pharmacists. I think that has been touched on by several of the previous speakers.

Pharmacists will need to report more carefully the number of prescriptions which have been filled so that the safety net conditions can be satisfied. Also, in cases in which a non-generic drug has been prescribed and the pensioner then reacts with some shock at the costs, the pharmacist can choose to ring the doctor and say, `Is it possible that I can dispense a non-generic drug as a substitute?'. I would point out that it is professionally totally improper for a pharmacist to make a substitution without consulting the doctor and so the pharmacist in those cases will be subject to a great deal more work. There will be, I understand, a $2 fee with which the pharmacist will be able to be recompensed under those circumstances.

Some pharmacist's practices have a very large number of pensioners, and particularly pensioners in nursing homes. This is so of the area in which I live and I think the pharmacist there would say that most of his clients are in nursing homes. He may well have a large number of those at least in the initial few months until those pensioners who are to be put on generic drugs have been transferred across. We believe that there are a number of issues involved in this $2.50 fee which places an unfair burden on pensioners, and we query whether the system will work as the Government evidently intends it to work, because it is aiming the feedback loop in the wrong direction.

The other matter that I want to address is the matter of clause 9. Today we have seen both the Government and the Opposition vote for the importation of scab labour to deal with those who exhibited no incompetence in a professional capacity but whose political views in relation to recompense for their labours was not acceptable to the Government. We saw a very unsavoury precedent created today when Government and Opposition voted that way in relation to allowing pilots into this country to fly our aircraft when we have a number of unemployed people in this country who are quite professionally capable of executing that task.

In the case of clause 9, we see another potentially very serious precedent being created. It relates very much to the industrial relations legislation which we also have before the Senate at the present time. The industrial relations legislation will allow the unions to enter into arrangements, and the question of whether an individual who is a member of a union, or an individual or a group of individuals who are not members of the union, can intrude into the decision-making process before the Industrial Relations Tribunal is very much an issue which is fundamental to the whole process of democracy. This involves the rights of individuals-in the case of the industrial tribunals-to be heard in relation to their employment.

Clause 9 says that the Tribunal-in this case the Remuneration Tribunal-must give effect to an agreement between the Pharmacy Guild of Australia or another pharmacists organisation that represents the majority of approved pharmacists, and the Government. In other words, to use Senator Walters's terms, the hands of the Tribunal will be tied by clause 9. The first part of clause 9 begs a very important question: If the Government were to enter into an agreement with the Pharmacy Guild, how does it know and in what sense does the Pharmacy Guild represent a majority of pharmacists? Does it mean that, if 80 or 90 per cent of pharmacists are members of the Guild, automatically the Pharmacy Guild represents a majority of pharmacists? It might be in this particular instance in relation to this agreement that the Guild is quite out of step with its members, that it in no sense represents-I am not suggesting that it does but it may well be-the majority of its members. So, does the first part of clause 9 mean that it represents the pharmacists in a general sense, or does it mean that it represents pharmacists in this particular instance with respect to this particular agreement? Clause 9 is not clear on that particular point.

I am not in any sense personally reflecting on the agreement here, because the agreement may or may not be a good agreement or a bad agreement. It may be the least agreement which the Guild could negotiate with the Government. The terms, while perhaps unsatisfactory to many pharmacists, may be the only agreement that could be achieved. I am not reflecting on that. I am reflecting on the fact that there may be one dissenting pharmacist in Australia or there may be a large number of dissenting pharmacists. There is evidence that there are a considerable number of pharmacists-I do not know whether it is a majority or not-who disagree with this agreement, but clause 9 freezes them out and they do not have an opportunity to be heard. Clause 9 goes on and says-it is not applicable in this case- that if the Tribunal has a matter under consideration and an agreement is reached, then even that process must be stopped and the Tribunal must give effect to the agreement.

Our very name, the Australian Democrats, means that one of our fundamental commitments is to democratic process, and clause 9 is not democratic. It is not democratic to freeze members out of a negotiation, to deny even the opportunity to be heard in an important matter such as a far-reaching agreement between the Government and the Guild which deals with complex matters of the mark-up charges, the fees for dispensing, the closure of pharmacies, and the remuneration of pharmacies that will be merged or closed. All those very important questions should properly be open to the submission of alternative evidence from one or any number of pharmacists who might disagree with that agreement.

It may be that there is no substance to their argument; it may be that there is a substantial argument there. Whatever the objective substance of their argument, they have a right to be heard and clause 9 is like the vote which was taken earlier today; clause 9 is anti-democratic in the extreme. It is for that reason that the Democrats and the Opposition, I understand from what it has said, are strongly opposed to it. The Democrats are opposed to this legislation for a number of reasons. We are opposed because, as I said in my opening remarks, we believe it is unfair, we believe it is wrongly constructed and we believe it will not achieve the objectives for which it was ostensibly designed. With particular reference to clause 9, we believe it is extremely un- democratic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on some aspects of the Social Welfare Legislation (Pharmaceutical Benefits) Amendment Bill, as I was a member of the Senate Committee which considered it. I am pleased that the senior members of the Department are present. My only regret is that Senator Richardson is absent.

SPEECH.PARA: I was particularly interested in the statements made by the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, Mr Staples, and the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, that one of the reasons for the introduction of this Bill was the problem of overprescribing. I have asked a number of people what they understood by the term `overprescribing'. All without exception said, `Doctors writing too many prescriptions', or words to that effect. I asked the question of Senator Richardson in committee-not once, not twice, but three times. I asked, firstly, for a definition of the term and, secondly, for the statistics to back up his statement that it was a major concern.

The Minister undertook to get from the Department a written reply. The reply was illuminating in more ways than one. There was no answer to my question on the definition of overprescribing. The Department produced three examples of hoarding-I repeat, hoarding-by three or four patients. Two that they referred to as hoarding were classic cases of kleptomania, and diagrams and photographs of these particular examples were produced.

In one, the deceased patient was found to have 1,000 tablets of Brufen, 1,000 tablets of Naprosyn, 3,500 tablets of Indocid and 9,400 tablets of Tegretol. If ever there was a classic case of kleptomania, that is it. That is the overprescribing. Obviously, those patients were able to obtain those quantities by taking advantage of the bulk billing situation. Obviously, they had a health care card or they would never have been able to afford the acquisition of that quantity of drugs over any period of time unless they were psychologically or psychiatrically disturbed and had access to free drugs.

There was no answer to my question on the definition of overprescribing. There were a couple of other examples and letters referring to the fact that a lot of unused drugs were found in the belongings of deceased people by relatives. There was a lot of anecdotal evidence as well. It does not seem to occur to the Department that it is human nature to hoard drugs if one is old and infirm. In some cases also the drug need be taken for only a short period until the temporary condition is relieved. I am sure that everyone here in this chamber in their homes will have a bottle with some unused tablets or antibiotics in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have and I am not old.

—I am sure the Minister has. One of the other features of Senator Richardson's statements related to incorrect prescribing, the situation when incorrect drugs have been prescribed-again, not overprescribing. I would like to nail this statement of overprescribing once and for all. There is no such thing as overprescribing. There is hoarding and there may be incorrect prescribing. The Minister's explanation, when I got the Minister down to it, was that:

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty is that until a day before pension age we have the number of scripts per year being something like 7, I think, and then when it hits pensioner age it jumps to 27 a year.

I can only presume that this is what the Minister is referring to when he talks about overprescribing. There can be no reliable statistics on how many prescriptions any one of us has written and certainly no notation of our age, unless of course the Minister's protestations about the confidentiality of information that is transmitted to the Health Insurance Commission from the pharmacist are incorrect. The other explanation is that there are many items obtainable under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme which normally do not require prescriptions, such as the paracetamols and minor pain killers. Similarly, hypnotics and sedatives become available at heavily discounted prices under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Is it any wonder that pensioners avail themselves of this opportunity to obtain medication to relieve symptoms which they previously have put up with or, alternatively, have paid for themselves?

Overprescribing is a word used by the Department and the Minister to indulge themselves once again in doctor bashing and somehow try to make doctors take the blame for the blow-out in the cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. It is a classic example of shooting the messenger when one is unhappy with the message. The word, no doubt, means what it says, but there are obviously no statistics available to support the contention. There is obviously hoarding and I understand that the Health Insurance Commission can demonstrate an almost doubling of prescription processing over the last month. I think we would all be surprised if this did not occur.

If we were faced with increasing costs of any necessity and we were given two months notice of a price increase, of course we would take steps to hoard that necessity or, as I heard it referred to, squirrel some away for future use. There will also be anecdotal evidence of incorrect prescribing, but again it can never be reliable or, for that matter, there can never be any statistics in this regard. One would need a doctor to check every prescription written by another doctor, and the mind can only boggle at the bureaucracy required. Let us once and for all, Minister and Department, drop the term overprescribing when discussing this legislation.

I would like now to turn to the thrust of the legislation. I understand its purpose is to rein in the cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, which cost we all recognise is escalating dramatically. The projected cost for 1990-91 approaches $1,600m, but the projected saving by this Bill is $245m. I will confidently predict what will occur. Statistics will show a blow-out in the number of prescriptions written in the last two months prior to the introduction of the Bill. Then there will be a significant drop in the number of prescriptions written, followed by a gradual rise in the number written, and within 12 months we will be back to where we started.

I can assure the Minister that the level and accuracy of prescribing by Australian doctors is of an extremely high standard. The high standard of education of Australian medical students and peer review has produced a quality of doctor of the best ethical and professional standard. Within the Bill there is an allocation of $3m in the first year and then $2m to, I quote Senator Richardson:
Educate doctors on this Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and how they ought to react to it.

I thought that I should inform the Minister, if he takes the trouble to listen, that every doctor I have ever known has been educated on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme from before graduation, and I know how they react to it. More bureaucracy and more regulation is not the way to ensure greater compliance.

It is interesting that millions of dollars have been allocated to pharmacists to ring doctors and to suggest to them that a cheaper generic drug could be substituted for a brand name drug. The doctors, who obviously will spend the same amount of time replying, will be paid nothing. It would be interesting to collate the type of response that the majority of pharmacists will get to such suggestions.

I am pleased to report that a very good relationship has been developed over many years between the pharmacy profession and my own, and at an individual level many friendships have been formed. The money spent on education, small as it is, would be better spent on education of the public in lifestyle. The `Life be in it' campaign is a good example. There have been greater improvements in health by changes in lifestyle-the cessation of smoking, weight reduction and exercise-than the use of the whole pharmacopoeia.

The introduction of a payment and the concept of an educational program based on pharmacists will have little, if any, effect. The whole scheme envisaged by the Bill is based on faulty premises. It is based, first, on the concept of over-prescribing-which does not exist; secondly, on the concept that a sum of $2m to $3m a year on education of doctors will lessen costs-it will not; thirdly, on the concept that introducing a $2.50 charge on pensioners and then a safety net will deter them taking prescribed medicines-it will not; and, finally, it is based on the reduction in the number of pharmacies-which will not affect the increasing number of people over the age of 60-and the increasing cost and consumption of pharmaceuticals.

The objectives of the Bill will not be achieved. If anything could be described as bandaid legislation, this is it.
