In the short time I have been here I have realised why bureaucrats and politicians sometimes make stupid decisions. I now realise that their isolation from what goes on at the interface with the public leads to theoretical decisions which have no basis in reality. They are obviously unfettered by the constraints of knowledge or experience.

It was interesting that none of the public witnesses or submissions were enthusiastically supporting the Bill. Guarded support came from the Pharmacy Guild, but I can also confidently predict that if one has an interest in this field one should follow the activities within the Pharmacy Guild in the next few months.

If the Minister and the Department are genuinely interested, as I am, in reducing the cost of the scheme, then surely they should listen to those who do have the knowledge and experience. I look forward to the next Liberal government when our policy will contain effective and lasting solutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to thank the Senate for what has been an interesting debate. I have to say that not much that has been said here this evening was not said at some point or other during the Committee proceedings. I note that when one looks at the contributions of all those who have spoken tonight that opposition tends to vary. The only Opposition speaker to really oppose the concept of what we are doing here this evening is Senator Herron, who says that the Government is unfettered by knowledge or experience. Neither are we fettered by the need for sectional pleading. We do not feel the need to defend our record.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to hear what Senator Herron said in defence of doctors. The first point I wish to make is that at no stage in this exercise have I attempted any form of doctor bashing and I do not wish to do so. I have the greatest respect for the profession. That does not mean that, in common with any other profession, there are not from time to time improvements to be made. It does not mean that all members of the profession keep as up to date as they might with new developments in their field. Anything that the Government or doctors' associations themselves can do to assist in keeping those members up to date would no doubt have an effect in easing this problem.

Although I have heard Senator Herron's `confident predictions', all I can say is that I have no doubt his confidence will be eroded by time and result. In drafting what would always be a difficult and at times painful prescription for the ills of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, the Government was mindful of the fact that overseas experience suggests that the introduction of some sort of price disincentive will have a profound effect on the usage of the scheme. One cannot imagine why Australia should be so uniquely endowed with wisdom that the reaction of Australians to this scheme will be different from reactions in other countries. I, for one, doubt very much that there will be the need for myself or for any other Government Minister in the course of the next few years to concede that Senator Herron was right.

One would hope, however, that when he is shown to be wrong he will have the good grace to acknowledge it. But he will not hear doctor-bashing coming from me. I am not one who wishes to engage in it. That does not mean that I will not acknowledge at times things that I think the profession is not doing properly, just as from time to time I might have said it of lawyers or any other profession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Politicians.
—Well, we are always hearing about things that politicians do not do properly. No doubt that will not stop; the deafening roar in our ears from the public will make sure of that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lees said that this was a simplistic solution and ill-considered, and Senator Patterson talked of it in terms of a quick-fix. The question of what to do about the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) has been around for many years. But I think that we would all concede that it is only since 1985 that a really serious blow-out in the costs has been occurring. If one looks at the history of the Federal Government, it probably is only in more recent years that this problem has come under the microscope. What can governments do but look at the experience overseas, after first acknowledging that we simply cannot leave the current situation as it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity you wouldn't do the same with welfare.

—Senator Alston, after the few days you have had, I would not say a whole lot about welfare. Mind you, in talking to the gallery tonight I hope you keep saying more. It is doing us no end of good. Whatever people want to say about the bad poll we had in the last few days, you will be singularly responsible for getting us back up in the polls. We are delighted every time you open your mouth.
—Order! I remind the Minister that he is to address the Chair and not other senators.
—I apologise, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is just that at times when it comes to some senators and their interjections, it is difficult to restrain my natural ebullient self.

SPEECH.PARA: In talking to the rest of the Bill-and I will restrain myself-I refer to Senator Coulter's statement that the measure is aimed at the wrong people, that it should be doctors and not pensioners. That statement runs pretty contrary to the speech made by Senator Herron. The Government's aim is to secure that 15 per cent reduction in the cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. It will be attained by addressing both. There will be an attempt to make doctors aware of what we see as a difficult situation. We keep hearing about over-prescribing and Senator Herron's great objection to the term. The other term I saw in my brief for today was `inappropriate prescribing'. I am not sure that he would like either.

Whatever one wants to call it, a problem exists. Some money will be spent in assisting doctors to overcome it. I would not dismiss the efforts of the Pharmacy Guild in the past few months during a very difficult time for it with a fairly evenly divided membership from all accounts but one which nonetheless came down in favour of supporting what the Government believes is a very necessary scheme.

I do not believe, however, that anything in this Bill could be called a dangerous precedent. There is nothing in this Bill that will be anti-democratic. The fact that we have ensured that there will be compensation for all will mean that in the end no-one needs to be disadvantaged by what we have done. In fact, in what we are doing there is unequal advantage for people in that some will be more advantaged than others, but no-one will be disadvantaged.

In developing a change to the scheme, as we have on this occasion, it is very hard to do it as well as we have. Far from it being ill considered and rushed through, I would have thought that great thought has been given to the scheme. That does not mean that we cannot acknowledge the need for change, as I did when dealing with the chronically ill.

There is never shame in admitting that something one has done or said might have been wrong; rather, I would see it as a strength. In response to all honourable senators' comments, there is no point in denying that this measure has not caused great heartache amongst many pensioners. As we have had an opportunity over the past few months to explain the measures, we have reduced the anxiety in the community very considerably and I am quite certain that, once the scheme is up and running, we can get rid of that anxiety entirely.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be headlines in Age Pension News.

—I say, not in response to the interjections, that I certainly hope Age Pension News continues to cover the issues that are of concern to those who read it. It is a very important means of communicating with the age pensioners.
—I will be watching it closely to see how big the headlines are.

—I will be watching it closely, too. I will also be looking as the cards and letters roll in from its very active readership. That publication is being received very well. It is a valuable tool in communicating with those who are reading it. We will continue to use it because it is the right way to go. Most importantly, as the Opposition Leader, Dr Hewson, acknowledged after the Budget, this part of the scheme is the right way to go. It is the only way that we will ever get around to controlling what has been a massive blow-out in costs. It is a necessary social reform brought about without causing disadvantage to those who are on pensions. In the end that is the obligation of the Government and it has kept it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak for only a few minutes tonight in regard to the Parliamentary Education Office. On Monday the first meeting was held of the advisory committee that has been established by the Presiding Officers of the Senate and the House of Representatives. The advisory committee is made up of Mr Price, the Hon. Don Dobie, Mr Free and Senators Aulich, McLean and me. This is the first of what will be a useful succession of meetings of the parliamentary education advisory committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I need not tell the Senate that the Education Office was established after the release of the Senate's report entitled Education for Active Citizenship dated February 1989. The Education Office has had a very good beginning and has established a number of programs that are very worthy of this Parliament and that are serving the interests of members of the House of Representatives and the Senate. These programs are bringing to the public at large, especially to young Australians, including school children, not only a knowledge about parliamentary matters but also an empowering of those young Australians to be fully aware of their own opportunities to make a contribution eventually as active citizens of this country.

There is a dispute between the Presiding Officers and the Government in regard to the Budget which touches upon a program that is vitally concerned with the Parliamentary Education Office. I refer to a $500,000 appropriation for the House of Representatives and a $500,000 appropriation for the Senate-$1m vital dollars for the schools visit program to enable young Australians, especially from distant States, to visit Parliament House.

Students come from schools in the Northern Territory-Senator Collins nods-Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland and Tasmania. Without the initiative that was begun last financial year to give subsidies to enable students to come from these more distant States, we will have an enormous drop in the number of tours.

To give some direct meaning to this problem to which I am drawing the Senate's attention, I have in front of me newsletter No. 11 of the Parliamentary Education Office, which was circulated this week subsequent to our advisory committee meeting on Monday. This newsletter sets out the education program bookings from mid-October to the end of November. Some seven pages of schools are listed as coming on particular days in that six-week period.

Only one of the schools on the list is from my State of South Australia. At any point during the period when there was money available to subsidise school visits, dozens of schools from South Australia took part. If I look at the list I find that there is only one school from Tasmania. There are hundreds of schools from New South Wales and Victoria, and if there were hundreds in the Australian Capital Territory--

TALK.START.PARA: —There aren't.

—There is certainly a sufficiency of schools from the ACT. This Parliament represents the whole nation. It is the major focal point of decisions that relate to the whole nation and it is important that the work of the Parliamentary Education Office, indeed the work of this Parliament, be displayed to all States equally.

SPEECH.PARA: It is essential that this chamber support our Presiding Officer and the Speaker of the House of Representatives in their submissions to the Government, especially the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), to ensure that the $1m program continues. I will watch this matter, as I am sure all of us on the advisory committee will. I believe that those involved in Estimates committees and those of us from the more remote States-people such as Senator Giles opposite, Senator Kernot from Queensland and Senator Vanstone from South Australia-will watch this and there will be trouble from the Senate if there is not approval by the beginning of the next calendar year for the continuation of the moneys to enable school visits to continue in the way that they have in this calendar year. I am glad to see the nodding heads of honourable senators in the chamber. We insist that the Government, especially the Minister for Finance, not only hear the very good arguments put by the Presiding Officers but also agree to them.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority: Tabling of Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly tonight on a matter about which I intend to say more at a later time, but there are some matters which should be addressed tonight. Yesterday at about 7.20 p.m.-reasonably close to the adjournment debate-on behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority (NCA), I tabled that Committee's report on Operation Ark, which included a qualifying or dissenting report signed by two senators and two members of the House of Representatives. I spoke very briefly to that report-I think with the indulgence of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, who was in the chamber at the time-simply to point out that the dissenting report was there and urge honourable senators to consider the qualifying statement, to consider very seriously the questions that arise from the matters raised therein and in particular to consider them in the light of what they might say about the operation of the NCA and the operation, for that matter, of the Joint Parliamentary Committee, and the relationship between the two. Those are very serious matters. At that point I sought leave to continue my remarks but concluded them for the evening.

SPEECH.PARA: Some remarks have been made in the other place today in relation to the tabling of that report and the qualifying statement which deserve an immediate response. Mr Lindsay, the Chairman of the Committee, has indicated some dissatisfaction with the style of the qualifying report. He is entitled to have that view. As I understand it-I stand to be corrected if I have misread what he has said-his view is that in camera evidence ought never be put in a report without the approval of the committee.

He is entitled to have the view that that is how things ought to be, but the point I want to raise this evening is that Mr Lindsay, in his remarks, referred to a report of what he describes as the Procedure Committee of the Senate of 2 May 1989 which in part dealt with this issue. He said that it was not able to agree on where the balance should be struck between the various considerations. We all know that there are good arguments on both sides on this matter. He went on to say:
It did, however, suggest certain guidelines be followed by senators who wished to refer in a dissenting report to evidence taken in camera. It recommended inter alia:

He then went on to list the recommendations, which I will not bother reading now. What my reading of and listening to his speech show-runless I have missed out on some parts of the `greens' or was not listening carefully to Mr Lindsay-is that he did not go on to make an additional point that I believe he should have made. As I see the structure of his speech at the moment, it was basically that he is of the view that in camera evidence ought never be used without the consent of the majority, and he refers to some guidelines in a Senate committee report to support that argument. What he does not go on to say is that those guidelines have not been adopted by the Senate. In fact, those guidelines have been sent back to that Committee, and one of the reasons those guidelines have gone back to the Committee is so that hopefully there will be some helpful suggestions or the guidelines will be amplified with respect to what course we should adopt where a senator or senators cannot get the approval of the majority to put some relevant in camera evidence in a Senate report.

It is absolutely obvious that a dissenting report does not agree with the majority and it ought therefore to be obvious that there is a high probability that the majority will not agree as to the relevance of certain in camera evidence being revealed. That is obvious. So the question that was raised, as I understand it by Senator Baume, is a very good one. What does one do? Does one say that the entitlement of the majority-that is, to include in camera evidence-should not be extended to a minority or individual senator? Have we reached the stage where Senate committees are run by the majority of numbers? Does that mean, therefore, that when Labor is in government what the Labor Caucus decides will be what the Senate committee decides at the time? Do we think that? Do honourable senators want to be in a position when the coalition is in government, which will not be too long, where force of numbers can deprive them of the privilege given to the majority of the committee, namely, when they think it appropriate to use in camera evidence?

This matter was not referred to by Mr Lindsay. To be perfectly fair, I have said that he has pointed out that it was difficult for the Committee to have a balance. He has been fair in that respect and has pointed out the guidelines put forward. But I wonder why he did not give us the other information that the guidelines have not yet been adopted and have been sent back to the Committee. Was Mr Lindsay ignorant? One hesitates to come to that conclusion. Mr Lindsay is the Chairman of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, which is an important committee-all committees are important. I am loath to come to the conclusion that he is ignorant. What is my other alternative, Mr President? If Mr Lindsay was in full knowledge, did he know that this matter had been referred back and chose not to tell the House? Was he selective in what he told the House? Did he tell the House that some guidelines were put forward by a Senate committee and deliberately chose not to say that those guidelines had not been adopted and had been referred back? I do not know the answer. I do not draw any conclusion, but I am concerned about the matter.

As I say, other matters can be referred to as a consequence of that tabling. I intend to continue my remarks about that. But that is all I wish to raise in relation to Mr Lindsay's statement in the chamber today.
I now wish to turn to some remarks by Mr Melham, which I will have further things to say about at a later date. Mr Melham commences his speech by saying:
What happened last night in the Senate under the cover of darkness . . .
`under the cover of darkness'; do you mind!

TALK.START.PARA: —Melodramatic.
—Somewhat melodramatic and somewhat wishing to imply, in my view, improper motives. He goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . was a cheap, grubby, political point scoring exercise-

I do not know whether Mr Melham is referring to the fact that the report was tabled last night or whether `cheap, grubby, political point scoring exercise' refers to his assessment of the qualifying statement. Quite frankly, I do not care which he was referring to. I just point out the tone with which Mr Melham commenced his remarks.

He went on to give us some indication to what he was referring to by saying that this was a `cheap, grubby, political point scoring exercise'. In the normal course of events, it happens that committee reports are tabled in the Senate. It is not unusual for there to be a qualifying or dissenting report attached. Somehow, this has turned into a `cheap, grubby, political point scoring exercise'. Perhaps honourable senators are now not meant to have an alternative view. What does that say about what the community will think of this place?

We know how fed up the community is with major party politics; how it wants more independents to be in Parliament because it thinks that Parliament has turned into just a number crunching exercise between the two major political parties. We know that the Australian Democrats believe that they should be given the right to speak and accorded the rights that all others are. Somehow, the Government thinks that if it has the numbers, everyone else can just shut up. I do not agree with that view. I believe very strongly that each member here has an individual responsibility as a parliamentarian. Fortunately, we on this side of the chamber have the opportunity to make the choice as to whether our Party is right or wrong and vote according to how we think.
Let me return to Mr Melham. Mr Melham said:
The Chairman of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority was unaware that the tabling was to take place last night . . .

That may be true about last night, but it was on the Senate red sheet all day yesterday. I have been informed that the Chairman of the Committee expected the report to be tabled at the appropriate time in the chamber. I have also been informed that the Chairman of the Committee was aware it was not done at that time. So I have no qualms at all in saying that it was, and still is, my view that the Chairman of the Committee knew that the report was being tabled yesterday. The fact that he may not have known that it was happening last night, as opposed to three o'clock or half past three or whenever it would have happened, is irrelevant.

Mr Melham's remarks create the impression that the Chairman of the Committee did not know that the report was being tabled yesterday. I strongly refute that allegation, if that is what Mr Melham is trying to say. Perhaps Mr Melham is simply ignorant; I do not know. Having commenced his remarks about the Chairman of the Joint Committee, he goes on to say:
or, indeed, that there was a qualifying statement.

Mr Melham may not have known that there was a qualifying statement; that would not surprise me one iota. But it is quite clear that the Chairman knew of my intention to put in a qualifying statement. If Mr Melham was not present at the appropriate time to learn that I intended putting in a qualifying statement, let Mr Melham tell the Parliament what he was doing at the appropriate time; that is his business. But do not let him go into the lower House and say that the Chairman of the Committee did not know there was a qualifying statement, when the Chairman of the Committee had been advised by me that I intended putting in a qualifying statement.

Did I go to the Chairman of the Committee 10 minutes before and say, `Here is my qualifying statement. Would you like to have a look at it and make a case for it not being put forward?'. No, I did not. I am not obliged to do so, and I have no intention of doing it if I think it is inappropriate on the occasion.

I look forward, hopefully not in the next fortnight of sittings-I hope that someone draws these remarks to Mr Melham's attention-to a statement being put out by Mr Melham explaining his remarks. Of course, Mr Melham went on to make a few other remarks that can relate only to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is this melonhead?

—Mr Melham is a member of the House of Representatives and should be accorded the respect that all others members and senators are accorded in these chambers. It would be nice if these things were dealt with on a reciprocal basis. Mr Melham says:

SPEECH.PARA: The first I knew of it was when I came back to my office after it was tabled in the Senate-which was, in my view, a gross discourtesy to other members of the Committee.

I simply say this: if I felt free to reveal all that happens in committee proceedings, I could give Mr Melham a very long lecture on what courtesy is in joint committees which would make very interesting reading. That is all I care to say about that matter.

Mr Melham goes on to say a bit more. Apart from having admitted his own ignorance, I cannot be responsible for his not wanting to inquire as to when reports are being tabled; that is not my problem. And it is not my problem if Mr Melham is not in the appropriate place. I know that not everybody can attend meetings all the time. But to say that one does not know something and blame someone else for one's lack of knowledge is hardly a point to make. That is the inference that I take from Mr Melham's remarks. Okay, he thinks it is a gross discourtesy. I have made my remarks about that. He goes on to say:
It was underhanded . . .

I think that here he is referring to my coming in last night and tabling this report, without going around and saying, `Mr Melham, please, can I do this? It was not done at the appropriate time of the day, so it's done a bit later, but do you mind?'. I am sorry if that is Mr Melham's view of what I should do. So I do not regard it as underhanded because I do not regard it as my responsibility to ask Mr Melham to do things that I am entitled to do. Nor do I regard it as deceitful. If I were doing something underhanded, I would do it in a way--

TALK.START.PARA: —You would do it honestly.

—It is very hard to imagine my doing something of an underhanded nature. It is hard to try to imagine the circumstances. But one thing is immediately apparent to me, and that is that if something were underhanded it would not be on the Senate red sheet. Am I supposed to wave a flag to every honourable senator in this chamber? There are other members of the NCA Committee in this Senate; I presume they look at their red sheet. I just cannot be responsible for whether they discuss things with their lower House members. It is not my problem. But it is my problem if someone says that I have been underhanded in doing something that was on the red sheet all day.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Melham then says that it was deceitful. I would like an explanation. I would like Mr Melham to get up again in the chamber to explain how I have been deceitful. I would be very interested to know. I would be particularly interested in how Mr Melham concludes that what happened was deceitful. For all I know, he is referring not just to me; perhaps he is saying there was some collusion.

The Minister extended some courtesy to me. My understanding is that committee reports can be tabled at any time. The courtesy that I have referred to was to move a motion to take note of the report and speak very briefly.

I do not mean by that to say that Senator Collins was part of some deceitful, underhanded practice at all. I simply acknowledge the Minister's courtesy in giving me the rights that are accorded to every other senator in this place. I want to place on record that if what happened in the chamber last night was deceitful, underhanded and cheap political point-scoring, Senator Collins should not be dragged into this matter. I wonder who else can be? Perhaps it is the view that the Senate procedures, if they are followed, are underhanded and deceitful. I do not think that is the case.
As I say, I have other remarks to make about this entire matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not now.

—No, not now. Let me summarise: the remarks I have made tonight needed to be made tonight to set the record straight because of the remarks made by Mr Lindsay-the Chairman of this Committee-and Mr Melham.

SPEECH.PARA: I intend to make further remarks about those matters at another point. I also intend to make further remarks about the qualifying statement at another point.

I simply want to say that I noted with much interest the remarks made today by these two gentlemen. Given that there were some very serious questions raised in the qualifying statement and that it shows that the Committee had some conflicting evidence before it, and has decided not to pursue those matters, I would have thought that the Committee members who submitted the majority report would have some explanation to offer to Parliament about that matter.

I would have thought that, if there is something wrong with the qualifying statement, up hill and down dale the Chairman and the other member of the Committee to speak on this matter would have addressed those remarks. I would have expected a bit of a blowtorch if the qualifying statement had made some ludicrous points. But there is silence. I do not expect that silence will last too long. It must be monumentally embarrassing for the Government to remain silent over this matter for ever and a day. But I would have thought that the two Government members who have chosen to speak on this matter would have said something about it. I intend to say something about it at a later stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not my intention to participate in the debate tonight until I heard the previous speaker. What is really involved in the discussion regarding the report of the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority (NCA) tabled by Mr Lindsay in the House of Representatives, and the dissenting report-and it is a dissenting report, not a qualifying report-that has been tabled by honourable senators opposite, really comes down to a debate about procedures and conduct-procedures that govern matters as important as confidentiality and trust.

SPEECH.PARA: It raises questions of what is appropriate, given the significance of the Committee that oversees the working of the NCA, not only in an immediate sense but also for the future. The Senate ought to be asking what manner of conduct leads to an effective working committee system, particularly with respect to the NCA. It is not a question of numbers; it is not a question of force; it is not a question of a majority insisting on its way. It is a question of propriety.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say that again?
—Order!
—Listen.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. If we are going to have impertinent interjections from the other side, I wonder if senators could make them from the seats from which they are entitled to make them.
—Order! There are too many interjections from both sides.

—On the point of order, that is not the point I am making. If there are going to be interjections of an impertinent nature, they should be made from the seat from which the senator is entitled to make them.
—Senator Faulkner, you should not interject unless you are sitting in your own seat.

—To rekindle-it is not a question of force of numbers; it is not a question of a majority insisting upon its way. It is a question of propriety-a simple matter of propriety. What happened in the Senate last night in terms of the tabling of the dissenting report was that contained in it was in camera evidence that should not have been incorporated in the report, should not have been tabled in the report and should not have been tabled in the Senate. In that being done, a fundamental breach of trust was involved, regardless of any advice that was given to honourable senators opposite. In a sense, it is a simple matter of decency. I really have no wish to approach this in a partisan manner, because the issue is too important in terms of the future working of Senate committees and joint committees such as the NCA committee. That really involves questions of honesty and whether or not people are prepared to be fair and reasonable in the way that they conduct themselves in the committee system. There is now a clear pattern of events in the behaviour of some members of the Opposition in the tabling of in camera evidence-in the selective release of in camera evidence-which does, and will, have an impact on the committee system of the Parliament as a whole. What happened last night was not the first time that in camera evidence has been tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: I have absolutely no problem with people writing a dissenting report-compiling a minority report-and arguing a position, pursuing a case and putting that case before this chamber and before the broader community. That is to be welcomed. There is ample room in this place for dissent and for minority views. There is no room for the lack of decency shown in the tabling of that in camera evidence. That is to be deplored.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I take it as a breach of Standing Orders to suggest that the tabling of a committee's statement with a dissenting report lacks decency. The honourable senator is suggesting that I did something indecent last night, and let me assure you I did not.
—There is no point of order; it was a debating point.

—I have taken offence at the remarks that the honourable senator has made and I ask that he withdraw them. He is referring to the tabling of something that can only relate to me and he has said that what happened was indecent.
—He was not imputing any motives to you, Senator Vanstone, and he is in order.
—Thank you, Mr President. Some people opposite are forever talking about courtesy and hearing arguments, and they are always the first to try to deny others that opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Lindsay has in no way been selective in the remarks he made in the House of Representatives late this afternoon. He has endeavoured to be fair and reasonable in conveying the terms of the Committee's deliberations and the sense of the Committee's report, and putting that report in context. He has endeavoured to be authoritative. He has not taken a simple paragraph or two out of context-out of the body of the evidence-and quoted it selectively.

How on earth can people make a judgment on the quality of a report, on the quality of a committee's deliberations and on the conclusions that have been drawn, if there is simply injected into a report a single paragraph or two of in camera evidence, without seeing the body of that evidence? That is a nonsense to suggest that that ought to occur in support of an argument. It sets the committee procedures back years.

Dealing with the committee on the NCA-I am relatively new to the Committee. It was a privilege to be elected to the Committee by the Federal parliamentary Labor Party, but the Senate should be aware of the political evolution that is occurring on that Committee. Not only senators on the Government side, but also Australian Democrat and independent senators and, indeed, I am sure, a number of senators within the Opposition's ranks would be interested to know that there appears to be a deliberate pattern of conduct designed to wreck the Committee's deliberations, to neuter it and to make it absolutely and utterly ineffective-in short, to make it unworkable and to defeat the very purpose for which the Parliament created the body.

Mr President, you would know about a matter that is law within the New South Wales Labor Party. Jack Lang said when he was Premier in the 1930s, `If you don't have the numbers then you wreck the gathering', and that is what has been occurring. The Committee should be a very serious deliberative body.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer learnt that--

—The Treasurer (Mr Keating) learnt it, quite literally, at Jack Lang's knee. The Committee should be serious. It should approach matters in a serious frame of mind. It is not. Until there is a change of attitude opposite, it will not and cannot.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the remarks of the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) in House of Representatives, I must say I agree with him. I thought the dissenting was simple provincial point scoring-cheap and low grade.

Some in the Opposition approached the matters that were before the Committee with preconceived and predetermined notions. There is no doubt in my mind about that. They regarded the Committee as an invitation to a beheading and were determined to see that through regardless of any evidence that was given by any of the people-and the list was very extensive-called before the Committee. It was really Christmas in Cape Town. That was the form of justice that some opposite wanted to see unfold. My view is: justice predetermined is justice denied.

We do have a level playing field on the Committee in respect of the National Crime Authority. We understand that from this morning's meeting and the manner in which things unfolded then. No-one in the Government's ranks had been given what I would have thought was the elementary courtesy of a copy of the dissenting report in time to read it. The copy arrived in my office after the Senate had risen last night. That is discourtesy and it is unfortunate.

But some in the Opposition have now made the position absolutely crystal clear in terms of the way they think the Committee should operate. I think that is a matter of regret. The simple fact of the matter for those honourable senators present and those who may be following the debate is that no courtesies were extended to the Government by some in the Opposition and, as a consequence, there is no good will. The Committee cannot work without good will on a two way basis.
The only conclusion to be drawn is that some in the Opposition lack the intellectual capacity to approach the issues. To show honourable senators how serious--

TALK.START.PARA: —Now we have put ourselves on a pedestal.
—The problem we have with Senator Vanstone is that if we could buy her at our price and sell her at her price, we would make a fortune.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the sensitivity of material that comes before the Committee, honourable senators should be aware that those who serve on the Committee are given special safes in which material should be locked up, including in camera evidence. What is the point of having anything confidential? What is the point of securing any document, any material that comes before the Committee? What is the point of the Committee actually going in camera? What is the point of talking in terms of confidentiality and saying to witnesses that they may speak freely, that the material they place before the Committee, the evidence they give, will be before the Committee and will go no further? It is absolutely farcical, given what happened last night.

No-one will be prepared to give evidence before the NCA Committee in the future; no one will be prepared to come forward. Some who were involved in this charade last night knew precisely that that would be the impact. That not only applies to the Committee on the NCA; it applies to every committee that the Parliament forms. The impact of it is right across the board.

To be fair to some people opposite, I have no doubt that will trouble some in the Opposition as much as it troubles people in the Government. What is the point if people are unable to come forward to contribute, to be part of the democratic process of giving evidence, in security of confidentiality? Everyone knows, given some of the committee work in this place over recent years, that a lot of invaluable material would have been lost if this kind of stupidity had gone on previously. So what we had last night was nothing short of a major assault on the Parliament's committee structures, on their procedures and on their effectiveness for the future.
I will join the debate when matters are raised again, as I am sure other senators will want to do. I conclude by saying that what happened last night was stupid, retrograde and ridiculous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Hawke Labor Government is developing a habit of playing fast and loose with the privacy of the individual-and that is of great concern to many in the community. This habit has been made clear by its attempts to introduce the Australia Card, to extend the use of the tax file number beyond its specified use, and now by Australia Post's Selectmail service. On Monday, following extreme concern expressed to me by a constituent, I asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, who represents the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley)-Senator Collins is in the chamber tonight-a question about Australia Post's new Selectmail service.

SPEECH.PARA: Householders have recently received in their letterboxes a colour brochure-no doubt quite expensive to produce-advertising this new Selectmail service. Selectmail is a system whereby householders can complete and return to Australia Post the bottom part of the brochure after filling out their name, address, age, number in the household, number of children, as well as ticking various boxes to indicate that they would like to receive advertising information about various goods and services-for example, cars, beauty aids, clothing, kitchenware, business services, life insurance, toys and holidays, to name a few of the many items listed.

My constituent expressed the view that this was a waste of money and that it would create more junk mail requiring disposal. However, the greatest concern to him was the potential invasion of privacy. The brochure describes the Selectmail service in some detail, including how it operates, and guarantees strict confidentiality. More than that, it specifically states:
Your name and address will go on to a confidential Selectmail list held by Australia Post which will not be recorded or copied by any suppliers of goods and services.

To follow up my constituent's concern, I contacted Australia Post to find out exactly how the system operates and, particularly, how the advertiser's or marketer's promotional material got into the system to be delivered to the householder. Does the advertiser or marketer forward the material to Australia Post, which then sends it to the people who it knows are interested in that item from the lists it has compiled from the completed and returned brochure tear-off section? No, Australia Post advised, the list of such people is rented to the advertiser-marketer.

This advice was obviously in conflict with the clear statement of confidentiality contained in the brochure. This prompted my question to Senator Collins, which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard, along with Senator Collins' inadequate answer. I have already sought that from Senator Collins and, I assume, have his approval for incorporation.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIA POST: SELECTMAIL SERVICE

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask whether the Minister is aware that Australia Post is distributing to householders a brochure advertising its new Selectmail service which claims as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Your name and address will go on to confidential Selectmail lists held by Australia Post which will not be recorded or copied by any suppliers of goods and services.

Does the obvious conflict between this claim and advice I received from Australia Post, that the Selectmail lists will be hired out to advertising agencies and other organisations wishing to use Selectmail services for the distribution of advertising material, reflect this Government's cavalier attitude to individual privacy as already revealed by the Australia Card and the tax file number? Or can the Minister give some other explanation?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Chapman's question is no, it does not represent anything of the sort. Australia Post does, in fact, operate as a list broker in the same way as a number of other organisations operate as list brokers in what has become the extremely competitive area of direct mail. Indeed, Australia Post operates a very sophisticated direct mail service that it can provide to customers on request, and, I must say, it does a very professional job. I do not have the detail of the particular correspondence that the Senator has referred to, but I will get that detail and I will get an answer for Senator Chapman, hopefully, before the end of the day.
—I thank the Senate. On Tuesday, Senator Collins provided a supplementary answer which I also seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

During Question Time yesterday, Senator Chapman asked me a question on Australia Post's `Selectmail' service, and the brochure advertising the service which states that lists Australia Post establishes will not be recorded or copied by any supplier of goods and services.

Senator Chapman expressed concern that Selectmail lists would be hired out to advertising agencies to facilitate the distribution of advertising material and that such a practice directly contravened the privacy of individuals.
* As I explained yesterday, Australia Post operates as a list broker in the same way as other organisations in the area of direct mail.

* Regarding the new Selectmail service advertised in the brochure, Australia Post assures me that it has compiled lists from information provided by people who answered the questionnaire indicating what particular kinds of advertising mail they would like to receive.
* Australia Post complies with accepted industry list rental practices to ensure confidentiality of list details and to maintain the integrity of its lists.

* the conditions of rental are that renters do not view list details; copies of names and addresses are not made available to the renter; and the list is generally supplied to a mailing house which addresses and despatches the mailing packages supplied by the renter, and then returns the list to the owner.
* The mailing house must be a member of the Direct Marketing Association.
* The Selectmail lists will be held and managed on behalf of Australia Post by S.A. Database Pty Limited.

* I understand that the Selectmail project was discussed with representatives from the Privacy Commission. The Commission saw no problem, because the person gave written authority to Australia Post to put their name on particular lists, and because the lists are not made available to renters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In summary, Senator Collins claims there is no invasion of privacy in the Selectmail system; firstly, because persons returning the tear-off had thereby given written authority to Australia Post to put their names on particular lists; secondly, because the conditions of rental are that renters do not view the list details which are subsequently returned to Australia Post; thirdly, because the list is generally-as Senator Collins described it-supplied to a mailing house which addresses and dispatches the mailing packages supplied by the renter. These claims do not stand up to scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: Taking this last point first, I note the Minister, no doubt advisedly, used the term `generally'. In other words, although in the current situation the actual mail-outs will be done by SA Database Pty Ltd, it is clear that this is not an absolute requirement for the operation of Selectmail. It is clear-as I was verbally advised by Australia Post at the outset-that provision of lists by Australia Post direct to marketers and advertisers, rather than mailing house intermediaries, is not absolutely excluded and could occur on another occasion. In any case, Senator Collins or his advisers are simply playing with words in distinguishing between a mailing house on the one hand and an advertiser or marketer on the other.

There is minimal difference in reality. But more importantly, the fact is that a mailing house is a third party which, on the basis of the information in the Selectmail brochure, a householder would not expect to be the recipient of his name or address or the other information he provides. The claim that the lists are not viewed is also no defence. To do the mail-out, names obviously go onto the mailing house's computer and are therefore accessible to third parties. Nor is the claim that the householder has given written authority for his name to go on the lists a defence.

I am amazed that the Privacy Commission saw no privacy problem, apparently because of this authority. The fact is that a householder has given his name and address on the clear understanding, as any reasonable person would interpret the assurances in the brochure, that it will remain confidential to Australia Post and that no third party will have access to it. Therefore, the Minister's assurances of the maintenance of privacy are worthless. It is clear that householders are being misinformed by Australia Post in their Selectmail brochure.

Australia Post will be providing all those consumers' personal and private details to mailing houses which will be acting in a de facto role for the supplier of goods and services. It matters not one iota that these mailing houses are members of the Direct Marketing Association. The fact remains that any individual who returns an application form to Australia Post for inclusion on its Selectmail listings, will run the risk of having his privacy invaded when his details are made available to a range of organisations outside Australia Post.

If that is the wish of a householder I have no objections, but it may not be his wish and many people may be returning applications blissfully unaware that their personal details will be made available to third parties. This is simply not good enough. The Selectmail brochure should not give the false expectation of complete confidentiality to householders. Before further distribution to householders it should be withdrawn and amended to indicate the potential lack of privacy involved by the information being released to third parties. Then, at least, householders can choose whether or not to be involved in the system on a fair basis. It is quite simply time for this Government to stop playing fast and loose with people's privacy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a media release on 7 October 1990 I accused the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of misleading the Parliament. I made this accusation following receipt on 4 October of answers to questions I had asked of officials from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet in the Senate Estimates Committee A on 21 September. These questions related to the decision by the Hawke Government to provide up to $125m to Victoria towards the construction of the Albert Park sports complex should Melbourne be successful in its bid to host the 1996 Olympic Games.

SPEECH.PARA: I had asked these questions because of an answer that Hansard reported the Prime Minister as having given to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in the House of Representatives on 13 September; because of a statement a few days prior to 13 September by Senator Peter Walsh, who was the Minister for Finance at the time the funding decision was taken; and because of an article by Alan Ramsey in the Sydney Morning Herald on 15 September in which he pointed out several factual inaccuracies in the Prime Minister's answer in the House of Representatives on 13 September and in Mr Hawke's statements on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) 7.30 Report on that same day, 13 September.
Mr Hawke, in his answer in the Parliament on 13 September, was reported by Hansard as saying that his Government's decision to provide the $125m:

. . . was taken following the investigation of an interdepartmental committee made up of representatives of the Department of Finance and Australian Construction Services which reported on the Victorian estimates.
On the evening of that same day, 13 September, the Prime Minister said on the ABC's 7.30 Report:
Let me repeat what I said in the Parliament. It was on the basis of what they, the IDC said, that we, Cabinet, were able to make the decision we did.

Before I proceed to develop this point there are two particular points to note about that 7.30 Report statement. The first is that Mr Hawke clearly believed-indeed, he said so-that he was repeating what he had said in the Parliament earlier that day. The second point to note is his words:
It was on the basis of what they, the IDC said, that we, Cabinet, were able to make the decision we did.
Those words clearly supported and indeed confirmed what Hansard reported him to have said in the House-namely, that the decision to provide the $125m was taken following the investigation by the IDC.

The facts relating to the Federal Government's decision to provide up to $125m for the Albert Park complex were set out in my press release of 7 October which I seek leave to table. I understand that I have Senator Collins's approval to do so.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts were as follows: First, Cabinet took the decision to provide $125m to Victoria on 23 January 1990. Secondly, Cabinet's decision to establish an interdepartmental committee (IDC) to report to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) on the estimates on the sporting complex was taken at the same time and in the same Cabinet decision on 23 January.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, the funding decision was announced publicly by the Prime Minister without any qualifications on 28 January. Fourthly, the Prime Minister wrote to the Victorian Premier confirming the funding on 7 February. The interdepartmental committee that was established on 23 January met only twice, on 5 February and 3 April. It did not report to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories until 12 June.
Sixthly, the then Victorian Premier, Mr Cain, refused to permit his officials to meet with the interdepartmental committee. Seventhly, one of my Senate Estimates questions to officials was:
Was the announcement of the Government's decision to provide the $125m made prior to or following the completion of the IDC's examination of the matter?
The written answer I received was:
There was never any expectation that the IDC would report prior to the announcement.

I said that these facts show conclusively that Prime Minister Hawke misled the Parliament on 13 September 1990 and that he also misled the Australian public on the 7.30 Report on the same evening. My comments were reported in the press the following day-Monday 8 October. Most press reports also carried a denial by a spokesman for the Prime Minister that Mr Hawke had misled the Parliament. However, by the middle of the same day, 8 October, the Prime Minister admitted that there had been an `inadvertent misstating' on his part and that he would clarify the true position when Parliament resumed the following day, 9 October.

Later on 8 October, however, he retracted this and said that he would not be making any such clarifying statement because Hansard had misreported him. The events following that are well known and I will not repeat them tonight other than to say that Hansard had, in fact, misreported the Prime Minister. Instead of him saying that the decision to provide the $125m grant was taken `following' the investigation of an IDC, the Prime Minister had actually said the decision was taken `subject to' an IDC reporting on the Victorian Government's estimates for the cost of the complex.

Hansard accepted full responsibility for the misreporting, despite some very strange circumstances, I must say, surrounding the incident. The Prime Minister claimed that the revelation that Hansard had misreported what he actually said cleared him from any charge of misleading the Parliament, although he has not to this day been able to square away his 7.30 Report statement. Because of the Hansard misreporting and other unexplained events-notably, whether the Prime Minister's office ever received the greens of his answer; Hansard says that they were dispatched to the office but never returned-the whole matter became covered in confusion. The press gallery swallowed the Prime Minister's protestations of innocence like sycophantic lambs, with the notable exception of Alan Ramsay, and Mr Hawke was painted as having escaped from the grave charge of misrepresenting the Parliament.

All this confusion was a smokescreen. The fact is that the Prime Minister did mislead Parliament on 13 September when he said that the Government's $125 million funding decision was subject to an interdepartmental committee reporting on Victorian estimates. The Cabinet decision of 23 January 1990, decision No. 13504, makes no reference whatsoever to the funding being subject to an IDC report. Indeed, it is totally clear from the document that the decision to fund the Albert Park complex was not subject to any qualification. Let me read the relevant operative paragraphs of Cabinet decision No. 13504. It starts off:
The Cabinet agreed that:-

(a) the Commonwealth provide up to a maximum of $125 million in January 1990 prices (indexed by the consumer price index) on a dollar-for-dollar basis with the Victorian Government towards construction of the Albert Park Sports Complex should Melbourne be selected as the city to host the 1990 Olympic Games; and

(b) an Inter-Departmental Committee(IDC), under the Chairmanship of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, and comprising representatives from the Departments of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Treasury, Administrative Services, and Finance, be convened to report to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories by 16 February 1990, following discussions with Victorian officials, on estimates for the construction of the Albert Park Sports Complex.
I will leave a couple of the other paragraphs out because they are not relevant. The final paragraph of the Cabinet decision said:

(c) the announcement of Commonwealth financial assistance be made jointly by the Prime Minister and the Premier of Victoria, with the text of the announcement to be settled by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Prime Minister and the Premier.
I seek leave, Mr President, to have the full Cabinet decision incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
CABINET MINUTE
Canberra, 23 January 1990
Submission 6932-Commonwealth Assistance for 1996 Melbourne Olympic Games.
The Cabinet agreed that:

(a) the Commonwealth provide up to a maximum of $125million in January 1990 prices (indexed by the consumer price index) on a dollar-for-dollar basis with the Victorian Government towards construction of the Albert Park Sports Complex should Melbourne be selected as the city to host the 1996 Olympic Games; and

(b) an Inter-Departmental Committee (IDC), under the Chairmanship of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, and comprising representatives from the Departments of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Treasury, Administrative Services and Finance, be convened to report to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories by 16 February 1990, following discussions with Victorian officials on estimates for the construction of the Albert Park Sports Complex.
2. The Cabinet also agreed that:

(a) Melbourne is selected as the city to host the 1996 Olympic Games, the Commonwealth will consider providing assistance and services of the type not readily available from other sources and which are normally Commonwealth Government functions, for example:
(i) operating and capital telecommunications services/equipment;
(ii) postal services;
(iii) medical support;
(iv) security and counter terrorist assistance;
(v) customs services;
(vi) ceremonial and hospitality;
(vii) minting of coins and stamps; and
(viii) quarantine services;
(b) any request for assistance by Melbourne, such as that outlined in sub-paragraph 2(a) above, be subject to appropriate prior inter-departmental consideration; and

(c) the announcement of Commonwealth financial assistance be made jointly by the Prime Minister and the Premier of Victoria, with the text of the announcement to be settled by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Prime Minister and the Premier.
Secretary to Cabinet

TALK.START.PARA: —The announcement was made by the Prime Minister and the then Victorian Premier, Mr Cain, on 28 January, five days after the Cabinet decision and four and a half months before the Interdepartmental Committee had even reported. The 28 January statement was without qualification. I seek leave to table the Prime Minister's press release of that date.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first paragraph of that press release to the Prime Minister of 28 January reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government will provide $125 million towards the cost of a world standard sporting complex at Albert Park, should Melbourne be chosen to host the 1996 Olympic Games.

There was no qualification, no conditionality, no `subject to' at all. If any further proof of the Prime Minister's misrepresentation is required, let me refer the Senate to the report of the interdepartmental committee which was eventually completed on 12 June, four months later than it had initially been asked to report, and which I seek leave to table.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a 10-page document. I will just read a few relevant paragraphs from the report. Paragraph 5 of the report talks about the issues that the IDC was set up to look at. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The IDC met on two occasions. One of the main issues for members was to define the scope of the construction project. This was seen as having two aspects . . .

Then it goes on to say what those two aspects were-namely, `defining the boundaries within which construction work associated with the facility was considered reasonable' and `deciding whether the term``construction'' was intended by the Government to cover all things necessary to equip the facility for the staging of the Olympic Games'. Paragraph 17 of the report said, under the sub-heading of cost estimates:
The ACS-
Australian Construction Services, part of the Department of Administrative Services-
advised that the information provided to date-
that is, by the Victorian Government-

adequately clarified the scope of the project. It indicated which components were in the $249 million estimate. The estimates appeared reasonable for the work involved, even generous. It should, therefore, be possible to build a high class multi-sports facility without any budget overruns.
The following paragraph, paragraph 18, says:

IDC members noted that, under the terms of the Government decision, even if there were any cost overruns these would not be borne by the Commonwealth as the decision had committed the Commonwealth to a dollar-for-dollar contribution with the Victorian Government of up to a maximum of $125 million in January 1990 prices.
Paragraph 24 says:

The Government is committed to providing up to a maximum of $125 million in January 1990 prices indexed by the Consumer Price Index(CPI). This commitment was confirmed in the Prime Minister's letters to the Victorian Premier of 7 February 1990 and 4 April 1990 which stated the Commonwealth would ``provide up to a maximum of $125 million in January 1990 prices''.
Paragraph 28 of the report said-following the question of whether the IDC should try to get more information on the costings:
To seek more information would be playing at the margins of the project.
There is another sentence which is not terribly relevant. Then it goes on to say:
The IDC noted that a public commitment of up to a maximum of $125 million in January 1990 prices has been made.

Last Friday, 12 October, I applied to the Prime Minister under the Freedom of Information Act for copies of all documents pertaining to this matter, including correspondence, Cabinet decisions, memoranda, minutes and other material held by his office and/or department relating to any financial or other assistance by the Commonwealth in support of Melbourne's bid to host the Olympic Games or for the conduct of the Olympic Games had the bid been successful. I will await receipt of those documents with interest. However, given what I have revealed to the Senate tonight, including the precise wording of the Cabinet decision, it is simply not possible that those documents will do other than confirm my allegation that Prime Minister Hawke misled the Federal Parliament on 13 September 1990.

There can be no more serious parliamentary offence by any politician. The gravity of the offence is merely compounded by its committal by a leader of a government. I have to say, and I am sad to say it in this chamber, that precisely the same misrepresentation of the Parliament was made on the same day by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, who used the same words as the Prime Minister actually used in the Parliament. So not only did the Leader of the Government, the Prime Minister, mislead the House on 13 September, but so also did the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, mislead this Parliament on 13 September.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on National Crime Authority: Tabling of Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unduly provoked to rise tonight to respond to some matters raised by Senator Loosley, who, I assume, was responding to some very objective, unbiased and clinical observations made by Senator Vanstone.
—Clinical, all right.
— Forgive me for not responding to the interjection. I find it so inane that I have not the slightest idea what the incoherent babbles are meant to represent.

SPEECH.PARA: May I say at the outset that, thus far, I have found Mr Lindsay, the Chairman of the Joint Statutory Committee on the National Crime Authority (NCA), a very reasonable, fair, objective person who has sought to discharge his responsibilities to the best of his ability within the provisions of the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —He comes from north Queensland, you see.

—I am reminded that he comes from north Queensland and that makes him a good fellow, says my colleague. But we are all tempted, as I once said in a letter to the Chairman of a committee I am on, to be ultimately partisan in our deliberations. Senator Collins will know what I mean when I say that, because he had the distinction of sharing the membership of another committee with me-indeed, on two inquiries, I believe. On that occasion the taking of the evidence was done in a very dignified, respectable and responsible way, as were the deliberations as we worked our way through the reports. Ultimately what happened, of course, was that we parted company, I suspect, on the facts in a philosophical way but, as gentlemen do, in a very decent way.
—And ladies.

—Yes, I am sorry; there was a lady on it also. The conclusions, I suspect, notwithstanding my endeavours to be driven by absolute altruism and objectivity, may have been vaguely tainted, but by my philosophical approach to life.

SPEECH.PARA: In the same way, Senator Collins signed the majority report, which made no conclusion in respect, for instance, of the mining of uranium within Kakadu National Park, notwithstanding the fact that I know that in his heart and conscience, and deep in his decency, he has a strong view about it. But he made a very pragmatic, practical, realistic and reasonable determination as to how he could conduct himself at the end of the day.

Senator Loosley referred-and I came in late and I had to scribble very quickly, as he was going through what was obviously a written statement-to confidentiality and trust. At the end of the day any committee of the Parliament will function to the extent that there is trust, confidentiality, but, most of all, good will. As I say this, let the Hansard note that Senator Loosley finds that a giggle.There has been in the decade I have been in this Parliament something of a downturn in the good will, cooperation and working of these committees. There was a time when we could approach issues, at least from the beginning of the reference, in a bipartisan way, when at least one would go through what one might describe as the deliberations in a respectable and responsible way before one drew one's conclusions. Sadly, this Government, in its inexorable, I suspect, path towards defeat, has become more contemptuous, more disrespectful and, might I say, more corrupt.

Government members of these committees see them as an organ, an instrument and an extension of the Government and the Executive, not as an intrinsic part of the Parliament. Need I observe that this Committee, in the short time I have been a member of it, epitomises that. If one wants to talk about trust, without breaking the confidences of the private procedures of the Committee, one can say that there has been an occasion when that particular Committee had to contemplate what I judge to be the most significant matter that can come before a committee. It took evidence over a period of weeks from a number of witnesses and in seeking to arrive at a conclusion--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I note for the record that there is another Labor senator who thinks this is very amusing. As some of us sought to work our way through the mountain of evidence taken over days of consideration, at the last hour on the last day, at the time of the last witness, I did little more than move a procedural motion that I, for my part at least, be allowed to review the Hansard, review the evidence, so as to allow me to arrive at a proper, reasoned and considered determination. I remind the House that this was in respect of what ultimately in my view is probably the paramount consideration that any Committee can contemplate. I was denied that opportunity. I was not allowed to read the Hansard before a decision was to be made in respect of that matter. Senator Loosley talks about good will and trust.
—And courtesy.

—And courtesy. Senator Loosley went on to talk about the NCA being a unique committee, a committee of particular significance. To the extent that his words are limited to those phrases, he is partially right. What is important about the National Crime Authority Committee is its responsibility for accountability to this Parliament- perhaps more so than any other committee. That places a greater onus and responsibility on its members than on those members of most other committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Then Senator Loosley talked about the taking of evidence in camera. I do not know what Senator Loosley thinks about the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. I seem to remember that he joined the cheer squad for the better part of its endeavours. In my view, that was not an improper position to take. As I recall, as a general rule of thumb principle, Mr Fitzgerald took the view that all of the evidence, as far as possible, subject to the certain and obvious qualifications, should be taken in public. Correct me if I am wrong.

I have a simple view about committees of the Senate: all evidence ought to be on the public record and taken and published unless witnesses can satisfy the committee that, by being required to do so, they would be denied natural justice, their evidence would be hearsay, their evidence would compromise them or their evidence could compromise the Parliament, a committee of the Parliament or law enforcement.

They are, in general terms, the qualifications I place, at least-I trust not unreasonable qualifications. Evidence which is taken in camera can be released by a resolution of the majority of the committee or by the attachment to a report to the Parliament. Evidence may be required to be used to substantiate and justify the conclusions of the recommendations of the report, whether it be a majority or minority report.

The taking of in camera evidence can be a slick, crude and unattractive way of subjugating and suppressing evidence which ought to be on the public record and for the knowledge of the Parliament. The Australian Labor Party-and I make no judgment about it-has a view in respect of the committees of which I am a member, at least, that all evidence taken in camera ought to remain in camera.

Committees ought to take a very serious and responsible view about what evidence they take in camera. It is so easy for witnesses to come before a committee of the Parliament, plead to give evidence in camera, table documents in camera, cleanse themselves of their sins and their evils and those to whom they may refer, find themselves under the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987, thus far unamended, and be excluded from any accountability to any court, anybody or any parliament. That is why when we accept the taking of evidence in camera we have to be very careful about the judgments that we make.

TALK.START.PARA: —You make that before you accept it.

—I am reminded by Senator Watson that a particular set of words are used to explain to witnesses that any evidence they give is capable of being public evidence. In my view, committees ought to give more consideration before they become gung ho, thinking they are getting sexy, juicy evidence, which excites them into taking some of it in camera.

SPEECH.PARA: A committee, of which I am a member, has invaluable evidence that will help the administration of sport in Australia and the administrative body of sport in Australia, and that intrinsically valuable evidence has been denied because of a blind principle about not disclosing in camera evidence. It is evidence that is deserving of being before all bodies funding sport in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee on drugs in sport.
—That is right.
—I was on it.

— Senator Collins made an invaluable contribution to the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and Arts, although not by way of his inclusion in the recommendations in the second report, because by then he had been elevated into the rarefied atmosphere of the Ministry. But certainly he signed the interim report and he made an invaluable contribution in his inquiries and questions of the witnesses before us. I have no doubt that Senator Collins is conscious of the inherent risks of taking in camera evidence and then finding oneself unable to disclose the in camera evidence and being frustrated that neither government instrumentalities or the public are conscious of the conduct of the recipients of government funds or, more particularly, taxpayers' funds.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, amongst this new gauche, macho group that have come into the Parliament at the last election, the understanding of the role of the Senate committees seems to have passed them by. I see Senator West giggling again over there. She epitomises perhaps better than most the stupidity, ignorance, arrogance and foolhardiness of members of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order--
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, I ask you to withdraw.
—Of course I will withdraw. What particular phrase was it you wished me to withdraw?
—I am asking you to withdraw the remarks you made about Senator West.

—I withdraw the remarks I made about Senator West. I have read very quickly the remarks in the House of Representatives made by Mr Lindsay. His words wreak of a lack of understanding of committee procedures. In fact, he really contemplates and imagines that the preparation of minority reports ought to be a matter of deliberation by the majority of the Committee. Since Lionel Murphy was the father of many of these committees, it is a pity that the House of Representatives has never come to grips with how these committees function and are intended. It is a pity that those members in the House of Representatives who are members of these joint committees never seem to understand Standing Orders or the obligations, responsibilities and duties of a committee. I say that in a charitable way about Mr Lindsay, but it really seems to be true that those gentlemen are not clear about how we function. I notice that the honourable member for Banks, Mr Melham, referred to the tabling of the minority report. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: What happened last night in the Senate under the cover of darkness . . .
Excuse the pun, but what a colourful expression--

TALK.START.PARA: —What time do you think it is? It is 10 to 12.
— Senator Faulkner would not know whether it was a.m. or p.m. Mr Melham continued:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . was a cheap, grubby, political point-scoring exercise on the part of the Opposition.
He went on to say:
The Chairman of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority was unaware that the tabling was to take place last night or, indeed, that there was a qualifying statement.

Mr Melham is a member of the Government; he is a member of this Committee. I would have imagined that the Chairman, who seems to have these informal meetings from time to time with Labor Party Caucus colleagues on the Committee, would have bothered to tell him that he had been notified in the most gracious way by the Deputy Chairman of the Committee that the documents were to be tabled that day as a result of his signing the documents and the matter being listed on the Order of Business sheet that day in the Senate. Senator Vanstone, in telling the Chairman, putting it on the Notice Paper, and tabling it last night was indulging herself under the cover of darkness. It really makes one wonder--

TALK.START.PARA: —Focus, Senator, focus.
—It is too dark; you cannot read.
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—It really makes one wonder as to the Committee's understanding of the Standing Orders. Senator Loosley referred to a courtesy. When he was referring to a courtesy, he was referring to the fact that he had not actually been given the set of words that were used in the minority report. My definition of `courtesy' might be something different from that of Senator Loosley, but once it is resolved that there will be a minority report, that report, Mr President, as you would know better than almost anybody in this chamber, is the exclusive province of the minority report and nobody else. There was not intended to be anything sneaky or underhand; it was done in the normal way in which these matters are done. Perhaps the problem is that the Labor Party has become so arrogant that it is not used to public minority reports.

SPEECH.PARA: I am reminded as I look at Senator Loosley about the conference in New South Wales some years ago where we saw Mr Anderson wheeled up and told that he was not going to be the Premier, and wheeled back out again. He humiliated himself before the television cameras and said, `I am no longer a candidate', and then somebody else was wheeled in and wheeled out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Laurie Brereton.
— Laurie Brereton walked in smiling and came out bruised. Poor old Mr Unsworth walked in confused and walked out muddled. From that day forth he was the Premier--
—He actually walked in confused and walked out the Premier.
— Pardon?
—Oh, forget it.
—He walked out the Premier on a death march to death row, guaranteed with a stamp of the crazy Right of New South Wales.
—What about the extreme crazy Right in Western Australia?
—Yes, there are extreme crazy Rights in Western Australia and in the Labor Party and they have all failed.
—Let us get back to in camera evidence.

—If we want to get back to in camera evidence, let me conclude by making a couple of obvious observations. There seems to be a view in the Labor Party that there ought to be no exposure of in camera evidence. It does beg some compelling questions; I have always acknowledged that. For instance, in respect of the report that was tabled last night, the sort of question I asked myself was: Was any evidence disclosed which had been given in camera which was unnecessary to be made public?
