Was there any in camera evidence that, upon sober reflection--
—There is silence.

—I was wondering whether Senator Crowley, with all her giggling, wants to be reminded that she ought to be in her own seat. I wondered whether there was any evidence provided in the report, which quite reasonably could have been asked of the witnesses in public, which would have compromised the National Crime Authority, its operations or its conduct. I do not believe that a case could be mounted, even by the fertile mind of Senator Loosely, which would cogently argue that in any way any of that evidence could not have been asked in public and replied to and provided in public.
—It would have had to be replied to, under the Act.

—Yes. I suspect the reason that the response to the report thus far has been one of confusion is that the Government does not know how to come to grips with it. I am not one who would ever presume to allege that the Government members on the Committee are in any way driven by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), political motives, political expediency or future political ambitions. But if the conduct of those on the Government side persists, one could be very much seduced by the temptation of that thought. The way this Committee conducts itself in the future will very much determine whether that is an illusion or a reality.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the conflicting arguments in respect to in-camera evidence, we are all aware that the Procedure Committee examined this very question. It examined it as a result of a matter raised by Senator Zakharov after she had tabled in-camera evidence herself.

TALK.START.PARA: —She did?
—She did it by leave, which is the proper way to do these thing, of courses; I have no argument about that.

SPEECH.PARA: But the Committee found itself subject to conflicting arguments and unable to resolve them. It made the obvious point that when in camera evidence is given, there is a temptation on the part of the witnesses to believe that it will remain in camera, notwithstanding the fact that the qualifications are clearly pointed out.

It went on to make the point that if minority reports are unable to expose in camera evidence where it is intrinsically related to the substance of the recommendations and the findings of the Committee, to so exclude it would be in fact to censor the minority report. In fact, it would leave the minority report naked of substance.

As I looked last night at the minority report and asked myself what it would represent in terms of substance and value if each part of it which included in camera evidence were removed, there would have been no minority report of consequence; no accountability to the Parliament; and nothing in it of fact and substance which would have allowed the Senate, the Parliament and the community to make value judgments about the integrity, conduct, value and workings of the National Crime Authority. That is what caused those of us who signed that report to sign it and have it contain the evidence that it did. There has been no allegation today by anybody who is responsible and well respected that the National Crime Authority has been compromised as a result of the evidence provided by the minority report. There has been bitching, whelping, complaining, yelling, whingeing and whining by members of the Government, or those in opposition to the minority report, that it does not satisfy them. But there is nothing in it--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are drunk.
—I raise a point of order--
—You are drunk too!
—Point of order.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, I ask you to withdraw those comments.
—Mr President, I withdraw the fact that they are both drunk.
—Senator Bolkus is not in his right place, either.
—Senator Reid is correct.

—There is something more than that required. For the record, I have not had a drink for several days. But it is absolutely outrageous for a Minister or any senator to come in here and make a blanket charge of impropriety or drunkenness against anyone.
—Order! I asked Senator Bolkus to withdraw unconditionally, and he did.
—Mr President, my allegation was not against Senator MacGibbon. It was against Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Vanstone, and I withdraw.
—I am sorry. My name was mentioned there and I did not capture the gist of it. Would the Minister mind repeating?
—The comments have been withdrawn, and I think that is where it should stay.

—Let me just conclude by saying this: I have watched the humour that this debate has stimulated on the other side. For what it is worth, let me put it on the record that one person, who at least has acknowledged the seriousness of what has happened and recognises the significance of this report-while he might ultimately stand to his feet and disagree with me-is Senator Collins, who has been, in his own way, through these difficulties.
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, your time has expired.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Press Articles on Leader of the Opposition

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I want very briefly to make a few remarks that I have been prompted to make by statements Senator Bolkus made today during the matter of public importance, when he alleged that Dr Hewson planned to kill off the Department of Social Security, which was, in fact, repeating the Australian Labor Party's total and disgraceful distortion of what Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition, did say. This followed Mr Keating's totally false accusation in the other place that Dr Hewson was proposing that the Opposition turn over $40 billion in Federal outlays to voluntary welfare organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: This pretty desperate and childish Labor attack on Dr Hewson was particularly disturbing-and it happened to coincide with another drubbing for the Labor Party in the polls. The most distinguished thing about this is that in no instance did either members of the Labor Party or the media report, in fact, what Dr Hewson actually said. I must say that, as an ex-journalist, I regret that some of my former colleagues do not at times maintain the standards which they generally keep up. In particular, I am very disappointed indeed that one of the Canberra press gallery-for whom I have a very high personal regard as well as a professional regard-Milton Cockburn, has fallen into what I believe to be an unfortunate error in this case. I mentioned to him that I planned to raise this, because, as I said, I have a high personal regard for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —You realise that none of them has picked up the fact that the public sector outlays for Social Security have gone down to $21m. That shows how ignorant he is, apart from anything else.

—I thank my colleague Senator Alston. The reason I am concerned about this is that the Labor Party is clearly doing what it can in a desperate situation, and I just believe the media has a responsibility to be more rigorous and intellectually honest than it has shown today. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation this morning in its news, I think, said something like Dr Hewson was being criticised for his plans to do away with the Department for Social Security. Mr Cockburn, in his paper this morning, wrote an article under the heading: Keating flays Hewson over welfare slip. Journalists do not write headlines, but it does emerge fairly from the context of the article because, in it, Mr Cockburn uses the adjectival device, which I thought rested mainly with the Australian Financial Review, of creating an atmospheric about the article rather than reporting the facts:

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer, Mr Keating, and the Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Howe, each capitalised on some naive remarks by Dr Hewson to a Melbourne newspaper that he saw no need for the Department of Social Security.

That is not in quotation marks. It is not a direct quote from Dr Hewson and it does not reflect what Dr Hewson said. For the record, I plan to read those relevant sections of the transcript of the interview by Niki Savva of the Melbourne Herald Sun, in which it is quite clear that he does not support the proposition that he saw no need for the Department of Social Security-and certainly no support whatsoever for the proposition that Dr Hewson was proposing that the Opposition turn over $40 billion in Federal outlays to voluntary welfare agencies.

The real news was that the Labor Party has got so desperate about its falling status that it will use any device, including dishonesty, to try to denigrate Dr Hewson. I will read relevant bits from the text of the transcript:

. . . one of the real issues is at what level do you deliver these benefits? Do you need Commonwealth, State, Local Government Departments of all these things? And the answer is no. There is a massive amount of duplication. I haven't looked at it for a while, but how many Canberra-based and other bureaucrats are there dispensing benefits? What bureaucracy is there that is distributing the dollar of benefit in the end? And, when you look at the size of that bureaucracy, you know, the extent to which a lot of people who don't actually touch the dollar, don't actually meet first hand to hand, the person who receives the pension, you say to yourself, is all that really necessary? And the answer is, it is not. There is duplication at each of the three levels.
He went on later:
Some benefits are better distributed at different levels, or managed at different levels.
He continued on this topic:

. . . the need to eliminate duplication. We are discussing some of those issues with State Liberal leaders right now . . . excess government, excess bureaucracy and a lot of money is wasted in that duplication.
Niki Savva asked:
So, you are not adverse to the idea, of say, abolishing the Federal Social Security Department and giving it to the States?

Dr Hewson did not in fact reply yes; nor did he reply no. He in fact replied with a lengthy discussion of whether or not one needed total duplication, but there is nothing in the transcript to justify the quote that he saw no need for the Department of Social Security. He said:
I'm not saying that I want to put all the money down there to those organisations and say off you go.
He continues later:
There is a long way from that group-
that is, the people at the coalface-

to a Canberra-based bureaucrat making social policy. And I think there is a lot of scope in there to distribute those benefits to those people. And, it may involve a larger role for those organisations . . .
like welfare agencies. He continued:
That is a personal view, it is not a policy view.
. . . a lot of money goes out the door and doesn't hit the target.
He went on:

. . . the genuinely needy in Australia don't get enough. The pensioner trying to struggle on a pension in a city like Sydney or Melbourne today, the genuine pensioner, minimal assets and so on, is really feeling the pinch, as are other genuine welfare recipients, or other beneficiaries of social security . . . There is a better way and that is what we have got to work towards.

There should not have been any confusion remaining when people were reporting this in this morning's newspapers. Yesterday, 17 October, the text of an interview with Amanda Buckley of the Daily Telegraph Mirror, which was made on Tuesday, 16 October, was distributed in the gallery. In it Dr Hewson says:

some departments could well be abolished. I wasn't necessarily saying that we would abolish the Department of Social Security but I used social security as an example of saying, look, you're trying to provide welfare assistance to people. It seems to me that there is a lesser argument for having that activity concentrated in Canberra, so far from the coal face in terms of those who are, who you are trying to assist.
He went on:

. . . they are better able to make sure that the money hits the target than some Canberra bureaucrat. So that argues for phasing down the Canberra-based Department and either making it a State function or a local function or handing the money out perhaps a little bit more-
not entirely-
through those voluntary organisations or religious-based organisations.
He said further:
. . . you certainly don't want Federal, State and local divisions or departments which is what you've got unnecessarily.
Amanda Buckley said:
So on this, if we just have a look at the Social Security area. You're not speaking I suppose of sending pensions and allowances back to the States.
Dr Hewson said:
No. You may still pay those from the Commonwealth level but they may be allocated at the local level and the State level.
There was a direct question:
You're not speaking I suppose of sending pensions and allowances back to the States.
The answer was no. He concluded:
It really poses the question what level is the most appropriate to have these departments.
Here we have a clear transcript. He went on:
One of the things that the Premiers' Conference should decide, for example, is where those responsibilities should lie so that you can eliminate duplication.

There is nothing in those transcripts which justifies Mr Keating saying that Dr Hewson was proposing that the Opposition turn over $40 billion in Federal outlays to voluntary welfare agencies. That is just false.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is desperate drivel.

—That is absolutely right, it is desperate drivel. There is nothing that supports the view in the Sydney Morning Herald of what Hewson says-whether he saw no need for the Department of Social Security. All I can say is that there is a basic principle here. If we want to knock down what someone says, we should put in quotes what that person has said so that we can knock it down honestly. When we fail to put it in quotes and when we misrepresent that person and then seek to knock it down in the public prints, we are doing our job badly. I could say that a very bad job was attempted to be done on Dr Hewson. But I think the facts speak for themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are much preoccupied in the Senate lately with matters relating to procedure changes to improve the efficiency with which we conduct business in this House. I was a member of the committee that developed the procedures that we are currently dealing with. Tonight's adjournment debate has been conclusive evidence of the overwhelming case that needs to be mounted for limiting debates on the adjournment to a maximum of 15 minutes. Senator Michael Baume demonstrated that one can very succinctly put a case in less than 15 minutes. Such a provision would certainly cut out the opportunity for members literally to talk about nothing for 30 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I rise briefly to speak is that my name got quite a mention in the adjournment debate tonight. I feel that a very short response is necessary. The question of in camera evidence was the most substantive issue tackled tonight. It is a very substantive issue for the Senate indeed. Senator Crichton-Browne made some prolonged reference to it in respect of me and the committee which I served on with him-the Senate Select Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts which inquired into drugs in sport. It is a disturbing fact that no absolute guarantee can be given to any witness who gives in camera evidence before a Senate committee that that evidence will perpetually remain in camera. The drugs in sport committee routinely took evidence from witnesses who were clearly under the impression that that was the case.

That disturbed me to such an extent that we had a discussion at a private meeting of the Committee about the matter and I insisted that in future all witnesses to whom the Committee gave permission to give evidence in camera before the Committee should be provided with a written brief that explained precisely what the correct position was with in camera evidence so that they could then give that evidence under no illusion as to what might happen to it. The Clerk of the Senate drafted that statement and it was routinely handed to the many witnesses that that particular Committee took in camera evidence from.

I understand that it is still the routine practice of the Senate for that statement on in camera evidence to be handed to and allowed to be read by witnesses before they give that evidence. Senator Crichton-Browne knows full well and accepts, I am sure, that despite all of the disturbing evidence that we took on that Committee as to the dreadful effects of anabolic steroids and other drugs, the drug that still remains the most abused drug in Australia is, of course, alcohol.

The matter of in camera evidence is an important one. What Senator Crichton-Browne has ignored is very stark: there is one committee of this Parliament which is unique and there is one committee of the Parliament at which the status of in camera evidence takes a position unlike in camera evidence before any other committee, and that is the Joint Committee the National Crime Authority. There is no other committee of this Parliament which equips all its members with a safe in which to keep the material they are given as members of that Committee. The Joint Committee which oversights the operations of the National Crime Authority is in that position, where each individual member of the Committee is provided with a safe within which that material is contained.

But it goes further than that. There is, in respect of the members of that Committee, not only a requirement to keep that material secure in a safe, for obvious reasons; there is an absolute prohibition on members of that Committee even disclosing the material to members of their own staff. That is how severe the onus is.

I have to say, with the greatest of respect to Senator Vanstone and any other senator, that there is no way at all that the status of in camera evidence given before that Committee can be compared with the in camera evidence given before any other committee of this Parliament. I know personally that the publication of the in camera evidence before that Joint Committee in a dissenting report last night has already caused the gravest concern in the law enforcement community and that that concern has already been expressed to members of that particular Committee.

I conclude by saying, with the greatest of respect to Senator Vanstone, that I believe that the decision that the senator took to publish in camera evidence of that particular Committee, considering the absolute prohibition that applies to every member of the Committee to even disclose material to members of their own staff in their office, and the requirement to contain it within a safe which is provided to each member, was on her part a very grave error of judgment. That, I might add, is absolutely detached from what the material may have been. It could have been the most innocuous material-I know it was not, but it could have been-but the fact that any member of the Committee took the decision to publish in camera evidence from that particular Committee has caused the gravest concern in the law enforcement community and it was a grave error of judgment on the part of Senator Vanstone.

I have no doubt that the Committee will debate the matter more substantively, and perhaps it may even be debated more substantively in the Senate. I believe that the Committee-and I will be surprised if it does not-will come to the conclusion that it cannot really perform very much more useful work, considering the extraordinary gravity of the task that they employ in terms of the evidence they take on that Committee, if any member of the Committee, either from the House of Representatives or the Senate, takes a decision in future to publish any of the in camera evidence that is placed before that Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
